{"uri": "2024-06-394876782", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:13:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:13:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:07:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://eu.statesman.com/story/news/2024/06/19/tropical-storm-alberto-nhc-first-storm-hurricane-season-gulf-mexico-texas-rainfall-path-track/74125594007/", "title": "National Hurricane Center names Alberto, the first tropical storm of the hurricane season", "body": "A storm dubbed \"Potential Tropical Cyclone One\" could bring winds, rainfall and flooding to parts of Texas's coast the National Hurricane Center said.\n\nThe tropical disturbance south of Texas in the Gulf of Mexico has intensified into the first tropical storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season.\n\nAlberto is expected to make landfall in Mexico late Wednesday. Already, the storm has brought significant rainfall to Texas. Those in South Texas and along the coast can expect to see continuing impact, which will include flooding rain, coastal flooding, gusty winds and high surf and rip currents, through Thursday.\n\nThe storm is expected to produce rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South Texas, with maximum totals of 15 inches possible, according to the NHC.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center issued a tropical storm warning for several areas along Coastal Texas early Tuesday morning before expanding the warning to include a broader range of Texas in the afternoon. The warning now stretches across nearly the entirety of the state's coastline from San Luis Pass near Galveston to the mouth of the Rio Grande.\n\nWhere is Tropical Storm Alberto?\n\nNHC warned that the system is very large, with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 415 miles to the north of the center, increasing significantly from an advisory Tuesday morning that cited 290 miles outward.\n\nWhen will Tropical Storm Alberto make landfall in Mexico?\n\nThe center of the storm will reach the coast of northeastern Mexico early Thursday morning, the NHC said.\n\nWatches and warnings in Texas\n\nNHC has issued a tropical storm warning for the Texas coast from San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande. A warning was also issued for the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\nTrack Tropical Storm Alberto\n\nKey messages from the National Hurricane Center: What you need to know about Tropical Storm Alberto\n\nWhat impact could Alberto have and what areas could be affected?\n\nWhat do tropical storm watches, warnings from NHC mean?\n\nWhat is storm surge? Graphics explain the deadly weather event\n\nTropical storm warning: A tropical storm warning means that tropical storm conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area within 36 hours.\n\nTropical storm watch: An announcement that sustained winds of 39 to 73 mph are possible within the specified area within 48 hours in association with a tropical, subtropical, or {"uri": "2024-06-395987412", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "13:44:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T13:44:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T13:43:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://eu.statesman.com/story/news/state/2024/06/20/tropical-storm-alberto-update-landfall-south-texas-flooding-heavy-rains-wind-mexico-disaster-2024/74154326007/", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto: Heavy rains, flooding in South Texas following landfall in Mexico", "body": "Storm chaser Mike Scantlin reported live from Rockport, Texas, on June 19, as Tropical Storm Alberto pounded the coast with flooding.\n\nMillions of people along the southern coast of Texas were under severe weather advisories as officials warned of high storm surge, torrential rain and possible tornadoes as Tropical Storm Alberto barreled over northern Mexico. Here's what we know.\n\nAlberto brings heavy rainfall, flooding to South Texas\n\nThe first named storm in the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season made landfall in Mexico, near the U.S. border, sometime between 4 a.m. and 7 a.m. local time, according to the National Hurricane Center. Along with sustained winds near 45 mph, the storm is forecast to dump up to 20 inches across parts of northeast Mexico with nearly a foot of rain expected throughout southern Texas.\n\nSuch high rainfall totals will likely produce \"considerable flash flooding and urban flooding\" as well as possible mudslides across northern Mexico, the NHC said.\n\nAfter making landfall, Alberto is expected to diminish in strength, though it could still produce life-threatening weather conditions.\n\nAlberto began drenching southern Texas on Wednesday, triggering widespread coastal flooding that left Surfside Beach, a city along the Texas Gulf Coast south of Houston, under several feet of water. The storm also lashed Mexico with heavy rain, and caused the deaths of at least three minors, Nuevo Leon state Governor Samuel Garcia told local media without providing details.\n\nAcross southern Texas, the combination of storm surge and high tide is raising alarms on Thursday as floodwaters could reach up to 4 feet along the coast. The deepest waters will breach the shore along the Texas coast just to the north of Mexico, where the surge will be accompanied by large and dangerous waves, according to NHC.\n\nLife-threatening surf and rip current conditions are among the central threats for the Gulf Coast of Texas through Friday. In deep South Texas, multiple counties were under a tornado watch as forecasters warned that a possible tornado or two could spin up through the morning.\n\nAll tropical storm watches and warnings have been discontinued all the U.S. Gulf Coast, and heavy rain and gusty winds are beginning to subside for South Texas.\n\nAcross the Coastal Bend of Texas, the National Weather Service reported a few gusts of wind above 50 mph and rainfall totals of about 2 to 7 inches.\n\n\"Between 4-8 inches of rain can fall across a widespread area from south of Houston to far northeastern Mexico from Monday to Thursday night, while rainfall totals as high as 8-12 inches can occur over South Texas and the higher elevations of northern Mexico,\" according to AccuWeather.\n\nPeople are also reading: Storm tracker: See latest details, possible path as tropical storm warning issued in Texas\n\nAlberto makes landfall in Mexico\n\nTropical Storm Alberto made landfall in Mexico early Thursday morning and is expected to move farther inland, according to the latest report by the NHC. A tropical storm warning has been issued for a portion of the northeastern Mexico coast.\n\nHere's a quick breakdown of conditions, as of 7 a.m. Thursday:\n\nTexas governor Greg Abbott issued a disaster proclamation for 51 counties Wednesday evening, as winds and flooding from the tropical storm continue hitting the state's coast. He also activated three platoons of the Texas National Guard, including more than 40 personnel, 20 vehicles and Chinook helicopters.\n\nWatches and warnings in Texas\n\nNHC has issued a tropical storm warning for the Texas coast from San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande. A warning was also issued for the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\nTrack Tropical Storm Alberto\n\nTropical Storm Alberto becomes first named storm of {"uri": "2024-06-395348699", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "03:33:11", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T03:33:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T21:11:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://eu.lubbockonline.com/story/news/2024/06/19/tropical-storm-alberto-nhc-first-storm-hurricane-season-gulf-mexico-texas-rainfall-path-track/74125594007/", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto is first named storm of the 2024 hurricane season | NHC updates", "body": "A storm dubbed \"Potential Tropical Cyclone One\" could bring winds, rainfall and flooding to parts of Texas's coast the National Hurricane Center said.\n\nThe tropical disturbance south of Texas in the Gulf of Mexico has intensified into the first tropical storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season.\n\nAlberto is expected to make landfall in Mexico early Thursday morning. Already, the storm has brought significant rainfall to Texas. Those in South Texas and along the coast can expect to see continuing impact, which will include flooding rain, coastal flooding, gusty winds and high surf and rip currents, through Thursday.\n\nThe storm is expected to produce rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South Texas, with maximum totals of 15 inches possible, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nNHC issued a tropical storm warning for several areas along Coastal Texas early Tuesday morning before expanding the warning to include a broader range of Texas in the afternoon. The warning now stretches across nearly the entirety of the state's coastline from San Luis Pass near Galveston to the mouth of the Rio Grande.\n\nWhere is Tropical Storm Alberto?\n\nNHC warned that the system is very large, with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 415 miles to the north of the center, increasing significantly from an advisory Tuesday morning that cited 290 miles outward.\n\nWhen will Tropical Storm Alberto make landfall in Mexico?\n\nThe center of the storm will reach the coast of northeastern Mexico early Thursday morning, the NHC said.\n\nWatches and warnings in Texas\n\nNHC has issued a tropical storm warning for the Texas coast from San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande. A warning was also issued for the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\nTrack Tropical Storm Alberto\n\nKey messages from the National Hurricane Center: What you need to know about Tropical Storm Alberto\n\nWhat impact could Alberto have and what areas could be affected?\n\nWhat do tropical storm watches, warnings from NHC mean?\n\nWhat is storm surge? {"uri": "2024-06-392920769", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "03:31:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T03:31:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T03:10:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.aol.com/double-trouble-two-tropical-systems-164052683.html", "title": "First alert of 2024 hurricane season: Tropical storm watch on Texas coast", "body": "First alert of 2024 hurricane season: Tropical storm watch on Texas coast\n\nDoyle Rice, USA TODAY\n\nUpdated June 18, 2024 at 5:10 AM\n\nThe 2024 Atlantic hurricane season is heating up.\n\nA system in the Gulf of Mexico that will soon become Tropical Storm Alberto has prompted a tropical storm watch for the Texas coast, the first alert of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season. On Monday afternoon, the National Hurricane Center issued an advisory for potential Tropical Cyclone One.\n\nHeavy, potentially flooding rain is expected across the western Gulf Coast, the National Hurricane Center said, with as much as 15 inches possible. The heavy rainfall and flash flooding threat is predicted to intensify into Tuesday morning, according to National Hurricane Center Director Michael Brennan.\n\nA tropical storm watch has been issued for the Texas coast from Port O'Connor southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande. The watch means tropical storm conditions are possible within the area, generally within 48 hours.\n\n\"There's a potential for flooding and flash flooding over the next several days with heavy rainfall already starting to move into portions of the Gulf Coast,\" Brennan said in an update Monday afternoon. \"This threat of flooding is going to continue as we move through the week.\"\n\nThe system's maximum sustained winds remained near 40 mph with higher gusts as of 11 p.m. EST Monday. The National Hurricane Center described the system as \"quite large\" with tropical storm-force winds extending outward up to 290 miles to the northeast of the center.\n\nThe hurricane center has forecast the system to become a tropical storm by Wednesday and advised residents along the western and northwestern Gulf coasts to closely monitor it.\n\nBy 11 p.m. Monday, the system was moving near 7 mph toward the north, according to the hurricane center. It was expected to turn toward the west-northwest by Tuesday night or Wednesday, and \"the system is likely to approach the western Gulf coast late Wednesday,\" the hurricane center said in a late Monday advisory.\n\nIt's one of two separate tropical systems - the other is in the Atlantic Ocean - that are forecast to strengthen this week and each could have an impact on portions of the southern U.S., forecasters said Monday.\n\nAlberto will be the first named storm of what's expected to be a doozy of an Atlantic hurricane season.\n\nTropical storm in the Gulf?\n\nThe Gulf system is forecast to strengthen into a tropical depression, then a tropical storm right before making landfall along the northern Gulf Coast of Mexico, AccuWeather said. Once its sustained winds reach 39 mph, it will become Tropical Storm Alberto.\n\nAlthough the center of the storm will likely make landfall in Mexico on Wednesday, the National Hurricane Center warned that heavy rainfall is still expected to spread over portions of the northwestern coast of the U.S. Gulf of Mexico by the middle of the week. In addition, gale warnings have been issued for portions of the Gulf of Mexico.\n\nAccuWeather senior meteorologist Dan Pydynowski explained that \"even if the tropical storm falls short of reaching tropical storm status, a plume of rich, deep tropical moisture is expected to surge into Mexico, Texas and Louisiana into the middle of the week.\"\n\nWeather Channel meteorologist Jim Cantore warned that \"double-digit rainfall totals (are) likely along the coastal counties of Texas and potentially Houston.\" Flash flooding is a possibility in some parts of Texas, including in Brownsville, Corpus Christi, Houston and San Antonio, according to Weather.com.\n\nAn Air Force Reserve Hurricane Hunter aircraft is scheduled to investigate the system later Monday.\n\nBusy season ahead: The 2024 NOAA hurricane season forecast is unlike any other. See the record predictions.\n\nAtlantic system also bears watching\n\nForecasters on Monday were also keeping watch on a budding tropical system in the Atlantic Ocean. The system, which was several hundred miles east of the Bahamas on Monday, \"is forecast to approach the coast of the southeast United States on Thursday or Friday,\" the Hurricane Center said.\n\n\"This appears to be a quick-moving and compact low-pressure area that will be moving westward into northeastern Florida or perhaps as far north as southeastern Georgia on Thursday,\" Pydynowski said.\n\nLocations from Melbourne, Florida, to Charleston, South Carolina, will be at risk for heavy rain from the storm.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Jacksonville, Florida, warned of \"numerous to widespread showers and embedded heavy storms pushing onshore at times with strong gusty winds as the main threat.\"\n\nAn 'extraordinary' year is possible\n\nOnce Alberto forms, it will be the start of what's expected to be a very active year for storms. NOAA Director Rick Spinrad said last month that the Atlantic hurricane season is shaping up to be \"extraordinary,\" with an \"85% chance for an above-average year.\"\n\nThe record for most named storms in a season is 30, set in 2020. A typical year averages about 14 tropical storms, seven of which spin into hurricanes, based on weather records spanning from 1991 to 2020.\n\nContributing: Cheryl McCloud and Kim Luciani, USA TODAY NETWORK - Florida\n\nThis article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Tropical storm brewing as hurricane season begins", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Aol"}, "authors": {"uri": "8187038512", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "12:44:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T12:44:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T12:41:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/two-tropical-depressions-could-form-121000717.html", "title": "Two tropical depressions could form, including one near Florida; Alberto poised for Mexico landfall", "body": "Forecasters with the National Hurricane Center said Thursday that, in addition to Tropical Storm Alberto which is poised for landfall in Mexico, there's potential for two tropical depressions to form.\n\nSeparate from Alberto, forecasters are watching two other potential systems, one in the Gulf, and one east of the Bahamas.\n\nThe latter, currently an area of storminess located about 150 miles east of the northern Bahamas, could affect coastal northern Florida on Friday.\n\nIts odds to developing had jumped to 40% in the next two to seven days, and it now has the potential to become a tropical depression as it moves west-northwest, the hurricane center said. The system is likely too far north to impact South Florida.\n\nThere's also a disturbance in the same area of the Gulf of Mexico as Alberto that could become a tropical depression this weekend. As of 8 a.m. Thursday, it had a 50% chance of developing in the next seven days and a 10% chance it the next two days.\n\nMeanwhile, Tropical Storm Alberto, the first named storm of the 2024 hurricane season, is expected to make landfall early Thursday south of the U.S. border with Mexico.\n\nAs of 8 a.m. Thursday, the storm was 255 miles south of Brownsville, Texas, and 25 miles west of Tampico, Mexico, traveling west at 13 mph, with maximum sustained winds of 45 mph.\n\nOnce inland, Alberto is forecast to weaken quickly and likely dissipate over Mexico by Thursday night, the National Hurricane Center said.\n\nAlberto is a large, slow-moving tropical storm, with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 250 miles north of the center.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center has issued a tropical storm warning for the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\nThe storm had caused coastal flooding near Galveston, Texas, where storm surge was expected to reach 2 to 4 feet, depending on tide. There was even some street flooding in Louisiana.\n\nRain in Texas is expected to diminish Thursday, with an inch or less expected, the NHC said.\n\nInland in Mexico rainfall could continue to be significant and potentially dangerous, given the mountainous terrain in some of the region.\n\nRainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico are possible, with maximum totals of 20 inches in areas with higher terrain, the NHC said. Flash flooding and mudslides are potential hazards.\n\nThe 2024 hurricane season, which officially began June 1, is expected to be extremely active.\n\nIn its annual May outlook, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said that the 2024 hurricane season has an 85% chance of being above normal, with 17 to 25 named storms with minimum sustained winds of 39 mph, and eight to 13 hurricanes. An average year has 14 named storms and seven hurricanes.\n\nIn addition, NOAA has forecast four to seven major hurricanes for 2024, meaning those that are Category 3 or above.\n\nExperts at Colorado State University stated in their 2024 forecast that the U.S. East Coast, including Florida, had a 34% chance of a major hurricane making landfall this year. The average from 1880-2020 was 21%.\n\nForecasters say that the record-warm water temperatures that now cover much of the Atlantic Ocean will continue into peak hurricane season from August to October. That warm water fuels hurricanes. By early June, the tropical Atlantic was already as hot as it usually is in mid-August -- peak hurricane season.\n\nHurricane season officially ends Nov. 30.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", {"uri": "8185557709", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:21:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:21:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:20:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.kxxv.com/weather/tropical-storm-alberto-forms-marking-the-atlantics-first-named-storm-of-2024", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto forms, marking the Atlantic's first named storm of 2024", "body": "Much of Texas' Gulf Coast is under a tropical storm warning as the first named storm of the year formed in the Gulf of Mexico. (Scripps News)\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said that a system packing heavy rains and gusty winds formed into a tropical storm on Wednesday, marking the first named storm of what is expected to be a busy 2024 hurricane season.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto had top sustained winds of 40 mph with higher gusts. It was located 185 miles east of Tampico, Mexico, and moving to the west at 9 mph, as of 10 a.m. CT Wednesday. Forecasters expected Alberto to come ashore early Thursday as a tropical storm just south of the U.S. and Mexico border.\n\nTropical storm warnings were issued as far north as San Luis Pass, Texas, and as far south as Tecolutla, Mexico. Tropical storm warnings mean tropical storm force conditions are expected within the next 36 hours.\n\nIn addition to gusty winds, the National Hurricane Center says 5 to 10 inches of rain could fall across northeast Mexico into South Texas.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said a storm surge of 2-4 feet is expected for much of the Texas coast. A water rise of 1-3 feet is possible along the Louisiana coast.\n\nForecasters also warned that tornadoes are possible for South Texas on Wednesday and Thursday.\n\nLast month, NOAA issued its projection for the upcoming Atlantic hurricane season. The agency predicts 17 to 25 systems will become at least tropical storms in 2024, with eight to 13 hurricanes and four to seven major hurricanes. If the forecast holds true, 2024 could be one of the busiest Atlantic hurricane seasons ever.\n\nNOAA also said systems like Alberto often end up becoming the most dangerous storms. Forecasters say freshwater flooding is the leading cause of death from tropical systems.\n\nRelated stories:\n\nAs Texas braces for heavy rainfall, here's how to prepare for extreme weather {"uri": "8185782520", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "18:18:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T18:18:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T18:16:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.al.com/hurricane/2024/06/tropical-storm-alberto-forms-in-the-gulf-of-mexico.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto forms in the Gulf of Mexico", "body": "The first named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season has formed -- and it's in the Gulf of Mexico.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said upgraded a tropical disturbance to Tropical Storm Alberto on Wednesday, just hours before it's expected to come ashore in Mexico. Landfall could come early Thursday morning, forecasters said.\n\nAlberto's effects are being felt far away into Texas, which is expected to get lot of rain and storm surge flooding from the storm. Parts of the Texas and Mexico coasts are under tropical storm warnings:\n\nAs of 1 p.m. CDT Wednesday, Tropical Storm Alberto was located about 295 miles south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas, and was moving westward at 9 mph.\n\nAlberto had sustained winds of 40 mph, making it a minimal tropical storm. The hurricane center said Alberto could strengthen some before coming ashore in Mexico early Thursday morning. It is not expected to become a hurricane.\n\nThe hurricane center added that Alberto is a large tropical storm, with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 415 miles north of the center.\n\nAlberto is expected to be a rainmaker above all else. The hurricane center said the storm could drop 5 to 10 inches of rain on parts of Texas and Mexico over the next few days. Some areas in Mexico could get up to 20 inches of rain.\n\nThat much rain could cause deadly flash flooding and mudslides.\n\nTropical storm warnings stretched along the western Gulf Coast. In Texas a tropical storm warning stretched from San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande. The northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla was also under a warning.\n\nThe hurricane center said a few tornadoes will also be possible in parts of Texas as Alberto's rain bands move onshore.\n\nThe hurricane center was also keeping tabs on two additional spots for potential tropical development -- and one of them is also in the Gulf near Alberto.\n\nForecasters said an area of low pressure is expected to develop this weekend over the southern Gulf. Alberto will be long gone by that point, but the new disturbance has a 30 percent chance of becoming a tropical depression in the next week.\n\nThe hurricane center thinks the new disturbance will track to the north or northwest.\n\nA second area to watch is in the western Atlantic near the Bahamas. It has only a 20 percent chance of becoming a depression but is expected to move in the direction of the U.S. southeast Atlantic coast (Florida, Georgia, Carolinas).", "source": {"uri": "al.com", See spaghetti models", "body": "Potential Tropical Cyclone One is getting closer to Mexico and starting to bring high winds to South Texas, according to the latest advisory from the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe system is expected to strengthen and is forecast to become a tropical storm by Wednesday before approaching the western Gulf Coast late Wednesday. Tropical storm conditions are expected within the warning area by Wednesday and tornadoes are possible through Wednesdasy evening across parts of Texas.\n\n\u27a4 Track all active storms\n\nIf it does become a tropical storm, it'll become the first named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, Alberto.\n\n\u27a4 Tropics watch, June 19: Tropical Storm Alberto expected to form today, 1st named storm of 2024 hurricane season\n\n\"The disturbance is quite large,\" NHC senior hurricane specialist Robbie Berg said, \"and tropical-storm-force winds extend outward up to 415 miles to the north of the center.\" Sustained wind of 38 mph and a gust to 47 mph was reported in Matagorda Bay, Texas.\n\nHeavy rain is forecast to extend well north of the center of the storm, spreading into portions of central Texas, according to AccuWeather.\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One is expected to bring 5 to 10 inches of rain across South Texas and into northeastern Mexico, with up to 15 inches possible, NHC forecasters said.\n\nFlash and urban flooding is expected, along with new and renewed river flooding. Storm surges of up to four feet are forecast for Galveston Bay and from Sargent, Texas to Sabine Pass, the NHC said.\n\n\u27a4 Excessive rainfall forecast\n\nFor an explanation of what the watches and warnings mean, scroll to the bottom of this story.\n\nTropical storm warnings:\n\nAt 8 a.m, EDT, the disturbance was centered about 295 miles southeast of Brownsville, Texas, near latitude 22.7 North, longitude 94.3 West.\n\nThe system is moving toward the west-northwest near 8 mph. A generally westward motion with an increase in forward speed is expected during the next day or so, and the system is forecast to reach the coast of northeastern Mexico by late tonight or early Thursday.\n\nMaximum sustained winds remain near 40 mph with higher gusts.\n\nSome increase in strength is possible before the system reaches the coast. The disturbance is forecast to become a tropical storm later today.\n\nThe disturbance is quite large, and tropical-storm-force winds extend outward up to 415 miles to the north of the center. A National Ocean Service tide station at San Luis Pass, Texas, recently reported a water level of 3.8 ft above Mean Higher High Water.\n\nSpecial note about spaghetti models: Illustrations include an array of forecast tools and models, and not all are created equal. The hurricane center uses only the top four or five highest performing models to help make its forecasts.\n\nTropical storm warning: A tropical storm warning means that tropical storm conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area within 36 hours.\n\nTropical storm watch: An announcement that sustained winds of 39 to 73 mph are possible within the specified area within 48 hours in {"uri": "8186824332", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:31:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:31:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T10:30:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/tropical-storm-alberto-brings-heavy-101700953.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto brings heavy rain, flooding to Texas ahead of Mexico landfall", "body": "Tropical Storm Alberto, the first named storm of the 2024 hurricane season, is expected to make landfall early Thursday south of the U.S. border with Mexico.\n\nAs of 5 a.m. Thursday, the storm was 250 miles south of Brownsville, Texas, traveling west at 13 mph, with maximum sustained winds of 50 mph.\n\nSeparate from Alberto, forecasters also are watching two other potential systems, one in the Gulf, and one east of the Bahamas. The latter could affect coastal northern Florida on Friday.\n\nOnce inland, Alberto is forecast to weaken quickly and likely dissipate over Mexico by Thursday or Thursday night, the National Hurricane Center said.\n\nAlberto is a large, slow-moving tropical storm, with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 275 miles north of the center.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center has issued a tropical storm warning for the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\nThe storm was causing coastal flooding near Galveston, Texas, 500 miles away from its likely landfall in Mexico. Storm surge there is expected to reach 2 to 4 feet, depending on tide. There was even some street flooding in Louisiana.\n\nA few tornadoes are also possible Thursday night in lower South Texas and southeast areas of the state, the NHC said.\n\nForecasters urged people to not focus solely on the storm's forecast track.\n\n\"The disturbance is very large with rainfall, coastal flooding, and wind impacts likely to occur far from the center along the coasts of Texas and northeastern Mexico,\" the hurricane center said.\n\nInland in Mexico and South Texas, rainfall could be significant and potentially dangerous, given the mountainous terrain in some of the region.\n\nRainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South Texas are possible, with maximum totals of 20 inches in areas of Mexico with higher terrain, the NHC said Wednesday night. Flash flooding and mudslides are potential hazards.\n\nA disturbance in the same area of the Gulf of Mexico as Alberto could become a tropical depression this weekend. As of 2 a.m. Thursday, it has a 50% chance of developing in the next seven days and a 10% chance it the next two days.\n\nMeanwhile, forecasters are watching an area of storminess several hundred miles east of the northern Bahamas that could approach northeastern Florida or southern Georgia early Friday.\n\nAs of 2 a.m. Thursday, it has a 30% chance of development over the next two days, with some slow development possible thereafter while the system moves west-northwest..\n\nThe system is likely too far north to impact South Florida.\n\nThe 2024 hurricane season, which officially began June 1, is expected to be extremely active.\n\nIn its annual May outlook, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said that the 2024 hurricane season has an 85% chance of being above normal, with 17 to 25 named storms with minimum sustained winds of 39 mph, and eight to 13 hurricanes. An average year has 14 named storms and seven hurricanes.\n\nIn addition, NOAA has forecast four to seven major hurricanes for 2024, meaning those that are Category 3 or above.\n\nExperts at Colorado State University stated in their 2024 forecast that the U.S. East Coast, including Florida, had a 34% chance of a major hurricane making landfall this year. The average from 1880-2020 was 21%.\n\nForecasters say that the record-warm water temperatures that now cover much of the Atlantic Ocean will continue into peak hurricane season from August to October. That warm water fuels hurricanes. By early June, the tropical Atlantic was already as hot as it usually is in mid-August -- peak hurricane season.\n\nHurricane season officially ends Nov. 30.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", See path", "body": "A tropical rainstorm bearing down on the Gulf Coast could bring major impacts to northeast Mexico and southeast Texas.\n\nThe tropical disturbance in the Gulf of Mexico south of Texas has intensified, prompting the National Weather Service to issue a tropical storm warning for several areas along Coastal Texas.\n\nThe NHC is also expected to name Alberto as the first storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season by Wednesday. To become a tropical storm, maximum sustained winds must reach at least 39 mph.\n\nCurrently, the NHC has dubbed the tropical event \"Potential Tropical Cyclone One,\" which allows the NHC to issue advisories, watches and warnings for the system that hasn't yet formed into a tropical storm but poses a threat.\n\nMore: NHC tracks system in Gulf of Mexico; Jim Cantore warns of 'double digit rainfall' in Texas\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One is expected to make landfall in Mexico late Wednesday but will bring significant rainfall to Texas far earlier, hitting Texas in the coming hours. Those in South Texas and along the coast can expect to see impact as early as Tuesday evening, which will include flooding rain, coastal flooding, gusty winds and high surf and rip currents.\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One: Where is it going?\n\nNHC warned that the system is very large, with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 290 miles northeast of the center.\n\nHeavy rain is forecast to extend well north of the center of the storm, spreading into portions of Central Texas. The Weather Channel has forecast rainfall of up to 15 inches in parts of the state, according to the NHC.\n\nNHC has issued a tropical storm warning for the Texas coast from Port O'Connor southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande. A warning was also issued for the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Puerto de Altamira.\n\nSpaghetti models for Potential Tropical Cyclone One\n\nSpecial note about spaghetti models: Illustrations include an array of forecast tools and models, and not all are created equal. The hurricane center uses only the top four or five highest-performing models to help make its forecasts.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center also is monitoring two other systems: a disturbance east of Florida with a low chance for development and another area in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico close to where Potential Tropical Cyclone One is.\n\nKey messages from the National Hurricane Center: What you need to know about Potential Tropical Cyclone One\n\nWhat impact could Potential Tropical Cyclone One have and what areas could be affected?\n\nWhat do tropical storm watches, warnings from NHC mean?\n\nWhat is storm surge? Graphics explain the deadly weather event\n\nTropical storm warning: A tropical storm warning means that tropical storm conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area within 36 hours.\n\nTropical storm watch: An announcement that sustained winds of 39 to 73 mph are possible within the specified area within 48 hours in association with a tropical, subtropical, or {"uri": "8187193975", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "14:24:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T14:24:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T14:18:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/tropical-storm-alberto-heavy-rains-134502176.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto: Heavy rains, flooding in South Texas following landfall in Mexico", "body": "Millions of people along the southern coast of Texas were under severe weather advisories as officials warned of high storm surge, torrential rain and possible tornadoes as Tropical Storm Alberto barreled over northern Mexico. Here's what we know.\n\nThe first named storm in the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season made landfall in Mexico, near the U.S. border, sometime between 4 a.m. and 7 a.m. local time, according to the National Hurricane Center. Along with sustained winds near 45 mph, the storm is forecast to dump up to 20 inches across parts of northeast Mexico with nearly a foot of rain expected throughout southern Texas.\n\nSuch high rainfall totals will likely produce \"considerable flash flooding and urban flooding\" as well as possible mudslides across northern Mexico, the NHC said.\n\nAfter making landfall, Alberto is expected to diminish in strength, though it could still produce life-threatening weather conditions.\n\nAlberto began drenching southern Texas on Wednesday, triggering widespread coastal flooding that left Surfside Beach, a city along the Texas Gulf Coast south of Houston, under several feet of water. The storm also lashed Mexico with heavy rain, and caused the deaths of at least three minors, Nuevo Leon state Governor Samuel Garcia told local media without providing details.\n\nAcross southern Texas, the combination of storm surge and high tide is raising alarms on Thursday as floodwaters could reach up to 4 feet along the coast. The deepest waters will breach the shore along the Texas coast just to the north of Mexico, where the surge will be accompanied by large and dangerous waves, according to NHC.\n\nLife-threatening surf and rip current conditions are among the central threats for the Gulf Coast of Texas through Friday. In deep South Texas, multiple counties were under a tornado watch as forecasters warned that a possible tornado or two could spin up through the morning.\n\nAll tropical storm watches and warnings have been discontinued all the U.S. Gulf Coast, and heavy rain and gusty winds are beginning to subside for South Texas.\n\nAcross the Coastal Bend of Texas, the National Weather Service reported a few gusts of wind above 50 mph and rainfall totals of about 2 to 7 inches.\n\n\"Between 4-8 inches of rain can fall across a widespread area from south of Houston to far northeastern Mexico from Monday to Thursday night, while rainfall totals as high as 8-12 inches can occur over South Texas and the higher elevations of northern Mexico,\" according to AccuWeather.\n\nPeople are also reading: Storm tracker: See latest details, possible path as tropical storm warning issued in Texas\n\nTropical Storm Alberto made landfall in Mexico early Thursday morning and is expected to move farther inland, according to the latest report by the NHC. A tropical storm warning has been issued for a portion of the northeastern Mexico coast.\n\nHere's a quick breakdown of conditions, as of 7 a.m. Thursday:\n\nTexas governor Greg Abbott issued a disaster proclamation for 51 counties Wednesday evening, as winds and flooding from the tropical storm continue hitting the state's coast. He also activated three platoons of the Texas National Guard, including more than 40 personnel, 20 vehicles and Chinook helicopters.\n\nNHC has issued a tropical storm warning for the Texas coast from San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande. A warning was also issued for the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\nOn Wednesday the NHC named the system in the Gulf, making it the first named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season.\n\n-- USA TODAY reporters Christopher Cann and Cheryl McCloud contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, See path", "body": "The tropical disturbance in the Gulf of Mexico south of Texas has intensified, prompting the National Weather Service to issue a tropical storm warning for several areas along Coastal Texas.\n\nThe NHC is also expected to name Alberto as the first storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season by Wednesday. To become a tropical storm, maximum sustained winds must reach at least 39 mph.\n\nCurrently, the NHC has dubbed the tropical event \"Potential Tropical Cyclone One,\" which allows the NHC to issue advisories, watches and warnings for the system that hasn't yet formed into a tropical storm but poses a threat.\n\nMore: NHC tracks system in Gulf of Mexico; Jim Cantore warns of 'double digit rainfall' in Texas\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One is expected to make landfall in Mexico late Wednesday but will bring significant rainfall to Texas far earlier, hitting Texas in the coming hours. Those in South Texas and along the coast can expect to see impact as early as Tuesday evening, which will include flooding rain, coastal flooding, gusty winds and high surf and rip currents.\n\nNHC warned that the system is very large, with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 290 miles northeast of the center.\n\nHeavy rain is forecast to extend well north of the center of the storm, spreading into portions of Central Texas. The Weather Channel has forecast rainfall of up to 15 inches in parts of the state, according to the NHC.\n\nNHC has issued a tropical storm warning for the Texas coast from Port O'Connor southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande. A warning was also issued for the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Puerto de Altamira.\n\nSpecial note about spaghetti models: Illustrations include an array of forecast tools and models, and not all are created equal. The hurricane center uses only the top four or five highest-performing models to help make its forecasts.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center also is monitoring two other systems: a disturbance east of Florida with a low chance for development and another area in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico close to where Potential Tropical Cyclone One is.\n\nWhat is storm surge? Graphics explain the deadly weather event\n\nTropical storm warning: A tropical storm warning means that tropical storm conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area within 36 hours.\n\nTropical storm watch: An announcement that sustained winds of 39 to 73 mph are possible within the specified area within 48 hours in association with a tropical, subtropical, or post-tropical cyclone.\n\n-- USA TODAY NETWORK - Florida reporter Cheryl McCloud contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8185569380", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:39:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:39:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:28:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/tropical-storm-alberto-forms-off-151800380.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto forms off Mexico, soaks Texas", "body": "Tropical Storm Alberto, the first named storm of the season, has formed in the Gulf of Mexico and is headed for the coast of Mexico.\n\nAs of 11 a.m. Wednesday, the storm was 295 miles south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas, traveling west at 9 mph, with maximum sustained winds of 40 mph.\n\nForecasters expect some slight strengthening Wednesday or Wednesday night before the center of Alberto reaches land.\n\nLandfall is expected early Thursday morning.\n\nOnce inland, the storm should weaken quickly, and likely dissipate over Mexico Thursday or Thursday night.\n\nAlberto is a large, slow-moving tropical storm, with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 415 miles north of the center.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center has issued a tropical storm warning from the Mexico border north along the Gulf Coast to near Houston.\n\nOn Wednesday morning, the storm was causing coastal flooding near Galveston, Texas, 500 miles away from its likely landfall in Mexico. Storm surge there is expected to reach 2 to 4 feet, depending on tide.\n\nForecasters urged people to not focus solely on the storm's forecast track.\n\nThe hurricane center has expanded the tropical storm warning north, to San Luis Pass near Houston.\n\n\"The disturbance is very large with rainfall, coastal flooding, and wind impacts likely to occur far from the center along the coasts of Texas and northeastern Mexico,\" the hurricane center said.\n\nInland in Mexico and South Texas, rainfall could be significant and potentially dangerous, given the mountainous terrain in some of the region.\n\nRainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South Texas are possible, with maximum totals of 15 inches. Flash flooding and mudslides are potential hazards.\n\nSeparate from the potential tropical storm, forecasters are also watching two other potential systems, one of which could affect Florida.\n\nAs of 8 a.m. Wednesday, a disturbance in the same area of the Gulf of Mexico as the potential tropical storm had a 30% chance of forming in the next seven days. It is expected to move slowly west-northwest or northwest and is expected to develop over the southwestern Gulf over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, forecasters are watching an area of storminess several hundred miles east of the central Bahamas and could approach the southern U.S. East Coast, potentially including Florida, late this week.\n\nIt has a 20% chance of development over the next seven days, with some slow development possible thereafter while the system moves westward or west-northwestward.\n\nThe 2024 hurricane season, which officially began June 1, is expected to be extremely active. Monday's watch was the first of the 2024 hurricane season, which forecasters say will be a strong one.\n\nIn its annual May outlook, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said that the 2024 hurricane season has an 85% chance of being above normal, with 17 to 25 named storms with minimum sustained winds of 39 mph, and eight to 13 hurricanes. An average year has 14 named storms and seven hurricanes.\n\nIn addition, NOAA has forecast four to seven major hurricanes for 2024, meaning those that are Category 3 or above.\n\nExperts at Colorado State University stated in their 2024 forecast that the U.S. East Coast, including Florida, had a 34% chance of a major hurricane making landfall this year. The average from 1880-2020 was 21%.\n\nForecasters say that the record-warm water temperatures that now cover much of the Atlantic Ocean will continue into peak hurricane season from August to October. That warm water fuels hurricanes. By early June, the tropical Atlantic was already as hot as it usually is in mid-August -- peak hurricane season.\n\nHurricane season officially ends Nov. 30.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", {"uri": "2024-06-394957560", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:33:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:33:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T00:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://m.arcamax.com/knowledge/weather/weathernews/s-3293720", "title": "System in Gulf of Mexico to become Tropical Storm Alberto today, forecasters say", "body": "FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. -- Potential Tropical Cyclone One brewing in the Gulf of Mexico is expected to become a tropical storm on Wednesday and has prompted the National Hurricane Center to issue a tropical storm warning for parts of Texas and coastal Mexico.\n\nIf the disturbance strengthens into a tropical storm -- the first of the season -- it will be named Alberto. Forecasters said it won't affect Florida.\n\nMeanwhile, a disturbance in the Atlantic has a 20% chance of developing in the next seven days and has a trajectory that will affect North Florida. The system is likely to bring rain to North Florida. Forecasters said South Florida will have a wet week regardless of where the Atlantic disturbance travels.\n\nAs of 8 a.m. Tuesday, the Gulf storm was 295 miles southeast of Brownsville, Texas, moving west-northwest at 8 mph, with maximum sustained winds of 40 mph. Forecasters are concerned about rainfall amounts, particularly in areas north of the center of the storm.\n\nIt is expected to strengthen and make landfall late Wednesday or early Thursday as a tropical storm in northeastern Mexico, with tropical storm force winds, and significant rainfall, extending into the U.S.\n\nThe NHC has expanded the tropical storm warning north, to San Luis Pass near Houston.\n\nThe warnings reach south to the mouth of the Rio Grande River. The government of Mexico also has issued a tropical storm warning for the northeastern coast of Mexico, south to Puerto de Altamira.\n\nThe hurricane center said the disturbance is \"quite large\" and has tropical-storm-force winds extending outward, up to 415 miles to the northeast of the center, toward South Texas.\n\nThe system is expected to continue making its turn to the west Tuesday night, and will reach the Gulf coast of Mexico by Wednesday night.\n\nForecasters urged people to not focus solely on the storm's forecast track.\n\n\"The disturbance is very large with rainfall, coastal flooding, and wind impacts likely to occur far from the center along the coasts of Texas and northeastern Mexico,\" the hurricane center said.\n\nRainfall could be significant and potentially dangerous, given the mountainous terrain in some of the region.\n\nRainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South Texas are possible, with maximum totals of 15 inches. Flash flooding and mudslides are potential hazards.\n\nStorm surge also is a concern, particularly along the flatter areas of the Texas coast. Galveston Bay could see 2 to 4 feet of surge.\n\nSeparate from the potential tropical storm, forecasters are also watching two other potential systems, one of which could affect Florida.\n\nAs of 8 a.m. Wednesday, a disturbance in the same area of the Gulf of Mexico as the potential tropical storm had a 30% chance of forming in the next seven days. It is expected to move slowly west-northwest or northwest and is expected to develop over the southwestern Gulf over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, forecasters are watching an area of storminess that several hundred miles east of the central Bahamas and could approach the southern U.S. East Coast, potentially including Florida, late this week.\n\nIt has a 20% chance of development over the next seven days, with some slow development possible thereafter while the system moves westward or west-northwestward.\n\nThe 2024 hurricane season, which officially began June 1, is expected to be extremely active. Monday's watch was the first of the 2024 hurricane season, which forecasters say will be a strong one.\n\nIn its annual May outlook, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said that the 2024 hurricane season has an 85% chance of being above normal, with 17 to 25 named storms with minimum sustained winds of 39 mph, and eight to 13 hurricanes. An average year has 14 named storms and seven hurricanes.\n\nIn addition, NOAA has forecast four to seven major hurricanes for 2024, meaning those that are Category 3 or above.\n\nExperts at Colorado State University stated in their 2024 forecast that the U.S. East Coast, including Florida, had a 34% chance of a major hurricane making landfall this year. The average from 1880-2020 was 21%.\n\nForecasters say that the record-warm water temperatures that now cover much of the Atlantic Ocean will continue into peak hurricane season from August to October. That warm water fuels hurricanes. By early June, the tropical Atlantic was already as hot as it usually is in mid-August -- peak hurricane season.\n\n(Sun Sentinel staff writer Robin Webb contributed to this report.)", "source": Alberto will be the first tropical storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season and is expected to make landfall in Mexico between late Wednesday and early Thursday morning.\n\nIn recent days, the disturbance has intensified significantly, prompting the National Weather Service to issue a tropical storm warning for several areas along Coastal Texas early Tuesday morning before expanding the warning to include a broader range of Texas later in the afternoon.\n\nThe warning now stretches across nearly the entirety of the state's coastline from San Luis Pass near Galveston to the mouth of the Rio Grande.\n\nMore: Tropical system brings heavy rain, flood threat to Corpus Christi, south Texas\n\nWhy is the tropical disturbance not yet a storm?\n\nCurrently, the NHC has dubbed the tropical event \"Potential Tropical Cyclone One,\" which allows the NHC to issue advisories, watches and warnings for the system that hasn't yet formed into a tropical storm but poses a threat.\n\nTo become a tropical storm, maximum sustained winds must reach at least 39 mph, and the disturbance reportedly has maximum sustained speeds of 40 mph. However, the cyclone has yet to have a \"well-defined center of circulation,\" which is another determining factor.\n\nWhen will Track Potential Tropical Cyclone One make landfall?\n\nNHC warned that the system is very large, with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 415 miles to the north of the center, increasing significantly from an advisory Tuesday morning that cited 290 miles outward.\n\n\"A generally westward motion with an increase in forward speed is expected during the next day or so, and the system is forecast to reach the coast of northeastern Mexico by late tonight or early Thursday,\" the latest advisory stated.\n\nAlready, the storm has brought significant rainfall to Texas. Those in South Texas and along the coast can expect to see continuing impact, which will include flooding rain, coastal flooding, gusty winds and high surf and rip currents, through Thursday.\n\nThe storm is expected to produce rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South Texas, with maximum totals of 15 inches possible, according to the NHC.\n\nWatches and warnings issued in Texas\n\nNHC has issued a tropical storm warning for the Texas coast from San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande. A warning was also issued for the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Puerto de Altamira.\n\nTrack Potential Tropical Cyclone One's path\n\nWhat do tropical storm watches, warnings from NHC mean?\n\nWhat is storm surge? It is the first named storm of the 2024 hurricane season.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto made landfall over Mexico around 7 a.m. CDT, with heavy rains and gusty winds expected to continue through Thursday morning along northeastern Mexico, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nAll tropical storm watches and warnings have been discontinued along the U.S. Gulf Coast, with rain and winds starting to subside for the southern Texas coast Thursday morning.\n\nHowever, a Tropical Storm Warning is in effect for the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla, the National Hurricane Center said in an advisory early Thursday morning.\n\nAcross the Coastal Bend of Texas, the National Weather Service reported a few gusts of wind above 50 mph and rainfall totals of about 2 to 7 inches.\n\n\"Between 4-8 inches of rain can fall across a widespread area from south of Houston to far northeastern Mexico from Monday to Thursday night, while rainfall totals as high as 8-12 inches can occur over South Texas and the higher elevations of northern Mexico,\" according to AccuWeather.\n\nAccording to the National Weather Service in Corpus Christi, there is a flood watch in effect until 1 p.m. local time this afternoon, a coastal flood warning through Friday evening and a high risk if rip currents through Friday afternoon.\n\n2024 Atlantic hurricane names: List of 2024 Atlantic hurricane season storm names starts with Alberto and Beryl\n\nTropical Storm Alberto made landfall over Mexico around 7 a.m. CDT Thursday, the National Hurricane Center said in an advisory. Landfall was recorded about 25 miles west of Tampico, Mexico, and about 255 miles south of Brownsville, Texas.\n\nAlberto is moving toward the west near 13 mph. This motion is expected to continue through Thursday, and on this track, the center of Alberto should move inland over Mexico shortly, the National Hurricane Center said at 5 a.m.\n\nThis forecast track shows the most likely path of the center of the storm. It does not illustrate the full width of the storm or its impacts, and the center of the storm is likely to travel outside the cone up to 33% of the time.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto spaghetti models\n\nIllustrations include an array of forecast tools and models, and not all are created equal. The hurricane center uses only the top four or five highest performing models to help make its forecasts.\n\nContributing: Cheryl McCloud, USA TODAY Network-Florida", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8186071950", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "23:33:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T23:33:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T23:32:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.oregonlive.com/weather/2024/06/tropical-storm-alberto-takes-aim-at-mexicos-gulf-coast.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto takes aim at Mexico's gulf coast", "body": "Tropical Storm Alberto, the first named storm of the 2024 hurricane season, has formed in the Gulf of Mexico and is headed for the coast of Mexico.\n\nAs of 2 p.m. Wednesday, the storm was 305 miles south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas, traveling west-southwest at 9 mph, with maximum sustained winds of 40 mph.\n\nSeparate from Alberto, forecasters also are watching two other potential systems, one in the Gulf, and one east of the Bahamas, which could affect Florida.\n\nForecasters expect Alberto to strengthen slightly Wednesday or Wednesday night before making landfall sometime early Thursday morning, south of the U.S. border with Mexico.\n\nOnce inland, the storm should weaken quickly, and likely dissipate over Mexico on Thursday or Thursday night.\n\nAlberto is a large, slow-moving tropical storm, with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 415 miles north of the center.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center has issued a tropical storm warning that stretches 400 or so miles, from the Mexico border north along the Gulf Coast to near Houston.\n\nOn Wednesday morning, the storm was causing coastal flooding near Galveston, Texas, 500 miles away from its likely landfall in Mexico. Storm surge there is expected to reach 2 to 4 feet, depending on tide. There was even some street flooding in Louisiana.\n\nForecasters urged people to not focus solely on the storm's forecast track.\n\nThe hurricane center has expanded the tropical storm warning north, to San Luis Pass near Houston.\n\n\"The disturbance is very large with rainfall, coastal flooding, and wind impacts likely to occur far from the center along the coasts of Texas and northeastern Mexico,\" the hurricane center said.\n\nInland in Mexico and South Texas, rainfall could be significant and potentially dangerous, given the mountainous terrain in some of the region.\n\nRainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South Texas are possible, with maximum totals of 15 inches. Flash flooding and mudslides are potential hazards.\n\nAs of 2 p.m. Wednesday, a disturbance in the same area of the Gulf of Mexico as Alberto had a 30% chance of forming in the next seven days. It is expected to move slowly northwest and develop over the southwestern Gulf over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, forecasters are watching an area of storminess several hundred miles east of the central Bahamas that could approach the southern U.S. East Coast, potentially including Florida, late this week.\n\nThe 2024 hurricane season, which officially began June 1, is expected to be extremely active. Monday's watch was the first of the 2024 hurricane season, which forecasters say will be a strong one.\n\nIn its annual May outlook, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said that the 2024 hurricane season has an 85% chance of being above normal, with 17 to 25 named storms with minimum sustained winds of 39 mph, and eight to 13 hurricanes. An average year has 14 named storms and seven hurricanes.\n\nIn addition, NOAA has forecast four to seven major hurricanes for 2024, meaning those that are Category 3 or above.\n\nExperts at Colorado State University stated in their 2024 forecast that the U.S. East Coast, including Florida, had a 34% chance of a major hurricane making landfall this year. The average from 1880-2020 was 21%.\n\nForecasters say that the record-warm water temperatures that now cover much of the Atlantic Ocean will continue into peak hurricane season from August to October. That warm water fuels hurricanes. By early June, the tropical Atlantic was already as hot as it usually is in mid-August -- peak hurricane season.", "source": {"uri": "oregonlive.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Oregon Live"}, {"uri": "8185556422", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:20:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:20:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:19:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.sun-sentinel.com/2024/06/19/tropical-storm-alberto-forms-off-mexico-soaks-texas/", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto forms off Mexico, soaks Texas", "body": "By Bill Kearney | South Florida Sun Sentinel and Angie DiMichele | adimichele@sunsentinel.com | South Florida Sun Sentinel\n\nTropical Storm Alberto, the first named storm of the season, has formed in the Gulf of Mexico and is headed for the coast of Mexico.\n\nAs of 11 a.m. Wednesday, the storm was 295 miles south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas, traveling west at 9 mph, with maximum sustained winds of 40 mph.\n\nForecasters expect some slight strengthening Wednesday or Wednesday night before the center of Alberto reaches land.\n\nLandfall is expected early Thursday morning.\n\nOnce inland, the storm should weaken quickly, and likely dissipate over Mexico Thursday or Thursday night.\n\nAlberto is a large, slow-moving tropical storm, with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 415 miles north of the center.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center has issued a tropical storm warning from the Mexico border north along the Gulf Coast to near Houston.\n\nOn Wednesday morning, the storm was causing coastal flooding near Galveston, Texas, 500 miles away from its likely landfall in Mexico. Storm surge there is expected to reach 2 to 4 feet, depending on tide.\n\nForecasters urged people to not focus solely on the storm's forecast track.\n\nThe NHC has expanded the tropical storm warning north, to San Luis Pass near Houston.\n\n\"The disturbance is very large with rainfall, coastal flooding, and wind impacts likely to occur far from the center along the coasts of Texas and northeastern Mexico,\" the hurricane center said.\n\nInland in Mexico and South Texas, rainfall could be significant and potentially dangerous, given the mountainous terrain in some of the region.\n\nRainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South Texas are possible, with maximum totals of 15 inches. Flash flooding and mudslides are potential hazards.\n\nSeparate from the potential tropical storm, forecasters are also watching two other potential systems, one of which could affect Florida.\n\nAs of 8 a.m. Wednesday, a disturbance in the same area of the Gulf of Mexico as the potential tropical storm had a 30% chance of forming in the next seven days. It is expected to move slowly west-northwest or northwest and is expected to develop over the southwestern Gulf over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, forecasters are watching an area of storminess that several hundred miles east of the central Bahamas and could approach the southern U.S. East Coast, potentially including Florida, late this week.\n\nIt has a 20% chance of development over the next seven days, with some slow development possible thereafter while the system moves westward or west-northwestward.\n\nThe 2024 hurricane season, which officially began June 1, is expected to be extremely active. Monday's watch was the first of the 2024 hurricane season, which forecasters say will be a strong one.\n\nIn its annual May outlook, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said that the 2024 hurricane season has an 85% chance of being above normal, with 17 to 25 named storms with minimum sustained winds of 39 mph, and eight to 13 hurricanes. An average year has 14 named storms and seven hurricanes.\n\nIn addition, NOAA has forecast four to seven major hurricanes for 2024, meaning those that are Category 3 or above.\n\nExperts at Colorado State University stated in their 2024 forecast that the U.S. East Coast, including Florida, had a 34% chance of a major hurricane making landfall this year. The average from 1880-2020 was 21%.\n\nForecasters say that the record-warm water temperatures that now cover much of the Atlantic Ocean will continue into peak hurricane season from August to October. That warm water fuels hurricanes. By early June, the tropical Atlantic was already as hot as it usually is in mid-August -- peak hurricane season.\n\nHurricane season officially ends Nov. 30.", "source": {"uri": "sun-sentinel.com", {"uri": "8185454237", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "14:12:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T14:12:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T14:07:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://davidsonian.com/2024/06/19/tropical-storm-warning-issued-for-texas-as-gulf-coast-braces-for-severe-weather/", "title": "Tropical Storm Warning Issued for Texas as Gulf Coast Braces for Severe Weather", "body": "The first tropical storm warning of this year's hurricane season was issued early Tuesday, prompting coastal communities in southern Texas to brace for heavy rain, flooding, and potential tornadoes. The National Hurricane Center (NHC) reported that the storm, developing over the southern Gulf of Mexico, was expected to reach land as a potential tropical cyclone.\n\nIf the storm strengthens, it will become the season's first named storm: Tropical Storm Alberto. As of Tuesday night, the system was centered approximately 365 miles southeast of Brownsville, Texas, and was predicted to become a tropical storm by Wednesday. It was forecasted to make landfall on Mexico's Gulf Coast by Wednesday night. The NHC estimated an 80% chance of the system becoming a tropical storm within the next two days.\n\nThe tropical storm warning covers coastal Texas from San Luis Pass to the mouth of the Rio Grande and extends along the Gulf Coast of Mexico. The storm is expected to affect large parts of Central America with rainfall. Forecasts on Tuesday night indicated maximum sustained winds near 40 miles per hour, expected to increase over the next 36 hours. Downpours and coastal flooding were predicted over the coming days.\n\nIn Texas, moderate coastal flooding was anticipated to begin along the coast as early as Tuesday, worsening through midweek. The situation was expected to escalate on Wednesday in the tropical storm warning area, potentially causing flash flooding and urban flooding as rivers overflow. Northeastern Mexico could experience mudslides.\n\nAt 4 a.m. CT on Tuesday, the NHC upgraded the season's first tropical storm watch to a tropical storm warning. By 7 a.m., Mexico's government issued a tropical storm warning for the northeastern coast, south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Puerto de Altamira, replacing the earlier watch.\n\nThe storm was moving northwest at 7 mph over the Gulf on Tuesday evening, with a projected westward turn overnight into Wednesday, before reaching northeastern Mexico by Wednesday night. Forecasts indicated that regions in northeastern Mexico and southern Texas could receive 5 to 10 inches of rainfall, with the possibility of more severe inundation in certain areas. Peak storm surge occurring in tandem with high tide could lead to flooding up to 4 feet above ground along the Gulf Coast in Texas and Mexico. The deepest water was predicted near the storm's landfall location and to its north, with storm surge likely accompanied by large, dangerous waves. These conditions are expected to create life-threatening surf and rip currents.\n\nThe Atlantic hurricane season officially began on June 1 and will run through the end of November. Most storm activity typically occurs from mid-August to mid-October. The terms \"hurricane\" and \"tropical cyclone\" refer to the same type of storm, with \"tropical cyclone\" serving as a broad classification for rotating, low-level cloud systems and thunderstorms over tropical or subtropical waters, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).\n\nA tropical cyclone becomes a tropical storm once its maximum wind speeds exceed 39 mph. When sustained winds reach 74 mph or higher, it is classified as a hurricane. As communities along the Gulf Coast prepare for the potential impacts of Tropical Storm Alberto, the importance of understanding and respecting these powerful natural phenomena cannot be overstated.", {"uri": "2024-06-395159214", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "21:05:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T21:05:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T20:26:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://eu.palmbeachpost.com/story/weather/2024/06/19/tropical-storm-alberto-forms-in-gulf-of-mexico-with-40-mph-winds/74149854007/", "title": "Alberto forms in Gulf as first named storm of season; will Atlantic system bring rain?", "body": "As hurricane season starts, Kimberly Miller, weather reporter for the Palm Beach Post, has helpful tips for the best hurricane survival kit and how to prepare for a hurricane.\n\nThe first winds and signs of tropical trouble for 2024 have officially arrived.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto formed Wednesday morning in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, the first named storm of what is expected to be a busy hurricane season.\n\nAt around 2 p.m., Alberto was located 185 miles east of Tampico, Mexico, and 295 miles south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas. Winds were peaking around 40 mph, according to the National Hurricane Center (NHC) in Miami. For Alberto to become a hurricane, sustained winds of 73 mph would have to happen, which isn't likely before the storm moves onto land, forecasters said.\n\n\"Rapid weakening is expected once the center moves inland, and Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico\" on Thursday, the NHC said.\n\nIt's the first real winds of the tropical season, with more assuredly on the way in the upcoming peak months. Some forecasts have even predicted more than double the number of average named storms for the 2024 season, citing a rising La Ni\u00f1a and water temperatures in the runway between Africa and the Gulf of Mexico that are 3.6 to 7 degrees warmer than normal.\n\nFederal forecasters last month predicted an \"extraordinary\" season with as many as 25 named storms possible -- the highest number of named storms the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has predicted.\n\nAn average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.\n\nAn early June storm dumped more than 20 inches of rain on parts of South Florida, stranding numerous motorists on flooded streets throughout Broward and Miami-Dade counties. That storm, despite producing a tornado in Martin County, did not have any sustained wind associated with it and never reached name status.\n\nCoastal flooding, not wind, likely biggest threat with Alberto\n\nAlberto was moving west on Wednesday at a slow 9 mph pace. Tropical storm warnings were in effect from the Texas coast at San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande, and from the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\nThe storm is expected to make landfall in northeastern Mexico on Thursday morning with rain and wind reaching Texas and coastal Louisiana, according to the NHC.\n\nAlberto isn't packing a big punch, but it is a relatively large storm, with tropical-storm-force winds extending up to 415 miles north of the center. The hurricane center said heavy rainfall from the storm will reach large regions of Central America, north across northeastern Mexico and into South Texas.\n\nOfficials said the peak storm surge could reach up to 2 to 4 feet, including around Galveston Bay in Texas.\n\nNick Carr, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service (NWS) in Miami, said flooding on the coast will be the biggest threat with Alberto.\n\n\"The wind will be nothing to write home about with this storm,\" he said. \"It's kind of a sprawling, disorganized system that is funneling a lot of water toward the northern part of Mexico and the southern part of Texas. It's a very sloppy, early-season system.\"\n\nTexas Gov. Greg Abbott has activated three platoons of the Lone Star State's National Guard, including more than 40 personnel, 20 vehicles and Chinook helicopters.\n\n\"Texans in at-risk areas are urged to remain vigilant, monitor weather conditions and take necessary precautions to keep themselves and their loved ones safe,\" Abbott said in a statement.\n\nFor now, the coastal city of Houston is not in any significant threat of flooding, but a tropical storm warning does cover coastal counties from just south of Galveston to the U.S.-Mexico border. Tropical storm-force winds with 50-mph gusts are likely along the coast.\n\n\"This rainfall will likely produce considerable flash and urban flooding along with new and renewed river flooding,\" the hurricane center said. \"Life-threatening flooding and mudslides are likely in and near areas of high terrain across the Mexican states of Coahuila, Nuevo Leon and Tamaulipas, including the cities of Monterrey and Ciudad Victoria.\"\n\nAlberto's arrival on the day before the official first day of summer is a somewhat late start to the season. The last time a storm formed this late into June was 2014 when Arthur formed June 30.\n\nSystem in Atlantic will bring some heavy surf and possible showers to South Florida\n\nMeanwhile, closer to home, an area of showers and thunderstorms a few hundred miles east of the Bahamas is still in the developmental stages. The system, with a surface trough of low pressure, is in environmental conditions that the hurricane center calls \"marginally conducive for some gradual development during the next few days while it moves westward or west-northwestward.\"\n\nThe system is forecast to approach the coast of the southeastern U.S. by Friday, but should veer north of South Florida and move closer to Jacksonville and southern Georgia.\n\nDevelopment chances are low, only 10% to 20% through the next two to seven days. Still, the system could bring some more rainfall to South Florida on Friday and throughout the weekend, but nothing more than an average June weekend in Palm Beach County.\n\nHURRICANE SEASON 2024: Colorado State University updates its seasonal hurricane forecast\n\nJUNE FLOODING: See dramatic images from flash flood, flooding in South Florida, including Fort Lauderdale\n\n2024 HURRICANE SEASON: Five tips to stay sane and safe in face of frightful forecast\n\nAs the southern states deal with rain and wind, much of the nation continues to struggle with record-breaking heat. More than 90 million Americans faced excessive heat watches, warnings or advisories Wednesday, mostly in the Upper Midwest and Northeast.\n\nThe heat could continue in those spots, with \"some monthly records possible,\" the NWS warned Wednesday.\n\nFirst named storms for Atlantic hurricane season", "source": {"uri": "eu.palmbeachpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "eu.palmbeachpost.com"},
