{"uri": "8186049403", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "23:08:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T23:08:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T23:04:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/tropical-storm-alberto-landfall-mexico-223200191.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto to make landfall Mexico early Thursday, drives flooding in coastal Texas", "body": "FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. -- Tropical Storm Alberto, the first named storm of the 2024 hurricane season, has formed in the Gulf of Mexico and is headed for the coast of Mexico.\n\nAs of 5 p.m. Eastern time Wednesday, the storm was 305 miles south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas, traveling west-southwest at 9 mph, with maximum sustained winds of 40 mph.\n\nSeparate from Alberto, forecasters also are watching two other potential systems, one in the Gulf, and one east of the Bahamas, which could affect Florida.\n\nForecasters expect Alberto to strengthen slightly Wednesday or Wednesday night before making landfall sometime early Thursday morning, south of the U.S. border with Mexico.\n\nOnce inland, the storm should weaken quickly, and likely dissipate over Mexico on Thursday or Thursday night.\n\nAlberto is a large, slow-moving tropical storm, with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 415 miles north of the center.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center has issued a tropical storm warning that stretches 400 or so miles, from the Mexico border north along the Gulf Coast to near Houston.\n\nOn Wednesday morning, the storm was causing coastal flooding near Galveston, Texas, 500 miles away from its likely landfall in Mexico. Storm surge there is expected to reach 2 to 4 feet, depending on tide. There was even some street flooding in Louisiana.\n\nForecasters urged people to not focus solely on the storm's forecast track.\n\nThe hurricane center has expanded the tropical storm warning north, to San Luis Pass near Houston.\n\n\"The disturbance is very large with rainfall, coastal flooding, and wind impacts likely to occur far from the center along the coasts of Texas and northeastern Mexico,\" the hurricane center said.\n\nInland in Mexico and South Texas, rainfall could be significant and potentially dangerous, given the mountainous terrain in some of the region.\n\nRainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South Texas are possible, with maximum totals of 15 inches. Flash flooding and mudslides are potential hazards.\n\nAs of 2 p.m. Wednesday, a disturbance in the same area of the Gulf of Mexico as Alberto had a 30% chance of forming in the next seven days. It is expected to move slowly northwest and develop over the southwestern Gulf over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, forecasters are watching an area of storminess several hundred miles east of the central Bahamas that could approach the southern U.S. East Coast, potentially including Florida, late this week.\n\nIt has a 20% chance of development over the next two days, with some slow development possible thereafter while the system moves westward or west-northwestward. Forecasters expect the system to reach the east coast by Friday.\n\nThe system is likely to stay north of South Florida, and impact coastal areas farther up the coast.\n\nThe 2024 hurricane season, which officially began June 1, is expected to be extremely active. Monday's watch was the first of the 2024 hurricane season, which forecasters say will be a strong one.\n\nIn its annual May outlook, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said that the 2024 hurricane season has an 85% chance of being above normal, with 17 to 25 named storms with minimum sustained winds of 39 mph, and eight to 13 hurricanes. An average year has 14 named storms and seven hurricanes.\n\nIn addition, NOAA has forecast four to seven major hurricanes for 2024, meaning those that are Category 3 or above.\n\nExperts at Colorado State University stated in their 2024 forecast that the U.S. East Coast, including Florida, had a 34% chance of a major hurricane making landfall this year. The average from 1880-2020 was 21%.\n\nForecasters say that the record-warm water temperatures that now cover much of the Atlantic Ocean will continue into peak hurricane season from August to October. That warm water fuels hurricanes. By early June, the tropical Atlantic was already as hot as it usually is in mid-August -- peak hurricane season.\n\n(Sun Sentinel staff writer Robin Webb contributed to this report.)", "source": See spaghetti models", "body": "Tropical storm warnings have been issued for parts of the Texas coast ahead of Potential Tropical Cyclone One, according to the latest advisory from the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe system is expected to strengthen and is likely to become a tropical storm by Wednesday before approaching the western Gulf Coast late Wednesday. Tropical storm conditions are expected within the warning area by Wednesday.\n\nIf it does become a tropical storm, it'll become the first named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, Alberto.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center warned the system is very large: with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 290 miles to the northeast of the center.\n\nHeavy rain is forecast to extend well north of the center of the storm, spreading into portions of central Texas, according to AccuWeather.\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One is expected to bring 5 to 10 inches of rain across South Texas and into northeastern Mexico, with up to 15 inches possible, NHC forecasters said.\n\nAccuWeather is predicting over half a foot of rain across parts of the Texas and Louisiana coasts, with up to 30 inches possible in the hardest-hit areas.\n\n\"Very warm waters in this area of the Gulf, as well as low wind shear will make this a conducive environment for the tropical rainstorm to strengthen,\" said AccuWeather Senior Meteorologist Dan Pydynowski.\n\nFor an explanation of what the watches and warnings mean, scroll to the bottom of this story.\n\nAt 5 a.m. EDT, Potential Tropical Cyclone One was located about 420 miles southeast of Brownsville, Texas, or 350 miles east-southeast of La Pesca, Mexico. Latitude 21.3 North, longitude 93.0 West.\n\nThe system is moving toward the north near 6 mph. A gradual turn toward the west-northwest and west is expected is expected Tuesday night and Wednesday, and the system is likely to approach the western Gulf Coast late Wednesday.\n\nMaximum sustained winds remain near 40 mph, with higher gusts. Some increase in strength is likely during the next 36 hours, and the disturbance is forecast to become a tropical storm by Wednesday.\n\nThe disturbance is quite large with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 290 miles to the northeast of the center, the National Hurricane Center said.\n\nSpecial note about spaghetti models: Illustrations include an array of forecast tools and models, and not all are created equal. The hurricane center uses only the top four or five highest performing models to help make its forecasts.\n\nTropical storm warning: A tropical storm warning means that tropical storm conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area within 36 hours.\n\nTropical storm watch: An announcement that sustained winds of 39 to 73 mph are possible within the specified area within 48 hours in {"uri": "8185609749", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:59:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:59:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:58:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/system-in-gulf-of-mexico-to-become-tropical-storm-alberto-today-forecasters-say/article_c6540b09-8693-5fdf-903f-9a7fe664998e.html", "title": "System in Gulf of Mexico to become Tropical Storm Alberto today, forecasters say", "body": "Angie DiMichele and Bill Kearney - South Florida Sun Sentinel (TNS)\n\nFORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. -- Potential Tropical Cyclone One brewing in the Gulf of Mexico is expected to become a tropical storm on Wednesday and has prompted the National Hurricane Center to issue a tropical storm warning for parts of Texas and coastal Mexico.\n\nIf the disturbance strengthens into a tropical storm -- the first of the season -- it will be named Alberto. Forecasters said it won't affect Florida.\n\nMeanwhile, a disturbance in the Atlantic has a 20% chance of developing in the next seven days and has a trajectory that will affect North Florida. The system is likely to bring rain to North Florida. Forecasters said South Florida will have a wet week regardless of where the Atlantic disturbance travels.\n\nAs of 8 a.m. Tuesday, the Gulf storm was 295 miles southeast of Brownsville, Texas, moving west-northwest at 8 mph, with maximum sustained winds of 40 mph. Forecasters are concerned about rainfall amounts, particularly in areas north of the center of the storm.\n\nIt is expected to strengthen and make landfall late Wednesday or early Thursday as a tropical storm in northeastern Mexico, with tropical storm force winds, and significant rainfall, extending into the U.S.\n\nThe NHC has expanded the tropical storm warning north, to San Luis Pass near Houston.\n\nThe warnings reach south to the mouth of the Rio Grande River. The government of Mexico also has issued a tropical storm warning for the northeastern coast of Mexico, south to Puerto de Altamira.\n\nThe hurricane center said the disturbance is \"quite large\" and has tropical-storm-force winds extending outward, up to 415 miles to the northeast of the center, toward South Texas.\n\nThe system is expected to continue making its turn to the west Tuesday night, and will reach the Gulf coast of Mexico by Wednesday night.\n\nForecasters urged people to not focus solely on the storm's forecast track.\n\n\"The disturbance is very large with rainfall, coastal flooding, and wind impacts likely to occur far from the center along the coasts of Texas and northeastern Mexico,\" the hurricane center said.\n\nRainfall could be significant and potentially dangerous, given the mountainous terrain in some of the region.\n\nRainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South Texas are possible, with maximum totals of 15 inches. Flash flooding and mudslides are potential hazards.\n\nStorm surge also is a concern, particularly along the flatter areas of the Texas coast. Galveston Bay could see 2 to 4 feet of surge.\n\nSeparate from the potential tropical storm, forecasters are also watching two other potential systems, one of which could affect Florida.\n\nAs of 8 a.m. Wednesday, a disturbance in the same area of the Gulf of Mexico as the potential tropical storm had a 30% chance of forming in the next seven days. It is expected to move slowly west-northwest or northwest and is expected to develop over the southwestern Gulf over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, forecasters are watching an area of storminess that several hundred miles east of the central Bahamas and could approach the southern U.S. East Coast, potentially including Florida, late this week.\n\nIt has a 20% chance of development over the next seven days, with some slow development possible thereafter while the system moves westward or west-northwestward.\n\nThe 2024 hurricane season, which officially began June 1, is expected to be extremely active. Monday's watch was the first of the 2024 hurricane season, which forecasters say will be a strong one.\n\nIn its annual May outlook, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said that the 2024 hurricane season has an 85% chance of being above normal, with 17 to 25 named storms with minimum sustained winds of 39 mph, and eight to 13 hurricanes. An average year has 14 named storms and seven hurricanes.\n\nIn addition, NOAA has forecast four to seven major hurricanes for 2024, meaning those that are Category 3 or above.\n\nExperts at Colorado State University stated in their 2024 forecast that the U.S. East Coast, including Florida, had a 34% chance of a major hurricane making landfall this year. The average from 1880-2020 was 21%.\n\nForecasters say that the record-warm water temperatures that now cover much of the Atlantic Ocean will continue into peak hurricane season from August to October. That warm water fuels hurricanes. By early June, the tropical Atlantic was already as hot as it usually is in mid-August -- peak hurricane season.\n\nHurricane season officially ends Nov. 30.\n\n-------\n\n(Sun Sentinel staff writer Robin Webb contributed to this report.)\n\n-------\n\n\u00a92024 South Florida Sun Sentinel. Visit at sun-sentinel.com. {"uri": "8186474727", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "06:49:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T06:49:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T06:46:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.latinpost.com/articles/163327/20240619/pitching-tropical-storm-alberto-becomes-1st-named-storm-of-the-year-to-affect-texas-and-mexico.htm", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto Becomes 1st Named Storm of the Year, To Affect Texas and Mexico", "body": "The 2024 Atlantic Hurricane Season is now officially underway as the first named storm of the year, Tropical Storm Alberto, has formed in the Gulf of Mexico and is expected to affect Mexico and Texas. Meteorologists are now monitoring the storm and have placed tropical storm warnings on areas that the Alberto is expected to hit.\n\nAccording to AccuWeather, activity has increased in the Atlantic as \"warm waters across portions of the Caribbean Sea and Gulf of Mexico have helped to promote prime conditions for tropical development this week.\"\n\nMexico is directly in the path of Tropical Storm Alberto's eye, but nearby Texas is also expected to get a taste of the storm's wrath. It is expected to make landfall in northeastern Mexico early Thursday morning, with the most affected areas being the Texas Gulf Coast and the northeastern coast of Mexico. Meteorologists have warned that tropical storm conditions are expected within the warning area within 36 hours.\n\n\"Abnormally warm waters and a pocket of relatively low wind shear located in the Bay of Campeche allowed for Alberto to gain enough organization on Wednesday to be upgraded to tropical storm status,\" explained AccuWeather Meteorologist and Lead Hurricane Forecaster Alex DaSilva.\n\nUsually, the first named storm of the Atlantic Hurricane Season forms around June 20. Tropical Storm Alberto became a tropical storm around June 19, which means that this season is progressing right on schedule.\n\nAs Tropical Storm Alberto approaches land, areas around the gulf coasts of Texas and Mexico are expected to receive rain and a lot of it, together with some strong winds and maybe even some flooding.\n\nREAD MORE: New Atlantic Hurricane Season Could Spell A Lot More Hurricanes This Year\n\nThe Weather Channel stated that Texas can expect some \"Flooding rain, coastal flooding, gusty winds, high surf, rip currents, and isolated tornadoes.\" Meanwhile, Mexico is also expected to experience the same but with the added danger of mudslides.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto may strengthen slightly before it makes landfall, and its impact will extend far from the center. The storm is expected to continue moving westward with winds of 39 miles per hour (mph) or greater in the warning areas, which include Brownsville and Corpus Christi.\n\nHeavy rains are expected along the Rio Grande and the Big Bend region, with rains expected to reach areas such as Austin, San Antonio, and Houston. So far, no hurricane warning has been issued.\n\nAs for Mexico, several governors whose states are on the storm's paths are already bracing themselves as the heavy rains could bring in mudslides and flash flooding. The most affected states may be Tamaulipas, Coahuila, and Nuevo Leon.\n\nTamaulipas Gov. Am\u00e9rico Villarreal has announced on X that schools across the state will remain closed between Wednesday and Friday, while Tamaulipas Civil Protection Coordinator Luis Gerardo Gonzalez announced that they have 333 shelters distributed throughout the state at each municipality and they will open upa more shelters as the hurricane moves.\n\nREAD NEXT: Texas Floods: Young Boy Dead as Search and {"uri": "2024-06-395097046", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:25:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:25:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T00:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://m.arcamax.com/knowledge/weather/weathernews/s-3293849", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto forms off Mexico, drives flooding in coastal Texas", "body": "FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. -- Tropical Storm Alberto, the first named storm of 2024 hurricane season, has formed in the Gulf of Mexico and is headed for the coast of Mexico.\n\nAs of 11 a.m. Wednesday, the storm was 295 miles south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas, traveling west at 9 mph, with maximum sustained winds of 40 mph.\n\nSeparate from Alberto, forecasters also are watching two other potential systems, one in the Gulf, and one east of the Bahamas, which could affect Florida.\n\nForecasters expect Alberto to strengthen slightly Wednesday or Wednesday night before making landfall sometime early Thursday morning, south of the U.S. border with Mexico.\n\nOnce inland, the storm should weaken quickly, and likely dissipate over Mexico on Thursday or Thursday night.\n\nAlberto is a large, slow-moving tropical storm, with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 415 miles north of the center.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center has issued a tropical storm warning that stretches 400 or so miles, from the Mexico border north along the Gulf Coast to near Houston.\n\nOn Wednesday morning, the storm was causing coastal flooding near Galveston, Texas, 500 miles away from its likely landfall in Mexico. Storm surge there is expected to reach 2 to 4 feet, depending on tide.\n\nForecasters urged people to not focus solely on the storm's forecast track.\n\nThe hurricane center has expanded the tropical storm warning north, to San Luis Pass near Houston.\n\n\"The disturbance is very large with rainfall, coastal flooding, and wind impacts likely to occur far from the center along the coasts of Texas and northeastern Mexico,\" the hurricane center said.\n\nInland in Mexico and South Texas, rainfall could be significant and potentially dangerous, given the mountainous terrain in some of the region.\n\nRainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South Texas are possible, with maximum totals of 15 inches. Flash flooding and mudslides are potential hazards.\n\nAdditional systems\n\nAs of 8 a.m. Wednesday, a disturbance in the same area of the Gulf of Mexico as Alberto had a 30% chance of forming in the next seven days. It is expected to move slowly northwest and is expected to develop over the southwestern Gulf over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, forecasters are watching an area of storminess several hundred miles east of the central Bahamas and could approach the southern U.S. East Coast, potentially including Florida, late this week.\n\nIt has a 20% chance of development over the next seven days, with some slow development possible thereafter while the system moves westward or west-northwestward.\n\nThe systems is likely to stay north of South Florida, and impact coastal areas farther up the coast.\n\nThe 2024 hurricane season, which officially began June 1, is expected to be extremely active. Monday's watch was the first of the 2024 hurricane season, which forecasters say will be a strong one.\n\nIn its annual May outlook, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said that the 2024 hurricane season has an 85% chance of being above normal, with 17 to 25 named storms with minimum sustained winds of 39 mph, and eight to 13 hurricanes. An average year has 14 named storms and seven hurricanes.\n\nIn addition, NOAA has forecast four to seven major hurricanes for 2024, meaning those that are Category 3 or above.\n\nExperts at Colorado State University stated in their 2024 forecast that the U.S. East Coast, including Florida, had a 34% chance of a major hurricane making landfall this year. The average from 1880-2020 was 21%.\n\nForecasters say that the record-warm water temperatures that now cover much of the Atlantic Ocean will continue into peak hurricane season from August to October. That warm water fuels hurricanes. By early June, the tropical Atlantic was already as hot as it usually is in mid-August -- peak hurricane season.\n\n(Sun Sentinel staff writer Robin Webb contributed to this report.)", "source": flooding.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto made landfall over Mexico around 7 a.m. CDT, with heavy rains and gusty winds expected to continue through Thursday morning along northeastern Mexico, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nAll tropical storm watches and warnings have been discontinued along the U.S. Gulf Coast, with rain and winds starting to subside for the southern Texas coast Thursday morning.\n\nHowever, a Tropical Storm Warning is in effect for the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla, the National Hurricane Center said in an advisory early Thursday morning.\n\nAcross the Coastal Bend of Texas, the National Weather Service reported a few gusts of wind above 50 mph and rainfall totals of about 2 to 7 inches.\n\n\"Between 4-8 inches of rain can fall across a widespread area from south of Houston to far northeastern Mexico from Monday to Thursday night, while rainfall totals as high as 8-12 inches can occur over South Texas and the higher elevations of northern Mexico,\" according to AccuWeather.\n\nAccording to the National Weather Service in Corpus Christi, there is a flood watch in effect until 1 p.m. local time this afternoon, a coastal flood warning through Friday evening and a high risk if rip currents through Friday afternoon.\n\n2024 Atlantic hurricane names: List of 2024 Atlantic hurricane season storm names starts with Alberto and Beryl\n\nTropical Storm Alberto made landfall over Mexico around 7 a.m. CDT Thursday, the National Hurricane Center said in an advisory. Landfall was recorded about 25 miles west of Tampico, Mexico, and about 255 miles south of Brownsville, Texas.\n\nAlberto is moving toward the west near 13 mph. This motion is expected to continue through Thursday, and on this track, the center of Alberto should move inland over Mexico shortly, the National Hurricane Center said at 5 a.m.\n\nThis forecast track shows the most likely path of the center of the storm. {"uri": "2024-06-394753356", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "13:22:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T13:22:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T12:46:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://eu.tallahassee.com/story/weather/hurricanes/2024/06/19/tropical-storm-alberto-expected-mexico/74138752007/", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto expected to form today, 1st named storm of 2024 hurricane season", "body": "Forecasters say a tropical system is likely to develop in the Gulf of Mexico this week as hurricane season kicks off.\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One is expected to become the first named tropical storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season: Alberto. The storm is forecast to reach the coast of northeastern Mexico by late Wednesday or early Thursday, according to the latest advisory from the National Hurricane Center.\n\nMeanwhile, the NHC is tracking two more disturbances in the Gulf of Mexico and the southwestern Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Florida.\n\nHeavy rain from Potential Tropical Cyclone One is already impacting parts of southern Mexico and northern portions of Central America, and portions of Texas are starting to feel it, the NHC said. The system is moving west-northwest and is expected to move further west and pick up speed Wednesday.\n\nTropical storm warnings have been issued for the Texas coast from San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande and for the northeastern coast of Mexico.\n\nForecasters predict considerable flash and urban flooding along with new and renewed river flooding, including potentially life-threatening flooding and mudslides in and near areas of higher terrain across the Mexican states of Coahuila, Nuevo Leon, and Tamaulipas. Swells generated by the disturbance will affect the coast of Louisiana and Texas as well as northeastern Mexico through early Thursday. These swells are likely to cause life threatening surf and rip current conditions.\n\n\u27a4 Track all active storms\n\nMeanwhile, forecasters still have their eyes on a low-pressure area off the east coast of Florida with a low chance of development.\n\n\"This appears to be a quick-moving and compact low-pressure area that will be moving westward into northeastern Florida or perhaps as far north as southeastern Georgia on Thursday,\" AccuWeather Senior Meteorologist Dan Pydynowski said. The storm's speed limits its development potential but it still could bring more rain, gusty winds and dangerous surf to the southeast Atlantic coast, forecasters said.\n\nAnother broad area of low pressure is forecast to develop over the southwestern Gulf of Mexico this weekend, the NHC said and it could gradually develop through early next week.\n\nSpecial note on the NHC cone: The forecast track shows the most likely path of the center of the storm. It does not illustrate the full width of the storm or its impacts, and the center of the storm is likely to travel outside the cone up to 33% of the time.\n\nForecast, impact: Potential Tropical Cyclone One expected to strengthen before landfall. See spaghetti models\n\nSpaghetti models for Potential Tropical Cyclone One\n\n\u27a4 Track Potential Tropical Cyclone One\n\nSpecial note about spaghetti models: Illustrations include an array of forecast tools and models, and not all are created equal. The hurricane center uses only the top four or five highest performing models to help make its forecasts.\n\nWhat is out there and how likely are they to strengthen?\n\nSouthwestern Atlantic:\n\nAn area of showers and thunderstorms located several hundred miles east of the Bahamas is associated with a surface trough of low pressure interacting with an upper-level trough. Environmental conditions are marginally conducive for some gradual development of this system during the next few days while it moves westward or west-northwestward. The system is forecast to approach the coast of the southeastern United States by the latter part of this week.\n\nSouthwestern Gulf of Mexico:\n\nAnother broad area of low pressure is forecast to develop over the southwestern Gulf of Mexico this weekend. Environmental conditions are expected to be conducive for gradual development of this system through early next week while it moves slowly west-northwestward or northwestward.\n\nWho is likely to be impacted?\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One is expected to produce rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South Texas, with maximum totals of 15 inches possible. This rainfall will likely produce considerable flash and urban flooding along with new and renewed river flooding. Mudslides are also possible in areas of higher terrain across northeast Mexico.\n\nTropical storm conditions are expected within the warning area Wednesday. A couple of tornadoes are possible Wednesday into the evening across parts of Deep South Texas and Southeast Texas. Swells generated by the disturbance will affect the coast of Texas and northeastern Mexico through early Thursday.\n\nForecasters urge all residents to continue monitoring the tropics and to always be prepared. That advice is particularly important for what is expected to be a very active hurricane season.\n\nThe Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 through Nov. 30.\n\nWhen is the peak of hurricane season?\n\nThe peak of the season is Sept. 10, with the most activity happening between mid-August and mid-October, according to the Hurricane Center.\n\nNational Hurricane Center map: What are forecasters watching now?\n\nSystems currently being monitored by the National Hurricane Center include:\n\nInteractive map: Hurricanes, tropical storms that have passed near your city\n\nWe will continue to update our tropical weather coverage daily. {"uri": "2024-06-394623975", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "11:30:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T11:30:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T11:30:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://eu.gainesville.com/story/weather/hurricanes/2024/06/19/tropical-storm-alberto-expected-mexico/74138752007/", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto expected to form today, 1st named storm of 2024 hurricane season", "body": "Forecasters say a tropical system is likely to develop in the Gulf of Mexico this week as hurricane season kicks off.\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One is expected to become the first named tropical storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season: Alberto. The storm is forecast to reach the coast of northeastern Mexico by late Wednesday or early Thursday, according to the latest advisory from the National Hurricane Center.\n\nHeavy rain from this system is already impacting parts of southern Mexico and northern portions of Central America, and portions of Texas are starting to feel it, the NHC said. The system is moving west-northwest and is expected to move further west and pick up speed Wednesday.\n\nTropical storm warnings have been issued for the Texas coast from San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande and for the northeastern coast of Mexico.\n\nForecasters predict considerable flash and urban flooding along with new and renewed river flooding, including potentially life-threatening flooding and mudslides in and near areas of higher terrain across the Mexican states of Coahuila, Nuevo Leon, and Tamaulipas. Swells generated by the disturbance will affect the coast of Louisiana and Texas as well as northeastern Mexico through early Thursday. These swells are likely to cause life threatening surf and rip current conditions.\n\nMeanwhile, forecasters still have their eyes on a low-pressure area off the east coast of Florida with a low chance of development.\n\n\"This appears to be a quick-moving and compact low-pressure area that will be moving westward into northeastern Florida or perhaps as far north as southeastern Georgia on Thursday,\" AccuWeather Senior Meteorologist Dan Pydynowski said. The storm's speed limits its development potential but it still could bring more rain, gusty winds and dangerous surf to the southeast Atlantic coast, forecasters said.\n\nSpecial note on the NHC cone: The forecast track shows the most likely path of the center of the storm. It does not illustrate the full width of the storm or its impacts, and the center of the storm is likely to travel outside the cone up to 33% of the time.\n\nForecast, impact: Potential Tropical Cyclone One expected to strengthen before landfall. See spaghetti models\n\nSpaghetti models for Potential Tropical Cyclone One\n\n\u27a4 Track Potential Tropical Cyclone One\n\nSpecial note about spaghetti models: Illustrations include an array of forecast tools and models, and not all are created equal. The hurricane center uses only the top four or five highest performing models to help make its forecasts.\n\nWhat is out there and how likely are they to strengthen?\n\nSouthwestern Atlantic:\n\nAn area of showers and thunderstorms located several hundred miles east of the Bahamas is associated with a surface trough of low pressure interacting with an upper-level trough. Environmental conditions are marginally conducive for some gradual development of this system during the next few days while it moves westward or west-northwestward. The system is forecast to approach the coast of the southeastern United States by the latter part of this week.\n\nSouthwestern Gulf of Mexico:\n\nAnother broad area of low pressure is forecast to develop over the southwestern Gulf of Mexico this weekend. Environmental conditions are expected to be conducive for gradual development of this system through early next week while it moves slowly west-northwestward or northwestward.\n\nWho is likely to be impacted?\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One is expected to produce rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South Texas, with maximum totals of 15 inches possible. This rainfall will likely produce considerable flash and urban flooding along with new and renewed river flooding. Mudslides are also possible in areas of higher terrain across northeast Mexico.\n\nTropical storm conditions are expected within the warning area Wednesday. A couple of tornadoes are possible Wednesday into the evening across parts of Deep South Texas and Southeast Texas. Swells generated by the disturbance will affect the coast of Texas and northeastern Mexico through early Thursday.\n\nForecasters urge all residents to continue monitoring the tropics and to always be prepared. That advice is particularly important for what is expected to be a very active hurricane season.\n\nThe Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 through Nov. 30.\n\nWhen is the peak of hurricane season?\n\nThe peak of the season is Sept. 10, with the most activity happening between mid-August and mid-October, according to the Hurricane Center.\n\nNational Hurricane Center map: What are forecasters watching now?\n\nSystems currently being monitored by the National Hurricane Center include:\n\nInteractive map: Hurricanes, tropical storms that have passed near your city\n\nWe will continue to update our tropical weather coverage daily. Why hasn't it yet?", "body": "A tropical rainstorm bearing down on the Gulf Coast could bring major impacts to northeast Mexico and southeast Texas.\n\nAs the tropical disturbance south of Texas in the Gulf of Mexico tracks closer, it's becoming more likely that it will become Alberto, the first named tropical storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, within the next 24 hours.\n\nTo become a tropical storm, maximum sustained winds must reach at least 39 mph. Although the disturbance has already reached the maximum sustained wind speeds necessary, there is still no evidence that a \"well-defined center of circulation has developed,\" according to the latest advisory from the National Hurricane Center.\n\nFor now, the NHC has dubbed the tropical event \"Potential Tropical Cyclone One,\" which allows the NHC to issue advisories, watches and warnings for the system that hasn't yet formed into a tropical storm but poses a threat of becoming one as it inches closer toward landfall.\n\nSee spaghetti models and track the storm NHC issues warning for South Texas as Potential Tropical Cyclone One intensifies\n\nHere's the latest data for Potential Tropical Cyclone One\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One is expected to make landfall in Mexico late Wednesday but will bring significant rainfall to Texas far earlier, hitting Texas in the coming hours. Those in South Texas and along the coast can expect to see impact as early as Tuesday evening, which will include flooding rain, coastal flooding, gusty winds and high surf and rip currents.\n\nNHC warned that the system is very large, with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 290 miles northeast of the center. Heavy rain is forecast to extend well north of the center of the storm, spreading into portions of Central Texas. {"uri": "2024-06-394636559", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "11:41:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T11:41:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T11:30:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.tcpalm.com/story/weather/hurricanes/2024/06/19/tropical-storm-alberto-expected-mexico/74138752007/", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto expected to form today, 1st named storm of 2024 hurricane season", "body": "Central Florida and parts of South Texas are expected to see rain, flash flooding, storm surges\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One is expected to become the first named tropical storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season: Alberto. The storm is forecast to reach the coast of northeastern Mexico by late Wednesday or early Thursday, according to the latest advisory from the National Hurricane Center.\n\nHeavy rain from this system is already impacting parts of southern Mexico and northern portions of Central America, and portions of Texas are starting to feel it, the NHC said. The system is moving west-northwest and is expected to move further west and pick up speed Wednesday.\n\nTropical storm warnings have been issued for the Texas coast from San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande and for the northeastern coast of Mexico.\n\nForecasters predict considerable flash and urban flooding along with new and renewed river flooding, including potentially life-threatening flooding and mudslides in and near areas of higher terrain across the Mexican states of Coahuila, Nuevo Leon, and Tamaulipas. Swells generated by the disturbance will affect the coast of Louisiana and Texas as well as northeastern Mexico through early Thursday. These swells are likely to cause life threatening surf and rip current conditions.\n\nMeanwhile, forecasters still have their eyes on a low-pressure area off the east coast of Florida with a low chance of development.\n\n\"This appears to be a quick-moving and compact low-pressure area that will be moving westward into northeastern Florida or perhaps as far north as southeastern Georgia on Thursday,\" AccuWeather Senior Meteorologist Dan Pydynowski said. The storm's speed limits its development potential but it still could bring more rain, gusty winds and dangerous surf to the southeast Atlantic coast, forecasters said.\n\nSpecial note on the NHC cone: The forecast track shows the most likely path of the center of the storm. It does not illustrate the full width of the storm or its impacts, and the center of the storm is likely to travel outside the cone up to 33% of the time.\n\nForecast, impact:Potential Tropical Cyclone One expected to strengthen before landfall. See spaghetti models\n\nSpaghetti models for Potential Tropical Cyclone One\n\n\u27a4 Track Potential Tropical Cyclone One\n\nSpecial note about spaghetti models: Illustrations include an array of forecast tools and models, and not all are created equal. The hurricane center uses only the top four or five highest performing models to help make its forecasts.\n\nWhat is out there and how likely are they to strengthen?\n\nSouthwestern Atlantic:\n\nAn area of showers and thunderstorms located several hundred miles east of the Bahamas is associated with a surface trough of low pressure interacting with an upper-level trough. Environmental conditions are marginally conducive for some gradual development of this system during the next few days while it moves westward or west-northwestward. The system is forecast to approach the coast of the southeastern United States by the latter part of this week.\n\nSouthwestern Gulf of Mexico:\n\nAnother broad area of low pressure is forecast to develop over the southwestern Gulf of Mexico this weekend. Environmental conditions are expected to be conducive for gradual development of this system through early next week while it moves slowly west-northwestward or northwestward.\n\nWho is likely to be impacted?\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One is expected to produce rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South Texas, with maximum totals of 15 inches possible. This rainfall will likely produce considerable flash and urban flooding along with new and renewed river flooding. Mudslides are also possible in areas of higher terrain across northeast Mexico.\n\nTropical storm conditions are expected within the warning area Wednesday. A couple of tornadoes are possible Wednesday into the evening across parts of Deep South Texas and Southeast Texas. Swells generated by the disturbance will affect the coast of Texas and northeastern Mexico through early Thursday.\n\nForecasters urge all residents to continue monitoring the tropics and to always be prepared. That advice is particularly important for what is expected to be a very active hurricane season.\n\nThe Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 through Nov. 30.\n\nWhen is the peak of hurricane season?\n\nThe peak of the season is Sept. 10, with the most activity happening between mid-August and mid-October, according to the Hurricane Center.\n\nNational Hurricane Center map: What are forecasters watching now?\n\nSystems currently being monitored by the National Hurricane Center include:\n\nInteractive map: Hurricanes, tropical storms that have passed near your city\n\nWe will continue to update our tropical weather coverage daily. There is a tropical disturbance in the Bay of Campeche that is likely to become a tropical depression or a tropical storm by sometime Wednesday. If the disturbance strengthens to a tropical storm, it will get the name \"Alberto\", which is the 1st named storm of the 2024 Hurricane Season.\n\nRight now the disturbance is called a Potential Tropical Cyclone. Which means it has a very good chance of becoming a tropical depression or storm soon. This also allows the National Hurricane Center to issue a forecast cone or track along with watches or warnings.\n\nThe center of the storm will track into Mexico between Tampico and Brownsville, Texas late Wednesday night into early Thursday morning.\n\nHowever, areas well away from the center of the storm will see heavy rainfall and even storm surge.\n\nHeavy rain will be the main concern with this system. Even if it never forms into tropical storm, heavy rain and possible flooding will be headed to parts of Texas and Mexico.\n\nHighest rainfall totals Wednesday into Thursday will be in South Texas and northern Mexico where 7 to 10 inches of rainfall is possible. Totals taper off farther north, but areas between San Antonio and Corpus Christi can expect between 4 to 7 inches. Along and south of I-10 will see the highest of the rainfall totals.\n\nRounds of heavy rain and high rainfall totals could cause flooding issues in those areas.\n\nEven though the center of the storm will pass well south of most of the Texas Coast, storm surge is possible for areas along the coast. Mostly between 1 to 3 feet, but areas in and around Galveston could see surge from around 2 to 4 feet.\n\nFor this reason along with the chance for gusty winds, a Tropical Storm Warning has been issued for most of the Texas coastline.\n\nWe won't see much from this storm. {"uri": "2024-06-393379662", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "11:23:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T11:23:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T11:21:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://eu.jacksonville.com/story/weather/hurricanes/2024/06/18/national-hurricane-center-spaghetti-models-radar-tropical-storm-alberto-atlantic-gulf-disturbances/74126522007/", "title": "National Hurricane Center tracking 3 systems. Gulf system could become 1st tropical storm", "body": "Forecasters say a tropical system is likely to develop in the Gulf of Mexico this week as hurricane season kicks off.\n\nThe tropics are heating up, with the National Hurricane Center keeping an eye on two disturbances in addition to Potential Tropical Cyclone One, according to the latest advisory from the National Hurricane Center.\n\nTropical storm warnings are in effect for portions of Texas ahead of Potential Tropical Cyclone One, which is expected to become a tropical storm before making landfall late Wednesday.\n\nThe large storm -- which has tropical-storm-force winds extending 290 miles northeast from the center -- could be a rainmaker, bringing 5-10 inches of rain and up to 15 inches to some locations, according to the National Hurricane Center. AccuWeather predicted some areas could see up to 30 inches.\n\nIf it does become a tropical storm, it'll become the first named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, Alberto. To become a tropical storm, maximum sustained winds must reach at least 39 mph.\n\nFuture Tropical Storm Alberto? Potential Tropical Cyclone One expected to strengthen before landfall. See spaghetti models\n\nThe National Hurricane Center also is monitoring two other systems: a disturbance east of Florida with a low chance for development and another area in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico close to where Potential Tropical Cyclone One is.\n\nSpecial note on the NHC cone: The forecast track shows the most likely path of the center of the storm. It does not illustrate the full width of the storm or its impacts, and the center of the storm is likely to travel outside the cone up to 33% of the time.\n\nForecast, impact: Potential Tropical Cyclone One expected to strengthen before landfall. See spaghetti models\n\nSpaghetti models for Potential Tropical Cyclone One\n\n\u27a4 Track Potential Tropical Cyclone One\n\nSpecial note about spaghetti models: Illustrations include an array of forecast tools and models, and not all are created equal. The hurricane center uses only the top four or five highest performing models to help make its forecasts.\n\nWhat is out there and how likely are they to strengthen?\n\nSouthwestern Atlantic: An area of cloudiness and showers located several hundred miles east of the Bahamas is associated with a surface trough and an upper-level area of low pressure.\n\nEnvironmental conditions could be conducive for some gradual development of this system during the next few days while it moves west or west-northwest. The system is forecast to approach the coast of the southeastern United States on Friday.\n\nSouthwestern Gulf of Mexico: Another broad area of low pressure is forecast to develop over the southwestern Gulf of Mexico this weekend.\n\nEnvironmental conditions are expected to be conducive for gradual development of this system early next week while it moves slowly north or northwest.\n\n\"With warm waters and low shear still present in the southern Gulf of Mexico and northwestern Caribbean next weekend, yet another opportunity for tropical development may present itself,\" said AccuWeather Senior Meteorologist Dan Pydynowski.\n\nDepending on environmental conditions, \"any moisture from this area may again funnel into the Gulf Coast for the last week of June,\" AccuWeather said.\n\nWho is likely to be impacted?\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One: This system is expected to strengthen and is likely to become a tropical storm by Wednesday before approaching the western Gulf Coast late Wednesday. Tropical storm conditions are expected within the warning area by Wednesday.\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One is expected to bring 5 to 10 inches of rain across South Texas and into northeastern Mexico, with up to 15 inches possible, NHC forecasters said. AccuWeather forecasters said up to 30 inches may be possible in some locations.\n\nThe Weather Channel meteorologist Jim Cantore warned \"double digit rainfall totals likely along the coastal counties of TX and potentially Houston.\"\n\nAtlantic: \"This appears to be a quick-moving and compact low-pressure area that will be moving westward into northeastern Florida or perhaps as far north as southeastern Georgia on Thursday,\" AccuWeather Senior Meteorologist Dan Pydynowski said.\n\nA stronger storm could bring gusty winds, especially to coastal locations. A less organized storm would bring rough surf and downpours from the northern Bahamas to the Southeast Atlantic coast, AccuWeather said.\n\nGulf of Mexico: \"Depending on the wind pattern in the atmosphere, any moisture from this area may again funnel into the Gulf Coast for the last week of June,\" according to AccuWeather. \"Given the expected rain in the coming week, the risk for localized flooding may increase.\"\n\nForecasters urge all residents to continue monitoring the tropics and to always be prepared. That advice is particularly important for what is expected to be a very active hurricane season.\n\nThe Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 through Nov. 30.\n\nWhen is the peak of hurricane season?\n\nThe peak of the season is Sept. 10, with the most activity happening between mid-August and mid-October, according to the Hurricane Center.\n\nNational Hurricane Center map: What are forecasters watching now?\n\nSystems currently being monitored by the National Hurricane Center include:\n\nInteractive map: Hurricanes, tropical storms that have passed near your city\n\nWe will continue to update our tropical weather coverage daily. It is expected to develop over the southwestern Gulf over the weekend and move slowly west-northwest or northwest.\n\nMeanwhile, forecasters are watching an area of storminess several hundred miles east of the northwestern Bahamas that could approach the southern U.S. East Coast, potentially including Florida, late this week.\n\nAs of 8 a.m. Thursday, it has a 40% chance of development over the next two days, with some slow development possible thereafter while the system moves west-northwestward. Forecasters expect the system to reach the east coast by Friday.\n\nThe system is likely to stay north of South Florida, and impact coastal areas farther up the coast.\n\n\"For the most part we really aren't expecting any significant impacts to South Florida from this system,\" a forecaster for the National Weather Service Miami said Thursday.\n\nAlberto should weaken quickly, and likely dissipate over Mexico later Thursday, the hurricane center said in its 11 a.m. update. However, it continues to bring flooding and rain to areas of Texas and Mexico.\n\n\"Alberto remains a large system and continues to produce moderate coastal flooding across portions of southern Texas, given the onshore wind flow,\" forecasters said. \"Heavy rainfall associated with Alberto will continue to impact northeastern Mexico throughout the day today, with considerable flash and urban flooding likely.\"\n\nThe National Hurricane Center has discontinued all tropical storm warnings in Mexico. It had previously issued a warning stretching from the Mexico border north along the Gulf Coast to near Houston.\n\nThe storm was causing coastal flooding near Galveston, Texas, 500 miles away from its likely landfall in Mexico. Storm surge there is expected to reach 2 to 4 feet, depending on tide. There was even some street flooding in Louisiana.\n\nA few tornadoes are also possible Thursday night in lower South Texas and southeast areas of the state, the NHC said.\n\nInland in Mexico and South Texas, rainfall could be significant and potentially dangerous, given the mountainous terrain in some of the region.\n\nRainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South Texas were possible, with maximum totals of 20 inches in areas of Mexico with higher terrain, the NHC said Wednesday night. Flash flooding and mudslides are potential hazards.\n\nThe 2024 hurricane season, which officially began June 1, is expected to be extremely active.\n\nIn its annual May outlook, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said that the 2024 hurricane season has an 85% chance of being above normal, with 17 to 25 named storms with minimum sustained winds of 39 mph, and eight to 13 hurricanes. An average year has 14 named storms and seven hurricanes.\n\nIn addition, NOAA has forecast four to seven major hurricanes for 2024, meaning those that are Category 3 or above.\n\nExperts at Colorado State University stated in their 2024 forecast that the U.S. East Coast, including Florida, had a 34% chance of a major hurricane making landfall this year. The average from 1880-2020 was 21%.\n\nForecasters say that the record-warm water temperatures that now cover much of the Atlantic Ocean will continue into peak hurricane season from August to October. That warm water fuels hurricanes. {"uri": "8186813774", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:24:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:24:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T10:24:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.sun-sentinel.com/2024/06/20/tropical-storm-alberto-forms-off-mexico-soaks-texas/", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto brings heavy rain, flooding to Texas ahead of Mexico landfall", "body": "By Bill Kearney | South Florida Sun Sentinel and Angie DiMichele | adimichele@sunsentinel.com | South Florida Sun Sentinel\n\nTropical Storm Alberto, the first named storm of the 2024 hurricane season, is expected to make landfall early Thursday south of the U.S. border with Mexico.\n\nAs of 5 a.m. Thursday, the storm was 250 miles south of Brownsville, Texas, traveling west at 13 mph, with maximum sustained winds of 50 mph.\n\nSeparate from Alberto, forecasters also are watching two other potential systems, one in the Gulf, and one east of the Bahamas. The latter could affect coastal northern Florida on Friday.\n\nOnce inland, Alberto is forecast to weaken quickly and likely dissipate over Mexico by Thursday night, the National Hurricane Center said.\n\nAlberto is a large, slow-moving tropical storm, with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 275 miles north of the center.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center has issued a tropical storm warning for the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\nThe storm had caused coastal flooding near Galveston, Texas, where storm surge was expected to reach 2 to 4 feet, depending on tide. There was even some street flooding in Louisiana.\n\nRain in Texas is expected to diminish Thursday, with an inch or less expected, the NHC said.\n\nInland in Mexico rainfall could continue to be significant and potentially dangerous, given the mountainous terrain in some of the region.\n\nRainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico are possible, with maximum totals of 20 inches in areas with higher terrain, the NHC said. Flash flooding and mudslides are potential hazards.\n\nA disturbance in the same area of the Gulf of Mexico as Alberto could become a tropical depression this weekend. As of 2 a.m. Thursday, it has a 50% chance of developing in the next seven days and a 10% chance it the next two days.\n\nMeanwhile, forecasters are watching an area of storminess several hundred miles east of the northern Bahamas that could approach northeastern Florida or southern Georgia early Friday.\n\nAs of 2 a.m. Thursday, it has a 30% chance of development over the next two days, with some slow development possible thereafter while the system moves west-northwest..\n\nThe system is likely too far north to impact South Florida.\n\nThe 2024 hurricane season, which officially began June 1, is expected to be extremely active.\n\nIn its annual May outlook, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said that the 2024 hurricane season has an 85% chance of being above normal, with 17 to 25 named storms with minimum sustained winds of 39 mph, and eight to 13 hurricanes. An average year has 14 named storms and seven hurricanes.\n\nIn addition, NOAA has forecast four to seven major hurricanes for 2024, meaning those that are Category 3 or above.\n\nExperts at Colorado State University stated in their 2024 forecast that the U.S. East Coast, including Florida, had a 34% chance of a major hurricane making landfall this year. The average from 1880-2020 was 21%.\n\nForecasters say that the record-warm water temperatures that now cover much of the Atlantic Ocean will continue into peak hurricane season from August to October. That warm water fuels hurricanes. By early June, the tropical Atlantic was already as hot as it usually is in mid-August -- peak hurricane season.\n\nHurricane season officially ends Nov. 30.", "source": {"uri": "sun-sentinel.com", {"uri": "8185071822", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "10:02:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T10:02:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T10:01:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/news/atlantic-hurricane-season-first-tropical-storm-texas-mexico-gulf-of-mexico/", "title": "Atlantic season's first tropical storm, Alberto, expected to form over Gulf Wednesday", "body": "The first tropical storm of the Atlantic season is expected to form over the Gulf of Mexico Wednesday, the National Hurricane Center said, giving the disturbance an 80% chance of getting the distinction. It would be named Alberto.\n\nForecasters said it could bring heavy rains, coastal flooding and gusty winds to the Texas and northeastern Mexico coasts through Thursday. Alberto is likely to reach the Mexican coast late Wednesday or early Thursday.\n\nA Tropical Storm Warning was issued for the Texas coast from the San Luis Pass south to the mouth of the Rio Grande and the northeastern coast of Mexico from the Rio Grande mouth to Puerto de Altamira.\n\nRainfall amounts of 5 to 10 inches are possible across northeast Mexico into southern Texas, with maximum totals of 15 inches, and they'd probably result in \"considerable flash and urban flooding along with new and renewed river flooding. Mudslides are also possible in areas of higher terrain across northeast Mexico,\" meteorologists said. A storm surge as high as four feet might hit parts of the Texas coast.\n\nThe disturbance was \"quite large\" early Wednesday, the hurricane center noted, with tropical-storm-force winds extending up to 415 miles to the north of the system's center.\n\nAs of 4 a.m. CDT, the center was some 315 miles southeast of Brownsville, Texas and moving west-northwest at 8 mph with maximum sustained winds of 40 mph.\n\nThe hurricane center upgraded what had been the season's first tropical storm watch to a tropical storm warning at 4 a.m. CT on Tuesday. Three hours later, the government of Mexico issued a tropical storm warning for the parts of the country's northeastern coast, south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Puerto de Altamira, replacing the tropical storm watch previously in effect there. The difference accounts for timing -- forecasters will generally issue a \"watch\" when tropical storm conditions are possible in the impacted area within roughly 48 hours, and a \"warning\" when the conditions become more imminent, about 36 hours out.\n\nThe Atlantic hurricane season officially began June 1 and runs through the end of November, with most storm activity typically happening during the later months of that window, between mid-August and mid-October. The terms hurricane and tropical cyclone can refer to the same kind of storm, with meteorologists using tropical cyclone as a broad classification that includes any weather phenomenon where rotating, low-level cloud systems and thunderstorms develop over tropical or subtropical waters, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.\n\nA tropical cyclone is categorized more specifically as a tropical storm once its maximum wind speeds exceed 39 mph. If it does, that will be the first named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season.\n\nHere's the forecast path for the storm:\n\nThe hurricane center will also continue to keep an eye on the Gulf for the possible development of a second system by this weekend. That would-be system has a low chance of becoming a tropical depression in the next seven days.\n\nAnd there's a third disturbance forecasters are monitoring in the southwestern Atlantic near the Bahamas. That disturbance, which also has a low chance of development, could affect the Atlantic coast of the Southeast U.S. by Friday.\n\nNone of the systems is expected to directly affect Alabama. However, the stormy weather from Potential Tropical Cyclone One is to blame for causing rip currents along Alabama's beaches as well as northwest Florida, and there will be a high rip current risk in place through Friday night.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Mobile is also warning about high surf, and a high surf advisory will also be in place through Thursday night.\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One was located about 420 miles southeast of Brownsville, Texas, as of 7 a.m. CDT Tuesday and was moving to the north at 6 mph, according to the hurricane center.\n\nThe disturbance had winds of 40 mph, which is tropical storm strength. However, it is still not organized enough to be classified as a tropical storm, according to forecasters.\n\nA tropical storm warning was in effect for the Texas coast from Port O'Connor southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande River and the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Puerto de Altamira.\n\nAccording to the hurricane center a tropical storm warning means that tropical storm conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area within 36 hours.\n\nThe disturbance is expected to be a big rainmaker above all else and could spread deadly flash flooding far from where it makes landfall.\n\nForecasts from the hurricane center show parts of Texas getting 5 to 10 inches of rain or more from the system through the end of the work week:\n\nThe rain from the tropical disturbance is expected to miss Alabama, but some scattered rain and storms will be possible over the next few days, mainly near the coast, according to the weather service in Mobile.\n\nIt's too soon to say what could evolve with the second Gulf disturbance, which could develop this weekend. The hurricane center expects it to also track slowly to the north or northwest, and the weather service said it could stay to the south of Alabama.\n\nHowever, forecasters will be keeping a close eye on it in case that changes.\n\nThe Atlantic hurricane season began June 1 and will last until Nov. 30. With winds of 50 mph and moving west at 13 mph, the storm is expected to soon make landfall, and will impact Mexico and south Texas.\n\nHeavy rain, coastal, flooding and gusty rain will continue to threaten portions of southeast Louisiana, but these indirect symptoms of Alberto should slow down by Saturday.\n\nSecond disturbance in the Gulf of Mexico\n\nNHC forecasters have been monitoring another disturbance in the Gulf since Tuesday and predict that it will form over southeastern Mexico and northern Central America Friday. The disturbance could gradually develop as it moves over the Bay of Campeche Saturday, then form into a tropical storm once it's in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico.\n\nThe system has a 20% chance of developing into a tropical storm within the next 2 days. The chance of formation within the next week is 50%, a 20% jump compared to yesterday's forecast.\n\nThere is another disturbance in the southwestern Atlantic Ocean that continues to create disorganized showers and thunderstorms. Alberto is the first named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season.\n\nThe storm is set to bring heavy rain, coastal flooding, and tropical storm force winds are likely along the Texas coast, according to the U.S. National Weather Service.\n\nA Tropical Storm Warning is in effect for the Texas coast from San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla. Tropical storm conditions are possible within the watch area by Wednesday.\n\nAlberto is forecast to bring heavy rain and coastal flooding to much of the western Gulf Coast. A Flood Watch has been issued for southeast Texas through the end of the week.\n\nThe center of the storm was expected to reach the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande by early Thursday morning.\n\nMichael Brennan, who is the director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Hurricane Center, said winds could get up to 45 mph to 50 mph before the storm makes landfall.\n\nAs much as 5 inches to 10 inches of rain was expected in some areas along the Texas coast, with even higher isolated totals possible, Brennan said.\n\nAnother area of low pressure is forecast to develop over the Bay of Campeche this weekend. Gradual development is possible early next week as it moves slowly north-northwest. This area currently has a 30% chance of development over the next seven days.\n\nSouthwestern Atlantic\n\nThe other area we are monitoring is located several hundred miles east of the Bahamas, where a trough of low pressure is producing showers and storms.\n\nConditions could become favorable for some gradual development as the area moves west-northwest through the week. The system is forecast to approach the southeastern United States by Friday.\n\nDevelopment chances are low, only 10% to 20% through the next two to seven days. {"uri": "2024-06-395748461", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:28:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:28:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T10:20:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://eu.pnj.com/story/weather/hurricanes/2024/06/20/tropical-storm-alberto-landfall-texas-mexico-impact/74153803007/", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto close to landfall. Portions of Texas under tornado warnings", "body": "All tropical storm watches and warnings have been discontinued all the U.S. Gulf Coast, and heavy rain and gusty winds are beginning to subside for South Texas.\n\nThere is a threat for tornadoes. NHC forecasters warned a tornado or two could occur this morning across parts of Deep South Texas. Several tornado warnings have been issued for parts of Texas Thursday morning, according to NWS Tornado.\n\nAcross the Coastal Bend of Texas, the National Weather Service reported a few gusts of wind above 50 mph and rainfall totals of about 2 to 7 inches.\n\n\"Between 4-8 inches of rain can fall across a widespread area from south of Houston to far northeastern Mexico from Monday to Thursday night, while rainfall totals as high as 8-12 inches can occur over South Texas and the higher elevations of northern Mexico,\" according to AccuWeather.\n\nWatches, warnings issued across Florida, Texas, Gulf Coast\n\nFor an explanation of what the watches and warnings mean, scroll to the bottom of this story.\n\nHow strong is Tropical Storm Alberto and where is it going?\n\nAt 5 a.m. EDT, the center of Tropical Storm Alberto was located 250 miles south of Brownsville, Texas, near latitude 22.3 North, longitude 97.3 West.\n\nAlberto is moving toward the west near 13 mph. This motion is expected to continue through today, and on this track, the center of Alberto should move inland over Mexico shortly, the National Hurricane Center said at 5 a.m.\n\nMaximum sustained winds are near 50 mph, with higher gusts.\n\nWeakening is anticipated after Alberto moves onshore and the storm is likely to dissipate over Mexico later Thursday or Thursday night.\n\nTropical-storm-force winds extend outward up to 275 miles from the center.\n\nSpaghetti models for Tropical Storm Alberto\n\nSpecial note about spaghetti models: Illustrations include an array of forecast tools and models, and not all are created equal. The hurricane center uses only the top four or five highest performing models to help make its forecasts.\n\n\u27a4 Track Potential Tropical Cyclone One\n\nKey messages from the National Hurricane Center: What you need to know about Tropical Storm Alberto\n\nCurrent forecast: Where is Tropical Storm Alberto going and how strong is it?\n\nWhat impact could Tropical Storm Alberto have and what areas could be affected?\n\nInteractive map: What tropical storms, hurricanes have impacted your area in the past?\n\nWhat do tropical storm watches, warnings from NHC mean?\n\nWhat is storm surge? Gulf system could become 1st tropical storm", "body": "The tropics are heating up, with the National Hurricane Center keeping an eye on two disturbances in addition to Potential Tropical Cyclone One, according to the latest advisory from the National Hurricane Center.\n\nTropical storm warnings are in effect for portions of Texas ahead of Potential Tropical Cyclone One, which is expected to become a tropical storm before making landfall late Wednesday.\n\nThe large storm -- which has tropical-storm-force winds extending 290 miles northeast from the center -- could be a rainmaker, bringing 5-10 inches of rain and up to 15 inches to some locations, according to the National Hurricane Center. AccuWeather predicted some areas could see up to 30 inches.\n\nIf it does become a tropical storm, it'll become the first named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, Alberto. To become a tropical storm, maximum sustained winds must reach at least 39 mph.\n\nFuture Tropical Storm Alberto? Potential Tropical Cyclone One expected to strengthen before landfall. See spaghetti models\n\nThe National Hurricane Center also is monitoring two other systems: a disturbance east of Florida with a low chance for development and another area in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico close to where Potential Tropical Cyclone One is.\n\nHere's the latest update from the NHC as of 2 a.m., June 18:\n\nSpecial note on the NHC cone: The forecast track shows the most likely path of the center of the storm. It does not illustrate the full width of the storm or its impacts, and the center of the storm is likely to travel outside the cone up to 33% of the time.\n\nForecast, impact: Potential Tropical Cyclone One expected to strengthen before landfall. See spaghetti models\n\n\u27a4 Track Potential Tropical Cyclone One\n\nSpecial note about spaghetti models: Illustrations include an array of forecast tools and models, and not all are created equal. The hurricane center uses only the top four or five highest performing models to help make its forecasts.\n\nSouthwestern Atlantic: An area of cloudiness and showers located several hundred miles east of the Bahamas is associated with a surface trough and an upper-level area of low pressure.\n\nEnvironmental conditions could be conducive for some gradual development of this system during the next few days while it moves west or west-northwest. The system is forecast to approach the coast of the southeastern United States on Friday.\n\nSouthwestern Gulf of Mexico: Another broad area of low pressure is forecast to develop over the southwestern Gulf of Mexico this weekend.\n\nEnvironmental conditions are expected to be conducive for gradual development of this system early next week while it moves slowly north or northwest.\n\n\"With warm waters and low shear still present in the southern Gulf of Mexico and northwestern Caribbean next weekend, yet another opportunity for tropical development may present itself,\" said AccuWeather Senior Meteorologist Dan Pydynowski.\n\nDepending on environmental conditions, \"any moisture from this area may again funnel into the Gulf Coast for the last week of June,\" AccuWeather said.\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One: This system is expected to strengthen and is likely to become a tropical storm by Wednesday before approaching the western Gulf Coast late Wednesday. Tropical storm conditions are expected within the warning area by Wednesday.\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One is expected to bring 5 to 10 inches of rain across South Texas and into northeastern Mexico, with up to 15 inches possible, NHC forecasters said. AccuWeather forecasters said up to 30 inches may be possible in some locations.\n\nThe Weather Channel meteorologist Jim Cantore warned \"double digit rainfall totals likely along the coastal counties of TX and potentially Houston.\"\n\nAtlantic: \"This appears to be a quick-moving and compact low-pressure area that will be moving westward into northeastern Florida or perhaps as far north as southeastern Georgia on Thursday,\" AccuWeather Senior Meteorologist Dan Pydynowski said.\n\nA stronger storm could bring gusty winds, especially to coastal locations. A less organized storm would bring rough surf and downpours from the northern Bahamas to the Southeast Atlantic coast, AccuWeather said.\n\nGulf of Mexico: \"Depending on the wind pattern in the atmosphere, any moisture from this area may again funnel into the Gulf Coast for the last week of June,\" according to AccuWeather. \"Given the expected rain in the coming week, the risk for localized flooding may increase.\"\n\nForecasters urge all residents to continue monitoring the tropics and to always be prepared. That advice is particularly important for what is expected to be a very active hurricane season.\n\nThe Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 through Nov. 30.\n\nThe peak of the season is Sept. 10, with the most activity happening between mid-August and mid-October, according to the Hurricane Center.\n\nSystems currently being monitored by the National Hurricane Center include:\n\nWe will continue to update our tropical weather coverage daily. {"uri": "8186721986", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "09:29:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T09:29:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T09:28:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.newstribune.com/news/2024/jun/20/tropical-storm-alberto-forms-becomes-first-named/", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto forms, becomes first named storm of hurricane season", "body": "MEXICO CITY (AP) -- Tropical Storm Alberto formed Wednesday in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, the first named storm of what is forecast to be a busy hurricane season.\n\nAlberto, which is bringing strong winds, heavy rainfall and some flooding along the coasts of Texas and Mexico, is expected to make landfall today in northern Mexico.\n\n\"The heavy rainfall and the water, as usual, is the biggest story in tropical storms,\" said Michael Brennan, director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said early Wednesday afternoon that Alberto was located about 180 miles east of Tampico, Mexico, and about 295 miles south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas, with maximum sustained winds of 40 mph.\n\nThe center of the storm was expected to reach the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande by early Thursday morning.\n\nBrennan said that winds could get up to 45-50 mph before the storm makes landfall.\n\nAs much as 5-10 inches of rain was expected in some areas along the Texas coast, with even higher isolated totals possible, Brennan said. He said some higher locations in Mexico could see as much as 20 inches of rain, which could result in mudslides and flash flooding, especially in the states of Tamaulipas, Coahuila and Nuevo Leon.\n\nTamaulipas Gov. Am\u00e9rico Villarreal said Wednesday on X, formerly Twitter, that schools across the state will remain closed from Wednesday through Friday.\n\nThe storm was moving west at 9 mph. Tropical storm warnings were in effect from the Texas coast at San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande and from the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\n\"Rapid weakening is expected once the center moves inland, and Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico\"today, the center said.\n\nThe U.S. National Weather Service said the main hazard for southern coastal Texas is flooding from excess rain. On Wednesday, the NWS said, there is \"a high probability\" of flash flooding in southern coastal Texas. Tornadoes or waterspouts are possible.\n\nNOAA predicts the hurricane season that began June 1 and runs through Nov. 30 is likely to be well above average, with between 17 and 25 named storms. The forecast calls for as many as 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes.\n\nAn average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.\n\nBrennan said the first named system in the Atlantic on average comes on June 20, so Alberto is \"about right on schedule.\"\n\nIn the Village of Surfside Beach, located on a barrier island on the Texas coast about 65 miles south of Houston, Mayor Gregg Bisso said Wednesday that rains had already left about 2 feet of water on streets on the west end of the island, making them impassable.\n\n\"We're on a barrier island and there's no place for the rain to go, plus the extremely high tides, everything is just hanging right there and it's flooding all the streets,\" Bisso said, adding that double red flags have been placed on the beach to warn people that no one should be in the water because of the extreme rip tides.\n\n\"Those conditions were extremely bad out there yesterday, and today,\" he said.\n\nAll of the homes on the island are elevated anywhere from 10-14 feet above the ground, so they don't expect homes to flood and evacuations were not ordered.\n\n\"We're just waiting for the rains to stop and the tide to go down,\" he said.\n\nBrennan said there will be dangerous rip currents from the storm and drivers should watch out for road closures and turn around if they see water covering roadways.\n\nA no-name storm earlier in June dumped more than 20 inches of rain on parts of South Florida, stranding numerous motorists on flooded streets and pushing water into some homes in low-lying areas.\n\n\"People underestimate the power of water and they sometimes don't always take rainfall and the threats that come with it seriously, especially if you are driving in an area and you see water covering the road, you don't want to drive into it,\" Brennan said. \"You don't know how deep the water is. The road may be washed out. it doesn't take but just a few inches of water that are moving to move your car.\"\n\nRoy Quiroz and his wife, Minda, cross a flooded section of The Strand near Kempner Street as rain falls Wednesday, June 19, 2024, in Galveston, Texas.
