{"uri": "8185599339", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:53:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:53:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:50:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/science-environment/2988444-tropical-storm-alberto-kicks-off-busy-hurricane-season", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto Kicks Off Busy Hurricane Season | Science-Environment", "body": "Tropical Storm Alberto developed in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, becoming the first named storm of a predicted intense hurricane season. Positioned east of Tampico, Mexico, Alberto generated winds of 40 mph, moving westward. The storm is expected to produce significant rainfall and potential flooding in South Texas and northeast Mexico.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto emerged on Wednesday in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, marking the first named storm of an anticipated active hurricane season.\n\nLocated 185 miles east of Tampico, Mexico, and 295 miles south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas, Alberto carried sustained winds at 40 mph, as noted by the National Hurricane Center in Miami. A tropical storm's winds range from 39 to 73 mph, while stronger winds classify the system as a hurricane.\n\nThe storm progressed westward at 9 mph, triggering tropical storm warnings from the Texas coast at San Luis Pass to the Rio Grande's mouth, continuing to Mexico's northeastern coast. Forecasters predicted slight strengthening before Alberto's center reaches land on Thursday, expecting rapid weakening and dissipation over Mexico.\n\nForecasters warned of 5 to 10 inches of rain across northeast Mexico and South Texas, with maximums of 20 inches in high-terrain areas of Coahuila, Nuevo Leon, and Tamaulipas. Flash flooding and possible mudslides are significant concerns. The US National Weather Service highlighted flooding risks in southern coastal Texas, predicting over eight inches of rain by Saturday, along with potential tornadoes and waterspouts.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration anticipates an above-average hurricane season, projecting 17 to 25 named storms, 13 hurricanes, and up to four major hurricanes.\n\n(This story has not been {"uri": "8186005329", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "22:07:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T22:07:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T22:06:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.americanpress.com/2024/06/19/update-sw-la-expected-to-feel-some-indirect-impacts-from-tropical-storm-alberto/", "title": "UPDATE: SW La. expected to feel some 'indirect impacts' from Tropical Storm Alberto - American Press", "body": "Coastal flooding will occur as the large wind field and fetch will help pile water along the coast through Thursday. (National Weather Service Lake Charles)\n\nTropical Storm Alberto formed on Wednesday in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, the first named storm of the hurricane season.\n\nAlberto, which is bringing strong winds, heavy rainfall and some flooding along the coasts of Texas and Mexico, is expected to make landfall in northern Mexico Thursday.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said Wednesday afternoon that Alberto was located about 170 miles east of Tampico, Mexico, and about 305 miles south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas, with maximum sustained winds of 40 mph. The storm is moving west-southwest at 9 miles per hour.\n\nJoe Rua, a meteorolgist with the National Weather Service's Lake Charles office, said Southwest Louisiana will see some indirect impacts, mainly coastal flood issues and hazardous seas.\n\n\"The large wind field and fetch of easterly winds will continue to pile water up along the coast, with the most significant coastal flooding along the southeast Texas and Southwest Louisiana coast that will likely extend up into the north end of Sabine and Calcasieu Lakes,\" Rua said. \"The coastal flood hazards will extend through 1 p.m. Thursday.\"\n\nHe said hazardous seas will continue into Thursday for all the coastal waters with seas from 5 to 13 feet.\n\nRua said there is the potential for another broad low to form in the southwest Gulf of Mexico over the weekend that has a 30 percent chance of Tropical Cyclone formation through the next 7 days.\n\n\"However, at this time no impacts are expected from this system as a strong area of high pressure is forecast to build across the northern Gulf Coast,\" he said.\n\nMichael Brennan, director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Hurricane Center, said the center of Alberto was expected to reach the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande by early Thursday.\n\nBrennan said that winds could get up to 45 mph to 50 mph before the storm makes landfall.\n\nAs much as 5 inches to 10 inches of rain was expected in some areas along the Texas coast, with even higher isolated totals possible, Brennan said. He said some higher locations in Mexico could see as much as 20 inches of rain, which could result in mudslides and flash flooding, especially in the states of Tamaulipas, Coahuila and Nuevo Leon.\n\nTropical storm warnings were in effect from the Texas coast at San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande and from the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\n\"Rapid weakening is expected once the center moves inland, and Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico\" Thursday, the center said.\n\nNOAA predicts the hurricane season that began June 1 and runs through Nov. 30 is likely to be well above average, with between 17 and 25 named storms. {"uri": "2024-06-393489117", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "12:58:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T12:58:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T12:21:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.aol.com/first-tropical-storm-warning-hurricane-122105246.html", "title": "First tropical storm warning of hurricane season issued along coastal Texas", "body": "First tropical storm warning of hurricane season issued along coastal Texas\n\nEmily Mae Czachor\n\nJune 18, 2024 at 2:21 PM\n\nThe first tropical storm warning of this year's hurricane season was issued early Tuesday, as coastal communities in southern Texas prepare for an oncoming bout of heavy rain and possible flooding. The storm was developing over the southern Gulf of Mexico and expected to reach land as a potential tropical cyclone, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nIf the storm becomes strong enough it will become the first named storm of the season: Tropical Storm Alberto.\n\nThe tropical storm warning covers coastal Texas areas from Port O'Connor to the mouth of the Rio Grande and extends downward along the Gulf Coast of Mexico. Rainfall linked to the potential tropical cyclone was expected to affect large parts of Central America, too.\n\nAlthough a map released by the National Hurricane Center showed the storm system striking coastal areas just after midnight on Thursday, meteorologists noted that the impacts would likely be felt on land sooner than that. The latest forecasts indicated that the system would likely increase in strength over the next 36 hours before becoming a tropical storm.\n\n\"The disturbance is very large with rainfall, coastal flooding, and wind impacts likely to occur far from the center along the coasts of Texas and northeastern Mexico,\" the hurricane center said in a Tuesday advisory.\n\nIn Texas, the hurricane center said moderate coastal flooding could begin along the coast as soon as Tuesday morning and continue through the middle of the week. The situation was forecast to worsen on Wednesday for people in the tropical storm warning area.\n\nThe annual Atlantic Hurricane Season officially began on June 1 and will run through the end of November, with most storm activity typically happening during the later months of that window, between mid-August and mid-October.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center upgraded what had been the current season's first tropical storm watch to a tropical storm warning at 4 a.m. CT on Tuesday. The difference accounts for timing -- forecasters will generally issue a \"watch\" when tropical storm conditions are possible in the impacted area within roughly 36 hours, and a \"warning\" when the conditions become more imminent, about 24 hours out.\n\nPete and Chasten Buttigieg on fatherhood\n\nNew Jersey diner owner, who is blind, dishes out friendship and inspiration\n\nMom creates camp for {"uri": "2024-06-395139473", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "20:31:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T20:31:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T11:23:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.fox61.com/article/news/nation-world/tropical-storm-alberto-forms-1st-named-storm-of-the-hurricane-season/507-f2940217-358c-4e70-8e32-ff5ca003cc35", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto forms in southwest Gulf, 1st named storm of the hurricane season", "body": "MIAMI -- Tropical Storm Alberto formed on Wednesday in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, the first named storm of what is forecast to be a busy hurricane season.\n\nAlberto, which is bringing strong winds, heavy rainfall and some flooding along the coasts of Texas and Mexico, is expected to make landfall in northern Mexico on Thursday.\n\n\"The heavy rainfall and the water, as usual, is the biggest story in tropical storms,\" said Michael Brennan, director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Hurricane Center.\n\nAlberto was located 185 miles (about 300 kilometers) east of Tampico, Mexico and 295 miles (about 480 kilometers) south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas. It had top sustained winds of 40 mph (65 kph), according to the National Hurricane Center in Miami. A tropical storm is defined by sustained winds of between 39 and 73 mph (62 and 117 kph), and above that the system becomes a hurricane.\n\nBrennan said that winds could get up to 45 mph (72 kph) to 50 mph (80 kph) before the storm makes landfall.\n\nAs much as 5 inches (13 centimeters) to 10 inches (25 centimeters) of rain was expected in some areas along the Texas coast, with even higher isolated totals possible, Brennan said. He said some higher locations in Mexico could see as much as 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain, which could result in mudslides and flash flooding, especially in the states of Tamaulipas, Coahuila and Nuevo Leon.\n\nAt the Hotel Miramar Inn in Tampico, Mexico, near where Alberto was expected to come ashore, front desk attendant Diana Flores said the wind was gusty, but still not strong, and the rain hadn't started yet. \"There are people in the restaurant and on the beach,\" Flores said early Wednesday.\n\nOuter bands of rain lashed parts of Tamaulipas state in the northeast corner of Mexico overnight.\n\nThe storm was moving west at 9 mph (15 kph). Tropical storm warnings were in effect from the Texas coast at San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande and from the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\n\"Rapid weakening is expected once the center moves inland, and Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico\" on Thursday, the center said.\n\nThe U.S. National Weather Service said the main hazard for southern coastal Texas is flooding from excess rain. On Wednesday, the NWS said, there is \"a high probability\" of flash flooding in southern coastal Texas. Tornadoes or waterspouts are possible.\n\nNOAA predicts the hurricane season that began June 1 and runs through Nov. 30 is likely to be well above average, with between 17 and 25 named storms. The forecast calls for as many as 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes.\n\nAn average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.\n\nBrennan said that the first named system in the Atlantic on average comes on June 20, so Alberto is \"about right on schedule.\"\n\nA no-name storm earlier in June dumped more than 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain on parts of South Florida, stranding numerous motorists on flooded streets and pushing water into some homes in low-lying areas.\n\nBrennan said there will be dangerous rip currents from the storm and drivers should watch out for road closures and turn around if they see water covering roadways.\n\n\"People underestimate the power of water and they sometimes don't always take rainfall and the threats that come with it seriously, especially if you are driving in an area and you see water covering the road, you don't want to drive into it,\" Brennan said. \"You don't know how deep the water is. The road may be washed out. it doesn't take but just a few inches of water that are moving to move your car.\"", "source": {"uri": "fox61.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "fox61.com"}, "authors": {"uri": "2024-06-395905636", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "12:37:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T12:37:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T12:30:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/weather/2024/06/20/tropical-storm-alberto-updates-landfall-texas/74154016007/", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto makes landfall in Mexico; danger looms for Texas", "body": "Texas is bracing for wind, rain and floods as Tropical Storm Alberto, the first named storm of the 2024 season, approaches.\n\nMillions of people along the southern coast of Texas were under severe weather advisories as officials warned of high storm surge, torrential rain and possible tornadoes as Tropical Storm Alberto barreled over northern Mexico.\n\nThe first named storm in the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season made landfall over northern Mexico, near the U.S. border, sometime shortly after 4 a.m., according to the National Hurricane Center. Along with sustained winds near 45 mph, the storm is forecast to dump up to 20 inches across parts of northeast Mexico with nearly a foot of rain expected throughout southern Texas.\n\nSuch high rainfall totals will likely produce \"considerable flash flooding and urban flooding\" as well as possible mudslides across northern Mexico, the NHC said.\n\nAfter making landfall, Alberto is expected to diminish in strength, though it could still produce life-threatening weather conditions.\n\nAlberto began drenching southern Texas on Wednesday, triggering widespread coastal flooding that left Surfside Beach, a city along the Texas Gulf Coast south of Houston, under several feet of water. The storm also lashed Mexico with heavy rain, and caused the deaths of at least three minors, Nuevo Leon state Governor Samuel Garcia told local media without providing details.\n\nAcross southern Texas, the combination of storm surge and high tide is raising alarms on Thursday as floodwaters could reach up to 4 feet along the coast. The deepest waters will breach the shore along the Texas coast just to the north of Mexico, where the surge will be accompanied by large and dangerous waves, according to NHC.\n\nLife-threatening surf and rip current conditions are among the central threats for the Gulf Coast of Texas through Friday. In deep South Texas, multiple counties were under a tornado watch as forecasters warned that a possible tornado or two could spin up through the morning.\n\nFlood advisories were also active. Multiple south-central counties received 1 and 3 inches of rain by 2 a.m. Thursday, the weather service office in Corpus Christy said, adding: \"Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.\"\n\nGov. Greg Abbott issued a disaster declaration for 51 counties and activated three platoons of the Texas National Guard, including more than 40 personnel, 20 vehicles and Chinook helicopters.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto is kicking off what experts have said will be a busy storm season. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Director Rick Spinrad said last month that the Atlantic hurricane season is shaping up to be \"extraordinary,\" with an \"85% chance for an {"uri": "8185603638", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:54:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:54:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:53:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://nypost.com/2024/06/19/us-news/tropical-storm-alberto-forms-in-gulf-of-mexico-as-texas-braces-for-flooding/", "title": "Tropical storm Alberto, first named forms in Gulf of Mexico in first...", "body": "Tropical Storm Alberto has formed in the Gulf of Mexico, marking the first named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season.\n\nThe storm is bringing heavy rain and coastal flooding to much of the Texas Gulf Coast, even though the center of the storm likely won't make landfall in the U.S.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto formed Wednesday morning, just one day before the average date of the first named storm of hurricane season in the Atlantic.\n\nHere's everything you need to know about Tropical Storm Alberto.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto is located in the western Gulf of Mexico about 295 miles south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center (NHC) said Tropical Storm Alberto is moving to the west at 9 mph, and that motion is expected to continue through Thursday. On that track, the NHC expects Tropical Storm Alberto to reach the northeastern coast of Mexico early Thursday morning.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto has maximum sustained winds of 40 mph, and some slight strengthening is expected Wednesday or Wednesday night before the storm makes landfall.\n\nOnce it does, rapid weakening is expected, and Alberto will likely dissipate over Mexico on Thursday or Thursday night.\n\nA Tropical Storm Warning has been issued for the Texas coast from Port O'Connor to the mouth of the Rio Grande. A Tropical Storm Warning has also been issued for parts of Mexico's coast from the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\nFlood alerts have been issued along the Gulf Coast from the U.S.-Mexico border to the Mississippi-Alabama border due to the threat of heavy rain as well as the combination of storm surge and high tide.\n\nThe Flood Watches extend the length of the Texas coastline from Brownsville through Corpus Christi and into the Galveston area.\n\nInland communities will be impacted as well, and the Flood Watches extend into Laredo and Zapata.\n\nCoastal flood alerts have also been issued and extend from the U.S.-Mexico border to the Mississippi-Alabama border.\n\nCoastal Flood Warnings are in effect from Port Mansfield to Port Lavaca, Galveston and Sabine Pass in Texas.\n\nCoastal Flood Advisories extend farther east and include communities along the Louisiana coast, as well as Gulfport and Biloxi in Mississippi.\n\nThe NHC says that the combination of storm surge and high tide will cause areas of the coastline that normally remain dry to be flooded by rising water moving inland from the shoreline.\n\nThe map below shows the height water could reach if the peak storm surge occurs at the time of high tide:\n\nTropical Storm Alberto is expected to dump a lot of rain across portions of Texas and northern Mexico.\n\nThe NHC said rainfall totals of 5-10 If the system does become a tropical storm, it'll be named Alberto.\n\nHeavy, potentially flooding rain is expected across the western Gulf Coast, the National Hurricane Center said Monday, with as much as 15 inches possible. The heavy rainfall and flash flooding threat is predicted to intensify into Tuesday morning, according to National Hurricane Center Director Michael Brennan.\n\nA tropical storm watch has been issued for the Texas coast from Port O'Connor southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande. The watch means tropical storm conditions are possible within the area, generally within 48 hours.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center warned the system is very large: with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 290 miles to the northeast of the center.\n\nAccuWeather is predicting over half a foot of rain across parts of the Texas and Louisiana coasts, with up to 30 inches possible in the hardest-hit areas.\n\n\"Very warm waters in this area of the Gulf, as well as low wind shear will make this a conducive environment for the tropical rainstorm to strengthen,\" said AccuWeather Senior Meteorologist Dan Pydynowski.\n\nFirst alert of 2024 hurricane season: Tropical storm watch on Texas coast\n\nThis forecast track shows the most likely path of the center of the storm. It has an 80 percent chance of becoming a tropical storm over the next two days. If the system becomes a tropical storm it will be named Alberto.\n\nMeteorologists are also tracking two other disturbances.\n\nAn area of showers several hundred miles east of the Bahamas could gradually develop over the next few days as it moves westward.\n\nThe system is forecast to approach the coast of the southeastern United States on Friday. {"uri": "2024-06-395932528", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "12:58:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T12:58:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T12:30:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.aol.com/tropical-storm-alberto-makes-landfall-123033524.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto makes landfall in Mexico; danger looms for Texas", "body": "Tropical Storm Alberto makes landfall in Mexico; danger looms for Texas\n\nChristopher Cann, USA TODAY\n\nJune 20, 2024 at 2:30 PM\n\nMillions of people along the southern coast of Texas were under severe weather advisories as officials warned of high storm surge, torrential rain and possible tornadoes as Tropical Storm Alberto barreled over northern Mexico.\n\nThe first named storm in the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season made landfall in Mexico, near the U.S. border, sometime between 4 a.m. and 7 a.m. local time, according to the National Hurricane Center. Along with sustained winds near 45 mph, the storm is forecast to dump up to 20 inches across parts of northeast Mexico with nearly a foot of rain expected throughout southern Texas.\n\nSuch high rainfall totals will likely produce \"considerable flash flooding and urban flooding\" as well as possible mudslides across northern Mexico, the NHC said.\n\nAfter making landfall, Alberto is expected to diminish in strength, though it could still produce life-threatening weather conditions.\n\nAlberto began drenching southern Texas on Wednesday, triggering widespread coastal flooding that left Surfside Beach, a city along the Texas Gulf Coast south of Houston, under several feet of water. The storm also lashed Mexico with heavy rain, and caused the deaths of at least three minors, Nuevo Leon state Governor Samuel Garcia told local media without providing details.\n\nAcross southern Texas, the combination of storm surge and high tide is raising alarms on Thursday as floodwaters could reach up to 4 feet along the coast. The deepest waters will breach the shore along the Texas coast just to the north of Mexico, where the surge will be accompanied by large and dangerous waves, according to NHC.\n\nLife-threatening surf and rip current conditions are among the central threats for the Gulf Coast of Texas through Friday. In deep South Texas, multiple counties were under a tornado watch as forecasters warned that a possible tornado or two could spin up through the morning.\n\nFlood advisories were also active. Multiple south-central counties received 1 and 3 inches of rain by 2 a.m. Thursday, the weather service office in Corpus Christy said, adding: \"Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.\"\n\nGov. Greg Abbott issued a disaster declaration for 51 counties and activated three platoons of the Texas National Guard, including more than 40 personnel, 20 vehicles and Chinook helicopters.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto is kicking off what experts have said will be a busy storm season. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Director Rick Spinrad said last month that the Atlantic hurricane season is shaping up to be \"extraordinary,\" with an \"85% chance for an above-average year.\"\n\nTropical Storm Alberto tracker\n\nContributing: Reuters; Doyle Rice, John Bacon, Kirsten Crow, USA TODAY\n\nThis article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Tropical Storm {"uri": "8186850367", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:47:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:47:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T10:47:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://english.elpais.com/climate/2024-06-20/mexico-bracing-for-alberto-after-tropical-storm-floods-southern-texas.html", "title": "Mexico bracing for 'Alberto' after tropical storm floods southern Texas", "body": "Tropical Storm Alberto formed Wednesday in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, the first named storm of what is forecast to be a busy hurricane season. Authorities in Mexico reported three deaths from its rains.\n\nAlberto, which is bringing strong winds, heavy rainfall and some flooding along the coasts of Texas and Mexico, is expected to make landfall in northern Mexico early Thursday.\n\n\"The heavy rainfall and the water, as usual, is the biggest story in tropical storms,\" said Michael Brennan, director of the U. S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)'s National Hurricane Center.\n\nCivil protection authorities in the northern state of Nuevo Le\u00f3n said one man died in the La Silla river in the city of Monterrey, the state capital. They also said that two minors died from electric shocks in the municipality of Allende. Local media reported that the minors were riding a bicycle in the rain.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said late Wednesday that Alberto was located about 135 miles (220 kilometers) east of Tampico, Mexico, and about 320 miles (510 kilometers) south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas, with maximum sustained winds of 50 mph (85 kph). The storm was moving west at nine miles per hour.\n\nThe center of the storm was expected to reach the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande by Thursday morning.\n\nAs much as 5 inches (13 centimeters) to 10 inches (25 centimeters) of rain was expected in some areas along the Texas coast, with even higher isolated totals possible, Brennan said. He said some higher locations in Mexico could see as much as 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain, which could result in mudslides and flash flooding, especially in the states of Tamaulipas, Coahuila and Nuevo Le\u00f3n.\n\nMany residents were excited about the prospect of heavy showers, as Tamaulipas and most of Mexico has been dealing with extreme droughts.\n\n\"We have been needing this water that we're now getting, thank God. Let's hope that we only get water,\" said Blanca Coronel Moral, a resident of Tampico. \"Our lagoon, which gives us drinking water, is completely dry.\"\n\nTropical storm warnings were in effect from the Texas coast at San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande and from the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla. Extensive coastal flooding has been reported at beaches and coastlines in southern Texas.\n\n\"Rapid weakening is expected once the center moves inland, and Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico\" on Thursday, the center said.\n\nThe U.S. National Weather Service said the main hazard for southern coastal Texas is flooding from excess rain. On Wednesday, the NWS said, there is \"a high probability\" of flash flooding in southern coastal Texas. Tornadoes or waterspouts are possible.\n\nAreas along the Texas coast were seeing some road flooding and dangerous rip currents Wednesday. \"We've seen a few brief spin-ups and some waterspouts out there,\" said Tyler Castillo, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service office in Corpus Christi.\n\nTim Cady, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Houston, said they'll be keeping an eye on coastal flooding as high tide approaches Thursday morning.\n\n\"When we have these strong onshore winds combined with the high tide, that can result in coastal inundation, particularly in our lower-lying coastal areas,\" Cady said.\n\nNOAA predicts the hurricane season that began June 1 and runs through November 30 is likely to be well above average, with between 17 and 25 named storms. {"uri": "8186308069", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "04:23:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T04:23:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T04:22:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://dothaneagle.com/ap/international/alberto-the-first-named-tropical-storm-of-the-season-dumps-rain-on-mexico-and-texas/article_c43dbca9-8bd7-59c8-a371-29f5eab2559f.html", "title": "Alberto, the first named tropical storm of the season, dumps rain on Mexico and Texas", "body": "The storm surge from Tropical Storm Alberto, floods the streets in Surfside Beach, Texas, Wednesday, June 19, 2024.\n\nBy ALFREDO PE\u00d1A and MARIANA MART\u00cdNEZ BARBA - Associated Press\n\nTAMPICO, Mexico (AP) -- Tropical Storm Alberto formed on Wednesday in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, the first named storm of what is forecast to be a busy hurricane season.\n\nAlberto, which is bringing strong winds, heavy rainfall and some flooding along the coasts of Texas and Mexico, is expected to make landfall in northern Mexico early Thursday.\n\n\"The heavy rainfall and the water, as usual, is the biggest story in tropical storms,\" said Michael Brennan, director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said late Wednesday that Alberto was located about 135 miles (220 kilometers) east of Tampico, Mexico, and about 320 miles (510 kilometers) south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas, with maximum sustained winds of 50 mph (85 kph). The storm was moving west at 9 miles per hour.\n\nThe center of the storm was expected to reach the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande by Thursday morning.\n\nAs much as 5 inches (13 centimeters) to 10 inches (25 centimeters) of rain was expected in some areas along the Texas coast, with even higher isolated totals possible, Brennan said. He said some higher locations in Mexico could see as much as 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain, which could result in mudslides and flash flooding, especially in the states of Tamaulipas, Coahuila and Nuevo Leon.\n\nThe municipal government of Tampico, a port city in Tamaulipas state, announced Wednesday afternoon that authorities had activated a command center in coordination with the water, electricity and oil companies.\n\nMany residents were excited about the prospect of heavy showers, as Tamaulipas and most of Mexico has been dealing with extreme droughts.\n\n\"We have been needing this water that we're now getting, thank God. Let's hope that we only get water,\" said Blanca Coronel Moral, a resident of Tampico. \"Our lagoon, which gives us drinking water, is completely dry.\"\n\nTamaulipas Gov. Am\u00e9rico Villarreal said Wednesday on X that schools across the state will remain closed between Wednesday and Friday.\n\nThe coordinator of civil protection in Tamaulipas, Luis Gerardo Gonzalez, said they have 333 shelters distributed throughout the state at each municipality. \"As the storm moves, we will be opening up more shelters.\"\n\nAuthorities urged residents to be aware of the alerts the state and municipal civil protections are sharing. They anticipate the storm arriving overnight with communities closest to the coast most affected.\n\nTropical storm warnings were in effect from the Texas coast at San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande and from the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\n\"Rapid weakening is expected once the center moves inland, and Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico\" on Thursday, the center said.\n\nThe U.S. National Weather Service said the main hazard for southern coastal Texas is flooding from excess rain. On Wednesday, the NWS said, there is \"a high probability\" of flash flooding in southern coastal Texas. Tornadoes or waterspouts are possible.\n\nNOAA predicts the hurricane season that began June 1 and runs through Nov. 30 is likely to be well above average, with between 17 and 25 named storms. The forecast calls for as many as 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes.\n\nAn average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.\n\nBrennan said there will be dangerous rip currents from the storm and drivers should watch out for road closures and turn around if they see water covering roadways.\n\nAreas along the Texas coast were seeing some road flooding and dangerous rip currents Wednesday, and waterspouts have been spotted offshore. \"We've seen a few brief spin-ups and some waterspouts out there,\" said Tyler Castillo, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service office in Corpus Christi.\n\nTim Cady, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Houston, said they'll be keeping an eye on coastal flooding as high tide approaches Thursday morning.\n\n\"When we have these strong onshore winds combined with the high tide, that can result in coastal inundation, particularly in our lower-lying coastal areas,\" Cady said.\n\nA no-name storm earlier in June dumped more than 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain on parts of South Florida, stranding numerous motorists on flooded streets and pushing water into some homes in low-lying areas.\n\n\"People underestimate the power of water and they sometimes don't always take rainfall and the threats that come with it seriously, especially if you are driving in an area and you see water covering the road, you don't want to drive into it,\" Brennan said.\n\n___ AP journalists Jamie Stengle in Dallas and Julie Walker in New York contributed to this report.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement (WFLA) -- A disturbance near the western Gulf of Mexico coast is forecast to become the first tropical storm, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe NHC said the \"very large\" system will bring rain, coastal flooding and wind impacts along the coasts of Texas and northeastern Mexico.\n\nWeather officials said tropical storm conditions are expected to begin Wednesday over portions of the Texas coast south of Port O'Connor, where a tropical storm warning is in effect.\n\nThe system's winds remain near 40 mph, with higher gusts. It has an 80% chance of becoming a tropical storm over the next two days. If the system becomes a tropical storm, it will be named Alberto.\n\nMeteorologists are also tracking two other disturbances.\n\nAn area of showers several hundred miles east of the Bahamas could gradually develop over the next few days as it moves westward.\n\nThe system is forecast to approach the coast of the southeastern United States on Friday. It has a 20% chance of developing over the next seven days.\n\nThe NHC is also tracking another disturbance in the Gulf of Mexico. {"uri": "2024-06-393791977", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "17:37:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T17:37:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T17:28:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://eu.pnj.com/story/weather/hurricanes/2024/06/18/tropical-storm-alberto-noaa-winds-circulation-determine-storm-designation/74137699007/", "title": "Winds are at 40 mph. Why isn't Potential Tropical Cyclone One Tropical Storm Alberto?", "body": "A tropical rainstorm bearing down on the Gulf Coast could bring major impacts to northeast Mexico and southeast Texas.\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One is poised to make landfall sometime late Wednesday, according to the latest advisory from the National Hurricane Center.\n\nForecasters are predicting the system will become Tropical Storm Alberto -- the first named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season -- before making landfall along the Gulf Coast.\n\n\u27a4 Track Potential Tropical Cyclone One\n\nBut there's some confusion over when a storm gets a name, especially since Potential Tropical Cyclone One already has maximum sustained winds of 40 mph.\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One: Where is it going and how strong is it?\n\nWatches, warnings issued across Florida, Texas, Gulf Coast\n\nWhy isn't Potential Tropical Storm One actually Tropical Storm Alberto?\n\nThe confusion comes from wind speed, which is generally the criteria used by NOAA to classify a developing system as a tropical storm.\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One has had sustained winds of 40 mph for the last several advisories, which is the general criteria used to classify a system as a tropical storm.\n\n\"A tropical cyclone in which the maximum sustained surface wind speed -- using the U.S., 1-minute average -- ranges from 39 mph to 73 mph,\" NOAA said on its website.\n\nBut there's another factor that comes into play: circulation.\n\nWithout a center of circulation, there isn't a tropical storm\n\nAt 11 a.m., the National Hurricane Center said the \"disturbance's overall envelope is becoming slightly better defined, although there is still no evidence that a well-defined center of circulation has developed.\"\n\nWithout that well-defined center of circulation, along with sustained winds of at least 39 mph, the system remains a potential tropical storm, according to the National Weather Service Miami.\n\nAt 11 a.m. Tuesday, an Air Force Reserve reconnaissance aircraft was surveying the system's wind field to assess its structure to see if it can now be classified as a tropical storm.\n\nWhy does the Hurricane Center issue advisories if it isn't a tropical storm?\n\nAdvisories are issued for potential storms based on how close they are to land.\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One currently is expected be a tropical storm by Wednesday and to make landfall along the Gulf Coast late Wednesday.\n\nThat would give residents in the storm's path little time to react to advisories and warnings from the National Hurricane Center on the track and impact the storm could have.\n\nSo advisories are issued for potential storms to give residents adequate time to prepare before landfall, the National Weather Service Miami said.", "source": {"uri": "eu.pnj.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Pensacola News Journal"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8185788738", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "18:23:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T18:23:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T18:22:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.americanpress.com/2024/06/19/tropical-storm-alberto-forms-in-southwest-gulf-1st-named-storm-of-the-hurricane-season/", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto forms in southwest Gulf, 1st named storm of the hurricane season - American Press", "body": "Satellite indicates several clusters of deep thunderstorms rotating around a larger low pressure area over the Bay of Campeche and the western Gulf. (National Weather Service Lake Charles)\n\nTropical Storm Alberto formed on Wednesday in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, the first named storm of what is forecast to be a busy hurricane season.\n\nAlberto, which is bringing strong winds, heavy rainfall and some flooding along the coasts of Texas and Mexico, is expected to make landfall in northern Mexico on Thursday.\n\n\"The heavy rainfall and the water, as usual, is the biggest story in tropical storms,\" said Michael Brennan, director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Hurricane Center.\n\nAlberto was located 185 miles (about 300 kilometers) east of Tampico, Mexico and 295 miles (about 480 kilometers) south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas. It had top sustained winds of 40 mph (65 kph), according to the National Hurricane Center in Miami. A tropical storm is defined by sustained winds of between 39 and 73 mph (62 and 117 kph), and above that the system becomes a hurricane.\n\nBrennan said that winds could get up to 45 mph (72 kph) to 50 mph (80 kph) before the storm makes landfall.\n\nAs much as 5 inches (13 centimeters) to 10 inches (25 centimeters) of rain was expected in some areas along the Texas coast, with even higher isolated totals possible, Brennan said. He said some higher locations in Mexico could see as much as 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain, which could result in mudslides and flash flooding, especially in the states of Tamaulipas, Coahuila and Nuevo Leon.\n\nAt the Hotel Miramar Inn in Tampico, Mexico, near where Alberto was expected to come ashore, front desk attendant Diana Flores said the wind was gusty, but still not strong, and the rain hadn't started yet. \"There are people in the restaurant and on the beach,\" Flores said early Wednesday.\n\nOuter bands of rain lashed parts of Tamaulipas state in the northeast corner of Mexico overnight.\n\nThe storm was moving west at 9 mph (15 kph). Tropical storm warnings were in effect from the Texas coast at San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande and from the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\n\"Rapid weakening is expected once the center moves inland, and Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico\" on Thursday, the center said.\n\nThe U.S. National Weather Service said the main hazard for southern coastal Texas is flooding from excess rain. On Wednesday, the NWS said, there is \"a high probability\" of flash flooding in southern coastal Texas. Tornadoes or waterspouts are possible.\n\nNOAA predicts the hurricane season that began June 1 and runs through Nov. 30 is likely to be well above average, with between 17 and 25 named storms. The forecast calls for as many as 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes.\n\nAn average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.\n\nBrennan said that the first named system in the Atlantic on average comes on June 20, so Alberto is \"about right on schedule.\"\n\nA no-name storm earlier in June dumped more than 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain on parts of South Florida, stranding numerous motorists on flooded streets and pushing water into some homes in low-lying areas.\n\nBrennan said there will be dangerous rip currents from the storm and drivers should watch out for road closures and turn around if they see water covering roadways.\n\n\"People underestimate the power of water and they sometimes don't always take rainfall and the threats that come with it seriously, especially if you are driving in an area and you see water covering the road, you don't want to drive into it,\" Brennan said. \"You don't know how deep the water is. The road may be washed out. it doesn't take but just a few inches of water that are moving to move your car.\"", "source": {"uri": "americanpress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Lake Charles American Press"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@americanpress.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": {"eng": "Texas"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Texas"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mexico", "type": "Tampico"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Tampico"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Mexico"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landfall", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Landfall"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Weather_Service", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "National Weather Service"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maximum_sustained_wind", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Maximum sustained wind"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Hurricane_Center", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "National Hurricane Center"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Low-pressure_area", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Low-pressure {"uri": "2024-06-395656932", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "09:14:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T09:14:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T11:23:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.wthr.com/article/news/nation-world/tropical-storm-alberto-forms-1st-named-storm-of-the-hurricane-season/507-f2940217-358c-4e70-8e32-ff5ca003cc35", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto forms in southwest Gulf, 1st named storm of the hurricane season", "body": "MIAMI -- Tropical Storm Alberto formed on Wednesday in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, the first named storm of what is forecast to be a busy hurricane season.\n\nAlberto, which is bringing strong winds, heavy rainfall and some flooding along the coasts of Texas and Mexico, is expected to make landfall in northern Mexico on Thursday.\n\n\"The heavy rainfall and the water, as usual, is the biggest story in tropical storms,\" said Michael Brennan, director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said Wednesday afternoon that Alberto was located about 150 miles (240 kilometers) east of Tampico, Mexico, and about 320 miles (515 kilometers) south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas, with maximum sustained winds of 40 mph (65 kph). The storm is moving west-southwest at 9 miles per hour.\n\nThe center of the storm was expected to reach the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande by Thursday morning.\n\nBrennan said that winds could get up to 45 mph (72 kph) to 50 mph (80 kph) before the storm makes landfall.\n\nAs much as 5 inches (13 centimeters) to 10 inches (25 centimeters) of rain was expected in some areas along the Texas coast, with even higher isolated totals possible, Brennan said. He said some higher locations in Mexico could see as much as 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain, which could result in mudslides and flash flooding, especially in the states of Tamaulipas, Coahuila and Nuevo Leon.\n\nTamaulipas Gov. Am\u00e9rico Villarreal said Wednesday on X that schools across the state will remain closed between Wednesday and Friday.\n\nThe coordinator of civil protection in Tamaulipas, Luis Gerardo Gonzalez, said they have 333 shelters distributed throughout the state at each municipality. \"As the storm moves, we will be opening up more shelters.\"\n\nAuthorities urged residents to be aware of the alerts the state and municipal civil protections are sharing. They anticipate the storm arriving overnight with communities closest to the coast most affected.\n\nThe municipal government of Tampico, a port city in Tamaulipas state, announced this afternoon that they have activated a Command Center in coordination with the water, electricity and oil companies.\n\nTampico has been dealing with extreme droughts. \"We have been needing this water that we're now getting, thank God. Let's hope that we only get water,\" said Blanca Coronel Moral, a resident of Tampico. \"Our lagoon, which gives us drinking water, is completely dry.\"\n\nTropical storm warnings were in effect from the Texas coast at San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande and from the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\n\"Rapid weakening is expected once the center moves inland, and Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico\" on Thursday, the center said.\n\nThe U.S. National Weather Service said the main hazard for southern coastal Texas is flooding from excess rain. On Wednesday, the NWS said, there is \"a high probability\" of flash flooding in southern coastal Texas. Tornadoes or waterspouts are possible.\n\nNOAA predicts the hurricane season that began June 1 and runs through Nov. 30 is likely to be well above average, with between 17 and 25 named storms. The forecast calls for as many as 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes.\n\nAn average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.\n\nBrennan said there will be dangerous rip currents from the storm and drivers should watch out for road closures and turn around if they see water covering roadways.\n\nAreas along the Texas coast were seeing some road flooding and dangerous rip currents Wednesday, and waterspouts have been spotted offshore. \"We've seen a few brief spin-ups and some waterspouts out there,\" said Tyler Castillo, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service office in Corpus Christi.\n\nTim Cady, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Houston, said they'll be keeping an eye on coastal flooding as high tide approaches Thursday morning.\n\n\"When we have these strong onshore winds combined with the high tide, that can result in coastal inundation, particularly in our lower-lying coastal areas,\" Cady said.\n\nA no-name storm earlier in June dumped more than 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain on parts of South Florida, stranding numerous motorists on flooded streets and pushing water into some homes in low-lying areas.\n\n\"People underestimate the power of water and they sometimes don't always take rainfall and the threats that come with it seriously, especially if you are driving in an area and you see water covering the road, you don't want to drive into it,\" Brennan said.", "source": {"uri": "wthr.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WTHR-TV 13 The storm, which has been slowly building, has the chance to be the very first named storm of the 2024 Atlantic Hurricane Season. {"uri": "8187640875", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "20:00:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T20:00:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:59:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.oann.com/newsroom/tropical-storm-alberto-brings-extreme-weather/", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto Brings Extreme Weather", "body": "Governor Greg Abbott has issued a severe weather disaster for 51 counties as Tropical Storm Alberto impacts southern Texas.\n\nThe first named tropical storm of hurricane season is starting to move inland over Mexico. However, that isn't stopping the United States from feeling Alberto's effects.\n\nHours before the storm was expected to make landfall on Thursday, officials in both Mexico and in Texas were monitoring water levels as heavy rainfall started to come down.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center has been tracking Alberto as it developed and crossed the Gulf of Mexico.\n\n\"We could see it strengthened a little bit. Right now, the peak winds are about 40mph, that could get up to 45 or 50mph before landfall, but it really only has less than 24 hours before the center moves inland over Mexico,\" Michael Brennan, Director of the National Hurricane Center said. \"But that, that really doesn't have much, much to do with what the impacts are going to look like on the Texas coast for example. The heavy rainfall is going to occur regardless of what those peak winds are.\n\nThe large storm has tropical winds extending around 415 miles from its center. While Alberto made landfall in Mexico early Thursday morning, Texas is still feeling the effects.\n\nParts of the Lone Star State have seen more than their monthly expected rainfall amounts in less than a day, with some areas getting over a foot of rain as officials warn of possible flash floods.\n\n\"We are already seeing impacts along the Texas coast in terms of, you know, some strong winds or some coastal flooding this morning, heavy rainfall, flood watches and warnings in effect,\" Brennan continued.\n\nPeople have been warned to avoid beaches as conditions are still hazardous with up to three feet of coastal flooding, rip currents and low visibility.\n\nFurther inland, the effects from the storm were still noticeable as officials prepared dozens of high-water trucks and boats to ready for possible water rescues as roads and homes flood.\n\nAt least three deaths have been attributed to the storm in Mexico due to electrified waters and fast currents.\n\nBack in Texas, tornado warnings were issued.\n\nFor as much damage as the storm has caused, many drought-impacted areas of Mexico and Texas are grateful for the rain.\n\nOfficials predict Alberto is only the start of what's expected to be a very busy hurricane season.\n\nThey're estimating as many as 25 named storms and seven major hurricanes may develop through November.\n\nStay informed! {"uri": "2024-06-394956512", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:31:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:31:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:24:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/us/noaa-names-tropical-storm-alberto-as-the-first-storm-of-the-2024-atlantic-hurricane-season-in-the-gulf-of-mexico/", "title": "NOAA names Tropical Storm Alberto as the first storm of the 2024 Atlantic Hurricane season in the Gulf of Mexico. - Internewscast Journal", "body": "MIAMI, Fla. -- Tropical Storm Alberto formed on Wednesday in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, the first named storm of what is forecast to be a busy hurricane season.\n\nAlberto was located 185 miles (about 300 kilometers) east of Tampico, Mexico and 295 miles (about 480 kilometers) south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas. It had top sustained winds of 40 mph, according to the National Hurricane Center in Miami.\n\nThe storm has already created more than 4 feet of storm surge in San Luis Pass, Texas, which is located just south of Galveston Island. Numerous homes along the coast have already flooded.\n\nAlberto is forecast to make landfall in Mexico on Wednesday night with winds near 45 mph and gusts up to 55 mph.\n\nStorm surge will be a problem from Galveston down to Corpus Christi.\n\nRainfall totals for Texas could reach up to 10 inches. The mountains in Mexico could see up to 20 inches in the next 24 hours. Flash flooding will be possible from Corpus Christi to Laredo and Brownsville through Wednesday.\n\nMore tropical activity\n\nAnother tropical system is developing in the western Atlantic Ocean, near the Bahamas. This system has a low chance to develop into a named storm. However, forecasters continue to monitor it as it moves west northwest toward the southeastern United States.\n\nThe area of showers and storms is currently located several hundred miles east of the Bahamas. It's expected to arrive on the US coast by the end of the week.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicts the hurricane season that began June 1 and runs through Nov. 30 is likely to be well above average, with between 17 and 25 named storms. The forecast calls for as many as 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes.\n\nAn average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.\n\nA no-name storm earlier in June dumped more than 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain on parts of South Florida, stranding numerous motorists on flooded streets and pushing water into some homes in low-lying areas.\n\nDifference between hurricanes, tropical storms and tropical depressions\n\nOnce a depression sustains wind over 39 mph, it is called a tropical storm.\n\nIf a storm develops strong rotation, and the wind speeds exceed 74 mph, we have a hurricane. Rain totals could reach 10 inches in Texas and up to 20 inches in the mountains of Mexico, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nA tropical storm warning is in effect for the Texas coast, from San Luis Pass to Corpus Christi to the mouth of the Rio Grande, with the heaviest rain expected in south Corpus Christi, with forecasters predicting between 6 and 10 inches. The system is forecast to approach the coast of the southeastern United States by the latter part of this week.\"\n\nTexas Gov. Greg Abbott ordered the state Division of Emergency Management to put the Texas State Emergency Operations Center to a readiness of level 2, meaning it began 24-hour operations: \"As we prepare for A westward motion with an increase in forward speed is expected through Thursday.\n\nOn the forecast track, the center of Alberto will reach the coast of northeastern Mexico early Thursday morning.\n\nMaximum sustained winds are near 40 mph with higher gusts. Some slight strengthening is forecast today or tonight before the center of Alberto reaches land. Tropical Storm Alberto is expected to produce rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South Texas.\n\nMaximum totals of around 20 inches are possible across the higher terrain of the Mexican states of Coahuila, Nuevo Leon, and Tamaulipas. This rainfall will likely produce considerable flash and urban flooding along with new and renewed river flooding.\n\nMudslides are also possible in areas of higher terrain across northeast {"uri": "2024-06-394917807", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:52:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:52:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T10:23:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.rocketcitynow.com/article/news/nation-world/tropical-storm-alberto-forms-1st-named-storm-of-the-hurricane-season/507-f2940217-358c-4e70-8e32-ff5ca003cc35", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto forms in southwest Gulf, 1st named storm of the hurricane season", "body": "MIAMI -- Tropical Storm Alberto formed on Wednesday in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, the first named storm of what is forecast to be a busy hurricane season.\n\nAlberto was located 185 miles (about 300 kilometers) east of Tampico, Mexico and 295 miles (about 480 kilometers) south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas. It had top sustained winds of 40 mph (65 kph), according to the National Hurricane Center in Miami. A tropical storm is defined by sustained winds of between 39 and 73 mph (62 and 117 kph), and above that the system becomes a hurricane.\n\nThe storm was moving west at 9 mph (15 kph). Tropical storm warnings were in effect from the Texas coast at San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande and from the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla. Some slight strengthening is forecast for Wednesday before the center of Alberto reaches land on Thursday, the center said.\n\n\"Rapid weakening is expected once the center moves inland, and Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico\" on Thursday, the center said.\n\nThe storm is expected to produce rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches (about 13 to 25 centimeters) across northeast Mexico into South Texas. Maximum totals around 20 inches (51 centimeters) are possible across the higher terrain of the Mexican states of Coahuila, Nuevo Leon, and Tamaulipas. Flash flooding is likely, and mudslides are possible in some areas, the center said.\n\nThe U.S. National Weather Service said the main hazard for southern coastal Texas is flooding from excess rain. Eight inches (20 centimeters) of rain or more could fall by Saturday morning. On Wednesday, the NWS said, there is \"a high probability\" of flash flooding in southern coastal Texas. Tornadoes or waterspouts are possible.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicts the hurricane season that began June 1 and runs through Nov. 30 is likely to be well above average, with between 17 and 25 named storms. The forecast calls for as many as 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes.\n\nAn average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.\n\nA no-name storm earlier in June dumped more than 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain on parts of South Florida, stranding numerous motorists on flooded streets and pushing water into some homes in {"uri": "8186342988", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "05:00:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T05:00:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T04:59:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://dothaneagle.com/ap/international/alberto-seasons-first-named-tropical-storm-dumps-rain-on-texas-and-mexico-which-reports-3/article_c43dbca9-8bd7-59c8-a371-29f5eab2559f.html", "title": "Alberto, season's first named tropical storm, dumps rain on Texas and Mexico, which reports 3 deaths", "body": "The storm surge from Tropical Storm Alberto, floods the streets in Surfside Beach, Texas, Wednesday, June 19, 2024.\n\nBy ALFREDO PE\u00d1A and MARIANA MART\u00cdNEZ BARBA - Associated Press\n\nTAMPICO, Mexico (AP) -- Tropical Storm Alberto formed Wednesday in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, the first named storm of what is forecast to be a busy hurricane season. Authorities in Mexico reported three deaths from its rains.\n\nAlberto, which is bringing strong winds, heavy rainfall and some flooding along the coasts of Texas and Mexico, is expected to make landfall in northern Mexico early Thursday.\n\n\"The heavy rainfall and the water, as usual, is the biggest story in tropical storms,\" said Michael Brennan, director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Hurricane Center.\n\nCivil protection authorities in the northern state of Nuevo Leon said one man died in the La Silla river in the city of Monterrey, the state capital. They also said that two minors died from electric shocks in the municipality of Allende. Local media reported that the minors were riding a bicycle in the rain.\n\nNuevo Leon Gov. Samuel Garc\u00eda wrote on his account on social media platform X that metro and public transportation services would be suspended in Monterrey from Wednesday night until midday Thursday when Alberto had passed.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said late Wednesday that Alberto was located about 135 miles (220 kilometers) east of Tampico, Mexico, and about 320 miles (510 kilometers) south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas, with maximum sustained winds of 50 mph (85 kph). The storm was moving west at 9 miles per hour.\n\nThe center of the storm was expected to reach the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande by Thursday morning.\n\nAs much as 5 inches (13 centimeters) to 10 inches (25 centimeters) of rain was expected in some areas along the Texas coast, with even higher isolated totals possible, Brennan said. He said some higher locations in Mexico could see as much as 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain, which could result in mudslides and flash flooding, especially in the states of Tamaulipas, Coahuila and Nuevo Leon.\n\nThe municipal government of Tampico, a port city in Tamaulipas state, announced Wednesday afternoon that authorities had activated a command center in coordination with the water, electricity and oil companies.\n\nMany residents were excited about the prospect of heavy showers, as Tamaulipas and most of Mexico has been dealing with extreme droughts.\n\n\"We have been needing this water that we're now getting, thank God. Let's hope that we only get water,\" said Blanca Coronel Moral, a resident of Tampico. \"Our lagoon, which gives us drinking water, is completely dry.\"\n\nTamaulipas Gov. Am\u00e9rico Villarreal said Wednesday on X that schools across the state will remain closed between Wednesday and Friday.\n\nThe coordinator of civil protection in Tamaulipas, Luis Gerardo Gonzalez, said they have 333 shelters distributed throughout the state at each municipality. \"As the storm moves, we will be opening up more shelters.\"\n\nAuthorities urged residents to be aware of the alerts the state and municipal civil protections are sharing. They anticipate the storm arriving overnight with communities closest to the coast most affected.\n\nTropical storm warnings were in effect from the Texas coast at San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande and from the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\n\"Rapid weakening is expected once the center moves inland, and Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico\" on Thursday, the center said.\n\nThe U.S. National Weather Service said the main hazard for southern coastal Texas is flooding from excess rain. On Wednesday, the NWS said, there is \"a high probability\" of flash flooding in southern coastal Texas. Tornadoes or waterspouts are possible.\n\nNOAA predicts the hurricane season that began June 1 and runs through Nov. 30 is likely to be well above average, with between 17 and 25 named storms. The forecast calls for as many as 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes.\n\nAn average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.\n\nBrennan said there will be dangerous rip currents from the storm and drivers should watch out for road closures and turn around if they see water covering roadways.\n\nAreas along the Texas coast were seeing some road flooding and dangerous rip currents Wednesday, and waterspouts have been spotted offshore. \"We've seen a few brief spin-ups and some waterspouts out there,\" said Tyler Castillo, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service office in Corpus Christi.\n\nTim Cady, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Houston, said they'll be keeping an eye on coastal flooding as high tide approaches Thursday morning.\n\n\"When we have these strong onshore winds combined with the high tide, that can result in coastal inundation, particularly in our lower-lying coastal areas,\" Cady said.\n\n___ AP journalists Jamie Stengle in Dallas and Julie Walker in New York contributed to this report.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "dothaneagle.com", Alberto is the first named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season.\n\nThe storm is set to bring heavy rain, coastal flooding, and tropical storm force winds are likely along the Texas coast.\n\nA Tropical Storm Warning is in effect for the Texas coast from San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla. Tropical storm conditions are possible within the watch area by Wednesday.\n\nAlberto is forecast to bring heavy rain and coastal flooding to much of the western Gulf Coast. A Flood Watch has been issued for southeast Texas through the end of the week.\n\nAnother area of low pressure is forecast to develop over the Bay of Campeche this weekend. Gradual development is possible early next week as it moves slowly north-northwest. This area currently has a 30% chance of development over the next 7 days.\n\nThe other area we are monitoring is located several hundred miles east of the Bahamas, where a trough of low pressure is producing showers and storms.\n\nConditions could become favorable for some gradual development as the area moves west-northwest through the week. The system is forecast to approach the southeastern United States by Friday.\n\nDevelopment chances are low, only 10% to 20% through the next two to seven days. {"uri": "8185858076", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:28:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:28:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:27:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.dallasnews.com/news/weather/2024/06/19/tropical-storm-warnings-on-texas-coast-as-alberto-forms-in-southwest-gulf/", "title": "Tropical storm warnings on Texas coast as Alberto forms in southwest Gulf", "body": "MEXICO CITY -- Tropical Storm Alberto formed on Wednesday in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, the first named storm of what is forecast to be a busy hurricane season.\n\nAlberto, which is bringing strong winds, heavy rainfall and some flooding along the coasts of Texas and Mexico, is expected to make landfall in northern Mexico on Thursday.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"The heavy rainfall and the water, as usual, is the biggest story in tropical storms,\" said Michael Brennan, director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Hurricane Center.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAlberto was located 185 miles east of Tampico, Mexico and 295 miles south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas. It had top sustained winds of 40 mph, according to the National Hurricane Center in Miami. A tropical storm is defined by sustained winds of between 39 mph and 73 mph, and above that the system becomes a hurricane.\n\nD-FW Weather Wise\n\nFrom snow to 100-degree heat, we've got you covered.\n\nSIGN UP\n\nOr with:\n\nGoogleFacebook\n\nBy signing up you agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy\n\nBrennan said that winds could get up to 45 mph to 50 mph before the storm makes landfall.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAs much as 5 inches to 10 inches of rain was expected in some areas along the Texas coast, with even higher isolated totals possible, Brennan said. He said some higher locations in Mexico could see as much as 20 inches of rain, which could result in mudslides and flash flooding, especially in the states of Tamaulipas, Coahuila and Nuevo Leon.\n\nAt the Hotel Miramar Inn in Tampico, Mexico, near where Alberto was expected to come ashore, front desk attendant Diana Flores said the wind was gusty, but still not strong, and the rain hadn't started yet. \"There are people in the restaurant and on the beach,\" Flores said early Wednesday.\n\nOuter bands of rain lashed parts of Tamaulipas state in the northeast corner of Mexico overnight.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe storm was moving west at 9 mph. Tropical storm warnings were in effect from the Texas coast at San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande and from the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Rapid weakening is expected once the center moves inland, and Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico\" on Thursday, the center said.\n\nThe U.S. National Weather Service said the main hazard for southern coastal Texas is flooding from excess rain. On Wednesday, the NWS said, there is \"a high probability\" of flash flooding in southern coastal Texas. Tornadoes or waterspouts are possible.\n\nNOAA predicts the hurricane season that began June 1 and runs through Nov. 30 is likely to be well above average, with between 17 and 25 named storms. The forecast calls for as many as 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAn average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.\n\nBrennan said that the first named system in the Atlantic on average comes on June 20, so Alberto is \"about right on schedule.\"\n\nA no-name storm earlier in June dumped more than 20 inches of rain on parts of South Florida, stranding numerous motorists on flooded streets and pushing water into some homes in low-lying areas.\n\nBrennan said there will be dangerous rip currents from the storm and drivers should watch out for road closures and turn around if they see water covering roadways.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"People underestimate the power of water and they sometimes don't always take rainfall and the threats that come with it seriously, especially if you are driving in an area and you see water covering the road, you don't want to drive into it,\" Brennan said. \"You don't know how deep the water is. The road may be washed out. it doesn't take but just a few inches of water that are moving to move your car.\"\n\nBy JAMIE STENGLE and MARIANA MART\u00cdNEZ BARBA Associated Press. Rapid weakening is expected once the centre moves inland, and Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico on Thursday or Thursday night.\n\n\"Alberto is a large tropical storm, with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 415 miles north of the centre.\"\n\nIn addition to high winds, Alberto is expected to bring heavy rain to Mexico and Texas, likely causing \"considerable flash and urban flooding along with new and renewed river flooding\".\n\nMeteorologists warned that storm surge will raise water levels by as much as three feet above normal tide levels, which will be accompanied by large and destructive waves.\n\nThe NHC is also monitoring another system closer to the island for signs of possible storm development, but estimated that there was only a 10 per cent chance of the disturbance becoming tropical in the next two days.\n\nThe system was southwest of Bermuda and expected to move farther west or northwest in the coming days.\n\nMeteorologists have warned in preseason forecasts that this year's hurricane season is expected to be busier than usual because of a number of factors.\n\nThe US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicted an 85 per cent chance of an above-normal hurricane season, blaming warm seas and the expected return of La Ni\u00f1a conditions this summer.\n\nThe NOAA forecasted 17 to 25 total named storms, of which 13 are expected to reach hurricane strength.\n\nThe organisation also forecast that between four and seven storms would reach or exceed Category 3 strength, with {"uri": "8185543537", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:11:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:11:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:10:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.tampabay.com/hurricane/2024/06/19/tropical-storm-alberto-texas-gulf-mexico/", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto forms in Gulf of Mexico, first storm of season", "body": "The massive, lumbering storm has tropical-storm-force winds extending more than 415 miles north of its center.\n\nAfter the slowest start to a hurricane season in a decade, the first named storm of the season, Tropical Storm Alberto, formed Wednesday.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto, a wide-reaching, lumbering storm, was about 295 miles south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas, around 11 a.m. The storm is moving west at about 9 mph, and maximum sustained winds were 40 mph, according to forecasters.\n\nThe tropical storm does not pose a threat to Florida.\n\nThe massive storm has tropical-storm-force winds extending more than 415 miles north of its center. On Wednesday morning, a weather station in Matagorda Bay in Texas reported gusts up to 47 mph.\n\nForecasters said Alberto could bring up to 15 inches of rain to northern Mexico into southern Texas, and will likely produce flash and urban flooding.\n\nIn parts of coastal Texas, storm surge could reach up to 4 feet, according to the hurricane center. In Mexico, minor flooding is possible, forecasters said.\n\n\"Users are reminded not to focus on the exact track of this system,\" forecasters said in a Wednesday update from the hurricane center. \"The disturbance is very large with rainfall, coastal flooding, and wind impacts likely to occur far from the center along the coasts of Texas and northeastern Mexico.\"\n\nWhile Tropical Storm Alberto is the first storm of the season, it is also the latest to form in a decade. In 2014, Hurricane Arthur formed on July 1, and remains the latest first storm of a season in recent history.\n\n* * *\n\n5 things to know about the 2024 hurricane season, according to forecasters.\n\nForecasters predict 'extremely active' 2024 hurricane season. {"uri": "2024-06-395125188", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "20:08:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T20:08:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T18:35:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.bradenton.com/e-edition/livefeed-news/article289390840.html", "title": "The year's first named storm has formed in the Gulf of Mexico: Tropical Storm Alberto", "body": "The first named storm of the season, Tropical Storm Alberto, has parts of the Texas and Mexican gulf coasts under Tropical Storm Warning.\n\nMeanwhile, the disturbance in the Atlantic Ocean still shows little signs of forming into something more.\n\nWind speed: 40 mph sustained winds. \"Some slight strengthening is forecast (Wednesday or Wednesday night) before the center of Alberto reaches land,\" the National Hurricane Center said in its 11 a.m. Wednesday advisory.\n\n\"Rapid weakening is expected once the center moves inland, and Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico Thursday or Thursday night.\"\n\nWhere is it: About 180 miles east of Tampico, Mexico, and 295 miles south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas. The hurricane center describes Alberto as \"large,\" with tropical storm force winds extending 415 miles north of the center.\n\nMovement: Alberto is moving west at 9 mph. \"A westward motion with an increase in forward speed is expected through Thursday,\" the hurricane center said. \"On the forecast track, the center of Alberto will reach the coast of northeastern Mexico early Thursday morning.\"\n\nAlerts: There's a Tropical Storm Warning for the Texas coast from San Luis Pass down to the mouth of the Rio Grande River and for the northeastern Mexican coast from that mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla, a resort town on the Gulf of Mexico.\n\nHazards: Alberto is forecast to dump up to 20 inches of rain \"across the higher terrain of the Mexican states of Coahuila, Nuevo Leon, and Tamaulipas\" and 5 to 10 inches in Northeast Mexico and South Texas, according to the National Hurricane Center's 2 p.m. Wednesday advisory. Mudslides are possible in parts of Northeast Mexico. Parts of Texas are looking at a storm surge up to 4 feet.\n\n\"The deepest water will occur along the immediate coast near and to the north of the landfall location, where the surge will be accompanied by large and dangerous waves,\" the hurricane center forecasts.\n\nTornadoes are possible in Texas. Swells \"are likely to cause life-threatening surf and rip current conditions.\"\n\n\"An area of showers and thunderstorms located several hundred miles east of the Bahamas is associated with a surface trough of low pressure,\" the hurricane center's 8 a.m. Wednesday update said. \"Environmental conditions are marginally conducive for some gradual development of this system during the next few days while it moves westward or west-northwestward.\"", "source": {"uri": "bradenton.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Bradenton Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": "david_j_neal@bradenton.com", "name": "David J.
