{"uri": "8185858657", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:32:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:32:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:27:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/tropical-storm-alberto-forms-in-southwest-gulf-1st-named-storm-of-the-hurricane-season-101718824926100.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto forms in southwest Gulf, 1st named storm of the hurricane season", "body": "Alberto, which is bringing strong winds, heavy rainfall and some flooding along the coasts of Texas and Mexico, is expected to make landfall in northern Mexico on Thursday.\n\n\"The heavy rainfall and the water, as usual, is the biggest story in tropical storms,\" said Michael Brennan, director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said early Wednesday afternoon that Alberto was located about 180 miles east of Tampico, Mexico, and about 295 miles south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas, with maximum sustained winds of 40 mph .\n\nThe center of the storm was expected to reach the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande by early Thursday morning.\n\nBrennan said that winds could get up to 45 mph to 50 mph before the storm makes landfall.\n\nAs much as 5 inches to 10 inches of rain was expected in some areas along the Texas coast, with even higher isolated totals possible, Brennan said. He said some higher locations in Mexico could see as much as 20 inches of rain, which could result in mudslides and flash flooding, especially in the states of Tamaulipas, Coahuila and Nuevo Leon.\n\nTamaulipas Gov. Am\u00e9rico Villarreal said Wednesday on X, formerly Twitter, that schools across the state will remain closed between Wednesday and Friday.\n\nThe storm was moving west at 9 mph . Tropical storm warnings were in effect from the Texas coast at San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande and from the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\n\"Rapid weakening is expected once the center moves inland, and Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico\" on Thursday, the center said.\n\nThe U.S. National Weather Service said the main hazard for southern coastal Texas is flooding from excess rain. On Wednesday, the NWS said, there is \"a high probability\" of flash flooding in southern coastal Texas. Tornadoes or waterspouts are possible.\n\nNOAA predicts the hurricane season that began June 1 and runs through Nov. 30 is likely to be well above average, with between 17 and 25 named storms. The forecast calls for as many as 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes.\n\nAn average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.\n\nBrennan said that the first named system in the Atlantic on average comes on June 20, so Alberto is \"about right on schedule.\"\n\nIn the Village of Surfside Beach, located on a barrier island on the Texas coast about 65 miles south of Houston, Mayor Gregg Bisso said Wednesday that rains had already left about 2 feet of water on streets on the west end of the island, making them impassable.\n\n\"We're on a barrier island and there's no place for the rain to go, plus the extremely high tides, everything is just hanging right there and it's flooding all the streets,\" Bisso said, adding that double red flags have been placed on the beach to warn people that no one should be in the water because of the extreme rip tides.\n\n\"Those conditions were extremely bad out there yesterday, and today,\" he said.\n\nAll of the homes on the island are elevated anywhere from 10 to 14 feet above the ground, so they don't expect homes to flood and evacuations were not ordered.\n\n\"We're just waiting for the rains to stop and the tide to go down,\" he said.\n\nBrennan said there will be dangerous rip currents from the storm and drivers should watch out for road closures and turn around if they see water covering roadways.\n\nA no-name storm earlier in June dumped more than 20 inches of rain on parts of South Florida, stranding numerous motorists on flooded streets and pushing water into some homes in low-lying areas.\n\n\"People underestimate the power of water and they sometimes don't always take rainfall and the threats that come with it seriously, especially if you are driving in an area and you see water covering the road, you don't want to drive into it,\" Brennan said. \"You don't know how deep the water is. The road may be washed out. it doesn't take but just a few inches of water that are moving to move your car.\"\n\n___ Stengle contributed to this report from Dallas. journalist Julie Walker The NHC classifies a tropical storm as a cyclone with maximum sustained winds from 39 mph to 73 mph.\n\nAs the week progresses, Alberto will likely cause heavy rainfall, costal flooding and wind damage in its path, forecasters said. {"uri": "8184133235", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "18:54:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T18:54:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T18:49:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/winds-40-mph-why-isnt-172821359.html", "title": "Winds are at 40 mph. Why isn't Potential Tropical Cyclone One Tropical Storm Alberto?", "body": "Potential Tropical Cyclone One is poised to make landfall sometime late Wednesday, according to the latest advisory from the National Hurricane Center.\n\nForecasters are predicting the system will become Tropical Storm Alberto -- the first named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season -- before making landfall along the Gulf Coast.\n\n\u27a4 Track Potential Tropical Cyclone One\n\nBut there's some confusion over when a storm gets a name, especially since Potential Tropical Cyclone One already has maximum sustained winds of 40 mph.\n\nThe confusion comes from wind speed, which is generally the criteria used by NOAA to classify a developing system as a tropical storm.\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One has had sustained winds of 40 mph for the last several advisories, which is the general criteria used to classify a system as a tropical storm.\n\n\"A tropical cyclone in which the maximum sustained surface wind speed -- using the U.S., 1-minute average -- ranges from 39 mph to 73 mph,\" NOAA said on its website.\n\nBut there's another factor that comes into play: circulation.\n\nAt 11 a.m., the National Hurricane Center said the \"disturbance's overall envelope is becoming slightly better defined, although there is still no evidence that a well-defined center of circulation has developed.\"\n\nWithout that well-defined center of circulation, along with sustained winds of at least 39 mph, the system remains a potential tropical storm, according to the National Weather Service Miami.\n\nAt 11 a.m. Tuesday, an Air Force Reserve reconnaissance aircraft was surveying the system's wind field to assess its structure to see if it can now be classified as a tropical storm.\n\nAdvisories are issued for potential storms based on how close they are to land.\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One currently is expected be a tropical storm by Wednesday and to make landfall along the Gulf Coast late Wednesday.\n\nThat would give residents in the storm's path little time to react to advisories and warnings from the National Hurricane Center on the track and impact the storm could have.\n\nSo advisories are issued for potential storms to give residents adequate time to prepare before landfall, the National Weather Service Miami said.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", {"uri": "8185617245", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:05:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:05:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:03:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-tropical-storm-alberto-forms-in-southwest-gulf-1st-named-storm-of-the-hurricane-season-6050073.html", "title": "World News | Tropical Storm Alberto Forms in Southwest Gulf, 1st Named Storm of the Hurricane Season | LatestLY", "body": "Miami, Jun 19 (AP) Tropical Storm Alberto formed on Wednesday in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, the first named storm of what is forecast to be a busy hurricane season.\n\nAlberto was located 185 miles (about 300 kilometres) east of Tampico, Mexico and 295 miles (about 480 kilometres) south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas.\n\nAlso Read | Vladimir Putin's North Korea Visit: Russian President Putin, Kim Jong Un Sign Strategic Partnership Treaty Calling for Mutual Assistance if Either Gets Attacked.\n\nIt had top sustained winds of 40 mph (65 kph), according to the National Hurricane Centre in Miami. A tropical storm is defined by sustained winds of between 39 and 73 mph (62 and 117 kph), and above that the system becomes a hurricane.\n\nThe storm was moving west at 9 mph (15 kph). Tropical storm warnings were in effect from the Texas coast at San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande and from the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla. Some slight strengthening is forecast for Wednesday before the centre of Alberto reaches land on Thursday, the centre said.\n\nAlso Read | Indian Millionaires Migration 2024: About 4,300 Millionaire To Leave India This Year and Go to Other Countries, Says Report.\n\n\"Rapid weakening is expected once the centre moves inland, and Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico\" on Thursday, the centre said.\n\nThe storm is expected to produce rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches (about 13 to 25 centimetres) across northeast Mexico into South Texas. Maximum totals around 20 inches (51 centimetres) are possible across the higher terrain of the Mexican states of Coahuila, Nuevo Leon, and Tamaulipas. Flash flooding is likely, and mudslides are possible in some areas, the centre said.\n\nThe US National Weather Service said the main hazard for southern coastal Texas is flooding from excess rain. Eight inches (20 centimetres) of rain or more could fall by Saturday morning. On Wednesday, the NWS said, there is \"a high probability\" of flash flooding in southern coastal Texas. Tornadoes or waterspouts are possible.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicts the hurricane season that began June 1 and runs through November 30 is likely to be well above average, with between 17 and 25 named storms. The forecast calls for as many as 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes.\n\nAn average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.\n\nA no-name storm earlier in June dumped more than 20 inches (50 centimetres) of rain on parts of South Florida, stranding numerous motorists on flooded streets and pushing water into some homes in low-lying areas. Meanwhile, the season's first named storm, Tropical Storm Alberto, lost steam after moving inland while drenching Mexico and Texas.\n\nThe Atlantic system as of the NHC's 8 a.m. tropical outlook remains a small area of low pressure located about 150 miles east of the northernmost Bahamas with disorganized shower and thunderstorm activity.\n\n\"While environmental conditions are only marginally conducive due to nearby dry air, further development of this system could lead to the development of a tropical depression while the low moves west-northwestward at 10 to 15 mph and approaches the northeastern coast of Florida or the Georgia coast early on Friday,\" said NHC Warning Coordination Meteorologist Robbie Berg.\n\nAn Air Force Reserve reconnaissance aircraft is slated to fly out to the system in the afternoon.\n\nThe NHC gives it a 40% chance of development in the next two to seven days.\n\nThe National Weather Service issued a high surf advisory that runs into Friday with breaking waves of 5 to 7 feet in the surf zone with a high rip current risk along coastal Central and Northeast Florida beaches.\n\n\"Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water,\" warned the NWS.\n\nErosion will be greatest at high tide around 7 p.m. and 7 a.m., the NWS stated. Volusia County beaches are still recovering from major washout that occurred during both Hurricane Ian and Hurricane Nicole in 2022.\n\nThe NWS also has a small craft advisory in place from Jupiter Inlet north to the Altamaha Sound, Georgia that runs through late Friday for northeast Florida and through Friday morning for Central Florida.\n\nWaves of 7 to 10 feet are expected offshore with 25-30 mph winds and gusts up to 35 mph farther north along Florida's coast.\n\nRain chances are highest in Brevard and Volusia counties in Central Florida as the low approaches with some thunderstorm activity, the NWS stated.\n\nAs far as Tropical Storm Alberto goes, the system gained some wind speed as it dumped rainfall over Mexico and Texas but fell back in strength to become Tropical Depression Alberto by late morning.\n\nIn its 11 a.m. advisory, the center of Alberto was located inland about 95 miles west of Tampico, Mexico and 280 miles south-southwest of Brownsville, Texas with sustained winds of 35 mph moving west at 18 mph. It had earlier Thursday maintained winds of 45 mph when it was a tropical storm.\n\nAll tropical storm warnings have ceased and the system is expected to diminish further throughout Thursday.\n\nRainfall is still an issue in Mexico with 5 to 10 inches expected with some areas in higher terrain of inland Mexico getting up to 20 inches. Rain in Texas, though, dropped off quickly Thursday morning with only another 1 inch expected in some southern parts of the state.\n\nThe NHC is also tracking a broad area of low pressure that is forecast to form over southeastern Mexico and northern Central America on Friday.\n\n\"Environmental conditions appear conducive for gradual development after this system moves over the Bay of Campeche on Saturday, and a tropicaldepression could form over the southwestern Gulf of Mexico this weekend while it moves slowly west-northwestward or northwestward,\" forecasters said.\n\nThe NHC {"uri": "8182551285", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "21:29:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T21:29:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T21:28:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.fox35orlando.com/news/potential-tropical-cyclone-one-disturbance-gulf-mexico-strengthening", "title": "Potential Tropical Cyclone One: Disturbance in Gulf of Mexico strengthening", "body": "MIAMI - The National Hurricane Center in Miami has designated an area of low pressure over the Bay of Campeche as Potential Tropical Cyclone One.\n\nThe system is expected to bring heavy rainfall to parts of the western Gulf Coast, prompting the issuance of a Tropical Storm Watch for parts of the coast of Texas and northeastern Mexico.\n\nAs of late Monday afternoon, the system's center was located about 470 miles southeast of Brownsville, Texas, with maximum sustained winds of 40 mph.\n\nThe system is moving north-northwest at approximately 7 mph and is expected to maintain this direction through Tuesday. A turn toward the west-northwest is anticipated Tuesday night or Wednesday, with the system likely approaching the western Gulf Coast late Wednesday.\n\nGradual strengthening is possible, and the disturbance is forecast to develop into a tropical storm by Wednesday. If it becomes better organized, as expected, it will most likely be named Tropical Storm Alberto. Tropical-storm-force winds extend up to 290 miles northeast of the center.\n\nA Tropical Storm Watch has been issued for the Texas coast from Port O'Connor southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande. Additionally, the government of Mexico has issued a Tropical Storm Watch for the northeastern coast of Mexico, south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Boca de Catan.\n\nResidents along the coasts of Texas and northeastern Mexico are advised to monitor this system's progress, as additional watches and warnings may be issued tonight and Tuesday.\n\nSummary of Watches and Warnings:\n\n- A Tropical Storm Watch is in effect for the Texas coast from Port O'Connor southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande.\n\n- A Tropical Storm Watch is also in effect for the northeastern coast of Mexico, south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Boca de Catan.\n\nA Tropical Storm Watch indicates that tropical storm conditions are possible within the watch area, generally within 48 hours.\n\nForecasters are also monitoring a rare area of low pressure in the southwestern Atlantic Ocean, several hundred miles east of Florida and the Bahamas.\n\nFOX 35 Storm Team Meteorologist Brooks Garner said the low is trying to develop along an old cold front in the western Atlantic. Garner said that could be the seed for a future tropical or subtropical system, set to make a run for Florida late this week.\n\nAccording to the NHC, it has a 30% chance of forming over the next seven days.\n\nThere's also an upper level low atop of that developing tropical system, which Garner said is the opposite of what the systems need to further develop. (They need high-pressure aloft.)\n\nThe current setup will obstruct any chance of rapid advancement of this system. This will keep the system much weaker than the earlier appeared potential from over the weekend, when the threat first became apparent.\n\nIf the area were to develop, such an event would be \"extremely rare\" for June, said FOX 35 Storm Team Meteorologist Noah Bergren. \"Historically, only three storms have made landfall from the east in June,\" he added. \"The most recent was Tropical Storm Danny in 2021, which hit South Carolina.\"\n\nRELATED: 'Extremely rare' tropical system could form off Florida's Atlantic Coast midweek\n\nThis unusual weather pattern is caused by a massive heat dome over New England, which creates an east-to-west flow over the southwest Atlantic Ocean.\n\nRegardless of development, the tropical activity will cause breezy conditions on Thursday and They said one man died in the La Silla river in the city of Monterrey, the state capital, and that two minors died from electric shocks in the municipality of Allende. Local media reported that the minors were riding a bicycle in the rain.\n\nAlberto is forecast to bring heavy rain and coastal flooding to much of the western Gulf Coast through the end of the week.\n\nThe U.S. National Weather Service said the main hazard for southern coastal Texas is flooding from excess rain. On Wednesday the NWS said there is \"a high probability\" of flash flooding in southern coastal Texas. Tornadoes or waterspouts are possible.\n\nSouthwestern Gulf of Mexico\n\nAnother area of low pressure is forecast to develop near the Yucatan Peninsula this weekend. Gradual development is possible early next week and a tropical depression could form as it moves slowly north-northwest. This area currently has a 50% chance of development over the next 7 days.\n\nSouthwestern Atlantic\n\nThe other area being monitored is located several hundred miles east of the Bahamas, where a trough of low pressure is producing showers and storms. The system is now approaching the southeastern United States.\n\nDevelopment chances are low, with only a 30% chance through the next two days.\n\nRegardless of development, tropical moisture will move into the region. The system is the first named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season this year.\n\nThe hurricane season runs from June through November, and can shut oil and gas production platforms in the Gulf of Mexico, wreak havoc on agriculture and cause significant damage to homes and roads. There could be as many as 25 named storms this season, compared with an average of 14.\n\nAlberto is a large system, with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 460 miles from the center, according to the weather agency. Rainfall of 5 to 10 inches is expected across northeast Mexico and into southern Texas. {"uri": "8185760811", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "18:00:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T18:00:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T17:58:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/science-environment/2988591-tropical-storm-alberto-heads-towards-gulf-coast", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto Heads Towards Gulf Coast | Science-Environment", "body": "Tropical Storm Alberto is moving westward across the Gulf of Mexico. Heavy rains, coastal flooding, and gusty winds are expected along the Texas and northeastern Mexico coasts. Alberto is likely to make landfall in northeastern Mexico by early Thursday, bringing potential for flash floods and mudslides.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto Intermediate Advisory Number 8A NWS National Hurricane Center Miami FL AL012024\n\n100 PM CDT Wed Jun 19 2024 ...ALBERTO MOVING WESTWARD OVER THE WESTERN Gulf of Mexico...\n\n...HEAVY RAINS, COASTAL FLOODING, AND GUSTY WINDS FORECAST ALONG THE COASTS OF TEXAS AND NORTHEASTERN Mexico THROUGH THURSDAY...\n\nABOUT 295 MI...475 KM SSE OF BROWNSVILLE TEXAS MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS...40 MPH...65 KM/H\n\nPRESENT MOVEMENT...W OR 270 DEGREES AT 9 MPH...15 KM/H MINIMUM CENTRAL PRESSURE...995 MB...29.39 INCHES\n\nSUMMARY OF WATCHES AND WARNINGS IN EFFECT: A Tropical Storm Warning is in effect for... * the Texas coast from San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the\n\nRio Grande * the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\nA Tropical Storm Warning means that tropical storm conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area.\n\nFor storm information specific to your area in the United States, including possible inland watches and warnings, please monitor\n\nproducts issued by your local National Weather Service forecast office. For storm information specific to your area outside of the\n\nUnited States, please monitor products issued by your national meteorological service.\n\nDISCUSSION AND OUTLOOK ----------------------\n\nAt 100 PM CDT (1800 UTC), the center of Tropical Storm Alberto was located near latitude 22.2 North, longitude 95.1 West. Alberto is\n\nmoving toward the west near 9 mph (15 km/h). A westward motion with an increase in forward speed is expected through Thursday. On the\n\nforecast track, the center of Alberto will reach the coast of northeastern Mexico early Thursday morning.\n\nMaximum sustained winds are near 40 mph (65 km/h) with higher gusts. Some slight strengthening is forecast today or tonight before\n\nthe center of Alberto reaches land. Rapid weakening is expected once the center moves inland, and Alberto is likely to dissipate\n\nover Mexico Thursday or Thursday night. Alberto is a large tropical storm, with tropical-storm-force winds\n\nextending outward up to 415 miles (665 km) north of the center. The estimated minimum central pressure is 995 mb (29.39 inches).\n\nHAZARDS AFFECTING LAND ----------------------\n\nKey messages for Alberto can be found in the Tropical Cyclone Discussion under AWIPS header MIATCDAT1 and WMO header WTNT41 KNHC.\n\nRAINFALL: Tropical Storm Alberto is expected to produce rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South Texas.\n\nMaximum totals around 20 inches are possible across the higher terrain of the Mexican states of Coahuila, Nuevo Leon, and\n\nTamaulipas. This rainfall will likely produce considerable flash and urban flooding along with new and renewed river flooding. Mudslides\n\nare also possible in areas of higher terrain across northeast Mexico.\n\nFor a complete depiction of forecast rainfall and flash flooding associated with Alberto, please see the National Weather Service\n\nStorm Total Rainfall Graphic, available at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at1.shtml?rainqpf and the Flash Flood Risk\n\ngraphic at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at1.shtml?ero STORM SURGE: The combination of a dangerous storm surge and\n\nthe tide will cause normally dry areas near the coast to be flooded by rising waters moving inland from the shoreline. The water could\n\nreach the following heights above ground somewhere in the indicated areas if the peak surge occurs at the time of high tide...\n\nSargent, TX to Sabine Pass, TX...2-4 ft Galveston Bay...2-4 ft\n\nMouth of the Rio Grande, TX to Sargent, TX...1-3 ft Sabine Pass, TX to Vermilion/Cameron Parish Line, LA...1-3 ft\n\nThe deepest water will occur along the immediate coast near and to the north of the landfall location, where the surge will be\n\naccompanied by large and dangerous waves. Surge-related flooding depends on the relative timing of the surge and the tidal cycle,\n\nand can vary greatly over short distances. For information specific to your area, please see products issued by your local\n\nNational Weather Service forecast office. For a complete depiction of areas at risk of storm surge inundation,\n\nplease see the National Weather Service Peak Storm Surge Graphic, available at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at1.shtml?peakSurge.\n\nStorm surge will raise water levels by as much as 1 to 3 feet above normal tide levels along the immediate coast of northeastern\n\nMexico in areas of onshore winds north of where the center makes landfall. Near the coast, the surge will be accompanied by large\n\nand destructive waves. WIND: Tropical storm conditions are expected within the warning\n\narea today through early Thursday. TORNADOES: A couple of tornadoes are possible today and tonight\n\nacross parts of Deep South Texas and Southeast Texas. SURF: Swells generated by Alberto will affect the coast of Texas\n\nand northeastern Mexico through Friday. These swells are likely to cause life-threatening surf and rip current conditions.\n\nPlease consult products from your local weather office. {"uri": "2024-06-396311308", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:03:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:03:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:58:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.fresnobee.com/news/nation-world/national/article289420228.html", "title": "Deadly Tropical Storm Alberto inundates inland areas of coastal Texas, Mexico", "body": "June 20 (UPI) -- The first named storm of this year's Atlantic hurricane season made landfall over Mexico Thursday morning and is expected to pummel Texas with heavy rain into Friday.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto made landfall at about 7 a.m. CDT about 25 miles west of Tampico, Mexico, and about 255 miles south of Brownsville, Texas.\n\nThe storm was moving westward along the Gulf of Mexico before it moved inland. By mid-morning, the storm was downgraded to a tropical depression as it traveled about 18 mph and packed 35-mph winds through central Mexico.\n\nDespite being downgraded, the National Hurrican Center warned Alberto still poses a threat to the region, due to heavy rain that can cause flooding and mudslides.\n\nTexas Gov. Greg Abbott on Wednesday issued a severe weather disaster declaration for 51 counties in anticipation of the heavy rainfall, coastal flooding and tropical force winds the storm was likely to produce.\n\n\"I urge Texans in at risk-areas to remain weather aware and heed the guidance of state and local officials to keep themselves and their families safe,\" Abbott said Wednesday.\n\nThe National Weather Service on Thursday reported winds above 50 mph in the Galveston Bay area and and rainfall totals of about 2 to 7 inches across the coastal bend.\n\nAccuWeather predicted rainfall totals of about 8 to 12 inches for the Big Bend area of Texas, and winds could reach speeds of up to 60 mph.\n\nStorm surge along the coast of northeastern Mexico, Texas and western Louisiana peaked at 1 to 3 feet, according to AccuWeather, but the Houston and Galveston areas could see up to 6 feet in some low-lying areas until conditions ease into Friday.\n\nFootage from CNN on Thursday morning showed the coastal town of Surfside Beach in Texas besieged by high waves crashing over a seawall and flooding residential areas.\n\nSurfside Mayor Gregg Bisso said the cleanup effort is on hold after the high water levels made it unsafe, but recovery will resume once the water has subsided enough.\n\nThe city also limited access to Follet's Island's west end where about 100 homes were left without power in the wake of the storm. Only residents, contractors and people with rental agreements can access that side of the island.\n\nAccess to the beach is also prohibited.\n\n\"We haven't even been able to get down on the beach yet to take a look at it, to see what it's what it looks like, see how much damage we've had to our dunes and things like that,\" Bisso said. \"As we get down there, we'll be able to assess the situation a lot better.\"\n\nIn San Antonio, CPS Energy said about 1,400 of its 938,000 customers were left without power on Thursday morning.\n\nThe White House on Thursday said President Joe Biden was briefed on Alberto, as well as on wildfires in the southwest United States and extreme heat across the rest of the country.\n\nIn Mexico, meanwhile, there were four confirmed deaths related to Alberto as of Thursday.\n\nOfficials in the northeastern state of Nuevo Le\u00f3n said a man died early Thursday morning when he was trying to repair a window on his home.\n\nSevere weather conditions caused by Alberto also claimed the lives of three minors on Wednesday. One 16-year-old boy drowned in Monterrey when he entered the La Silla River to try to retrieve a ball.\n\nThe other two minors were killed by electrocution from a light pole while riding their bikes in Pino Su\u00e1rez.\n\nResidents in northeastern Mexico, however, see Alberto as also bringing much needed rain to the region, which for over a year has suffered from severe drought.\n\nErick Te\u00f3dulo Cavazos Cavazos, director of Civil Protection of Nuevo Le\u00f3n, told local media on Thursday that rains from Alberto are resupplying dams such as La Boca and El Cuchillo.\n\n\"We have to wait for the figures from El Cuchillo, but everything that comes from the Santa Catarina River and the La Silla River goes to El Cuchillo,\" he said. \"We also had a dam that was in a water crisis in the entire Linares region, in the municipality of Cerro Prieto, water is entering.\"\n\nAccuWeather also is keeping an eye on a possible second tropical storm system that could form this weekend and once again hammer notheastern Mexico and southern Texas.\n\n\"There is a moderate chance for development from June 21-23 across a similar area in the Gulf of Mexico,\" said AccuWeather Meteorologist Andrew Kienzle. \"This feature will need to be watched for possible impacts on the Gulf coasts of the United States and Mexico this weekend into early next week.\"", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8185903840", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "20:15:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T20:15:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T20:14:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/science-environment/2988634-tropical-storm-alberto-unleashes-chaos-across-gulf-coast", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto Unleashes Chaos Across Gulf Coast | Science-Environment", "body": "Tropical Storm Alberto, the first named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, has formed in the Gulf of Mexico. It brings torrential rains, coastal flooding, and strong winds across northeastern Mexico and southern Texas. The storm is predicted to dissipate by Thursday, with possible intensification into a Category 1 hurricane.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto, the first named storm of 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, has formed over the western Gulf of Mexico, the U.S. National Hurricane Center (NHC) said on Wednesday, bringing coastal flooding across the southern U.S. coast. The \"very large\" storm was located about 180 miles (290 km) east of Tampico, Mexico, packing maximum sustained winds of 40 mph (65 kph), the Miami-based forecaster said.\n\nAlberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico as early as Thursday night, after bringing torrential rainfall, coastal flooding and strong winds from the center along north-eastern Mexico and the south Texas coast. The NHC warned of likely \"life-threatening flooding and mudslides\" across north-eastern Mexico, including Monterrey, Mexico's third-biggest city in Nuevo Leon state.\n\n\"We don't rule out that Tropical Storm Alberto could intensify to a Category 1 hurricane\", Alejandra Mendez, who heads Mexico's SMN national meteorological service, told a news conference, citing water temperatures above 31\u00b0C (88\u00b0F). Hurricanes have sustained wind speeds of at least 119 kph.\n\nMendez added the storm was interacting with formations in the Pacific, which will together bring rains over large parts of Central America, a region that is still facing strong rainfall that left some 11 people dead in El Salvador over the weekend, due to landslides and road accidents. The storm has gathered up humidity from both the Gulf and the Pacific Ocean, Mendez said, and should bring much-needed rain over swathes of Mexico, which has suffered from an extended drought that has drained the country's dams.\n\nSome dams, especially in the north-eastern Tamaulipas state, are as little as 8% full. Nuevo Leon state Governor Samuel Garcia said people should avoid leaving the house when it is raining and workers were ready to address possible impacts on the electricity grid, water and sewage systems.\n\nIn the United States as far as Louisiana, videos showed flooded coastal towns and water smashing into sea walls, while in Tamaulipas, videos shared on social media showed ominous gray skies as forecasters warned Alberto could bring waves as high as 20 feet (6 meters). Across the Gulf on Mexico's Yucatan peninsula, local news outlets filmed strong winds and heavy rainfall, after authorities recorded as much as 192 millimeters in the last day.\n\nThe NHC predicted \"moderate coastal flooding\" along much of the Texan coast through Thursday, while Mexican forecasters expect further weekend rains in the south from another formation over the Caribbean. Forecasters have warned that this year's Atlantic hurricane season will likely be highly active due to impacts from the La Nina weather pattern and warmer ocean waters.\n\n(This story has not been It could become a tropical depression over the weekend, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe next named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season will be Beryl.\n\nSpecial note on the NHC cone: The forecast track shows the most likely path of the center of the storm. It does not illustrate the full width of the storm or its impacts, and the center of the storm is likely to travel outside the cone up to 33% of the time.\n\nSpecial note about spaghetti models: Illustrations include an array of forecast tools and models, and not all are created equal. The hurricane center uses only the top four or five highest performing models to help make its forecasts.\n\nWhat is out there and how likely are they to strengthen?\n\nInvest 92L: A small area of low pressure located about 150 miles east of the northernmost Bahamas continues to produce disorganized showers and thunderstorms.\n\nWhile environmental conditions are only marginally conducive due to nearby dry air, further development of this system could lead to the development of a tropical depression while the low moves west-northwest at 10 to 15 mph and approaches the northeastern coast of Florida or the Georgia coast early on Friday.\n\nAn Air Force Reserve reconnaissance aircraft is scheduled to investigate this system this afternoon, if necessary.\n\nSouthwestern Gulf of Mexico: A broad area of low pressure is forecast to form over southeastern Mexico and northern Central America on Friday.\n\nEnvironmental conditions appear conducive for gradual development after this system moves over the Bay of Campeche on Saturday, and a tropical depression could form over the southwestern Gulf of Mexico thisweekend while it moves slowly west-northwest or northwest.\n\nWho is likely to be impacted?\n\nInvest 92L: \"Regardless of development, this feature can bring high seas, gusty winds and areas of heavy rain and thunderstorms to the Southeast coast,\" said Kienzle.\n\nFrom late Thursday to Saturday, 1-2 inches of rain can generally fall along the Southeast coastal regions, particularly across southeastern Georgia.\n\nSouthwestern Gulf of Mexico: This system could become a tropical depression over the southwestern Gulf of Mexico over the weekend as it moves slowly west-northwest or northwest, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"There is a moderate chance for development from June 21-23 across a similar area in the Gulf of Mexico,\" according to AccuWeather.\n\n\"This feature will need to be watched for possible impacts on the Gulf coasts of the United States and Mexico this weekend into early next week,\" Kienzle said.\n\nForecasters urge all residents to continue monitoring the tropics and to always be prepared. That advice is particularly important for what is expected to be a very active hurricane season.\n\nThe Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 through Nov. 30.\n\nWhen is the peak of hurricane season?\n\nThe peak of the season is Sept. 10, with the most activity happening between mid-August and mid-October, according to the Hurricane Center.\n\nNational Hurricane Center map: What are forecasters watching now?\n\nSystems currently being monitored by the National Hurricane Center include:\n\nInteractive map: Hurricanes, tropical storms that have passed near your city\n\nWe will continue to update our tropical weather coverage daily. {"uri": "8185538234", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:08:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:08:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:07:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.live5news.com/2024/06/19/first-alert-tropical-storm-alberto-forms-gulf-mexico/", "title": "FIRST ALERT: Tropical Storm Alberto forms in Gulf of Mexico", "body": "CHARLESTON, S.C. (WCSC) - Tropical Storm Alberto has formed in the Gulf of Mexico, becoming the first named storm of this year's Atlantic hurricane season.\n\nWATCH OUR HURRICANE SPECIAL: 'Ahead of the storm': Hurricane Season 2024\n\nAt 11 a.m., Alberto was located about 295 miles south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas; and about 185 miles east of Tamplico, Mexico. It has maximum sustained winds of 40 mph, and was moving to the west at 9 mph.\n\nOn the forecast track, the center of Alberto will reach the coast of northeastern Mexico early Thursday morning.\n\nA Tropical Storm Warning is in effect for the Texas coast from San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande; and the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Puerto de Altamira.\n\nIt was expected to bring heavy rains, coastal flooding and gusty winds to the coasts of Texas and Northeastern Mexico through Thursday.\n\nA Tropical Storm Warning means that tropical storm conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area.\n\nThe entire South Carolina coast is under a high risk of rip currents through Wednesday night. The risk extends from Georgia through South Carolina and into Coastal Pinder and Coastal New Hanover Counties in North Carolina from 8 a.m. into the evening.\n\nClick here to download the free Live 5 First Alert Weather app.\n\nLive 5 First Alert Meteorologist Joey Sovine says Wednesday should be considered a \"no-swim day\" because of the heightened risk of rip currents.\n\nRip currents can pose a life-threatening risk by sweeping even the best swimmers away from shore and into deeper water.\n\nIf you must go into the water, swim near a lifeguard. If you are caught in a rip current, relax and float: Do not swim against the current. If you are able, swim in a direction following the shoreline. If you are unable to escape, face the shore and call or wave for help.\n\nBut because some beaches do not have lifeguards and because of the higher risk, lifeguards on duty could potentially be working to help someone else.\n\nAn area closer to the Lowcountry, however, has a lower chance of tropical development. A group of thunderstorms located several hundred miles east of the Bahamas is associated with a surface trough of low pressure.\n\nIts chances of development into a tropical depression over the next seven days remain at just 20% as it slowly moves toward the southeastern United States.\n\nLive 5 First Alert Meteorologist Joey Sovine says the chance of showers by the end of the week could increase as the system moves closer to the coast, even if it does not take on tropical characteristics.\n\nHurricane season began on June 1 and continues through Nov. 30.\n\nLast month, the National Hurricane Center released what it called the most active pre-season forecast in the agency's history, which calls for a \"hyperactive\" season.\n\nThe official forecast calls for between 17 and 25 named storms, with between eight and 13 reaching hurricane status. {"uri": "8183332935", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "09:48:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T09:48:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T09:48:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://bocanewsnow.com/2024/06/18/first-tropical-storm-warning-of-the-season-issued/", "title": "First Tropical Storm Warning Of The Season Issued - BocaNewsNow.com", "body": "Texas Is Front And Center As System Still Developing Off Florida Coast.\n\nBOCA RATON, FL (BocaNewsNow.com) (Copyright \u00a9 2024 MetroDesk Media, LLC) -- The first Tropical Storm Warning is now on the books and it's Texas with the honors. The system identified early Tuesday as \"potential tropical cyclone one\" is growing in the Gulf, and right now it is set to make landfall on the western Gulf of Mexico coast. While that forms, there is another system to our east that is being watched by the National Hurricane Center. For now, there's nothing to worry about. But forecasters have predicted an extremely active hurricane season, and just a few weeks into the season, it's already shaping up to be busy.\n\nThis is the early Tuesday morning advisory from the National Hurricane Center:\n\nBULLETIN Potential Tropical Cyclone One Advisory Number 3 NWS National Hurricane Center Miami FL AL012024 400 AM CDT Tue Jun 18 2024\n\n... TROPICAL STORM WARNING ISSUED FOR A PORTION OF THE WESTERN GULF OF MEXICO COAST...\n\nSUMMARY OF 400 AM CDT...0900 UTC... INFORMATION -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- - LOCATION...21.3N 93.0W ABOUT 350 MI...565 KM ESE OF LA PESCA MEXICO ABOUT 420 MI...680 KM SE OF BROWNSVILLE TEXAS MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS...40 MPH...65 KM/H PRESENT MOVEMENT... N OR 360 DEGREES AT 6 MPH...9 KM/H MINIMUM CENTRAL PRESSURE...999 MB...29.50 INCHES\n\nWATCHES AND WARNINGS -- -- -- -- -- -- - CHANGES WITH THIS ADVISORY:\n\nThe Tropical Storm Watch for the Texas coast from Port O'Connor southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande has been changed to a Tropical Storm Warning.\n\nA Tropical Storm Warning means that tropical storm conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area within 36 hours.\n\nA Tropical Storm Watch means that tropical storm conditions are possible within the watch area, generally within 48 hours.\n\nFor storm information specific to your area in the United States, including possible inland watches and warnings, please monitor products issued by your local National Weather Service forecast office. For storm information specific to your area outside of the United States, please monitor products issued by your national meteorological service.\n\nDISCUSSION AND OUTLOOK -- -- -- -- -- -- -- - At 400 AM CDT (0900 UTC), the disturbance was centered near latitude 21.3 North, longitude 93.0 West. The system is moving toward the north near 6 mph (9 km/h). A gradual turn toward the west-northwest and west is expected is expected tonight and Wednesday, and the system is likely to approach the western Gulf coast late Wednesday.\n\nMaximum sustained winds remain near 40 mph (65 km/h) with higher gusts. Some increase in strength is likely during the next 36 hours, and the disturbance is forecast to become a tropical storm by Wednesday.\n\nThe disturbance is quite large with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 290 miles (465 km) to the northeast of the center.\n\nThe estimated minimum central pressure is 999 mb (29.50 inches).\n\nHAZARDS AFFECTING LAND -- -- -- -- -- -- -- - Key messages for Potential Tropical Cyclone One can be found in the Tropical Cyclone Discussion under AWIPS header MIATCDAT1 and WMO header WTNT41 KNHC.\n\nRAINFALL: Potential Tropical Cyclone One is expected to produce rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South Texas, with maximum totals of 15 inches possible. This rainfall will likely produce flash and urban flooding along with new and renewed river flooding. Mudslides are also possible in areas of higher terrain across northeast Mexico.\n\nFor a complete depiction of forecast rainfall and flash flooding associated with Potential Tropical Cyclone One, please see the National Weather Service Storm Total Rainfall Graphic, available at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at1.shtml? rainqpf and the Flash Flood Risk graphic at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at1.shtml? ero\n\nSTORM SURGE: The combination of a dangerous storm surge and the tide will cause normally dry areas near the coast to be flooded by rising waters moving inland from the shoreline. The water could reach the following heights above ground somewhere in the indicated areas if the peak surge occurs at the time of high tide...\n\nSargent, TX to Sabine Pass, TX...2-4 ft Galveston Bay...2-4 ft Mouth of the Rio Grande, TX to Sargent, TX...1-3 ft Sabine Pass, TX to Vermilion/Cameron Parish Line, LA...1-3 ft\n\nThe deepest water will occur along the immediate coast near and to the north of the landfall location, where the surge will be accompanied by large and dangerous waves. Surge-related flooding depends on the relative timing of the surge and the tidal cycle, and can vary greatly over short distances. For information specific to your area, please see products issued by your local National Weather Service forecast office.\n\nFor a complete depiction of areas at risk of storm surge inundation, please see the National Weather Service Peak Storm Surge Graphic, available at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at1.shtml? peakSurge.\n\nIn Mexico, minor coastal flooding is possible north of where the center of the system crosses the coast in areas of onshore winds.\n\nWIND: Tropical storm conditions are expected within the warning area by Wednesday.", "source": {"uri": "bocanewsnow.com", "dataType": "news", It had top sustained winds of 40 mph, according to the National Hurricane Center in Miami. A tropical storm is defined by sustained winds of between 39 and 73 mph, and above that the system becomes a hurricane.The storm was moving west at 9 mph.The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicts the hurricane season that began June 1 and runs through Nov. 30 is likely to be well above average, with between 17 and 25 named storms. The forecast calls for as many as 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes.An average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.A no-name storm earlier in June dumped more than 20 inches of rain on parts of South Florida, stranding numerous motorists on flooded streets and pushing water into some homes in low-lying areas.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto formed on Wednesday in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, the first named storm of what is forecast to be a busy hurricane season.\n\nVideo above: 2024 hurricane season expected to be one for the record books\n\nAlberto was located 185 miles east of Tampico, Mexico and 295 miles south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas. It had top sustained winds of 40 mph, according to the National Hurricane Center in Miami. Emiliano Rodr\u00edguez Mega reported from Mexico City.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto, the first named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season, brought intense rain and coastal flooding to parts of Texas and northeastern Mexico on Wednesday, hours before it was expected to make landfall.\n\nOfficials in Mexico were monitoring the levels of dams, rivers and streams and were also cleaning drainage points to prevent potential flooding.\n\nIn Texas, officials warned of flooded roads in the Houston area early Wednesday afternoon. The tide was rushing beneath the elevated houses in some coastal cities, such as Surfside Beach, about 40 miles south of Galveston, by Wednesday morning. The city closed its beach earlier this week and warned visitors to stay away as the flooding worsened.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center warned that Alberto was a large storm, with tropical-force winds extending about 415 miles north of its center in the Gulf of Mexico as it moved west toward northeastern Mexico. The storm had maximum sustained winds of 40 miles per hour, but the main concern was rainfall of a foot or more that was predicted for parts of Texas and Mexico. Tropical storm warnings were issued for coastal areas on both sides of the border.\n\nForecasters predicted that Alberto could make landfall early Thursday near the Mexican city of Tampico, but its effects were expected to extend far beyond that.\n\nMayor Gregg Bisso of Surfside Beach said that while the flooding was slowly easing there on Wednesday evening, the city was bracing for things to intensify at any moment, as they did when Hurricane Nicholas slammed into the city in 2021, causing major damage.", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Times"}, And near Florida, a disturbance set to bring more rain to the state appears to be weakening.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center is tracking the tropical system, which is projected to beeline straight into Mexico -- potentially as Tropical Storm Alberto -- late Wednesday night. This has prompted tropical storm warnings in Mexico and tropical storm watches in Texas.\n\nBut there's a chance the struggling system could fail to organize, the hurricane center warned. Either way, it's expected to bring an intense amount of rain to the region, with inches falling as far as Louisiana. The hardest hit spots could see up to 15 inches of rain.\n\nAs of 8 a.m. Tuesday, the system maintained its tropical-storm-strength 40 mph sustained winds but failed to organize overnight.\n\n\"Since the system still lacks a well-defined center it will continue to be designated as a potential tropical cyclone,\" the hurricane center said.\n\nThe hurricane center is also watching two disturbances, one near Florida. The system -- a disorganized collection of thunderstorms -- appeared to be weaker on Tuesday morning than it was the day before.\n\nForecasters lowered its chances of strengthening from 30% in the next week to 20% but said the system still had a chance of gradually developing in the next few days as it nudges away from the Bahamas and nears the U.S. East Coast.\n\nThe system could provide an extra boost of moisture in the air when it is closest to Florida, potentially adding a little more rain to the usual afternoon showers later in the week.\n\nMonday night, the hurricane center also started watching a second disturbance in the same area as the potential tropical cyclone near Texas. {"uri": "8185584371", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:40:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:40:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:39:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://wgno.com/weather/tracking-the-tropics/tropical-storm-alberto-forms-in-gulf-heres-the-latest-track-and-potential-impacts/", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto forms in Gulf. Here's the latest track and potential impacts.", "body": "NEW ORLEANS (WGNO) -- Tropical Storm Alberto has become the first named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, which is expected to be above normal due to anticipated La Ni\u00f1a conditions and warm sea surface temperatures.\n\nAn U.S. Air Force Reserve reconnaissance aircraft and a NOAA buoy confirmed Alberto's well-defined center of circulation and increasing storm activity near the center, leading to its classification as a tropical storm. Alberto currently has sustained winds of 40 mph and a central pressure of 995 millibars.\n\nAlberto is moving westward at 9 mph and is expected to continue this path, reaching northeastern Mexico by Thursday morning. The storm may strengthen slightly, with a peak intensity of around 45 mph before landfall. Rapid weakening is forecast after landfall, with the storm likely dissipating over Mexico's mountainous terrain by Friday.\n\nRegardless of its exact track, Alberto is expected to bring heavy rainfall, moderate coastal flooding, and tropical-storm-force winds to areas far from its center. Tropical storm conditions are expected today along portions of the Texas coast south of San Luis Pass and along parts of northeastern Mexico within the Tropical Storm Warning area.\n\nHeavy rainfall is anticipated to affect large regions of Central America, northeastern Mexico, and South Texas. For Louisiana and Mississippi, isolated to scattered heavy downpours are possible as Alberto's outer bands move across the region. Any storms that develop are expected to be brief.\n\nA Wind Advisory is in effect for southeast Louisiana, including areas south of the I-12 corridor, near area tidal lakes and along the coast.\n\nExpect strong east winds of 20 to 25 mph, with gusts up to 40 mph possible, from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Wednesday. The National Weather Service recommends securing any loose items and reminds residents to be cautious when travelling, especially in high profile vehicles.\n\nModerate coastal flooding is likely along much of the coasts of Mississippi, Louisiana, Texas, and Mexico through Thursday. Forecasters said the future Tropical Storm Alberto will bring heavy rainfall, coastal flooding and gusty winds to the coasts of Texas and northeastern Mexico through Thursday.\n\nORLANDO, Fla. - The National Hurricane Center is monitoring a disturbance in the Atlantic Ocean that could impact Florida this week.\n\nFormation likely isn't in the cards, however. Forecasters said there's a 20% chance of formation in the next week, which is less than Tuesday's 30% prediction.\n\n\"It's not expected to develop into anything other than a very weak low pressure area,\" FOX 35 Storm Team Meteorologist Jessica Dobson said.\n\nWEDNESDAY FORECAST: Breezy day with scattered showers expected across Central Florida\n\nDespite this, the area of showers and thunderstorms currently east of the Bahamas is expected to bring some showers and winds to the Florida coast as it approaches the southeast U.S. in the second half of this week, according to the National Weather Service office in Melbourne.\n\nOn Wednesday, windy conditions are expected to move onshore, and there's a possibility of a few lightning storms in the afternoon, the NWS added.\n\nAt the beach, forecasters said to expect large breaking waves and a high risk of rip currents.\n\n\"Entering the waters is strongly discouraged,\" the NWS said.\n\nThis isn't the only thing the National Hurricane Center is keeping an eye on. Potential Tropical Cyclone One, which is expected to become Tropical Storm Alberto later on Wednesday, is currently located in the Gulf of Mexico. {"uri": "8185534447", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:06:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:06:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:04:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/weather/2024/06/19/tropical-rainstorm-texas-surge-flooding/", "title": "Tropical rainstorm lashing South Texas with flooding, strong winds, ocean surge", "body": "While approaching the coast of northeast Mexico, the potential tropical storm was pushing a surge of ocean water ashore, leading to coastal flooding along the southern Texas coast early Wednesday.\n\nForecasters at the National Hurricane Center said the peak storm surge could reach up to 2 to 4 feet, including around Galveston Bay.\n\nFlood watches blanket South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley, and stretch along the coastline to Cameron Parish, La. The alerts no longer include Houston, since the heaviest rains should stay primarily south of the metro.\n\nA tropical storm warning does, however, cover coastal counties from just south of Galveston to the U.S.-Mexico border, and incudes Rockport, Corpus Christi and Brownsville. While the system may not organize enough to earn the name Alberto, tropical storm-force winds with 50-mph gusts are still probable along the shoreline.\n\nRockport was gusting to 36 mph around 7 a.m. Central time, and Padre Island to 39 mph. Rainfall totals have been light thus far, with Brownsville leading the pack at 0.95 inches. That said, the core of the deep tropical moisture, and subsequent downpours, will soon arrive.\n\nAs of 7 a.m. Central time, Potential Tropical Cyclone 1 -- the designation used by the National Hurricane Center to describe a system that is bringing tropical storm effects without having the requisite structure for a name -- was centered just under 300 miles southeast of Brownsville. It was moving west-northwest at 8 mph.\n\nThe system may not become a tropical storm. Instead, a broad swirl of disturbed weather, including showers and thunderstorms, is present across the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, the western Caribbean Sea and Central America. Initially it was believed that some of the more diffuse circulation would tighten up in the Bay of Campeche and become a tropical storm that would hit Mexico.\n\nSatellite and aircraft observations do indicate that the broader low-pressure system is in the process of developing a more well-defined center of circulation. Shower and thunderstorm activity hasn't filled in around that nascent center, however.\n\nScattered downpours were pivoting ashore in South Texas, and will become more numerous and intense as the day wears on. The heaviest rains will last from noon to midnight in southern regions, and probably won't make it much north of San Antonio or Victoria.\n\nA widespread 4 to 8 inches is likely in South Texas, with localized totals over 10 inches possible. Downpours will taper to intermittent showers by early Thursday.\n\nA near record-moist air mass will be in place, allowing for intense rainfall rates. A weather balloon launched Wednesday morning from Brownsville recorded 2.78 inches of moisture present from the bottom to the top of the atmosphere. That's just shy of the 2.93-inch record set on July 17, 1996.\n\nSome of the storm's most serious flooding is probable in northeast Mexico and Central America.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding and mudslides are likely in and near areas of higher terrain across the Mexican states of Coahuila, Nuevo Leon, and Tamaulipas, including the cities of Monterrey and Ciudad Victoria,\" the Hurricane Center wrote.\n\nHowever, some of the rainfall in Mexico will be quite beneficial, as the area has been enduring serious drought.\n\nRains from a large, swirling area of showers and thunderstorms across the southwest Gulf of Mexico and Central America, known as the Central American Gyre, have produced disastrous flooding in parts Guatemala and El Salvador, causing at least 14 fatalities, according to the Associated Press. This same gyre spawned the potential tropical storm heading into Mexico and could give rise another in the Gulf of Mexico next week.\n\nIt's still looking like 40- to 50-mph gusts will be possible along the immediate coastline from Houston-Galveston southward, with lesser but still blustery winds expected inland.\n\nThe onshore flow will push water against the coast, leading to a surge of up to 2 to 4 feet in the most prone areas and 1 to 3 feet elsewhere. Because of the system's sprawling circulation, the surge was forecast to affect areas hundreds of miles from its center, as far away as the western shore of Louisiana.\n\nWith landfalling tropical cyclones and disturbances, sporadic tornadoes sometimes occur ahead, and to the right, of the center. Since South Texas will be in the \"front right quadrant\" of the system, a subtle change of low-level winds with height, known as wind shear, could support an isolated tornado risk.\n\nThe National Weather Service Storm Prediction Center has advertised a Level 1 out of 5 Marginal risk for severe weather.", "source": {"uri": "washingtonpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Post"}, Meanwhile, the season's first named storm, Tropical Storm Alberto, was drenching Mexico and Texas as it moved inland.\n\nThe Atlantic system as of the NHC's 8 a.m. tropical outlook remains a small area of low pressure located about 150 miles east of the northernmost Bahamas with disorganized shower and thunderstorm activity.\n\n\"While environmental conditions are only marginally conducive due to nearby dry air, further development of this system could lead to the development of a tropical depression while the low moves west-northwestward at 10 to 15 mph and approaches the northeastern coast of Florida or the Georgia coastearly on Friday,\" said NHC Warning Coordination Meteorologist Robbie Berg.\n\nAn Air Force Reserve reconnaissance aircraft is slated to fly out to the system in the afternoon.\n\nThe NHC gives it a 40% chance of development in the next two to seven days.\n\nThe National Weather Service issued a high surf advisory that runs into Friday with breaking waves of 5 to 7 feet in the surf zone with a high rip current risk along coastal Central and Northeast Florida beaches.\n\n\"Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water,\" warned the NWS.\n\nErosion will be greatest at high tide around 7 p.m. and 7 a.m., the NWS stated. Volusia County beaches are still recovering from major washout that occurred during both Hurricane Ian and Hurricane Nicole in 2022.\n\nThe NWS also has a small craft advisory in place from Jupiter Inlet north to the Altamaha Sound, Georgia that runs through late Friday for northeast Florida and through Friday morning for Central Florida.\n\nWaves of 7 to 10 feet are expected offshore with 25-30 mph winds and gusts up to 35 mph farther north along Florida's coast.\n\nRain chances are highest in Brevard and Volusia counties in Central Florida as the low approaches with some thunderstorm activity, the NWS stated.\n\nAs far as Tropical Storm Alberto goes, the system gained some wind speed as it dumped rainfall over Mexico and Texas.\n\nIn its 8 a.m. advisory, the center of Alberto was located inland about 25 miles west of Tampico, Mexico and 255 miles south of Brownsville, Texas with sustained winds of 45 mph moving west at 13 mph.\n\nA tropical storm warning remains in effect for the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande down to Tecolutla, but the system is expected to weaken as it moves further inland and dissipate by Thursday night.\n\nTropical-storm-force winds extend out 250 miles from the center and rainfall of 5 to 10 inches is expected with some areas in higher terrain of inland Mexico getting up to 20 inches, although rain in Texas is dropping off quickly with only another 1 inch expected in some southern parts of the state.\n\nThe NHC still warns that there could be some tornado activity across the most southern portions of Texas on Thursday.\n\nThe NHC is also tracking a broad area of low pressure that is forecast to form over southeastern Mexico and northern Central America on Friday.\n\n\"Environmental conditions appear conducive for gradual development after this system moves over the Bay of Campeche on Saturday, and a tropicaldepression could form over the southwestern Gulf of Mexico this weekend while it moves slowly west-northwestward or northwestward,\" forecasters said.\n\nThe NHC gives it a 20% chance of formation over the next two days and 50% in the next {"uri": "8185537901", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:09:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:09:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:07:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/science-environment/2988365-tropical-storm-alberto-kicks-off-2024-atlantic-hurricane-season", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto Kicks Off 2024 Atlantic Hurricane Season | Science-Environment", "body": "Tropical Storm Alberto, the first named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, has formed over the Western Gulf of Mexico. Located approximately 185 miles east of Tampico, Mexico, the storm has maximum sustained winds of 40 mph. It is expected to dissipate over Mexico by Thursday night.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto, the first named storm of 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, has formed over the Western Gulf of Mexico, the U.S. National Hurricane Center said on Wednesday.\n\nThe storm was located about 185 miles (300 km) east of Tampico, Mexico, packing maximum sustained winds of 40 mph (65 kph), the Miami-based forecaster {"uri": "2024-06-395758605", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:37:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:37:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T09:55:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/first-named-storm-forms-in-gulf/article_1085fe9b-3378-5fb2-a43c-e93313b41a91.html", "title": "First named storm forms in Gulf", "body": "JAMIE STENGLE AND MARIANA MART\u00cdNEZ BARBA\n\nAssociated Press\n\nTROPICAL WEATHER\n\nMEXICO CITY -- Tropical Storm Alberto formed Wednesday in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, the first named storm of what is forecast to be a busy hurricane season.\n\nAlberto, which is bringing strong winds, heavy rainfall and some flooding along the coasts of Texas and Mexico, is expected to make landfall in northern Mexico on Thursday. \"The heavy rainfall and the water, as usual, is the biggest story in tropical storms,\" said Michael Brennan, director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Hurricane Center.\n\nAlberto was 185 miles east of Tampico, Mexico and 295 miles south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas. It had top sustained winds of 40 mph, according to the National Hurricane Center in Miami. A tropical storm is defined by sustained winds of between 39 and 73 mph, and above that the system becomes a hurricane.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nIowa DCI: Wall Lake trucker David Schultz's death 'not a homicide' Jefferson, S.D. dad shares secret to fatherhood on Father's Day celebration Lost and found: How Arnolds Park got a miniature train back after more than 50 years Perley to step down as Thompson CEO; Beaulieu to take over Man dies in standoff with authorities in Sac County Former Sioux City hotel under renovation, to become high-rise senior housing this year Omaha ballpark seeks to ban two Texas A&M fans who were kicked out of College World Series game Tyson Foods heir suspended as CFO after second alcohol-related arrest Boat speed rule imposed on Okoboji lakes in wake of heavy rains, storms that also led to wastewater discharges Sioux City man pleads not guilty of manslaughter Our Opinion: WITCC settlement in human trafficking case raises more questions Marriage licenses for Woodbury County for June 17, 2024 Chainsaw sculptures among latest upgrades to Sioux City's historic Hubbard Park Top area softball performers: RSM last unbeaten team; Mentzer, Moreau swinging hot bats Man pleads not guilty in Sioux City fatal hit and run\n\nBrennan said that winds could get up to 45 mph to 50 mph before the storm makes landfall. As much as 5-10 inches of rain was expected in some areas along the Texas coast, with even higher isolated totals possible, Brennan said. He said some higher locations in Mexico could see as much as 20 inches of rain, which could result in mudslides and flash flooding, especially in the states of Tamaulipas, Coahuila and Nuevo Leon.\n\nThe U.S. National Weather Service said the main hazard for southern coastal Texas is flooding from excess rain. On Wednesday, the NWS said, there is \"a high probability\" of flash flooding in southern coastal Texas. Tornadoes or waterspouts are possible.\n\nNOAA predicts the hurricane season that began June 1 and runs through Nov. 30 is likely to be well above average, with between 17 and 25 named storms. The forecast calls for as many as 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes.\n\nAn average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.\n\nBrennan said the first named system in the Atlantic on average comes on June 20, so Alberto is \"about right on schedule.\"\n\nA no-name storm earlier in June dumped more than 20 inches of rain on parts of south Florida, stranding motorists on flooded streets and pushing water into some homes in low-lying areas.\n\nLove\n\n0\n\nFunny\n\n0\n\nWow\n\n0\n\nSad\n\n0\n\nAngry\n\n0\n\nBe {"uri": "8185144065", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "10:47:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T10:47:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T10:46:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/tropical-storm-texas-extreme-heat-wave-northeast-rcna157893", "title": "First tropical storm of the season heads for Texas as extreme heat wave hits the Northeast", "body": "The weather system is expected to be upgraded and renamed Tropical Storm Alberto by the time it makes landfall in Mexico early Thursday.\n\nThe United States was buffeted by extreme weather on Wednesday, with Texas braced for the first tropical storm of the hurricane season while the Northeast still faced a major heat wave.\n\nSouthern Texas is braced for a major storm to hit late Wednesday into Thursday, with considerable flash flooding likely, according to forecasters.\n\nThe weather system, currently named Potential Tropical Cyclone One, is expected to be upgraded and renamed Tropical Storm Alberto by the time it makes landfall on the Gulf coast of Mexico early Thursday.\n\nTropical storm warnings are in place along the Texas coast from the San Luis Pass to the mouth of the Rio Grande, with high winds and as much as 10 to 15 inches of rain expected in Corpus Christi. The state government enacted a large-scale emergency response in anticipation of widespread flooding.\n\nThe National Weather Center office in Houston said at 4:30 a.m. CT (5.:30 a.m. ET) that there had already been reports of coastal flooding as rain moves inland.\n\n\"The disturbance is very large, with rainfall, coastal flooding and wind impacts likely to occur far from the center along the coasts of Texas and northeastern Mexico, \" the National Hurricane Center said in an update.\n\nThe NHC also said early Wednesday that life-threatening mudslides were likely in higher areas of northern Mexico, including around the cities of Monterrey and Ciudad Victoria.\n\nOn Tuesday night, Texas gov. Greg Abbott ordered the state's division of emergency management to put the Texas State Emergency Operations Center to a readiness of level 2, meaning it began 24-hour operations.\n\n\"As we prepare for severe tropical weather, Texas is activating all personnel and resources needed to support Texans and communities that will be potentially impacted by excessive rain and flooding,\" he said in a statement.\n\nThe Texas A&M Forest Service has mobilized four teams comprising of 100 personnel and 24 vehicles, while the Texas National Guard has three platoons of more than 40 personnel in total, alongside 20 vehicles, including Chinook helicopters.\n\nThe NWS told people in affected areas to have five to seven days' of food, water and other necessary supplies.\n\nThe storm warning came as 71 million people were under some form of heat advisory or warning Wednesday, as a severe heat wave is set to last through Friday.\n\nSeveral parts of the Midwest, Interior Northeast and New England could reach temperatures of 95 degrees or above on Wednesday, with Bangor, Maine, set to hit 106 on the heat index, a measure of how hot it feels that factors in humidity.\n\nNBC News meteorologist Michelle Grossman warned early Wednesday that extreme heat is not to be taken lightly.\n\n\"It is dangerous -- extreme heat is the number one weather-related killer so you need to take it seriously,\" she said.\n\n\"If you don't have air conditioning, you need to find places, libraries, movies, a cooling center that will keep you cool and comfortable over the next several days,\" Grossman added.\n\nPeople in Syracuse, New York, were warned Tuesday not to open fire hydrants to get some relief from the heat. Fire Chief Michael Monds said in a statement that opening hydrants can affect firefighters' ability to tackle fires and to do so is a civil penalty that comes with a potential $500 fine.", "source": {"uri": "8183761096", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "14:17:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T14:17:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T14:16:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.foxweather.com/weather-news/bryan-norcross-warnings-issued-possible-tropical-storm-alberto-gulf", "title": "Bryan Norcross: Warnings are issued for possible Tropical Storm Alberto in the Gulf", "body": "The FOX Forecast Center is tracking Potential Tropical Cyclone 1 in the Gulf of Mexico that's expected to make landfall in Mexico, but the storm's impacts will reach as far as Texas and Louisiana. As a result, Tropical Storm Warnings were issued for the Texas coast on Tuesday morning.\n\nWinds over 40 mph are already blowing across the Gulf of Mexico. If the system in the southern Gulf can develop a well-defined center, the low-pressure area will be named Tropical Storm Alberto, but it has a lot of consolidating to do. Currently, the center of the giant circulation is just a broad area with light winds. It's hard to even tell where the center is.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center has designated this system Potential Tropical Cyclone One, for now. The word \"cyclone\" is confusing every time this naming convention comes around. Substitute the word \"threat,\" and it's clear - the system is a potential tropical threat.\n\nThis low is the same super-broad area of low pressure that straddled Central America for days. Now, it has eased north into the Gulf. Normally, it takes quite a while for big lumbering systems to tighten up a smaller circulation. In this case, however, there is an embedded swirl that might take over and hasten the process. The swirl is what's left of a weak disturbance that moved across the Caribbean.\n\nThis situation is an extreme case of the cone being almost wholly disassociated from the worst weather. Whether this system consolidates or not, the impact zone will extend hundreds of miles north of the cone across northern Mexico and Texas. Even Louisiana may feel the effects.\n\nThe strong winds across the northern and central Gulf are caused by the air being squeezed between the low pressure of potential Alberto and the heat-dome high-pressure system over the Northeast US. The blocking effect of the high will also deflect the center of potential Alberto toward the Mexican coast and limit how far north it can get. The high heat risk in the Midwest and Northeast shows the effects of the heat-dome high there.\n\nWaves of tropical rain will begin Tuesday on the Texas coast. As we saw in South Florida just over a week ago, the flooding doesn't start right away. Then all of a sudden, blam! Stay aware in all of coastal Texas including metro Houston. South Texas has an \"advantage\" because it's been in drought. There is more room for the water to soak in, but flash flooding is still possible.\n\nStorm surge is likely at the coast. The strong and persistent onshore winds are pushing Gulf water against the shoreline. The forecast is for the surge to reach up to 4 feet above normal high tide level in some areas, especially in bays and harbors open to the Gulf. Coastal and marine interests should stay informed and take action.\n\nImpacts from potential Alberto are forecast to peak Wednesday into Thursday, and let up by Thursday evening.\n\nUnfortunately, there is increasing computer-forecast consensus that some version of this scenario will repeat itself over the weekend. By then, the heat-dome high will have changed configuration into the Atlantic, so the steering pattern could be different.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center has introduced a potential development area in the southern Gulf. The chances of development are in the low category for now, but it's early in the process, and there is always a lot of uncertainty.\n\nDon't look at any particular computer forecast at this point. There is no system to follow yet, and there may never be. But everyone in coastal Texas, Louisiana, and Mississippi should plan to stay in touch with the forecasts later in the week.\n\nWe're calling this possible Gulf system Potential Disturbance #3.\n\nIn the Atlantic, a low-pressure area is still trying to develop from the old front that was part of the Florida deluge - Disturbance #2. There is no indication it could get very strong, and it might not even be tropical. But the steering flow around the heat-dome high-pressure system to the north should eventually push it toward Florida or the Southeast coast.\n\nWhatever form it takes, it's forecast to arrive at the coast about Friday. The National Hurricane Center gives it a low chance of developing into any kind of system with tropical characteristics.\n\nWhen extreme and unusual weather systems like the heat-dome high develop, quite often unusual things happen around the periphery. So we'll watch closely the developments in the Gulf of Mexico.", "source": {"uri": "foxweather.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FOX Weather"}, "authors": [{"uri": "bryan_norcross@foxweather.com",
