We manage your personal data in accordance with our privacy policy.\n\nA tropical storm warning has been issued for parts of South Texas and northeastern Mexico, bringing with it the risk of heavy rainfall and flooding.\n\nThe warning is in effect for the Texas coast from Port O'Connor south to the mouth of the Rio Grande, as well as the northeastern coast of Mexico, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"The disturbance is very large with rainfall, coastal flooding, and wind impacts likely to occur far from the center along the coasts of Texas and northeastern Mexico,\" the center said overnight.\n\nMaximum sustained winds this morning remained near 40 mph and the disturbance is forecast to become a tropical storm by Wednesday.\n\nThe system has been classified as a potential tropical cyclone by the center since it has not yet become better organized, but is expected to become the first named storm system of the year by early Wednesday.\n\nThe system was expected to disrupt ship-to-ship transfer operations off the Texas coast as of Monday evening because of heavy seas. In the Gulf of Mexico, the transfer typically is from an Aframax or Suezmax onto a very large crude carrier (VLCC) at designated lightering zones near Corpus Christi, Galveston and Beaumont-Port Arthur.\n\nProlonged lightering delays can prevent crude tanker tonnage from becoming available and exert upward pressure on freight rates, while also adding to demurrage fees.\n\nThe storm is expected to turn towards the west-northwest and west tonight and Wednesday, with the system forecast to approach the western Gulf coast late Wednesday, the NHC said.\n\nRainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches are seen across northeast Mexico into South Texas, with maximum totals of 15 inches possible. {"uri": "2024-06-393565422", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "14:09:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T14:09:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T14:02:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.sunherald.com/news/weather/article289355830.html", "title": "Tropical system strengthens on way to Mexico. And there's another disturbance behind it", "body": "The system that will likely become Tropical Storm Alberto strengthened Tuesday as it moved toward the Mexican coastline, and forecasters warned it could bring rain and minor coastal flooding to South Mississippi even though it's predicted landfall is hundreds of miles away.\n\nThe system, which is still called Potential Tropical Cyclone One, now has an 80 percent chance of becoming a tropical depression or tropical storm within 2 days, the National Hurricane Center said.\n\nForecasters also spotted another disturbance in the same area of the southwestern Gulf of Mexico but said its chance of development was much lower.\n\nAnd forecasters predicted another system would reach the southeastern coast of the United States near Florida on Friday.\n\nWhat to expect in South MS\n\nThe Mississippi Coast is not expected to feel direct impacts from any of the three systems.\n\nBut the churn from the system headed toward Mexico will likely send rain, winds and minor coastal flooding to Mississippi and Louisiana, the National Weather Service said.\n\nThe southern parts of Hancock, Harrison and Jackson counties are under a coastal flood advisory. The National Weather Service predicted minor coastal flooding, especially in the area of Shoreline Park near Bay St. Louis, until 4 p.m. Wednesday.\n\nThe impacts will be worst at high tide, which falls between 7 a.m. and 1 p.m. Wednesday, the NWS said.\n\nForecasters said parking lots and roads could flood. Few closures are expected, but water could portions of roads in Shoreline Park on Wednesday.\n\nA small craft advisory is also in place in the Mississippi Sound. The tropical system could bring winds of 20 to 25 mile per hour to Mississippi, with gusts up to 35 miles per hour, the NWS said. The small craft advisory ends 7 a.m. Thursday.\n\nWhere will system make landfall?\n\nIt is too early to tell where the system will hit land, but a predicted track shows the storm hitting the northeastern coast of Mexico.\n\nThe largest impacts will be in Mexico and south Texas, where forecasters issued a tropical storm warning.\n\nThe disturbance is a large system that will bring heavy rain, coastal flooding and wind far from its center.\n\nRain from the system could lead to flash flooding to urban areas and mudslides in parts of Mexico, the National Hurricane Center said.\n\nForecasters track two more systems\n\nThe National Hurricane Center is also tracking two separate systems in the Atlantic region.\n\nForecasters said showers currently located east of the Bahamas could gradually develop as they move west and northwest throughout the week.\n\nThe system is expected to reach the southeastern United States coast by Friday. It has only a 10 percent chance of development within two days and a 20 percent chance within the next week.\n\nForecasters also spotted a disturbance in the same area as Potential Tropical Cyclone One.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said that system is forecast to develop in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico and could gradually strengthen early next week as it moves west and northwest. The system is the first named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season this year.\n\nThe hurricane season runs from June through November, and can shut oil and gas production platforms in the Gulf of Mexico, wreak havoc on agriculture and cause significant damage to homes and roads. There could be as many as 25 named storms this season, compared with an average of 14.\n\nAlberto is a large system, with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 460 miles from the center, according to the weather agency. Rainfall of 5 to 10 inches is expected across northeast Mexico and into southern Texas. {"uri": "2024-06-395566126", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "07:56:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T07:56:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T07:51:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/world/tropical-storm-alberto-floods-texas-mexico-braces-landfall-9403643/", "title": "Tropical storm Alberto brings floods to Texas as Mexico braces for landfall", "body": "Forecasters predicted that Alberto could make landfall early Thursday near the Mexican city of Tampico, but its effects were expected to extend far beyond that.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto, the first named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season, brought intense rain and coastal flooding to parts of Texas and northeastern Mexico on Wednesday, hours before it was expected to make landfall.\n\nOfficials in Mexico were monitoring the levels of dams, rivers and streams and were also cleaning drainage points to prevent potential flooding.\n\nIn Texas, officials warned of flooded roads in the Houston area early Wednesday afternoon. The tide was rushing beneath the elevated houses in some coastal cities, such as Surfside Beach, about 40 miles south of Galveston, by Wednesday morning. The city closed its beach earlier this week and warned visitors to stay away as the flooding worsened.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center warned that Alberto was a large storm, with tropical-force winds extending about 415 miles north of its center in the Gulf of Mexico as it moved west toward northeastern Mexico. The storm had maximum sustained winds of 40 mph, but the main concern was rainfall of a foot or more that was predicted for parts of Texas and Mexico. Tropical storm warnings were issued for coastal areas on both sides of the border.\n\nAlso read | Mexico's tactic to cut immigration to the US : grind migrants down\n\nForecasters predicted that Alberto could make landfall early Thursday near the Mexican city of Tampico, but its effects were expected to extend far beyond that.\n\nAhead of the storm, Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas activated a range of emergency management resources, including high-water boats and helicopters with hoist capabilities. On Wednesday afternoon, he declared a severe-weather disaster declaration for 51 counties.\n\nThe effects of the storm were already being felt Wednesday.\n\nThere were reports of property damage on North Padre Island after coastal bulkheads collapsed from the storm surge. And on South Padre Island, officials were distributing free sandbags to businesses and residents. In Corpus Christi, at least two people were rescued and taken to higher ground after their cars became submerged in floodwaters, officials said.\n\nAlso read | Two killed and several wounded in shooting during a Juneteenth celebration in a Texas park\n\nAs Alberto approached, the National Weather Service issued a tornado warning late Wednesday night for an area of Texas along the U.S.-Mexico border that included the cities of McAllen, Mission and Pharr. Tornado warnings that were issued earlier for counties near Corpus Christi were extended. A tornado watch was in effect until 7 a.m. local time for much of Texas south of San Antonio, an area that is home to about 2.5 million people.", "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8186277464", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "03:55:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T03:55:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T03:54:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/alberto-the-first-named-tropical-storm-of-the-season-dumps-rain-on-mexico-and-texas/article_8300f2b3-eafb-5bc6-88d8-1e12f6dba427.html", "title": "Alberto, the first named tropical storm of the season, dumps rain on Mexico and Texas", "body": "TAMPICO, Mexico (AP) -- Tropical Storm Alberto formed on Wednesday in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, the first named storm of what is forecast to be a busy hurricane season.\n\nAlberto, which is bringing strong winds, heavy rainfall and some flooding along the coasts of Texas and Mexico, is expected to make landfall in northern Mexico early Thursday.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\n\"The heavy rainfall and the water, as usual, is the biggest story in tropical storms,\" said Michael Brennan, director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Hurricane Center.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said late Wednesday that Alberto was located about 135 miles (220 kilometers) east of Tampico, Mexico, and about 320 miles (510 kilometers) south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas, with maximum sustained winds of 50 mph (85 kph). The storm was moving west at 9 miles per hour.\n\nThe center of the storm was expected to reach the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande by Thursday morning.\n\nAs much as 5 inches (13 centimeters) to 10 inches (25 centimeters) of rain was expected in some areas along the Texas coast, with even higher isolated totals possible, Brennan said. He said some higher locations in Mexico could see as much as 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain, which could result in mudslides and flash flooding, especially in the states of Tamaulipas, Coahuila and Nuevo Leon.\n\nThe municipal government of Tampico, a port city in Tamaulipas state, announced Wednesday afternoon that authorities had activated a command center in coordination with the water, electricity and oil companies.\n\nMany residents were excited about the prospect of heavy showers, as Tamaulipas and most of Mexico has been dealing with extreme droughts.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"We have been needing this water that we're now getting, thank God. Let's hope that we only get water,\" said Blanca Coronel Moral, a resident of Tampico. \"Our lagoon, which gives us drinking water, is completely dry.\"\n\nTamaulipas Gov. Am\u00e9rico Villarreal said Wednesday on X that schools across the state will remain closed between Wednesday and Friday.\n\nThe coordinator of civil protection in Tamaulipas, Luis Gerardo Gonzalez, said they have 333 shelters distributed throughout the state at each municipality. \"As the storm moves, we will be opening up more shelters.\"\n\nAuthorities urged residents to be aware of the alerts the state and municipal civil protections are sharing. They anticipate the storm arriving overnight with communities closest to the coast most affected.\n\nTropical storm warnings were in effect from the Texas coast at San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande and from the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"Rapid weakening is expected once the center moves inland, and Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico\" on Thursday, the center said.\n\nThe U.S. National Weather Service said the main hazard for southern coastal Texas is flooding from excess rain. On Wednesday, the NWS said, there is \"a high probability\" of flash flooding in southern coastal Texas. Tornadoes or waterspouts are possible.\n\nNOAA predicts the hurricane season that began June 1 and runs through Nov. 30 is likely to be well above average, with between 17 and 25 named storms. The forecast calls for as many as 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes.\n\nAn average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.\n\nBrennan said there will be dangerous rip currents from the storm and drivers should watch out for road closures and turn around if they see water covering roadways.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAreas along the Texas coast were seeing some road flooding and dangerous rip currents Wednesday, and waterspouts have been spotted offshore. \"We've seen a few brief spin-ups and some waterspouts out there,\" said Tyler Castillo, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service office in Corpus Christi.\n\nTim Cady, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Houston, said they'll be keeping an eye on coastal flooding as high tide approaches Thursday morning.\n\n\"When we have these strong onshore winds combined with the high tide, that can result in coastal inundation, particularly in our lower-lying coastal areas,\" Cady said.\n\nA no-name storm earlier in June dumped more than 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain on parts of South Florida, stranding numerous motorists on flooded streets and pushing water into some homes in low-lying areas.\n\n\"People underestimate the power of water and they sometimes don't always take rainfall and the threats that come with it seriously, especially if you are driving in an area and you see water covering the road, you don't want to drive into it,\" Brennan said.\n\n___ AP journalists Jamie Stengle in Dallas and Julie Walker in New York contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Star"}, "authors": [], "concepts": Maximum sustained winds are 45 mph. The storm is expected to dissipate later today, with continuing impacts of heavy rainfall and urban flooding in the region. Stay updated through local meteorological services.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto Intermediate Advisory Number 11A NWS National Hurricane Center Miami FL AL012024\n\n700 AM CDT Thu Jun 20 2024 ...ALBERTO MOVING INLAND OVER Mexico...\n\n...HEAVY RAINS AND FLASH FLOODING CONTINUE IN NORTHEASTERN Mexico... SUMMARY OF 700 AM CDT...1200 UTC...INFORMATION\n\n---------------------------------------------- LOCATION...22.3N 98.3W\n\nABOUT 25 MI...45 KM W OF TAMPICO Mexico ABOUT 255 MI...410 KM S OF BROWNSVILLE TEXAS\n\nMAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS...45 MPH...75 KM/H PRESENT MOVEMENT...W OR 275 DEGREES AT 13 MPH...20 KM/H\n\nMINIMUM CENTRAL PRESSURE...997 MB...29.44 INCHES WATCHES AND WARNINGS\n\nA Tropical Storm Warning is in effect for... * the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\nA Tropical Storm Warning means that tropical storm conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area, in this case through\n\nthis morning. For storm information specific to your area, please monitor\n\nproducts issued by your national meteorological service. DISCUSSION AND OUTLOOK\n\n---------------------- At 700 AM CDT (1200 UTC), the center of Tropical Storm Alberto was\n\nlocated near latitude 22.3 North, longitude 98.3 West. Alberto is moving toward the west near 13 mph (20 km/h). This motion is\n\nexpected to continue through today, as Alberto moves further inland over Mexico.\n\nMaximum sustained winds are near 45 mph (75 km/h) with higher gusts. Weakening is anticipated as Alberto continues to move inland, and\n\nthe storm is likely to dissipate over Mexico later today or tonight. Tropical-storm-force winds extend outward up to 250 miles (400 km)\n\nfrom the center. The estimated minimum central pressure is 997 mb (29.44 inches).\n\nHAZARDS AFFECTING LAND ----------------------\n\nKey messages for Alberto can be found in the Tropical Cyclone Discussion under AWIPS header MIATCDAT1 and WMO header WTNT41 KNHC.\n\nRAINFALL: Rainfall associated with Tropical Storm Alberto is expected to begin to diminish across southern Texas during the day,\n\nwith additional rainfall totals of 1 inch or less expected. Heavy rainfall will continue to impact northeast Mexico through this\n\nmorning, with rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches expected. Maximum rainfall totals around 20 inches are possible across the higher\n\nterrain of the Mexican states of Coahuila, Nuevo Leon, and Tamaulipas. This rainfall will likely produce considerable flash\n\nand urban flooding along with new and renewed river flooding. Mudslides are also possible in areas of higher terrain across\n\nnortheast Mexico. For a complete depiction of forecast rainfall and flash flooding\n\nassociated with Alberto, please see the National Weather Service Storm Total Rainfall Graphic, available at\n\nhurricanes.gov/graphics_at1.shtml?rainqpf and the Flash Flood Risk graphic at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at1.shtml?ero\n\nSTORM SURGE: The combination of a dangerous storm surge and the tide will cause normally dry areas near the coast to be flooded\n\nby rising waters moving inland from the shoreline. The water could reach the following heights above ground somewhere in the indicated\n\nareas if the peak surge occurs at the time of high tide... Sargent, TX to Sabine Pass, TX...2-4 ft\n\nGalveston Bay...2-4 ft Mouth of the Rio Grande, TX to Sargent, TX...1-3 ft\n\nSabine Pass, TX to Vermilion/Cameron Parish Line, LA...1-3 ft The deepest water will occur along the immediate coast near and to\n\nthe north of the landfall location, where the surge will be accompanied by large and dangerous waves. Surge-related flooding\n\ndepends on the relative timing of the surge and the tidal cycle, and can vary greatly over short distances. For information\n\nspecific to your area, please see products issued by your local National Weather Service forecast office.\n\nFor a complete depiction of areas at risk of storm surge inundation, please see the National Weather Service Peak Storm Surge Graphic,\n\navailable at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at1.shtml?peakSurge. Storm surge will raise water levels by as much as 1 to 3 feet above\n\nnormal tide levels along the immediate coast of northeastern Mexico in areas of onshore winds north of where the center makes\n\nlandfall. Near the coast, the surge will be accompanied by large and destructive waves.\n\nWIND: Tropical storm conditions are expected within the warning area through this morning.\n\nTORNADOES: A tornado or two could occur this morning across parts of Deep South Texas.\n\nSURF: Swells generated by Alberto will affect the coast of Texas and northeastern Mexico through Friday. These swells are\n\nlikely to cause life-threatening surf and rip current conditions. Please consult products from your local weather office.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", It could become a tropical depression over the weekend, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe next named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season will be Beryl.\n\nHere's the latest update from the NHC as of 8 a.m., June 20:\n\nSpecial note on the NHC cone: The forecast track shows the most likely path of the center of the storm. It does not illustrate the full width of the storm or its impacts, and the center of the storm is likely to travel outside the cone up to 33% of the time.\n\nSpecial note about spaghetti models: Illustrations include an array of forecast tools and models, and not all are created equal. The hurricane center uses only the top four or five highest performing models to help make its forecasts.\n\nInvest 92L: A small area of low pressure located about 150 miles east of the northernmost Bahamas continues to produce disorganized showers and thunderstorms.\n\nWhile environmental conditions are only marginally conducive due to nearby dry air, further development of this system could lead to the development of a tropical depression while the low moves west-northwest at 10 to 15 mph and approaches the northeastern coast of Florida or the Georgia coast early on Friday.\n\nAn Air Force Reserve reconnaissance aircraft is scheduled to investigate this system this afternoon, if necessary.\n\nSouthwestern Gulf of Mexico: A broad area of low pressure is forecast to form over southeastern Mexico and northern Central America on Friday.\n\nEnvironmental conditions appear conducive for gradual development after this system moves over the Bay of Campeche on Saturday, and a tropical depression could form over the southwestern Gulf of Mexico thisweekend while it moves slowly west-northwest or northwest.\n\nInvest 92L: \"Regardless of development, this feature can bring high seas, gusty winds and areas of heavy rain and thunderstorms to the Southeast coast,\" said Kienzle.\n\nFrom late Thursday to Saturday, 1-2 inches of rain can generally fall along the Southeast coastal regions, particularly across southeastern Georgia.\n\nSouthwestern Gulf of Mexico: This system could become a tropical depression over the southwestern Gulf of Mexico over the weekend as it moves slowly west-northwest or northwest, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"There is a moderate chance for development from June 21-23 across a similar area in the Gulf of Mexico,\" according to AccuWeather.\n\n\"This feature will need to be watched for possible impacts on the Gulf coasts of the United States and Mexico this weekend into early next week,\" Kienzle said.\n\nForecasters urge all residents to continue monitoring the tropics and to always be prepared. That advice is particularly important for what is expected to be a very active hurricane season.\n\nThe Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 through Nov. 30.\n\nThe peak of the season is Sept. 10, with the most activity happening between mid-August and mid-October, according to the Hurricane Center.\n\nSystems currently being monitored by the National Hurricane Center include:\n\nWe will continue to update our tropical weather coverage daily. {"uri": "8187386527", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "16:34:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T16:34:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T16:27:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/photos-tropical-storm-alberto-brings-heavy-flooding-to-texas-after-making-landfall-in-mexico-162616021.html", "title": "Photos: Tropical Storm Alberto brings heavy flooding to Texas after making landfall in Mexico", "body": "At least three people have been reported dead in Mexico after Tropical Storm Alberto, the first named storm of the season, officially made landfall Thursday morning. The storm is expected to bring nearly two feet of rain to the country's Gulf Coast. In Texas, coastal cities experienced a storm surge -- an abnormal rise of seawater -- of more than four feet.\n\nOne man died in the La Salle River in Monterrey -- located around three hours from the Texas border, Mexican authorities said, adding that two minors riding their bikes in the rain died from electric shocks in the municipality of Allende.\n\nThe National Weather Service issued a flood watch for Corpus Christi and nearby cities in Texas, which will be in place until 1 p.m. local time. The National Hurricane Center also said the storm made landfall with maximum winds of 45 mph and should dissipate over Mexico by the end of the day.\n\nAlthough the worst is believed to be over for Texas, many areas are still dealing with flooding on their streets.\n\nOn Wednesday, Gov. Greg Abbott issued a disaster declaration for 51 Texas counties, \"to ensure Texans and at-risk regions have the resources and personnel needed to respond to this storm,\" he said in a statement.\n\nSouthern parts of the United States have already experienced flooding this hurricane season. Southern Florida recently went through days of extreme rainfall and flooding -- with two people reportedly dying during the storms. According to the National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration, the Atlantic hurricane season is only just beginning.\n\n\"The upcoming Atlantic hurricane season is expected to have above-normal activity due to a confluence of factors,\" the administration said in a May 23 statement. \"NOAA is forecasting a range of 17 to 25 total named storms (winds of 39 mph or higher). With a high formation chance of becoming a tropical storm, areas are under warnings and are likely to experience flash floods, mudslides, and dangerous storm surges.\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One Advisory Number 5 NWS National Hurricane Center Miami FL AL012024\n\n400 PM CDT Tue Jun 18 2024 ...TROPICAL STORM WARNING EXTENDED NORTHWARD ALONG THE TEXAS\n\nCOAST... ...HEAVY RAINFALL, COASTAL FLOODING, AND GUSTY WINDS EXPECTED ALONG\n\nTHE COASTS OF TEXAS AND NORTHEASTERN Mexico THROUGH THURSDAY... SUMMARY OF 400 PM CDT...2100 UTC...INFORMATION\n\n---------------------------------------------- LOCATION...22.1N 92.7W\n\nABOUT 345 MI...555 KM ESE OF LA PESCA Mexico ABOUT 395 MI...635 KM SE OF BROWNSVILLE TEXAS\n\nMAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS...40 MPH...65 KM/H PRESENT MOVEMENT...N OR 360 DEGREES AT 6 MPH...9 KM/H\n\nMINIMUM CENTRAL PRESSURE...999 MB...29.50 INCHES WATCHES AND WARNINGS\n\n-------------------- CHANGES WITH THIS ADVISORY:\n\nThe Tropical Storm Warning has been extended northward along the Texas coast to San Luis Pass.\n\nSUMMARY OF WATCHES AND WARNINGS IN EFFECT: A Tropical Storm Warning is in effect for... * the Texas coast from San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the\n\nRio Grande * the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Puerto de Altamira.\n\nA Tropical Storm Warning means that tropical storm conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area within 36 hours.\n\nFor storm information specific to your area in the United States, including possible inland watches and warnings, please\n\nmonitor products issued by your local National Weather Service forecast office. For storm information specific to your area\n\noutside of the United States, please monitor products issued by your national meteorological service.\n\nDISCUSSION AND OUTLOOK ----------------------\n\nAt 400 PM CDT (2100 UTC), the disturbance was centered near latitude 22.1 North, longitude 92.7 West. The system is moving toward the\n\nnorth near 6 mph (9 km/h). A turn toward the northwest and west with an increase in forward speed is expected tonight and on\n\nWednesday, and the system is forecast to reach the Gulf coast of Mexico by Wednesday night.\n\nMaximum sustained winds are near 40 mph (65 km/h) with higher gusts. Some increase in strength is possible during the next 36 hours,\n\nand the disturbance is forecast to become a tropical storm by Wednesday. * Formation chance through 48 hours...high...80 percent. * Formation chance through 7 days...high...80 percent.\n\nThe disturbance is quite large, and tropical-storm-force winds extend outward up to 415 miles (665 km) to the north of the center.\n\nThe estimated minimum central pressure is 999 mb (29.50 inches). HAZARDS AFFECTING LAND\n\n---------------------- Key messages for Potential Tropical Cyclone One can be found in the\n\nTropical Cyclone Discussion under AWIPS header MIATCDAT1 and WMO header WTNT41 KNHC.\n\nRAINFALL: Potential Tropical Cyclone One is expected to produce rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South\n\nTexas, with maximum totals of 15 inches possible. This rainfall will likely produce flash and urban flooding along with new and renewed\n\nriver flooding. Mudslides are also possible in areas of higher terrain across northeast Mexico.\n\nFor a complete depiction of forecast rainfall and flash flooding associated with Potential Tropical Cyclone One, please see the\n\nNational Weather Service Storm Total Rainfall Graphic, available at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at1.shtml?rainqpf and the Flash Flood Risk\n\ngraphic at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at1.shtml?ero STORM SURGE: The combination of a dangerous storm surge and\n\nthe tide will cause normally dry areas near the coast to be flooded by rising waters moving inland from the shoreline. The water could\n\nreach the following heights above ground somewhere in the indicated areas if the peak surge occurs at the time of high tide...\n\nSargent, TX to Sabine Pass, TX...2-4 ft Galveston Bay...2-4 ft\n\nMouth of the Rio Grande, TX to Sargent, TX...1-3 ft Sabine Pass, TX to Vermilion/Cameron Parish Line, LA...1-3 ft\n\nThe deepest water will occur along the immediate coast near and to the north of the landfall location, where the surge will be\n\naccompanied by large and dangerous waves. Surge-related flooding depends on the relative timing of the surge and the tidal cycle,\n\nand can vary greatly over short distances. For information specific to your area, please see products issued by your local\n\nNational Weather Service forecast office. For a complete depiction of areas at risk of storm surge inundation,\n\nplease see the National Weather Service Peak Storm Surge Graphic, available at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at1.shtml?peakSurge.\n\nIn Mexico, minor coastal flooding is possible north of where the center of the system crosses the coast in areas of onshore\n\nwinds. WIND: Tropical storm conditions are expected within the warning\n\narea by tonight or Wednesday. TORNADOES: A couple of tornadoes may occur Wednesday across parts\n\nof Deep South into southeast Texas. SURF: Swells generated by the disturbance will affect the coast of\n\nTexas and northeastern Mexico through early Thursday. These swells are likely to cause life-threatening surf and rip current\n\nconditions. Please consult products from your local weather office. {"uri": "8186762019", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "09:54:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T09:54:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T09:53:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.wafb.com/2024/06/19/tropical-storm-alberto-forms-la-coast-inundated-by-coastal-flooding/", "title": "Coastal flooding from TS Alberto inundates southeast La. roadways", "body": "NEW ORLEANS (WVUE) - An area of low pressure in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico was upgraded to Tropical Storm Alberto on Wed., June 19, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nCoastal flooding associated with Alberto's circulation will continue in southeast Louisiana over the next 24-48 hours. Roadways in Grand Isle, Leeville, and Golden Meadow were overtopped when high tide came Wednesday morning.\n\nFlorissant Highway (Hwy. 46) in St. Bernard Parish, which leads to Shell Beach, was impassable at some points due to high water. The St. Bernard Parish Sheriff's Office was only allowing trucks to pass.\n\nSaltwater from the Gulf overtopped Hwy. 1 in spots between Grand Isle, Leeville, and Golden Meadow.\n\nLouisiana State Police were stationed along the highway monitoring conditions.\n\nVideo from the Bridge Side Marina showed water encroaching on a patio seating area.\n\nHwy. 1 was closed near the Grand Isle Marina, according to Weldon Danos, Executive Director of the Grand Isle Port Commission.\n\nThe Mandeville Police Department is asking to avoid the area of Lakeshore Drive.\n\nIMPORTANT LINKS\n\nAlberto is expected to make landfall in Mexico Wednesday night or early Thursday morning. The NHC says slight strengthening is likely before a rapid weakening once the center moves inland.\n\nAlberto is a large storm with winds extending 415 miles north of the center. Maximum sustained winds were 40 mph.\n\n\"The heavy rainfall and the water, as usual, is the biggest story in tropical storms,\" said NHC Director Michael Brennan.\n\nBrennan said that winds could get up to 45 mph (72 kph) to 50 mph (80 kph) before the storm makes landfall.\n\nTropical Storm Warnings are in effect for the Texas coast, from San Luis Pass south to the mouth of the Rio Grande and the northeastern coast of Mexico, south of the river to Tecoluta.\n\nAs much as 5 inches (13 centimeters) to 10 inches (25 centimeters) of rain was expected in some areas along the Texas coast, with even higher isolated totals possible, Brennan said. He said some higher locations in Mexico could see as much as 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain, which could result in mudslides and flash flooding, especially in the states of Tamaulipas, Coahuila and Nuevo Leon.\n\nAlberto is the first named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicts the hurricane season from June 1 to Nov. 30 is likely to be well above average, with between 17 and 25 named storms. An average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.\n\nThis is the latest A-named storm that has formed to start a hurricane season since 2014.\n\nIf you are able to do so safely, submit your photos and videos to fox8live.com/pics.", "source": {"uri": "wafb.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WAFB"}, "authors": [], "concepts": A westward motion with an increase in forward speed is expected through Thursday. What it means to Dallas-Fort Worth", "body": "Communities along the southern coastline of Texas have been on alert since early Tuesday morning for the season's first named storm out of the Gulf of Mexico to develop -- Tropical Storm Alberto -- even as a storm warning was issued by the National Hurricane Center for the coastline of northern Mexico.\n\n\"Heavy rainfall and coastal flooding expected along the coasts of Texas and northeastern Mexico over the next day or two,\" according to hurricane center forecasters.\n\nAs of early Wednesday morning, the system was about 465 miles southeast of Brownsville, Texas, according to the hurricane center, and was forecast to become a tropical storm later in the day, reaching Mexico's Gulf Coast by Wednesday night.\n\n[ RELATED STORY: Why are storms and hurricanes named? ]\n\nIf the tropical disturbance does metastasize into a storm -- the National Weather Service estimates that happening later Wednesday -- heavy rainfall is certain to inundate parts of South Texas. As of early Wednesday, the weather service in Fort Worth noted that much of North Texas may be spared from any severe effects from the storm, with nearly zero chance of rain. Up to an inch of rain is expected in the southern parts of Central Texas.\n\n\u26a1 More trending stories from our newsroom:\n\n\u2192Cowboys legend Michael Irvin says wife Sandy, 58, suffers from early onset Alzheimer's\n\n\u2192 Fred's Texas Cafe opens a new restaurant outside of Fort Worth\n\n\u2192 Pastor of Southlake's Gateway Church accused of molesting 12-year-old girl in 1980s\n\n\"A low pressure system of tropical origin will make westward progress from the Gulf of Mexico into southern portions of Texas over the next 36 hours,\" Fort Worth meteorologist Matt Stalley wrote on the NWS website Tuesday.\n\nAlthough the brunt of the tropical storm is expected to hit well south of the Dallas-Fort Worth region, \"It will still offer some rain chances during the midweek period, along with slightly cooler temperatures due to attendant widespread cloud cover.\"\n\nHighs in the Metroplex is expected to be in the 80s midweek, a respite from recent hot days.\n\nNorth Texas has already felt the burn of an early heat wave as the \"feel like\" temperatures around the Metroplex topped triple digits in early June as a heat dome moved north from Mexico. (WBRC) - Dry and breezy on Juneteenth: We begin our Wednesday morning with overcast skies and temps in the 70s. The Juneteenth holiday is shaping up to be very nice. We will likely remain partly sunny to mostly cloudy with high temperatures climbing into the upper 80s and lower 90s. It looks to remain breezy today with easterly winds at 10-15 mph and gusting at times above that. The heat index will remain close to the actual air temperature.\n\nNext Big Thing: The big story for the end of the week is the heat. We will likely see decreasing clouds giving way to partly cloudy skies Thursday, Friday, and into Saturday. With more sunshine, temperatures should continue to heat up. We will likely see highs in the lower 90s on Thursday. We could see temperatures climb into the mid-90s Friday and into the weekend. Humidity may slowly increase, so the heat index could flirt near 100\u00b0F. It'll be a hot weekend, so you'll want to make sure you stay hydrated and take several breaks if you have to work outdoors. Rain chances will remain isolated Saturday and Sunday with the greatest coverage occurring south of I-20. Our chances of rain may increase early next week with scattered storms possible on Monday and Tuesday.\n\nTropical Update: The National Hurricane Center has designated the area of low pressure spinning away in the Bay of Campeche as \"Potential Tropical Cyclone One\" so they can issue forecasts, watches, and warnings. We will likely see this system impact Mexico Wednesday afternoon. It is expected to bring heavy rainfall and possible flooding for Mexico, southern Texas, and along the coastal areas of Texas. Rainfall totals of 5-10 inches will be possible over the next 48 hours. If this system establishes a closed low, it will likely become our first tropical storm of the season. The first name up on the 2024 Atlantic hurricane list is \"Alberto\".\n\nWe are also watching two areas that have a low chance of forming into a tropical depression or storm in the next five to seven days. One area we continue to watch is in the Atlantic. Odds are lowering (at 20%) for something to form. The system will remain small and could produce gusty winds and rain for parts of Florida, Georgia, and into the Carolinas over the weekend. I don't see this system impacting us at the moment.\n\nThe second area to watch is right where the Potential Tropical Cyclone One is located in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico. Once this storm moves inland over Mexico, we could see another low develop over the weekend. It remains too far out to know if another tropical depression could form, but we will likely see more rain and possible flooding for parts Mexico, Central America, and perhaps for southern Texas. Hurricane season peaks in September and comes to an end on November 30th. None of these systems are forecast to impact us, but it will likely create rough surf along the Gulf Coast this week. Double red flags are flying along the Alabama Gulf Coast. {"uri": "8185410851", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "13:40:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T13:40:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T13:38:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.foxweather.com/weather-news/bryan-norcross-tropical-storm-conditions-impact-texas-coast-june-19", "title": "Bryan Norcross: Tropical storm conditions to impact the Texas coast Wednesday", "body": "The Gulf system officially designated Potential Tropical Cyclone ONE (the technical name for a potential tropical threat) has not yet organized around a well-defined center, so it can't be officially named Tropical Storm Alberto yet.\n\nThe consensus of the computer forecast models is that the giant circulation will likely consolidate before it makes landfall on the Mexican coast tonight or early tomorrow. The National Hurricane Center is giving that an 80% chance of happening, but it might run out of time. In any case, naming the system won't make any difference to the impacts on the Gulf Coast. It's purely for the record book.\n\nThe strong winds to the north of the ostensible center of potential Alberto are caused by the air being squeezed between the tropical system's low pressure and the extra strong heat-dome high-pressure system over the northeast US. Those persistent gusty winds blowing east to west are already pushing the water toward the coast, causing minor to moderate storm-surge flooding at high tide.\n\nTides have been 2 to 4 feet above normal on the northern Gulf Coast, especially in Louisiana and Mississippi. But today, the focus will be on the Texas coast, where the strongest onshore winds will occur. High tide tomorrow morning will likely see additional flooding.\n\nWinds of 40 to 50 mph are likely on the southern half of the Texas coast, with gusty winds affecting the rest of Texas and across the northern Gulf.\n\nThere is a widespread risk of flash flooding from the southern counties of metro Houston to the Mexico border. Five to 10 inches of rain is forecast with up to 15 inches possible in some areas. South Texas is in a drought, so the land can absorb quite a bit of rain. If it doesn't all come at once, it will be a good thing - they are desperate for water. On the other hand, areas around Houston were drenched in May, which means it will flood with less rain.\n\nThe rain threat near the coast from potential Alberto should end Thursday morning. However, it will still be quite breezy throughout the day, keeping the tide levels somewhat higher than normal.\n\nNEXT IN THE GULF: Then, weirdly, we look to the same spot in the southern Gulf for the next potential tropical system. The consensus of the computer forecasts is that another low-pressure area will develop late Friday or early Saturday and move slowly over the same waters tread by potential Alberto. For now, we are calling this system Potential Tropical Disturbance #3.\n\nThis system will keep the onshore winds blowing along the Texas coast, though so far, it's forecast to be weaker than potential Alberto.\n\nA key rule applies here, however. Forecasts for systems that have not yet developed or are just developing are always subject to significant changes.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center has the chance of this system developing into at least a tropical depression in the low category for now. But the atmospheric pattern is forecast to be conducive to strengthening, so let's keep an open mind.\n\nIN THE ATLANTIC: The system we've been watching in the Atlantic is related to an old front and an upper-level disturbance, Disturbance #2, does not look likely to develop. The various computer forecast models have mostly lost interest. Still, a weak area of low pressure is forecast to arrive at the Southeast coast as a briefly gusty moisture surge Thursday night or Friday. The National Hurricane Center still gives it a slight chance of developing tropical characteristics before that time.\n\nAs is typical in June, dry air and Saharan dust cover the tropical Atlantic and {"uri": "2024-06-394803774", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "14:07:44", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T14:07:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T13:59:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/first-tropical-storm-season-heading-135906672.html", "title": "First tropical storm of the season heading for Texas bringing risk of flash floods", "body": "After days of intense heat that has beaten down on some US states, a tropical storm is heading to South Texas, prompting flood warnings and heavy rainfall.\n\nA potential tropical cyclone is due to move onshore and head inland across southern Texas, bringing with it heavy rain and tropical storm-force winds on Wednesday, the National Weather Service (NWS) has warned.\n\nThe weather system, currently named Potential Tropical Cyclone One, was forecast to make its landfall on early Thursday in northern Mexico as 'Tropical Storm Alberto.'\n\nThe NWS said this will bring heavy to excessive rainfall for much of southern Texas this week.\n\nConsiderable flash and urban flooding as well as river flooding are all likely in some areas, the National Hurricane Center said, as a result of the rainfall from the potential tropical cyclone that will impact large regions of Central America, northeastern Mexico, and South Texas.\n\nLife-threatening flooding and mudslides are likely in higher areas of Mexico, including around the cities of Monterrey and Ciudad Victoria.\n\nModerate coastal flooding is also likely, the center has warned, along much of the Texas Coast through midweek. The Texas coast south of Port O'Connor and portions of northeastern Mexico have been issued with a Tropical Storm Watch.\n\n\"Small creeks & streams may rise out of their banks, and low-lying areas, especially in urban areas, may easily flood. Turn around, don't drown!\" the NWS wrote on X.\n\nThe NWS has stated that more than 50 per cent of flood fatalities are vehicle-related, and has warned those likely to be impacted by the flash and river flooding threats not to risk driving in flood waters.\n\nTropical Storm Warnings have been issued for many Texas areas such as coastal Jackson, Matagorda, Matagorda Bay, the Gulf Waters, and the Brazoria Counties, NWS Houston said, adding that Flood Watches and Coastal Flood Warnings are also in place along the coast.\n\nForecasters say that the lower and middle Texas coasts will be mostly impacted by the heavy rain and gale-force winds, along with a coastal front that has the potential to enhance the heavy rainfall inland from the coast.\n\nHow sharp the front will get, however, cannot yet be predicted, the NWS said.\n\nThe tropical cyclone will also most likely be helped along by the strong high-pressure system that is also currently sustaining the extreme heat wave across the Ohio Valley and the Northeast.\n\nThe high-pressure system will steer the cyclone westward towards northern Mexico on Wednesday, and the cyclone could acquire tropical storm status before making landfall early Thursday, the NWS detailed in their daily update.\n\nHeavy rain is also due to sweep west across southern Texas into the Rio Grand Valley over Wednesday night, with rainfalls of five to 10 inches possible from northeast Mexico to South Texas - with a maximum total of 15 inches possible.\n\nThe heaviest rainfall is forecast to move west of the Rio Grand Valley into northern Mexico before tapering off early Friday.\n\nThe Four Corners region, consisting of the southwestern states of Colorado, Utah, Arizona, and New Mexico surrounding their connecting corners, will experience some of the tropical moisture from the storm, which will activate showers and thunderstorms on Thursday and Friday.\n\nMoisture from a 'tropical wave' could also reach northeastern Flordia and coastal Georgia by Thursday night to Friday morning, the NWS stated.\n\nWhile the tropical activity starts its journey into Texas, the ongoing heatwave will continue to impact areas of the Midwest, including locations in the Ohio Valley, Great Lakes, Northeast, and the Mid-Atlantic, over the next few days.\n\nDaily records and monthly records are expected to be challenged by the very high temperatures, with some heat readings likely to peak from 100 to 105F degrees in some areas.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [{"uri": Alberto is the first named storm of the season. It has maximum sustained wind speeds of 40 mph. It's moving west at 9 mph towards the eastern coast of Mexico. Tropical storm warnings are in effect for parts of the Texas coast and northeastern Mexico coast. No tropical headlines are expected for Louisiana.\n\nWednesday morning, PTC One upgraded to Tropical Storm Alberto when a well defined center of circulation was established. This is the first named storm of this season. It has maximum wind speeds of 40 mph and tropical storm winds extend very far away from the center.\n\nAs the system moves westwards, the pressure gradient will tighten over the Northern Gulf between its lower pressure and high pressure to the northeast. This will bring some breezy to gusty at times winds across the region.\n\nA Wind Advisory will be in effect. until 7 PM Wednesday for areas from Coastal Mississippi, the Southshore, and to Assumption Parish. In general, east/southeast winds will be around 10-15 mph with gusts near 20-30 mph around the Greater Baton Rouge area on Wednesday. Winds will be higher toward the coast and south of the Tidal Lakes with gusts around 35 mph possible.\n\nWith higher winds from the east, this brings a coastal flooding concern for east facing shorelines. A Coastal Flood Warning is in effect for areas near Lake Maurepas and Pontchartrain with a Coastal Flood Advisory in effect for the rest of the Louisiana coast. Breezy to gusty easterly winds will cause some minor coastal flooding during high tide cycles.\n\nOver in the Southwest Atlantic east of the Bahamas, an area of low pressure (disturbance 1) could develop with some slow development this week as it moves generally west/northwestward. There is a low chance (20%) of tropical development over the next seven days.\n\nAnother area of low pressure (disturbance 2) is forecasted is develop over this upcoming weekend, also in the Southwestern Gulf of Mexico. {"uri": "2024-06-393339892", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "10:48:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T10:48:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T10:47:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.wesh.com/article/tropics-mexico-texas-potential-tropical-cyclone-one-alberto/61152745", "title": "Potential Tropical Cyclone One looms off Mexico's coast, NHC tracking two additional systems", "body": "The National Hurricane Center is tracking \"Potential Tropical Cyclone One\" as it continues to loom off Mexico Tuesday morning. The system has the potential to become Tropical Storm Alberto. The system is producing winds of 40 mph, but does not have a closed circulation yet. Officials say the storm will most likely be upgraded on Tuesday afternoon.More: What is a \"Potential Tropical Cyclone?As the system approaches land, the NHC is concerned about heavy rainfall and moderate flooding, which they say could start as early as Tuesday afternoon. With a new cone issued on Tuesday morning, the NHC reminds users to not focus on the exact forecast track of this system. According to the NHC, the disturbance is very large and will produce downpours, coastal flooding and wind far from its center -- including on the coast of Texas and northeast Mexico. As of Tuesday morning, tropical storm warnings have been issued for coastal Texas from Port O'Connor southward to the Mouth of the Rio Grande. The NHC says rainfall associated with Potential Tropical Cyclone One will impact large regions of Central America, northeastern Mexico and south Texas, and has the potential to prompt flash floods and mudslides. The NHC predicts that tropical conditions will impact these areas starting Wednesday.Formation chance remains high for Potential Tropical Cyclone One, holding at 80% for both the next 48 hours and the next seven days. For more information on conditions, warnings, maps and more, click here. More: Difference between tropical storm, hurricane watch and warningSouthwestern Atlantic Ocean: The NHC is watching another area of cloudiness and showers closer to Central Florida -- several hundred miles east of the Bahamas. Officials say environmental conditions could be conducive for some gradual development during the next few days as it moves west or northwest, though the chance remains low and has decreased from previous forecasts (10% in the next 48 hours; 20% in the next seven days). The NHC says the system is forecast to approach the southeastern United States on Friday. Southwestern Gulf of Mexico: Additionally, the NHC has their eye on another broad area of low pressure that is forecast to develop in the Gulf of Mexico this weekend. Environmental conditions are expected to be conducive for gradual development of this system early next week, the NHC says. Formation chance in the next 48 hours is low (at 0%) and the chance for formation over the next seven days is 20%. >>> Surviving the Season | 2024 Hurricane Special from WESH 2 >>> WESH 2 Hurricane Survival Guide 2024\n\nThe National Hurricane Center is tracking \"Potential Tropical Cyclone One\" as it continues to loom off Mexico Tuesday morning.\n\nThe system has the potential to become Tropical Storm Alberto. This will come just days after Alberto took a similar trek through the region.\n\nThis system will be monitored for possible development into a tropical depression or storm. Computer model forecast guidance suggests that if this system does develop, it would be steered westward into eastern Mexico by upper-level high pressure over the southern U.S.\n\nThis new spoke of the Central American Gyre should be smaller in size than Alberto as it crosses the Gulf of Mexico. This should limit the amount of rainfall and storm surge along the Gulf Coast in comparison to Alberto. We'll talk about impacts in the next section.\n\nSimilar track, but very different impacts than Alberto: This next system will be steered westward across the Bay of Campeche by a heat dome over the Lower 48, but its presence may not be made as well known across the neighborhood this time.\n\nAlberto was a very large system, and that allowed it to dump heavy rainfall and spread storm surge from eastern Mexico to the Upper Texas Coast. Some areas in eastern Mexico saw more than 6 inches of rain, while Rockport, Texas, saw nearly 10 inches. Parts of the Texas coast saw up to four feet of storm surge, as well.\n\nIn Texas, rainfall will be more limited, but some areas across the Rio Grande Valley will pick up another inch or two.\n\nFarther south, an additional 5 to 10 inches of rain from Alberto's moisture and this new system is expected in eastern Mexico. This area has already received heavy rainfall, so this additional rainfall could cause flooding and mudslides in a more localized area.\n\nA weekend of choppy seas and enhanced rip current potential can be expected along the Texas Coast, but water levels shouldn't rise as much as they did in recent days.\n\nMORE ON WEATHER.COM\n\n- Why The Atlantic's Slow Start To Hurricane Season Is Meaningless\n\nJonathan Belles has been a graphics meteorologist and writer for weather.com for 8 years and also assists in video production for The Weather Channel en espa\u00f1ol. {"uri": "8185526581", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:00:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:00:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T14:59:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/tropical-storm-alberto-update-spaghetti-models-impacts-three-states-1914847", "title": "Tropical storm update: spaghetti models show impacts hitting 3 states", "body": "Southern states are preparing for impacts from a potential tropical storm as the National Hurricane Center (NHC) continues to monitor the system's path.\n\nNational Weather Service (NWS) meteorologists issued a slew of advisories along the coasts of Texas, Louisiana and Mississippi as Potential Tropical Cyclone One -- which will become Tropical Storm Alberto if it continues to strengthen -- sends rough waters and foul weather miles away from the storm's center.\n\nAs of Wednesday morning, most spaghetti models -- computer models illustrating potential storm paths -- show the storm making landfall in Mexico by Wednesday night, although a few models show the storm's path careening off to the north toward the southern U.S.\n\n\"Latest update for Potential Tropical Cyclone One. This system continues to drift west in the southwestern Gulf,\" the NWS said. \"This system is expected to steadily strengthen, drifting westward, impacting Mexico and south Texas. Some indirect impacts will be possible across our local area through midweek. Continue to monitor the forecast for any changes to expected impacts.\"\n\nThe NWS issued a tropical storm warning in Texas, flood warnings and advisories across several states, and several ocean-related warnings such as a high surf warning, a coastal flood warning, a rip current statement and a gale warning among others as the storm continues to cause impacts.\n\n\"Tropical Storm force winds possible until Wednesday afternoon,\" the tropical storm warning said. \"Very strong winds will cause hazardous seas which could capsize or damage vessels and reduce visibility. Mariners should alter plans to avoid these hazardous conditions. Remain in port, seek safe harbor, alter course and/or secure the vessel for severe conditions.\"\n\nInland flooding also is a concern, particularly in Texas where the storm could bring up to 6 inches of rain to some areas. NWS meteorologist Geoff Bogorad told Newsweek that so far, around an inch or two of rain has already fallen in the Deep South. The heaviest rain will fall throughout the day on Wednesday.\n\nMost of the flood-related warnings are expected to expire by Thursday afternoon.\n\nMultiple agencies, including the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), have issued forecasts warning that 2024 will be an exceptionally strong year for hurricanes. NOAA's forecast anticipates 17 to 25 named storms, for an above-average hurricane season. Of the 25, eight to 13 will be hurricanes and four to seven will be major hurricanes. The forecast amount of named storms, hurricanes and major hurricanes is the highest NOAA has ever issued in a May outlook.\n\nSeveral factors are contributing to the storm-heavy predictions this year, It had top sustained winds of 40 mph (65 kph), according to the National Hurricane Center in Miami. A tropical storm is defined by sustained winds of between 39 and 73 mph (62 and 117 kph), and above that the system becomes a hurricane.\n\nNewsletters", "source": {"uri": "djournal.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8184611026", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "04:04:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T04:04:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T04:03:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.theyucatantimes.com/2024/06/tropical-rainstorm-to-bring-heavy-rain-to-the-gulf-of-mexico/", "title": "Tropical rainstorm to bring heavy rain to the Gulf of Mexico - The Yucatan Times", "body": "A tropical storm warning has been issued along part of the coast of Texas and Mexico as a tropical rainstorm gains strength in the Gulf of Mexico.\n\nAfter a tropical rainstorm brought heavy rainfall to portions of Florida last week, AccuWeather hurricane experts warn that yet another tropical rainstorm is expected to impact the southern U.S. in the coming days.\n\nIn addition to the tropical rainstorm, two other areas in the Atlantic Basin are being monitored for tropical development later this week, including one off the Southeast coast. It is possible that one of these areas could strengthen into Alberto, becoming the first named storm of the season.\n\nThis AccuWeather Enhanced RealVue\u2122 Satellite image from Tuesday morning, June 18, shows an area of showers and thunderstorms, dubbed a tropical rainstorm by AccuWeather meteorologists, in the Bay of Campeche.\n\nAccuWeather began to highlight portions of the western Gulf of Mexico with a high risk for tropical development last Thursday afternoon. A tropical rainstorm developed late on Sunday and is forecast to steer toward the border between Mexico and Texas into the middle of the week. The storm is expected to drift north-northwestward, bringing with it rounds of heavy rain.\n\nA tropical storm warning has been issued along the Gulf Coast from Port O'Connor, Texas, southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande River, with a tropical storm watch southward from there to Puerto de Altamira, Mexico, due to the expected impacts from the strengthening system.\n\n\"Very warm waters in this area of the Gulf, as well as low wind shear will make this a conducive environment for the tropical rainstorm to strengthen,\" said AccuWeather Senior Meteorologist Dan Pydynowski.\n\nGiven these factors, the rainstorm is forecast to strengthen into a tropical depression, then a tropical storm, right before making landfall along the northern Gulf Coast of Mexico. Should the storm produce sustained winds of 39 mph or greater prior to any other development in the Atlantic Basin, it will be given the name Alberto.\n\nA tropical storm is likely to bring widespread strong wind gusts to the Mexican states of Tamaulipas and Nuevo Leon, as well as portions of South Texas. Some storm surge can also be expected along the coast north of the storm's landfall. For both Mexico and the United States, given the risk for damaging winds, storm surge and flooding rainfall, this storm is a 1 on the AccuWeather RealImpact\u2122 Scale for Hurricanes.\n\nGiven the limited time over water and close proximity to land, the tropical disturbance will need to intensify quickly in order to reach tropical storm strength before landfall Wednesday night. {"uri": "8185609213", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:58:44", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:58:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:57:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.thedailyherald.sx/regional/tropical-storm-alberto-forms-over-the-western-gulf-of-mexico", "title": "...TROPICAL STORM ALBERTO FORMS OVER THE WESTERN GULF OF MEXICO...", "body": "...HEAVY RAINS, COASTAL FLOODING, AND GUSTY WINDS FORECAST ALONG THE COASTS OF TEXAS AND NORTHEASTERN MEXICO THROUGH THURSDAY...\n\nBULLETIN\n\nTropical Storm Alberto Advisory Number 8\n\nNWS National Hurricane Center Miami FL AL012024\n\n1000 AM CDT Wed Jun 19 2024\n\nSUMMARY OF 1000 AM CDT...1500 UTC...INFORMATION\n\n-----------------------------------------------\n\nLOCATION...22.2N 95.0W\n\nABOUT 185 MI...300 KM E OF TAMPICO MEXICO\n\nABOUT 295 MI...480 KM SSE OF BROWNSVILLE TEXAS\n\nMAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS...40 MPH...65 KM/H\n\nPRESENT MOVEMENT...W OR 270 DEGREES AT 9 MPH...15 KM/H\n\nMINIMUM CENTRAL PRESSURE...995 MB...29.39 INCHES\n\nWATCHES AND WARNINGS\n\n--------------------\n\nCHANGES WITH THIS ADVISORY:\n\nThe government of Mexico has extended the Tropical Storm Warning southward to Tecolutla.\n\nSUMMARY OF WATCHES AND WARNINGS IN EFFECT:\n\nA Tropical Storm Warning is in effect for...\n\n* the Texas coast from San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande\n\n* the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\nA Tropical Storm Warning means that tropical storm conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area.\n\nFor storm information specific to your area in the United States, including possible inland watches and warnings, please monitor products issued by your local National Weather Service forecast office. For storm information specific to your area outside of the United States, please monitor products issued by your national\n\nmeteorological service.\n\nDISCUSSION AND OUTLOOK\n\n----------------------\n\nAt 1000 AM CDT (1500 UTC), the center of Tropical Storm Alberto was located near latitude 22.2\n\nNorth, longitude 95.0 West. Alberto is moving toward the west near 9 mph (15 km/h). A westward motion with an increase in forward speed is expected through Thursday. On the forecast track, the center of Alberto will reach the coast of northeastern Mexico early Thursday morning.\n\nMaximum sustained winds are near 40 mph (65 km/h) with higher gusts. Some slight strengthening is forecast today or tonight before the center of Alberto reaches land. Rapid weakening is expected once the center moves inland, and Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico Thursday or Thursday night.\n\nAlberto is a large tropical storm, with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 415 miles (665 km) north of the center.\n\nThe minimum central pressure based on dropsonde data is 995 mb (29.39 inches).\n\nHAZARDS AFFECTING LAND\n\n----------------------\n\nRAINFALL: Tropical Storm Alberto is expected to produce rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South Texas. Maximum totals around 20 inches are possible across the higher terrain of the Mexican states of Coahuila, Nuevo Leon and Tamaulipas. This rainfall will likely produce considerable flash and urban flooding along with new and renewed river flooding. Mudslides are also possible in areas of higher terrain across northeast Mexico.\n\nSTORM SURGE: The combination of a dangerous storm surge and the tide will cause normally dry ar-eas near the coast to be flooded by rising waters moving inland from the shoreline. The water could reach the following heights above ground somewhere in the indicated areas if the peak surge occurs at the time of high tide...\n\nSargent, TX to Sabine Pass, TX...2-4 ft\n\nGalveston Bay...2-4 ft\n\nMouth of the Rio Grande, TX to Sargent, TX...1-3 ft\n\nSabine Pass, TX to Vermilion/Cameron Parish Line, LA...1-3 ft\n\nThe deepest water will occur along the immediate coast near and to the north of the landfall location, where the surge will be accompanied by large and dangerous waves. Surge-related flooding depends on the relative timing of the surge and the tidal cycle, and can vary greatly over short distances. For information specific to your area, please see products issued by your local National Weather Service forecast office.\n\nStorm surge will raise water levels by as much as 1 to 3 feet above normal tide levels along the imme-diate coast of northeastern Mexico in areas of onshore winds north of where the center makes land-fall. Near the coast, the surge will be accompanied by large and destructive waves.\n\nWIND: Tropical storm conditions are expected within the warning\n\narea today through early Thursday.\n\nTORNADOES: A couple of tornadoes are possible today and tonight across parts of Deep South Texas and Southeast Texas.\n\nSURF: Swells generated by Alberto will affect the coast of Texas and northeastern Mexico through Friday. These swells are likely to cause life-threatening surf and rip current conditions. Please consult products from your local weather office.\n\nForecaster Berg", "source": {"uri": "thedailyherald.sx", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Daily Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8185592264", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:46:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:46:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:45:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://edition.channel5belize.com/tropical-storm-alberto-forms/", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto Forms", "body": "Tropical Storm Alberto formed on Wednesday in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, marking the first named storm of what is expected to be a busy hurricane season. According to the National Hurricane Center in Miami, Alberto was positioned 185 miles east of Tampico, Mexico, and 295 miles south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas, with top sustained winds of 40 mph. A tropical storm has sustained winds between 39 and 73 mph; beyond that range, it becomes a hurricane.\n\nThe storm was moving west at 9 mph.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration forecasts a well above-average hurricane season, which began on June 1 and runs through November 30. They predict between 17 and 25 named storms, with up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. In comparison, an average Atlantic hurricane season typically produces 14 named storms, seven hurricanes, and three major hurricanes.", "source": {"uri": "edition.channel5belize.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-06-394944427", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:18:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:18:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:13:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://eu.news-journalonline.com/story/news/hurricane/2024/06/19/florida-hurricane-season-forecast-tropical-storm-alberto-born-storm-sequel-brews-weathertiger/74135051007/", "title": "Storm sequel on horizon? Alberto targets Texas, 'featherweight' system nears Florida", "body": "Dr. Ryan Truchelut at WeatherTiger explains hurricane forecast models.\n\nOne is expansive, the other petite; one is messy, the other is neat.\n\nWe've got an odd couple situation in the Tropics in the third week of hurricane season, with the first named storm of 2024 lumbering across the western Gulf and a featherweight disturbance set to approach Florida from the east. And like all venerable intellectual property, this classic set-up may well reboot into an immediate sequel early next week.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto is born with little chance to strengthen\n\nFirst things first: with its thunderstorm activity sprawling across the western half of the Gulf of Mexico, much of Central America, and a chunk of the Eastern Pacific, newly designated Tropical Storm Alberto is living large as it angles westward on a path towards northern Mexico. Alberto has slowly consolidated this week from a broad gyre of cyclonic rotation that sometimes forms over Central America early or late in the hurricane season, logically known as a Central American Gyre (CAG).\n\nWhile this gyre has lent Alberto its outsized attitude, the larger the disturbance, the slower the rate of strengthening. So, while Alberto is generating low-end tropical-storm-force gusts hundreds of miles north of its center, only modest additional intensification from its maximum winds of 40 mph as of 11 a.m. Wednesday is likely prior to landfall early Thursday.\n\nTropical Storm Warnings are in effect for South Texas and northern Mexico, and a few of feet of coastal storm surge will also continue in these areas for the next day or two.\n\nThe primary impact of Alberto will be flash flooding.\n\nStorm totals of 4-8\" are probable in the southern Rio Grande Valley, which may well cause localized flash floods, particularly in urban areas. South Texas is in a drought, so there will be some benefit to the region as well. Rains taper by Friday as Alberto clips westward through Mexico, guided by a powerful ridge of high pressure to its north.\n\nA breezy tropical system approaches Florida with little punch, increased rain chances\n\nThis week's jet stream pattern over the eastern United States has more ridges than Ruffles, so look for high pressure to also be the dominant influence on a diminutive disturbance several hundred miles east of Florida.\n\nThunderstorm activity with this small area of low pressure remains limited due to a nearby dry airmass, and it probably won't organize further prior to reaching Florida. However, a slim chance of last-minute development while crossing the Gulf Stream can't be ruled out, as unlike large storms, the intensity of small systems takes the elevator up (or down).\n\nEven if a depression or minimal tropical storm briefly forms, impacts on Florida will be little different than a typical day in June.\n\nExpect enhanced rain chances along Florida's Atlantic coast and into North Florida on Thursday and Friday, and continued breezy conditions into the weekend, but that's about it. In all likelihood, the only necessary watch or warning is a Clickbait Watch for the usual suspects on social media hyping this modest feature beyond what it is.\n\nA brief history of Albertos and expect something of a storm sequel into late June\n\nClimatologically, those two features should be plenty for late June. However, unlike twenty years ago when Spiderman rebooted every five years, today Spiderman reboots literally thousands of times per film, thus a tropical instant replay is in the works.\n\nThe gyre that never ends is expected to spit another disturbance into the southern Gulf of Mexico almost as soon as Alberto moves ashore, and models suggest this broad area of rotation may slowly become a tropical depression over the weekend.\n\nThe early read on track and impacts of this disturbance is that it might copy Alberto, though perhaps be a bit weaker, with a general path towards Mexico and rains extending north into Texas through early next week. Weirdly, this system may also be accompanied by its own small disturbance east of Florida, though indications are that will probably remain offshore, with an even lower chance of any tropical development than during round one.\n\nA final synchronicity worth mentioning: do you get d\u00e9j\u00e0 vu hearing about Alberto?\n\nIf so, that's because this isn't the name's first trip through the content mines.\n\nThis is the eighth iteration of a moniker that first hit the NHC list in 1982 and has repeated every six years since. Oddly, an Alberto has impacted Florida each dozen years starting in 1982, including tropical storm landfalls in 1994, 2006, and 2018.\n\nSo, while Alberto V08's path into the western Gulf fits that pattern, if history rhymes Floridians might want to set a Google Calendar reminder now to expect heavy rain in June 2030.\n\nIn the meantime, we've got our pair of comedically mismatched dyads to monitor this week, whether they are spreading rainfall to Florida and the Gulf Coast or working together by night to solve crimes in a CBS spin-off provisionally titled NHC: Miami.\n\nAs David Caruso might say if smugglers were trafficking contraband through Miami International Airport inside the tail engine of an L-1011, keep watching the skies.\n\nDr. Ryan Truchelut is chief meteorologist at WeatherTiger, a Tallahassee company providing forensic meteorology expert witness services, and agricultural and hurricane forecasting subscriptions. Visit weathertiger.com to discover how to put our expertise to work for you.", "source": {"uri": "eu.news-journalonline.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Florida Today"}, "authors": [], "concepts": The system has been classified as a potential tropical cyclone by the center since it has not yet become better organized, but is expected to become the first named storm system of the year by early Wednesday.\n\nThe port of Corpus Christi in South Texas and the Houston Ship Channel remained open as of Tuesday morning, but the nearby ports of Galveston and Texas City closed to inbound and outbound shipping traffic at 10pm ET Monday due to heavy weather, the US Coast Guard said.\n\nThe system was expected to disrupt ship-to-ship transfer operations off the Texas coast as of Monday evening because of heavy seas. In the Gulf of Mexico, the transfer typically is from an Aframax or Suezmax onto a very large crude carrier (VLCC) at designated lightering zones near Corpus Christi, Galveston and Beaumont-Port Arthur.\n\nProlonged lightering delays can prevent crude tanker tonnage from becoming available and exert upward pressure on freight rates, while also adding to demurrage fees.\n\nThe storm is expected to turn towards the west-northwest and west tonight and Wednesday, with the system forecast to approach the western Gulf coast late Wednesday, the NHC said.\n\nRainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches are seen across northeast Mexico into South Texas, with maximum totals of 15 inches possible. {"uri": "8186269777", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "03:46:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T03:46:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T03:45:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.nbcmiami.com/weather/hurricane-season/john-morales-tropical-storm-alberto-hurricane/3341599/", "title": "John Morales: As Alberto is deemed 2024's first named storm, we look back to 2020", "body": "The number 20 keeps popping into my head this week. Twenty inches of rain in South Florida in just a couple of days' time last week. The 20 of June. And the year 2020.\n\nAs this week began, two tropical disturbances were being monitored for potential development by the National Hurricane Center (NHC). The one in the Gulf of Mexico showed so much potential, that NHC labeled it early as Potential Tropical Cyclone One (PTC 1) and issued Tropical Storm Warnings for Mexico and South Texas.\n\nSatellite pictures and aircraft reconnaissance data showed a very large counterclockwise gyre taking up much of the western half of the Gulf of Mexico on Tuesday. The low-pressure system was so broad that it was struggling to consolidate into a well-defined tropical depression or storm. But on Wednesday, a better-defined center of circulation with a good deal of thunderstorm activity formed, and with that, the first named tropical storm of the year -- Alberto.\n\nThere is a moderate to severe drought across South Texas and especially in the Upper Rio Grande and West Texas. The same applies to many regions of northern Mexico. If there isn't going to be much of a windstorm with Alberto (at least compared to what Texas is accustomed to), then let there be drought-busting rains!\n\nRain is something we hope not to see much of for another week or two in South Florida. Early this week some neighborhoods still had standing water. Many families lost everything.\n\nAs NHC upped the chance for tropical development east of the Bahamas, forecast models were projecting that a deep plume of moisture could be drawn up from the south into our same part of Florida that just flooded.\n\nAs Tuesday and Wednesday went by, thankfully, that Atlantic disturbance showed no signs of organization. NHC lowered the chance for tropical cyclone formation to 20% (yes, another 20) in the next week, and models backed off from their projections that soupy deluge-producing air would park itself over South Florida by the weekend.\n\nWhich brings up the other 20s.\n\nWhat is the significance of the date June 20? That's the average date by which the first named tropical storm of the year forms in the Atlantic basin. Alberto made it just in the nick of time. Dare I say, the year is off to an average start?!\n\nMeteorologists try to learn from history to at least be prepared for a potential repeat. So, the year 2020 is in my mind too. It is the most recent year in which conditions in the tropical Atlantic are considered analog to 2024. Oceanic and atmospheric conditions this spring and early (meteorological) summer are in some ways similar to 2020. There were 30 named storms in the Atlantic that year, and some entities have predicted as many or more this year!\n\nBy this date in 2020, Arthur, Bertha, and Cristobal had already formed, and Dolly was about to. This year, only Alberto has been baptized in the Gulf.\n\nOkay, I'll say it: this year has not started off as everyone expected.", "source": {"uri": "nbcmiami.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC 6
