{"uri": "2024-06-394687811", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "12:26:11", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T12:26:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T11:04:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/us/tropical-storm-approaching-texas-while-northeast-braces-for-extreme-heat-wave/", "title": "\"Tropical Storm Approaching Texas while Northeast Braces for Extreme Heat Wave\" - Internewscast Journal", "body": "The United States was buffeted by extreme weather Wednesday, with Texas bracing for the first tropical storm of the hurricane season while the Northeast still faced a major heat wave.\n\nSouthern Texas braced for a major storm to hit late Wednesday into Thursday, with considerable flash flooding likely, according to forecasters.\n\nThe weather system, currently named Potential Tropical Cyclone One, is expected to be upgraded and renamed Tropical Storm Alberto by the time it makes landfall on the Gulf Coast of Mexico early Thursday.\n\nTropical storm warnings are in place along the Texas coast from the San Luis Pass to the mouth of the Rio Grande, with high winds and as much as 10 to 15 inches of rain expected in Corpus Christi. The state government enacted a large-scale emergency response in anticipation of widespread flooding.\n\nThe National Weather Center office in Houston said at 4:30 a.m. CT (5.:30 a.m. ET) that there had already been reports of coastal flooding as rain moves inland.\n\n\"The disturbance is very large, with rainfall, coastal flooding and wind impacts likely to occur far from the center along the coasts of Texas and northeastern Mexico, \" the National Hurricane Center said in an update.\n\nThe hurricane center also said early Wednesday that life-threatening mudslides were likely in higher areas of northern Mexico, including around the cities of Monterrey and Ciudad Victoria.\n\nOn Tuesday night, Texas Gov. Greg Abbott ordered the state Division of Emergency Management to put the Texas State Emergency Operations Center to a readiness of level 2, meaning it began 24-hour operations.\n\n\"As we prepare for severe tropical weather, Texas is activating all personnel and resources needed to support Texans and communities that will be potentially impacted by excessive rain and flooding,\" he said in a statement.\n\nThe Texas A&M Forest Service has mobilized four teams comprising of 100 personnel and 24 vehicles, while the Texas National Guard has three platoons of more than 40 personnel in total, alongside 20 vehicles, including Chinook helicopters.\n\nThe weather service told people in the affected areas to have five to seven days' supplies of food, water and other necessities.\n\nThe storm warning came as 71 million people were under some form of heat advisory or warning Wednesday, as a severe heat wave is set to last through Friday.\n\nSeveral parts of the Midwest, the interior Northeast and New England could reach temperatures of 95 degrees Fahrenheit or above Wednesday, with Bangor, Maine, set to hit 106 on the heat index, a measure of how hot it feels that factors in humidity.\n\nNBC News meteorologist Michelle Grossman warned early Wednesday that extreme heat is not to be taken lightly.\n\n\"It is dangerous -- extreme heat is the No. 1 weather-related killer, so you need to take it seriously,\" she said.\n\n\"If you don't have air conditioning, you need to find places, libraries, movies, a cooling center that will keep you cool and comfortable over the next several days,\" Grossman added.\n\nPeople in Syracuse, New York, were warned Tuesday not to open fire hydrants to get some relief from the heat. Fire Chief Michael Monds said in a statement that opening hydrants can affect firefighters' ability to tackle fires and to do so would bring a civil penalty that comes with a potential $500 fine.", Alberto to bring heavy rains, strong winds and flooding in Mexico and Texas - Travel And Tour World", "body": "Tropical storm Alberto is setting its sights on coastal regions of Mexico and Texas.\n\nIt has emerged as the first significant weather system of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season.\n\nThe storm which formed rapidly in the warm waters of the Gulf of Mexico may bring heavy rains, strong winds and potential flooding to areas along its projected path.\n\nAs of the latest updates from the National Hurricane Center (NHC), Alberto has intensified steadily, with maximum sustained winds reaching up to 60 miles per hour.\n\nMeteorologists are closely monitoring its movement as it moves northwestward at a pace of 12 miles per hour.\n\nOfficials in both Mexico and Texas are advising residents to prepare for possible impacts from Alberto.\n\nEmergency management teams are activating response plans, urging people in low-lying areas to consider evacuation as a precautionary measure against potential flooding.\n\nIn Mexico, particularly in coastal communities along the Gulf, preparations are underway to secure boats and evacuate vulnerable populations to shelters.\n\nAuthorities are urging residents to stock up on essential supplies and stay informed through local news and weather updates.\n\nIn Texas, coastal counties are bracing for heavy rainfall and gusty winds as Alberto approaches.\n\nLocal officials are urging residents to clear drainage systems and secure outdoor furniture and objects that could become projectiles in strong winds.\n\nForecast models indicate that Alberto will likely make landfall along the Gulf Coast within the next 24 to 36 hours, although the exact location remains uncertain.\n\nThe storm's impact is expected to be felt across a broad swath of the region, potentially affecting transportation, power infrastructure, and agriculture.\n\nThe NHC has issued tropical storm warnings and watches for various coastal areas, urging residents to heed official advice and take necessary precautions.\n\nSmall craft advisories are also in effect, warning mariners of dangerous sea conditions as Alberto churns through the Gulf waters.\n\nMeteorologists are continuing to track Alberto's progress closely, providing regular updates on its strength and trajectory.\n\nResidents are advised to stay tuned to official sources of information and to avoid spreading rumors or unverified reports during this critical period.\n\nAs communities in Mexico and Texas brace for the arrival of Tropical Storm Alberto, emergency responders and volunteers are standing by to assist those in need.\n\nThe storm serves as a stark reminder of the importance of preparedness and resilience in the face of natural The chance for development is 20%.\n\nThe second area is between Mexico and the Yucat\u00e1n Peninsula in the Gulf of Mexico. {"uri": "8187382541", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "16:25:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T16:25:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T16:24:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.sanpedrosun.com/weather/2024/06/20/first-tropical-storm-of-2024-hurricane-season-named/", "title": "First Tropical Storm of 2024 Hurricane Season named - The San Pedro Sun", "body": "On Wednesday, June 19th, the first named storm of the 2024 Atlantic Basin Hurricane Season is forming in the western region of the Gulf of Mexico. The storm, named Alberto, has sustained winds of 40 miles per hour. According to the National Hurricane Center, the storm will move slowly to the west, approaching northeastern Mexico. The effects were also felt along the coast of Texas in the United States, with strong winds and heavy rain.\n\nAlberto is expected to produce rainfall totals of five to ten inches across northeast Mexico and southern Texas. The maximum rainfall expected by late Thursday was 15 inches. There are concerns that this rainfall may lead to flash and urban flooding. A tropical storm warning has been issued for the Texas coast from Corpus Christi to the mouth of the Rio Grande. Forecasters shared that the Texas coast will gradually improve after Thursday.\n\nWhile this storm poses no threat to Belize, the country's weather has changed significantly over the past few days. Following the prolonged heat wave, the weather forecast calls for cloudy skies and cooler temperatures. The National Meteorological Service of Belize indicated on June 17th that heavy showers and thunderstorms can be expected over central and northern Belize over the following days.\n\nThis year, scientists forecast above-average activity for the North Atlantic basin, predicting 23 storms with an average of 14 named storms, 11 hurricanes with an average of seven hurricanes, and five major hurricanes with an average of three major hurricanes. According to them, this year also has an 85% chance of an \"above average\" season.\n\nBelizeans are advised to monitor any updates on the weather during the hurricane season and to follow information from official sources only. The most active period for tropical storms in Belize is from the end of August through mid-October. Residents of San Pedro Town are encouraged to make any necessary hurricane preparations.\n\nFor further reference on how to improve your emergency family plan, contact San Pedro National Emergency Management Organization Coordinator Vanessa Parham via WhatsApp or call 614-5865, or visit their official website https://site.nemo.org.bz/preparedness-guidelines for additional tips.", "source": {"uri": "8184877740", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "07:52:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T07:52:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T07:51:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://kpel965.com/ixp/33/p/hurricane-center-monitoring-additional-development-in-the-gulf/", "title": "Hurricane Center Monitoring Additional Development in the Gulf", "body": "The National Hurricane Center's forecast department is taking a page from Louisiana's used car dealers. As far as the Gulf of Mexico and tropical storm development is concerned, the NHC is \"stacking them deep\". No, we don't know about selling the cheap, but we do know there is another area of concern in the Gulf of Mexico besides the system currently known as Potential Tropical Cyclone One.\n\nFirst things first, let's get you caught up on PTC One. The graphic below is from the National Hurricane Center and it shows the projected track of that storm system. As you can see a landfall is expected in northern Mexico. At the time of landfall, the system is expected to have achieved Tropical Storm status. If it does, it would earn the name Alberto.\n\nThe effects of PTC One/Alberto on Louisiana are expected to be minimal. The state has already experienced an increase in tropical moisture and tropical showers spawned by the system but not much more than that is really projected for Louisiana. And as the system eventually moves onshore the threat of rain and storms spawned by it should decrease.\n\nMeanwhile, if you look at the graphic below also from the National Hurricane Center you can see the yellow shading beneath the \"Red X\". The \"X\" is PTC One but the yellow shading suggests another tropical system could be forming in that same area of the Gulf of Mexico over the next seven days.\n\nCurrent early weather model runs suggest a similar fate for that system if it develops at all. Right now the Hurricane Center is only suggesting a 30% probability of tropical cyclone formation over the next seven days. Of course, with sea surface water temps as warm as they are any system that does form in the Gulf will have the potential to strengthen. {"uri": "8184082442", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "18:08:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T18:08:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T18:06:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/science-environment/2987395-tropical-disturbance-threatens-texas-and-mexico-with-heavy-rainfall-and-flooding", "title": "Tropical Disturbance Threatens Texas and Mexico with Heavy Rainfall and Flooding | Science-Environment", "body": "Potential Tropical Cyclone One Intermediate Advisory Number 4A NWS National Hurricane Center Miami FL AL012024\n\n100 PM CDT Tue Jun 18 2024 ...DISTURBANCE REMAINS LARGE BUT DISORGANIZED OVER THE WESTERN Gulf of Mexico...\n\n...HEAVY RAINFALL AND COASTAL FLOODING EXPECTED ALONG THE COASTS OF TEXAS AND NORTHEASTERN Mexico OVER THE NEXT DAY OR TWO...\n\nABOUT 405 MI...655 KM SE OF BROWNSVILLE TEXAS MAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS...40 MPH...65 KM/H\n\nPRESENT MOVEMENT...NNE OR 20 DEGREES AT 6 MPH...9 KM/H MINIMUM CENTRAL PRESSURE...999 MB...29.50 INCHES\n\nSUMMARY OF WATCHES AND WARNINGS IN EFFECT: A Tropical Storm Warning is in effect for... * the Texas coast from Port O'Connor southward to the mouth of the\n\nRio Grande * the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Puerto de Altamira.\n\nA Tropical Storm Warning means that tropical storm conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area within 36 hours.\n\nFor storm information specific to your area in the United States, including possible inland watches and warnings, please\n\nmonitor products issued by your local National Weather Service forecast office. For storm information specific to your area\n\noutside of the United States, please monitor products issued by your national meteorological service.\n\nDISCUSSION AND OUTLOOK ----------------------\n\nAt 100 PM CDT (1800 UTC), the disturbance was centered near latitude 22.0 North, longitude 92.6 West. The system is moving toward the\n\nnorth-northeast near 6 mph (9 km/h). A turn toward the northwest and west with an increase in forward speed is expected tonight and\n\non Wednesday, and the system is forecast to reach the Gulf coast of Mexico by Wednesday night.\n\nMaximum sustained winds are near 40 mph (65 km/h) with higher gusts. Some increase in strength is likely during the next 36 hours,\n\nand the disturbance is forecast to become a tropical storm by Wednesday. * Formation chance through 48 hours...high...80 percent. * Formation chance through 7 days...high...80 percent.\n\nThe disturbance is quite large, and satellite-derived wind data indicate that tropical-storm-force winds extend outward up to 415\n\nmiles (665 km) north of the center. The minimum central pressure based on Air Force Reserve dropsonde\n\ndata is 999 mb (29.50 inches). HAZARDS AFFECTING LAND\n\n---------------------- Key messages for Potential Tropical Cyclone One can be found in the\n\nTropical Cyclone Discussion under AWIPS header MIATCDAT1 and WMO header WTNT41 KNHC.\n\nRAINFALL: Potential Tropical Cyclone One is expected to produce rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South\n\nTexas, with maximum totals of 15 inches possible. This rainfall will likely produce flash and urban flooding along with new and renewed\n\nriver flooding. Mudslides are also possible in areas of higher terrain across northeast Mexico.\n\nFor a complete depiction of forecast rainfall and flash flooding associated with Potential Tropical Cyclone One, please see the\n\nNational Weather Service Storm Total Rainfall Graphic, available at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at1.shtml?rainqpf and the Flash Flood Risk\n\ngraphic at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at1.shtml?ero STORM SURGE: The combination of a dangerous storm surge and\n\nthe tide will cause normally dry areas near the coast to be flooded by rising waters moving inland from the shoreline. The water could\n\nreach the following heights above ground somewhere in the indicated areas if the peak surge occurs at the time of high tide...\n\nSargent, TX to Sabine Pass, TX...2-4 ft Galveston Bay...2-4 ft\n\nMouth of the Rio Grande, TX to Sargent, TX...1-3 ft Sabine Pass, TX to Vermilion/Cameron Parish Line, LA...1-3 ft\n\nThe deepest water will occur along the immediate coast near and to the north of the landfall location, where the surge will be\n\naccompanied by large and dangerous waves. Surge-related flooding depends on the relative timing of the surge and the tidal cycle,\n\nand can vary greatly over short distances. For information specific to your area, please see products issued by your local\n\nNational Weather Service forecast office. For a complete depiction of areas at risk of storm surge inundation,\n\nplease see the National Weather Service Peak Storm Surge Graphic, available at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at1.shtml?peakSurge.\n\nIn Mexico, minor coastal flooding is possible north of where the center of the system crosses the coast in areas of onshore\n\nwinds. WIND: Tropical storm conditions are expected within the warning\n\narea by tonight or Wednesday. TORNADOES: A couple of tornadoes may occur across parts of Deep\n\nSouth Texas on Wednesday. SURF: Swells generated by the disturbance will affect the coast of\n\nTexas and northeastern Mexico through Wednesday night. These swells are likely to cause life-threatening surf and rip current\n\nconditions. Please consult products from your local weather office. You can find the latest information on that storm here.There is also an area of low pressure developing in the Atlantic, northeast of the Bahamas. The odds of that disturbance becoming a tropical depression are quite low, but the storm is expected to impact the southeast coast by the end of the week. The low would track west to west-northwest and bring rain to coastal Georgia and northern Florida on Friday and Saturday. Atlantic Ocean still shows little signs of forming into something more.\n\nWind speed: 40 mph sustained winds. \"Some slight strengthening is forecast (Wednesday or Wednesday night) before the center of Alberto reaches land,\" the National Hurricane Center said in its 11 a.m. Wednesday advisory.\n\n\"Rapid weakening is expected once the center moves inland, and Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico Thursday or Thursday night.\"\n\nWhere is it: About 185 miles east of Tampico, Mexico, and 295 miles south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas.\n\nMovement: Alberto is moving west at 9 mph. \"A westward motion with an increase in forward speed is expected through Thursday,\" the hurricane center said. \"On the forecast track, the center of Alberto will reach the coast of northeastern Mexico early Thursday morning.\"\n\nAlerts: There's a Tropical Storm Warning for the Texas coast from San Luis Pass down to the mouth of the Rio Grande River and for the northeastern Mexican coast from that mouth of the Rio Grande to Tecolutla.\n\nAdvisories: There will be an intermediate advisory at 2 p.m. Eastern time and a complete advisory at 5 p.m., Eastern time.\n\nThe Atlantic Disturbance\n\n\"An area of showers and thunderstorms located several hundred miles east of the Bahamas is associated with a surface trough of low pressure,\" the hurricane center's 8 a.m. Wednesday update said. {"uri": "2024-06-395304780", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "02:13:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T02:13:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T01:49:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.newsmax.com/us/texas-greg-abbott-tropical-storm-alberto/2024/06/19/id/1169409/", "title": "Texas Gov. Abbott Declares Disaster as Alberto Looms in Gulf", "body": "Texas Gov. Greg Abbott issued a disaster declaration for dozens of southern counties in the state Wednesday as Tropical Storm Alberto is forecast to hit landfall in northern Mexico on Thursday.\n\n\"I issued a disaster declaration today for 51 counties as Tropical Storm Alberto moves through the Gulf Coast. Texas continues to deploy all necessary assistance to impacted communities. Texans should remain vigilant to keep themselves and their families safe,\" Abbott posted on X along with his official declaration of a state of disaster.\n\nThe first named stormed of the 2024 hurricane season is predicted to bring strong winds and heavy rainfall with flooding expected along the coasts of Texas and Mexico. By Wednesday afternoon the storm had wind speeds up to 40 miles per house, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nAlberto is expected to make landfall just south of the U.S.-Mexico border early Thursday.\n\n\"The heavy rainfall and the water, as usual, is the biggest story in tropical storms,\" said Michael Brennan, director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Hurricane Center.\n\nAlberto is expected to produce rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico and into South Texas, forecasters said. Up to 20 inches are possible across the higher terrains in Mexico.\n\nInformation from The Associated Press was used in this report.\n\nJames Morley III \u2709 James Morley III is a writer with more Alberto is moving toward the west near 9 mph [15 km/h]. A westward motion with an increase in forward speed is expected through Thursday. On the forecast track, the center of Alberto will reach the coast of northeastern Mexico early Thursday morning.\n\n\"Maximum sustained winds are near 40 mph [65 km/h] with higher gusts. Some slight strengthening is forecast today or tonight before the center of Alberto reaches land. Rapid weakening is expected once the center moves inland, and Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico Thursday or Thursday night.\n\n\"Alberto is a large tropical storm, with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 415 miles [665 km] north of the center. (WBRC) - Summer begins Today: Today is the summer solstice which officially begins at 3:50 p.m.. And today will likely feel like summer.\n\nWe are seeing temperatures starting out in the 60s to 70s this morning. We will likely end up with partly cloudy skies by this afternoon. High temperatures are forecast to climb into the lower 90s with easterly winds continuing at five to 10 mph.\n\nIf you plan on attending the MLB game at Rickwood Field this evening, we are looking at temperatures near 90\u00b0F at the first pitch. It is expected to be partly cloudy with temperatures cooling into the lower 80s by the end of the game.\n\nNext Big Thing: The big story going into the weekend is that temperatures will continue to trend a little warmer. We will likely see high temperatures climb into the mid 90s Friday, Saturday, and Sunday. Humidity levels may increase a little Saturday and Sunday, so the heat index could flirt near 100\u00b0F. If you plan on working outdoors this weekend, you'll definitely want to take some breaks and stay hydrated. Your best bet is to work early in the morning while temperatures are in the 70s and 80s. The weekend will likely remain partly cloudy, so don't forget to apply the sunscreen too! The UV Index will remain very high.\n\nWe have to monitor a weak tropical disturbance in the Atlantic that could impact Georgia and Florida by the end of the week. It is forecast to move due west and could help generate a small rain chance for the southern half of Alabama Saturday. I've added a 20% chance for an isolated shower or storm Saturday. Widely scattered showers and storms are possible on Sunday. Scattered rain and storm chances may continue into early next week. We could really use the rain for our lawn and to help cool us off.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto forms: \"Potential Tropical Cyclone One\" has a closed low and the National Hurricane Center has upgraded it to Tropical Storm Alberto. It is the first name storm of the 2024 Atlantic Hurricane Season. Tropical Storm Warnings have been issued for coastal Texas from San Luis Pass southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande. While Alberto is forecast to make landfall in Mexico tonight, the impacts from the storm will be felt hundreds of miles north of the center of circulation in parts of Texas. Southern Texas could pick up five to 10 inches of rain. We have already seen storm surge flood parts of coastal Texas earlier this morning.\n\nThis system will not impact central Alabama, but it is creating a high rip current threat along the Gulf Coast. Double red flags are flying at the Alabama Gulf Coast today and tomorrow. It means you are not allowed in the water. The surf may back off a little over the weekend.\n\nWe continue to monitor two other systems that have a low chance to develop. An area of low pressure may form in the Atlantic and push west into the northern Bahamas and into Florida/Georgia over the weekend. Odds of development remain low at 20%. It could produce some rain and breezy conditions for Georgia and Florida Friday into Saturday. There's a chance that if any of it holds together, it could help generate a few showers across the southern half of Alabama Saturday. Another low could develop in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico over the weekend. Odds for tropical development remain low at 30%.\n\nThe same areas getting hit by Alberto now could receive more rain and wind over the weekend and into early next week. The next name on the 2024 Atlantic Hurricane list is Beryl. Tropical storm conditions with wind gusts up to 57 mph are expected along the Texas coast south of the San Luis Pass.\n\nHeavy rainfall and the threat of flash floods will intensify in the western Gulf Coast, according to National Hurricane Center Director Michael Brennan.\n\n\"Major rainfall flooding may prompt many evacuations and rescues,\" the weather service said. \"Rivers and tributaries may rapidly overflow their banks in multiple places. Small streams, creeks, canals, and ditches may become dangerous rivers. Flood control systems and barriers may become stressed.\"\n\nThe cyclone is predicted to bring rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches from northeastern Mexico to south Texas, possibly peaking at 15 inches. The weather service's office in Brownsville, Texas reported a 40% chance of rapid onset flooding Wednesday with rainfall totals of 2 to 3 inches possibly lasting hours.\n\nThe National Weather Service said that \"the situation is somewhat favorable for tornadoes\" and warned residents to seek safe shelter.\n\nForecasters said the eventual storm is expected to weaken upon landfall Wednesday night and diminish by Thursday evening. More downpours will continue across the Rio Grande Valley and south Texas on Thursday before conditions improve.\n\nTexas weather map\n\nUS weather watches and warnings\n\nNational weather It's expected to reach the northeastern coast of Florida or the Georgia coast early on Friday morning.\n\nEven if this system doesn't develop further, it's still expected to impact Florida's coast.\n\nFrom Thursday night to Friday morning, bands of breezy to gusty showers and isolated storms are expected north of Cape Canaveral, according to the National Weather Service office in Melbourne.\n\nHazardous beach and marine conditions are also expected along the coast. There's a high risk of life-threatening rip currents with large breaking waves at all of Central Florida's Atlantic beaches, forecasters said.\n\n\"Beachgoers should remain out of the water!\" NWS Melbourne said.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center is also monitoring a broad area of low pressure located in the Gulf of Mexico, near where Tropical Storm Alberto officially formed on Wednesday. There's a 50% chance that this disturbance forms over the next week.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto is currently located about 25 miles west of Tampico, Mexico, as of 8 a.m., the NHC said. Maximum sustained winds are near 45 mph, but weakening is expected as the first named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season moves inland over Mexico on Thursday. (WFLA) -- A \"very large\" disturbance in the Gulf of Mexico is expected to become the season's first tropical storm Wednesday.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said the system will bring as much as 15 inches of rain, coastal flooding and wind impacts to the coasts of Texas and northeastern Mexico.\n\nTropical storm conditions are expected Wednesday along portions of the Texas coast south of San Luis Pass and along portions of the coast of northeastern Mexico, the NHC said.\n\nThe system has an 80% chance of developing.\n\nThe NHC is also tracking an area of showers and thunderstorms located several hundred miles east of the Bahamas.\n\nWeather officials said this system could gradually develop over the next few days as it moves westward. It is expected to approach the coast of the southeastern United States by the latter part of this week. It has a 20% chance of developing.\n\nAnother disturbance could develop over the southwestern Gulf of Mexico this weekend, according to the NHC. Officials said the system could gradually develop through early next week as it moves slowly west-northwestward or northwestward. {"uri": "2024-06-394886333", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:21:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:21:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T11:03:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/florida/articles/2024-06-19/tropical-storm-alberto-forms-in-southwest-gulf-1st-named-storm-of-the-hurricane-season", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto Forms in Southwest Gulf, 1st Named Storm of the Hurricane Season", "body": "MIAMI (AP) -- Tropical Storm Alberto formed on Wednesday in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, the first named storm of what is forecast to be a busy hurricane season.\n\nAlberto was located 185 miles (about 300 kilometers) east of Tampico, Mexico and 295 miles (about 480 kilometers) south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas. It had top sustained winds of 40 mph (65 kph), according to the National Hurricane Center in Miami. A tropical storm is defined by sustained winds of between 39 and 73 mph (62 and 117 kph), and above that the system becomes a hurricane.\n\nThe storm was moving west at 9 mph (15 kph).\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicts the hurricane season that began June 1 and runs through Nov. 30 is likely to be well above average, with between 17 and 25 named storms. The forecast calls for as many as 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes.\n\nAn average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.\n\nA no-name storm earlier in June dumped more than 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain on parts of South Florida, stranding numerous motorists on flooded streets and pushing water into some homes in low-lying areas.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. For storm information specific to your area outside of the United States, please monitor products issued by your national\n\nmeteorological service.\n\nDISCUSSION AND OUTLOOK\n\n----------------------\n\nAt 700 AM CDT (1200 UTC), the disturbance was centered near latitude 21.5 North, longitude 92.8 West. The system is moving toward the north near 6 mph (9 km/h). A gradual turn toward the west-northwest and west is expected is expected tonight and Wednesday, and the system is likely to\n\napproach the western Gulf coast late Wednesday.\n\nMaximum sustained winds remain near 40 mph (65 km/h) with higher gusts. Some increase in strength is likely during the next 36 hours, and the disturbance is forecast to become a tropical storm by Wednesday.\n\n* Formation chance through 48 hours...high...80 percent.\n\n* Formation chance through 7 days...high...80 percent.\n\nThe disturbance is quite large with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 290 miles (465 km) to the northeast of the center.\n\nThe estimated minimum central pressure is 999 mb (29.50 inches).\n\nHAZARDS AFFECTING LAND\n\n----------------------\n\nRAINFALL: Potential Tropical Cyclone One is expected to produce rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South Texas, with maximum totals of 15 inches possible. This rainfall will likely produce flash and urban flooding along with new and renewed river flooding. Mudslides are al-so possible in areas of higher terrain across northeast Mexico.\n\nSTORM SURGE: The combination of a dangerous storm surge and the tide will cause normally dry areas near the coast to be flooded by rising waters moving inland from the shoreline. The water could reach the following heights above ground somewhere in the indicated areas if the peak surge occurs at the time of high tide...\n\nSargent, TX to Sabine Pass, TX...2-4 ft\n\nGalveston Bay...2-4 ft\n\nMouth of the Rio Grande, TX to Sargent, TX...1-3 ft\n\nSabine Pass, TX to Vermilion/Cameron Parish Line, LA...1-3 ft\n\nThe deepest water will occur along the immediate coast near and to the north of the landfall location, where the surge will be accompanied by large and dangerous waves. Surge-related flooding depends on the relative timing of the surge and the tidal cycle, and can vary greatly over short distances. For information specific to your area, please see products issued by your local National Weather Service forecast office.\n\nIn Mexico, minor coastal flooding is possible north of where the center of the system crosses the coast in areas of onshore winds.\n\nWIND: Tropical storm conditions are expected within the warning area by Wednesday.\n\nForecaster Berg", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8184236522", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "20:28:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T20:28:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T20:26:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.nola.com/news/hurricane/tropical-disturbances-hurricane-season-gulf/article_26fc6722-2d80-11ef-957f-af08ef319a97.html", "title": "How normal is the fairly busy start of 2024 hurricane season? Here's what experts say.", "body": "National Hurricane Center forecasters have had a busy week at the start of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season.\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone 1, forecast to become Tropical Storm Alberto at some point Tuesday, is expected to make landfall near northeast Mexico and South Texas this week.\n\nLarge and unorganized, the system that formed in the Bay of Campeche is expected to dump heavy rains and bring up to 4 feet of storm surge with it, and forecasters are already watching another disturbance behind it in the Gulf of Mexico.\n\nAt the same time, a disturbance in the Atlantic has a 20% chance for development over the next two days, according to the NHC.\n\nThe NHC forecast map is colorful already, and we're just 17 days into the season.\n\nThe developments have raised concerns that such early activity could foreshadow a very busy hurricane season as predicted by scientists, researchers and meteorologists.\n\nBut while an active season is predicted, there is no need to panic, one New Orleans-based weather expert with the NHC said Tuesday.\n\nHigh activity normal in active hurricane season\n\nTropical activity at the beginning of hurricane season, which starts on June 1, is not a cause of concern, said National Hurricane Center forecaster Mike Efferson.\n\nIt's not uncommon to see developments in the Atlantic and Gulf near the U.S. early on in the season, Efferson said, nothing that there have been several seasons in the last decade where forecasters were tracking systems before June 1.\n\n\"If we have an above-normal seasons, it's not odd to have a few more systems develop this early in the season,\" Efferson said.\n\nMany of the early developments in the Atlantic or Gulf may not strengthen into a tropical storm or hurricane, or affect land.\n\n\"There are about 100 waves that come across the African coast,\" Efferson said. \"And maybe 10% will develop into tropical storms or hurricanes.\"\n\nWhy do systems develop in the Gulf?\n\nSystems can develop early in the Gulf for a variety of reasons, Efferson said, including cold fronts, warming temperatures, weakening upper-level winds and easterly winds.\n\nThere are still some cold fronts moving toward the Gulf in May and June, creating tropical waves that could often develop into a disturbance or something stronger.\n\nDuring this time of year, upper-level winds in the Gulf start to weaken, allowing for potential development. These winds are not strong enough to hinder the development of a disturbance, Efferson said.\n\nEasterly winds, or winds that move from east to west, combined with showers and thunderstorms are another factor that promote system development. When this combination of winds and rain approaches the Central American coast, it starts to rotate in a broad area, creating a cyclonic rotation.\n\nHow busy could the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season be?\n\nHurricane forecasters and researchers predict that the 2024 season will be one of the most active in modern history due to La Nina's return and record warm waters in the Atlantic Ocean and in the Gulf.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicted that there is an 85% chance of this year's Atlantic hurricane season being above average.\n\nNOAA forecasters predict that there will be 17-25 named storms, with 8-13 of these storms reaching hurricane strength and 4-7 becoming major hurricanes, meaning a Category 3 or higher.\n\nIn June, Colorado State University researchers predicted that there will be 23 storms, with 11 reaching hurricane status and five becoming major hurricanes. CSU said that their predictions have been correct 64 percent of the time within the last nine years.\n\nWhat should you do to prepare?\n\nEven though early tropical activity in the Gulf is normal and expected during this time of year, Efferson said that people should still prepare in advance.\n\nThis means stocking up on essential items, such as nonperishable food, water and batteries, Efferson said. Cash or extra checkbooks, flashlights and medications are some other items that you should have in your hurricane kit.\n\nClick here to learn more about how to prepare for the hurricane season. If this is your first season in New Orleans, read our guide on how to prepare and what to expect.", "source": {"uri": "nola.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NOLA"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8185574743", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:33:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:33:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:32:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/us-world/tropical-storm-alberto-forms-in-southwest-gulf-1st-named-storm-of-the-hurricane-season/", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto forms in southwest Gulf, 1st named storm of the hurricane season - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "MIAMI (AP) -- Tropical Storm Alberto formed on Wednesday in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, the first named storm of what is forecast to be a busy hurricane season.\n\nAlberto was located 185 miles (about 300 kilometers) east of Tampico, Mexico and 295 miles (about 480 kilometers) south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas. It had top sustained winds of 40 mph (65 kph), according to the National Hurricane Center in Miami. A tropical storm is defined by sustained winds of between 39 and 73 mph (62 and 117 kph), and above that the system becomes a hurricane.\n\nThe storm was moving west at 9 mph (15 kph).\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicts the hurricane season that began June 1 and runs through Nov. 30 is likely to be well above average, with between 17 and 25 named storms. The forecast calls for as many as 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes.\n\nAn average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.\n\nA no-name storm earlier in June dumped more than 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain on parts of South Florida, stranding numerous motorists on flooded streets and pushing water into some homes in low-lying areas.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. Some isolated spots could see up to eight inches.\n\nEmergency management officials in Corpus Christi distributed pre-filled sandbags to residents on Tuesday, in time for the winds and heavy rains that began Wednesday morning.\n\nJace Johnson, emergency management coordinator in Corpus Christi, said the Gulf Coast city was only beginning to feel the effect of the storm. \"Some winds,\" he said, {"uri": "8185782237", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "18:17:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T18:17:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T18:16:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.staradvertiser.com/2024/06/19/breaking-news/tropical-storm-alberto-forms-over-gulf-of-mexico/", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto forms over Gulf of Mexico | Honolulu Star-Advertiser", "body": "A satellite image of Tropical Storm Alberto at 7:20 a.m. today is seen.\n\nMEXICO CITY >> Tropical Storm Alberto, the first named storm of 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, has formed over the western Gulf of Mexico, the U.S. National Hurricane Center (NHC) said today, bringing coastal flooding across the southern U.S. coast.\n\nThe storm was located about 185 miles east of Tampico, Mexico, packing maximum sustained winds of 40 mph (65 kph), the Miami-based forecaster said. Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico as early as Thursday night.\n\nThe NHC said the storm was very large and that rainfall, coastal flooding and strong winds could occur far from the center along north-eastern Mexico and the south Texas coast.\n\nHeavy rains will also impact large regions of Central America, the NHC warned, a region that is still facing strong rains that left some 11 people dead in El Salvador over the weekend, due to landslides and road accidents.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding and mudslides are likely in and near higher terrain across the Mexican states of Coahuila, Nuevo Leon and Tamaulipas,\" the NHC said, including the eastern city of Ciudad Victoria and Monterrey, Mexico's third-biggest city in Nuevo Leon state.\n\nNuevo Leon State Governor Samuel Garcia said on X that people should avoid leaving the house or crossing waterways if it is raining and to keep emergency kits at hand. Workers were ready to address possible impacts on the electricity grid, water and sewage supplies caused by strong winds and rains, he said.\n\nIn Tamaulipas state, which runs along the Gulf coast, videos shared on social media showed ominous gray skies, while in the United States as far as Louisiana videos showed flooded coastal towns and water smashing into sea walls.\n\nAcross the Gulf on Mexico's Yucatan peninsula, local news reported strong winds and torrential rains. Some authorities, however, said the storm could help fill the country's dams, depleted by an extended drought.\n\nThe NHC predicted \"moderate coastal flooding\" along much of the Texan coast through Thursday as southern areas experience tropical storm conditions.\n\nForecasters have warned that this year's Atlantic hurricane season will likely be highly active due to impacts from the La Nina It's the first Potential Tropical Cyclone of hurricane season. The system will become Tropical Storm Alberto if it produces sustained winds of at least 39 mph.According to the NHC, the storm is located over the Bay of Campeche. Regardless of development, the NHC predicts several days of heavy rainfall across portions of southern Mexico and Central America, which can cause life-threatening floods. By the middle of the week, this heavy rainfall is expected to expand into portions of Texas and Louisiana. Any system that forms will likely take a quick turn to the northwest and approach the Mexico coast or perhaps southern Texas by Wednesday night or early Thursday. More detail about the system's exact strength and track will become available when it develops a center of circulation over the next 48 hours. {"uri": "8185591162", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:46:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:46:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:44:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/hurricanewire/tropical-storm-activity-lowcountry-coast-south-carolina/article_e41bb96a-2e3a-11ef-8b58-475db5f2f38f.html", "title": "Activity ramps up in the Atlantic Basin. What does it mean for the Lowcountry?", "body": "Subscribe to our Hurricane Wire newsletter to receive updates directly to your inbox.\n\nThe Atlantic hurricane season is less than three weeks old, and activity is picking up as three weather systems are being tracked in the Atlantic Basin.\n\nOne of those, referred to as Disturbance 1, is expected to make landfall on June 20 or 21 along the U.S. southeastern coast -- though it has been weakening along the way. Currently several hundred miles east of the Bahamas, its potential to develop into a tropical cyclone over the foreseeable future is low, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nBeaufort County Feds release their forecast for the 2024 hurricane season. It's not pretty. By Tony Kukulich tkukulich@postandcourier.com\n\n\"The system is rather disorganized and most of our models indicate that it will not become a tropical cyclone as it approaches the southeast coast,\" Steven Taylor, lead meteorologist with the NSW office in Charleston, told The Post and Courier. \"They system is going to keep gusty winds blowing along the coast, which will increase the chance for rip currents and high surf for the next few days.\"\n\nRain can be expected as the disturbance makes landfall on Thursday night or Friday morning, but no extreme weather conditions or flooding are expected.\n\n\"It doesn't look like this system is going to be a significant player in terms of any kinds of severe weather for the area other than the rip current risk,\" Taylor added.\n\nA system spinning in the Gulf of Mexico, the aptly named Potential Tropical Cyclone One, has a high likelihood of becoming the season's first tropical cyclone, which the National Weather Service says could happen June 19.\n\nBeaufort County News Controversial hotel, parking garage project in downtown Beaufort paused indefinitely By Tony Kukulich tkukulich@postandcourier.com\n\nTropical storm warnings are up along the the Gulf Coast of Texas and Mexico.\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone One is moving toward the west-northwest at around near 8 mph, and an increase in forward speed is expected during the next day or so. The system is forecast to reach the coast of northeastern Mexico by late Wednesday or early Thursday. It presents no threat to South Carolina.\n\nCommunity News Hurricane evacuation changes enhance safety, efficiency Brandon Roberts broberts@journalscene.com\n\nMaximum sustained winds remain near 40 mph with higher gusts. Some increase in strength is possible before the system reaches the coast.\n\nA third system that is also in the western Gulf of Mexico, Disturbance 2, appears to pose no serious threat as it has a low chance of becoming a tropical cyclone.\n\nThe onshore winds are keeping temperatures moderate along the coast of the Palmetto State, though that is forecast to change. Temperatures should begin to rising over the weekend and into next week.\n\n\"By Monday, we can be looking at excessive heat indices of 105 to 110 degrees, which would potentially see a heat advisory for the area Monday,\" Taylor warned.\n\nSign up for our free Hurricane Wire newsletter Hurricane Wire is a pop-up newsletter during hurricane season that delivers anyone who lives on the East Coast all the information they need to know as storms brew in the Atlantic and beyond.\n\nEmail\n\nSUBSCRIBE", "source": {"uri": "postandcourier.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Post and Courier"}, Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico as early as Thursday night.\n\nThe NHC said the storm was very large and that rainfall, coastal flooding and strong winds could occur far from the center along north-eastern Mexico and the south Texas coast.\n\nHeavy rains also will affect large regions of Central America, the NHC warned, a region that is still facing strong rains that left some 11 people dead in El Salvador over the weekend because of landslides and road accidents.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding and mudslides are likely in and near higher terrain across the Mexican states of Coahuila, Nuevo Leon and Tamaulipas,\" the NHC said, including the eastern city of Ciudad Victoria and Monterrey, Mexico's third-biggest city in Nuevo Leon state.\n\nNuevo Leon State Governor Samuel Garcia said on the social media platform X that people should avoid leaving the house or crossing waterways while it is raining and to keep emergency kits on hand. {"uri": "8185669746", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "17:23:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T17:23:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:43:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/storm-sequel-horizon-alberto-targets-161346378.html", "title": "Storm sequel on horizon? Alberto targets Texas, 'featherweight' system nears Florida", "body": "One is expansive, the other petite; one is messy, the other is neat.\n\nWe've got an odd couple situation in the Tropics in the third week of hurricane season, with the first named storm of 2024 lumbering across the western Gulf and a featherweight disturbance set to approach Florida from the east. And like all venerable intellectual property, this classic set-up may well reboot into an immediate sequel early next week.\n\nFirst things first: with its thunderstorm activity sprawling across the western half of the Gulf of Mexico, much of Central America, and a chunk of the Eastern Pacific, newly designated Tropical Storm Alberto is living large as it angles westward on a path towards northern Mexico. Alberto has slowly consolidated this week from a broad gyre of cyclonic rotation that sometimes forms over Central America early or late in the hurricane season, logically known as a Central American Gyre (CAG).\n\nWhile this gyre has lent Alberto its outsized attitude, the larger the disturbance, the slower the rate of strengthening. So, while Alberto is generating low-end tropical-storm-force gusts hundreds of miles north of its center, only modest additional intensification from its maximum winds of 40 mph as of 11 a.m. Wednesday is likely prior to landfall early Thursday.\n\nTropical Storm Warnings are in effect for South Texas and northern Mexico, and a few of feet of coastal storm surge will also continue in these areas for the next day or two.\n\nThe primary impact of Alberto will be flash flooding.\n\nStorm totals of 4-8\" are probable in the southern Rio Grande Valley, which may well cause localized flash floods, particularly in urban areas. South Texas is in a drought, so there will be some benefit to the region as well. Rains taper by Friday as Alberto clips westward through Mexico, guided by a powerful ridge of high pressure to its north.\n\nThis week's jet stream pattern over the eastern United States has more ridges than Ruffles, so look for high pressure to also be the dominant influence on a diminutive disturbance several hundred miles east of Florida.\n\nThunderstorm activity with this small area of low pressure remains limited due to a nearby dry airmass, and it probably won't organize further prior to reaching Florida. However, a slim chance of last-minute development while crossing the Gulf Stream can't be ruled out, as unlike large storms, the intensity of small systems takes the elevator up (or down).\n\nEven if a depression or minimal tropical storm briefly forms, impacts on Florida will be little different than a typical day in June.\n\nExpect enhanced rain chances along Florida's Atlantic coast and into North Florida on Thursday and Friday, and continued breezy conditions into the weekend, but that's about it. In all likelihood, the only necessary watch or warning is a Clickbait Watch for the usual suspects on social media hyping this modest feature beyond what it is.\n\nClimatologically, those two features should be plenty for late June. However, unlike twenty years ago when Spiderman rebooted every five years, today Spiderman reboots literally thousands of times per film, thus a tropical instant replay is in the works.\n\nThe gyre that never ends is expected to spit another disturbance into the southern Gulf of Mexico almost as soon as Alberto moves ashore, and models suggest this broad area of rotation may slowly become a tropical depression over the weekend.\n\nThe early read on track and impacts of this disturbance is that it might copy Alberto, though perhaps be a bit weaker, with a general path towards Mexico and rains extending north into Texas through early next week. Weirdly, this system may also be accompanied by its own small disturbance east of Florida, though indications are that will probably remain offshore, with an even lower chance of any tropical development than during round one.\n\nA final synchronicity worth mentioning: do you get d\u00e9j\u00e0 vu hearing about Alberto?\n\nIf so, that's because this isn't the name's first trip through the content mines.\n\nThis is the eighth iteration of a moniker that first hit the NHC list in 1982 and has repeated every six years since. Oddly, an Alberto has impacted Florida each dozen years starting in 1982, including tropical storm landfalls in 1994, 2006, and 2018.\n\nSo, while Alberto V08's path into the western Gulf fits that pattern, if history rhymes Floridians might want to set a Google Calendar reminder now to expect heavy rain in June 2030.\n\nIn the meantime, we've got our pair of comedically mismatched dyads to monitor this week, whether they are spreading rainfall to Florida and the Gulf Coast or working together by night to solve crimes in a CBS spin-off provisionally titled NHC: Miami.\n\nAs David Caruso might say if smugglers were trafficking contraband through Miami International Airport inside the tail engine of an L-1011, keep watching the skies.\n\nDr. Ryan Truchelut is chief meteorologist at WeatherTiger, a Tallahassee company providing forensic meteorology expert witness services, and agricultural and hurricane forecasting subscriptions. Visit weathertiger.com to discover how to put our expertise to work for you.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"eng": "Tropical cyclone"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_America", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Central America"}, "location": null}, {"uri": SUMMARY OF 700 PM CDT...0000 UTC...INFORMATION\n\n---------------------------------------------- LOCATION...20.5N 93.0W\n\nABOUT 375 MI...620 KM SE OF LA PESCA Mexico ABOUT 465 MI...750 KM SE OF BROWNSVILLE TEXAS\n\nMAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS...40 MPH...65 KM/H PRESENT MOVEMENT...NNW OR 345 DEGREES AT 7 MPH...11 KM/H\n\nMINIMUM CENTRAL PRESSURE...999 MB...29.50 INCHES WATCHES AND WARNINGS\n\nA Tropical Storm Watch is in effect for... * The Texas coast from Port O'Connor southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande * The northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio\n\nGrande to Boca de Catan. A Tropical Storm Watch means that tropical storm conditions are\n\npossible within the watch area, generally within 48 hours. For storm information specific to your area in the United\n\nStates, including possible inland watches and warnings, please monitor products issued by your local National Weather Service\n\nforecast office. For storm information specific to your area outside of the United States, please monitor products issued by\n\nyour national meteorological service. DISCUSSION AND OUTLOOK\n\n---------------------- At 700 PM CDT (0000 UTC), the poorly defined disturbance was\n\ncentered near latitude 20.5 North, longitude 93.0 West. The system is moving toward the north-northwest near 7 mph (11 km/h), and this\n\ngeneral motion is expected to continue through Tuesday. A turn toward the west-northwest is expected Tuesday night or Wednesday,\n\nand system is likely to approach the western Gulf coast late Wednesday.\n\nMaximum sustained winds remain near 40 mph (65 km/h) with higher gusts. The disturbance is forecast to to become a tropical storm\n\nby Wednesday. * Formation chance through 48 hours...high...80 percent. * Formation chance through 7 days...high...80 percent. The disturbance is quite large with tropical-storm-force winds\n\nextending outward up to 290 miles (465 km) to the northeast of the center.\n\nThe estimated minimum central pressure is 999 mb (29.50 inches) based on Air Force Reserve dropsonde data.\n\nHAZARDS AFFECTING LAND ----------------------\n\nKey messages for Potential Tropical Cyclone One can be found in the Tropical Cyclone Discussion under AWIPS header MIATCDAT1 and WMO\n\nheader WTNT41 KNHC. RAINFALL: Potential Tropical Cyclone One is expected to produce\n\nrainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into southeastern Texas, with maximum totals of 15 inches possible. This\n\nrainfall will likely produce flash and urban flooding along with new and renewed river flooding. Mudslides are also possible in\n\nareas of higher terrain across northeast Mexico. For a complete depiction of forecast rainfall and flash flooding\n\nassociated with Potential Tropical Cyclone One, please see the National Weather Service Storm Total Rainfall Graphic, available at\n\nhurricanes.gov/graphics_at1.shtml?rainqpf and the Flash Flood Risk graphic at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at1.shtml?ero\n\nSTORM SURGE: The combination of a dangerous storm surge and the tide will cause normally dry areas near the coast to be flooded\n\nby rising waters moving inland from the shoreline. The water could reach the following heights above ground somewhere in the indicated\n\nareas if the peak surge occurs at the time of high tide... Sargent, TX to Sabine Pass, TX...2-4 ft\n\nGalveston Bay...2-4 ft Mouth of the Rio Grande, TX to Sargent, TX...1-3 ft\n\nSabine Pass, TX to Vermilion/Cameron Parish Line, LA...1-3 ft The deepest water will occur along the immediate coast near and to\n\nthe north of the landfall location, where the surge will be accompanied by large and dangerous waves. Surge-related flooding\n\ndepends on the relative timing of the surge and the tidal cycle, and can vary greatly over short distances. For information\n\nspecific to your area, please see products issued by your local National Weather Service forecast office.\n\nFor a complete depiction of areas at risk of storm surge inundation, please see the National Weather Service Peak\n\nStorm Surge Graphic, available at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at1.shtml?peakSurge.\n\nIn Mexico, minor coastal flooding is possible north of where the center of the disturbance crosses the coast in areas of onshore\n\nwinds. The patch of disturbed weather is moving at 10 to 15 mph and is expected to reach the northeastern coast of Florida or the Georgia coast early Friday.\n\nThe small area of low pressure is currently moving northwest from the Bahamas and producing disorganized showers and thunderstorms, according to federal meteorologists.\n\nIf the system does reach Florida, its impacts would likely be contained to the greater Jacksonville area, said Rodney Wynn, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service's Tampa Bay office.\n\n\"We're not concerned about this area at all,\" he said. \"If it does develop into something, that will be very weak and most likely impact the Carolinas more than it will Florida.\"\n\nAn Air Force Reserve reconnaissance plane is on standby to investigate the system Thursday afternoon, if deemed necessary, the hurricane center says.\n\nFederal meteorologists are also watching a broad area of low pressure expected to form over southeastern Mexico and northern Central America Friday. The tropical storm killed three people there, but also brought much-needed rain to a region experiencing severe drought.\n\nIn Texas, coastal areas were seeing some road flooding and dangerous rip currents Wednesday. {"uri": "8187559673", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:44:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:44:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:43:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2024/06/20/tropical-storm-alberto-texas-mexico/3111718902967/", "title": "Deadly Tropical Storm Alberto inundates inland areas of coastal Texas, Mexico - UPI.com", "body": "The storm was moving westward along the Gulf of Mexico before it moved inland. By mid-morning, the storm was downgraded to a tropical depression as it traveled about 18 mph and packed 35-mph winds through central Mexico.\n\nDespite being downgraded, the National Hurrican Center warned Alberto still poses a threat to the region, due to heavy rain that can cause flooding and mudslides.\n\nTexas Gov. Greg Abbott on Wednesday issued a severe weather disaster declaration for 51 counties in anticipation of the heavy rainfall, coastal flooding and tropical force winds the storm was likely to produce.\n\n\"I urge Texans in at risk-areas to remain weather aware and heed the guidance of state and local officials to keep themselves and their families safe,\" Abbott said Wednesday.\n\nThe National Weather Service on Thursday reported winds above 50 mph in the Galveston Bay area and and rainfall totals of about 2 to 7 inches across the coastal bend.\n\nAccuWeather predicted rainfall totals of about 8 to 12 inches for the Big Bend area of Texas, and winds could reach speeds of up to 60 mph.\n\nStorm surge along the coast of northeastern Mexico, Texas and western Louisiana peaked at 1 to 3 feet, according to AccuWeather, but the Houston and Galveston areas could see up to 6 feet in some low-lying areas until conditions ease into Friday.\n\nFootage from CNN on Thursday morning showed the coastal town of Surfside Beach in Texas besieged by high waves crashing over a seawall and flooding residential areas.\n\nSurfside Mayor Gregg Bisso said the cleanup effort is on hold after the high water levels made it unsafe, but recovery will resume once the water has subsided enough.\n\nThe city also limited access to Follet's Island's west end where about 100 homes were left without power in the wake of the storm. Only residents, contractors and people with rental agreements can access that side of the island.\n\nAccess to the beach is also prohibited.\n\n\"We haven't even been able to get down on the beach yet to take a look at it, to see what it's what it looks like, see how much damage we've had to our dunes and things like that,\" Bisso said. \"As we get down there, we'll be able to assess the situation a lot better.\"\n\nIn San Antonio, CPS Energy said about 1,400 of its 938,000 customers were left without power on Thursday morning.\n\nThe White House on Thursday said President Joe Biden was briefed on Alberto, as well as on wildfires in the southwest United States and extreme heat across the rest of the country.\n\nIn Mexico, meanwhile, there were four confirmed deaths related to Alberto as of Thursday.\n\nOfficials in the northeastern state of Nuevo Le\u00f3n said a man died early Thursday morning when he was trying to repair a window on his home.\n\nSevere weather conditions caused by Alberto also claimed the lives of three minors on Wednesday. One 16-year-old boy drowned in Monterrey when he entered the La Silla River to try to retrieve a ball.\n\nThe other two minors were killed by electrocution from a light pole while riding their bikes in Pino Su\u00e1rez.\n\nResidents in northeastern Mexico, however, see Alberto as also bringing much needed rain to the region, which for over a year has suffered from severe drought.\n\nErick Te\u00f3dulo Cavazos Cavazos, director of Civil Protection of Nuevo Le\u00f3n, told local media on Thursday that rains from Alberto are resupplying dams such as La Boca and El Cuchillo.\n\n\"We have to wait for the figures from El Cuchillo, but everything that comes from the Santa Catarina River and the La Silla River goes to El Cuchillo,\" he said. \"We also had a dam that was in a water crisis in the entire Linares region, in the municipality of Cerro Prieto, water is entering.\"\n\nAccuWeather also is keeping an eye on a possible second tropical storm system that could form this weekend and once again hammer notheastern Mexico and southern Texas.\n\n\"There is a moderate chance for development from June 21-23 across a similar area in the Gulf of Mexico,\" said AccuWeather Meteorologist Andrew Kienzle. \"This feature will need to be watched for possible impacts on the Gulf coasts of the United States and Mexico this weekend into early next week.\"", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-394609316", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "11:17:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T11:17:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T11:10:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://www.wesh.com/article/potential-tropical-cyclone-one-tropical-storm/61170546", "title": "Texas, Mexico brace for tropical storm conditions ahead of Potential Tropical Cyclone One", "body": "The National Hurricane Center is tracking \"Potential Tropical Cyclone One\" as it continues to loom off the coast of Mexico on Wednesday morning.The system is forecast to become Tropical Storm Alberto some time today, the NHC said, most likely before it makes landfall on Wednesday night. While the system is producing winds of 40 mph (and even a 63 mph wind gust well north), it does not yet have a closed circulation -- preventing the upgrade to a tropical storm. On Tuesday, the NHC said the disturbance remains large but disorganized. More: What is a \"Potential Tropical Cyclone?\"As the system approaches land, the NHC is concerned about heavy rainfall and moderate flooding. The tropical downpours are likely to impact large regions of Central America, northeastern Mexico and south Texas.Tropical storm warnings have been issued for a majority of these areas as conditions are expected to worsen today. Life-threatening flooding and even mudslides are possible, the NHC said. With a new cone issued on Wednesday morning, the NHC reminds users to not focus on the exact forecast track of this system. According to the NHC, the disturbance is very large and could produce dangerous conditions far from its center. Formation chance remains high for Potential Tropical Cyclone One, holding at 80% for both the next 48 hours and the next seven days.For more information on conditions, warnings, maps and more, click here. More: Difference between tropical storm, hurricane watch and warningSouthwestern Atlantic Ocean:The NHC is watching another area of cloudiness and showers closer to Central Florida -- several hundred miles east of the Bahamas.Officials say environmental conditions could be conducive for some gradual development during the next few days as the system moves west or northwest, though the chance remains low and has decreased from previous forecasts (10% in the next 48 hours; 20% in the next seven days).The NHC says the system is forecast to approach the southeastern United States on Friday.Southwestern Gulf of Mexico:Additionally, the NHC has its eye on another broad area of low pressure that is forecast to develop in the Gulf of Mexico this weekend. Environmental conditions are expected to be conducive for gradual development of this system early next week, the NHC says.The formation chance in the next 48 hours is low (at 0%), and the chance for formation over the next seven days has increased slightly, staying low at 30%.>>> Surviving the Season | 2024 Hurricane Special from WESH 2>>> WESH 2 Hurricane Survival Guide 2024\n\nThe National Hurricane Center is tracking \"Potential Tropical Cyclone One\" as it continues to loom off the coast of Mexico on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe system is forecast to become Tropical Storm Alberto some time today, the NHC said, most likely before it makes landfall on Wednesday night.\n\nWhile the system is producing winds of 40 mph (and even a 63 mph wind gust well north), it does not yet have a closed circulation -- preventing the upgrade to a tropical storm. On Tuesday, the NHC said the disturbance remains large but disorganized.\n\nMore: What is a \"Potential Tropical Cyclone?\"\n\nAs the system approaches land, the NHC is concerned about heavy rainfall and moderate flooding. The tropical downpours are likely to impact large regions of Central America, northeastern Mexico and south Texas.\n\nTropical storm warnings have been issued for a majority of these areas as conditions are expected to worsen today. Life-threatening flooding and even mudslides are possible, the NHC said.\n\nWith a new cone issued on Wednesday morning, the NHC reminds users to not focus on the exact forecast track of this system. According to the NHC, the disturbance is very large and could produce dangerous conditions far from its center.\n\nFormation chance remains high for Potential Tropical Cyclone One, holding at 80% for both the next 48 hours and the next seven days.\n\nThe NHC is watching another area of cloudiness and showers closer to Central Florida -- several hundred miles east of the Bahamas.\n\nOfficials say environmental conditions could be conducive for some gradual development during the next few days as the system moves west or northwest, though the chance remains low and has decreased from previous forecasts (10% in the next 48 hours; 20% in the next seven days).\n\nThe NHC says the system is forecast to approach the southeastern United States on Friday.\n\nSouthwestern Gulf of Mexico:\n\nAdditionally, the NHC has its eye on another broad area of low pressure that is forecast to develop in the Gulf of Mexico this weekend. Environmental conditions are expected to be conducive for gradual development of this system early next week, the NHC says.\n\nThe formation chance in the next 48 hours is low (at 0%), and the chance Track system, see possible impacts", "body": "As Tropical Storm Alberto made landfall in Mexico Thursday morning, the National Hurricane Center is tracking two disturbances that could become tropical depressions in the coming days.\n\nOne of them, now called Invest 92L, is located off the eastern coast of Florida and is expected to approach Northeast Florida or the Georgia coast Friday, June 21, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe second disturbance is in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico and has an even higher chance for development. The National Hurricane Center said it could become a tropical depression over the weekend.\n\nThe next named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season will be Beryl.\n\nA small area of low pressure -- Invest 92L -- located about 150 miles east of the northernmost Bahamas continues to produce disorganized showers and thunderstorms, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\u27a4 Tropics watch, June 20: National Hurricane Center tracking 2 tropical disturbances and TS Alberto\n\nWhile environmental conditions are only marginally conducive due to nearby dry air, further development of this system could lead to the development of a tropical depression while the low moves west-northwest at 10 to 15 mph and approaches the northeastern coast of Florida or the Georgia coast early on Friday.\n\nAn Air Force Reserve reconnaissance aircraft was scheduled to investigate this system Thursday afternoon, if necessary.\n\nSpecial note about spaghetti models: Illustrations include an array of forecast tools and models, and not all are created equal. The hurricane center uses only the top four or five highest performing models to help make its forecasts.\n\n\"Thunderstorm activity with this small area of low pressure remains limited due to a nearby dry airmass, and it probably won't organize further prior to reaching Florida,\" said Dr. Ryan Truchelut is chief meteorologist at WeatherTiger.\n\n\"However, a slim chance of last-minute development while crossing the Gulf Stream can't be ruled out, as unlike large storms, the intensity of small systems takes the elevator up (or down).\n\n\"Even if a depression or minimal tropical storm briefly forms, impacts on Florida will be little different than a typical day in June. Expect enhanced rain chances along Florida's Atlantic coast and into North Florida on Thursday and Friday, and continued breezy conditions into the weekend, but that's about it\" Truchelut said.\n\nTruchelut works with the USA TODAY Network-Florida to provide the latest storm information Florida residents need.\n\nStorm sequel on horizon? Alberto targets Texas, 'featherweight' system nears Florida\n\n\"Regardless of development, this feature can bring high seas, gusty winds and areas of heavy rain and thunderstorms to the Southeast coast,\" said AccuWeather Meteorologist Andrew Kienzle.\n\nAccuWeather predicted that from late Thursday to Saturday, 1 to 2 inches of rain could fall along the Southeast coastal regions, particularly across southeastern Georgia.\n\n\"Wind gusts directly along the coastline can reach speeds upward of 25-35 mph as this feature advances northwestward over the upcoming days,\" AccuWeather said.\n\nInvest 92L is expected to move across North Central Florida late Thursday night, Friday morning, according to the National Weather Service Jacksonville.\n\nThe disturbance has the potential to bring numerous showers and embedded thunderstorms with a potential of heavy rainfall and gusty winds.\n\nIt \"still appears as this feature is moving too fast to become organized into significant tropical system, but some convective gusts to gale force and localized flooding possible in urban areas and along the beachfront locations during times of high tide late tonight,\" NWS forecasters said.\n\nWhile Invest 92L had a 40 percent chance of developing into a tropical depression as it approaches Florida and Georgia, regardless of development, \"the main threats with any storms will be The NHC identified the system a few hundred miles from the Bahamas at the beginning of the week, but has now tagged that small area of low pressure as Invest 92-L. The invest, which was last located about 250 miles east of the northernmost Bahamas, is producing disorganized showers and thunderstorms, the NHC said. So far, environmental conditions are only marginally conducive for development due to nearby dry air, but the NHC says further development is possible as Invest 92-L moves northwest and approaches the southeast coast of the United States. Invest 92-L is expected to approach the northeastern coast of Florida as well as Georgia early on Friday morning, according to the NHC. Formation chances remain low, holding at 30% for both the next 48 hours and the next seven days. Tropical Storm Alberto: As of Thursday morning, Alberto had not made landfall in Mexico -- but the NHC is watching closely. The storm is producing winds of 50 mph, but those are expected to decrease one the tropical storm hits land. Alberto is expected to bring a large amount of rainfall to Mexico, Central America and Texas and it moves across the area and back out into the Pacific. The NHC says they are most concerned about life-threatening floods and the potential for mudslides. For more information on wind speeds, warnings, maps and more, click here. Another disturbance: The NHC is tracking a third disturbance located in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, which is forecast to form near the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico on Friday. According to the NHC, environmental conditions appear conducive for gradual development and add that it's possible this disturbance will form into a tropical depression this weekend. It is expected to move slowly to the northwest.
