{"uri": "8182580265", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "22:04:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T22:04:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T22:03:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://www.click2houston.com/news/local/2024/06/17/tropical-storm-watch-issued-for-parts-of-texas-coast-as-area-of-low-pressure-churns-in-bay-of-campeche/", "title": "Tropical Storm Watch issued for parts of Texas coast as area of low pressure churns in Bay of Campeche", "body": "The National Hurricane Center has begun issuing advisories on an area of low pressure, designated Potential Tropical Cyclone 1, which is currently located in the Bay of Campeche.\n\nRecommended Videos\n\nA Tropical Storm Watch has been issued along the Texas coast from Port O'Connor southward to the mouth of the Rio Grande. A Tropical Storm Watch has also been issued for the Mexican coast south of the mouth of the Rio Grande to Boca de Catan.\n\nHouston will get the 'dirty side' of this week's tropical system. Here's what it means for us\n\nHere is the current information on the system from the National Hurricane Center as of 4 p.m. Monday:\n\nLOCATION...20.3N 93.2W\n\nABOUT 380 MI...615 KM SE OF LA PESCA MEXICO\n\nABOUT 470 MI...755 KM SE OF BROWNSVILLE TEXAS\n\nMAXIMUM SUSTAINED WINDS...40 MPH...65 KM/H\n\nPRESENT MOVEMENT...NNW OR 345 DEGREES AT 7 MPH...11 KM/H\n\nMINIMUM CENTRAL PRESSURE...1001 MB...29.56 INCHES\n\nAt 400 PM CDT (2100 UTC), the disturbance was centered near latitude 20.3 North, longitude 93.2 West. The system is moving toward the north-northwest near 7 mph (11 km/h) and this general motion is expected to continue through Tuesday. A turn toward the west-northwest is expected Tuesday night or Wednesday, and system is likely to approach the western Gulf coast late Wednesday. Maximum sustained winds are near 40 mph (65 km/h) with higher gusts. Some slow strengthening is possible, and the disturbance is forecast to become a tropical storm by Wednesday.\n\n* Formation chance through 48 hours...high...70 percent.\n\n* Formation chance through 7 days...high...70 percent.\n\nThe disturbance is quite large with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 290 miles (465 km) to the northeast of the center. The estimated minimum central pressure is 1001 mb (29.56 inches).\n\nHAZARDS AFFECTING LAND\n\n----------------------\n\nRAINFALL: Potential Tropical Cyclone One is expected to produce rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South Texas, with maximum totals of 15 inches possible. This rainfall will likely produce flash and urban flooding along with new and renewed river flooding. Mudslides are also possible in areas of higher terrain across northeast Mexico. For a complete depiction of forecast rainfall and flash flooding associated with Potential Tropical Cyclone One, please see the National Weather Service Storm Total Rainfall Graphic, available at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at1.shtml?rainqpf and the Flash Flood Risk graphic at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at1.shtml?ero\n\nSTORM SURGE: The combination of a dangerous storm surge and the tide will cause normally dry areas near the coast to be flooded by rising waters moving inland from the shoreline. The water could reach the following heights above ground somewhere in the indicated areas if the peak surge occurs at the time of high tide...\n\nSargent, TX to Sabine Pass, TX...2-4 ft\n\nGalveston Bay...2-4 ft\n\nMouth of the Rio Grande, TX to Sargent, TX...1-3 ft\n\nSabine Pass, TX to Vermilion/Cameron Parish Line, LA...1-3 ft\n\nThe deepest water will occur along the immediate coast near and to the north of the landfall location, where the surge will be accompanied by large and dangerous waves. Surge-related flooding depends on the relative timing of the surge and the tidal cycle, and can vary greatly over short distances. For information specific to your area, please see products issued by your local National Weather Service forecast office. For a complete depiction of areas at risk of storm surge inundation, please see the National Weather Service Peak Storm Surge Graphic, available at hurricanes.gov/graphics_at1.shtml?peakSurge. In Mexico, minor coastal flooding is possible north of where the center of the disturbance crosses the coast in areas of onshore winds.\n\nWIND: Tropical storm conditions are possible within the watch area by Wednesday.\n\nFlood threat increasing in Houston this week\n\nThe next advisory from the National Hurricane Center will be at 10 p.m.", "source": {"uri": "click2houston.com", "dataType": Currently, upper-level cloud cover from this system is visible over north and central Georgia.\n\nIf it becomes a tropical storm, it is expected to be named Alberto. Meteorologists are closely observing the storm's development and potential to strengthen into a tropical cyclone.\n\n\ud83d\udcca By The Numbers:\n\n\ud83c\udf0d The Big Picture: This marks the beginning of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, which typically runs from June 1 to November 30. Early disturbances like this one are common and often set the stage for the season's activity. The southeastern U.S. frequently experiences impacts from Gulf-originated storms, making vigilance essential.\n\n\ud83c\udf1f Why It Matters: For residents of the southeastern U.S., early-season storms can bring heavy rainfall, flooding, and strong winds. What the data says", "body": "The first named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season could be christened soon, as just a little strengthening is needed for Potential Tropical Cyclone One to become Tropical Storm Alberto. Forecasters have warned the system could bring rain and minor coastal flooding to South Mississippi, even though its predicted landfall is hundreds of miles away.\n\nRegardless, this is the latest in the season that we have made it without a named storm since 2014, when powerful Arthur kicked the hurricane season off with a Category 2 storm.\n\nHere is a look at the first storm from the past 10 Atlantic hurricane seasons, with the dates of the first named storm, along with damages and deaths that were recorded.\n\n2023: Arlene, June 1 to 3\n\nA subtropical storm with maximum sustained winds of 70 mph, Arlene struck Western Cuba and South Florida, but did not cause any reported damage.\n\n2022: Alex, June 5 to 6\n\nA tropical storm with maximum sustained winds of 70 mph, Alex made landfall in Bermuda, the Northern Bahamas, Cuba, Florida and the Yucatan Peninsula. The storm killed four people and caused more than $100,000 in damage.\n\n2021: Ana, May 22 to 23\n\nA tropical storm with maximum sustained winds of just 45 mph, Ana struck Bermuda, but did not cause any reported damage.\n\n2020: Arthur, May 16 to 19\n\nA tropical storm with maximum sustained winds of 60 mph, Arthur did not make landfall, but approached land closely enough to cause more than $110,000 in damage. Arthur ultimately passed within 20 miles of Cape Hatteras, N,C.\n\n2019: Andrea, May 20 to 21\n\nA subtropical system with maximum sustained winds of 40 mph, Andrea most closely approached Bermuda, but did not cause any damage.\n\n2018: Alberto, May 25 to 31\n\nWhile Alberto never reached hurricane status, and its maximum sustained winds never exceeded 65 mph, the storm caused 18 deaths and more than $125 million in damage. Alberto developed in the Gulf of Mexico near the Yucatan Peninsula, and made its way north, with a landfall near Laguna Beach, Fla. Alberto passed through the entire United States, dissipating over Ontario, Canada.\n\n2017: Arlene, April 19 to 21\n\nA tropical storm with maximum sustained winds of 50 mph, Arlene never threatened land.\n\n2016: Alex, January 12 to 15\n\nAn exceptionally rare January hurricane, the first of its kind since Alice in 1955. Alex was born near the Bahamas and passed near Bermuda before dissipating in the Atlantic Ocean. Damage from the storm was minimal and there were no deaths.\n\n2015: Ana, May 8 to 11\n\nA tropical storm with maximum sustained winds of 60 mph, Ana formed off the east coast of Florida. The storm moved north, making landfall near North Myrtle Beach, S.C. Two deaths are attributed to the storm in North Carolina.\n\n2014: Arthur, July 1 to 5\n\nA hurricane that reached Category 2 status, with maximum sustained winds of 100 mph, Arthur caused nearly $40 million in damage and 2 deaths. Arthur gained Tropical Storm status over Grand Bahama, and would become the earliest storm on record to make landfall in North Carolina, coming ashore at Shackleford Banks.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8183667422", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "13:18:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T13:18:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T13:17:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://www.nola.com/news/hurricane/potential-cyclone-another-disturbance-gulf-forecasters-hurricane-season/article_8420f42c-2d67-11ef-8a1c-1b3b43ca528e.html", "title": "Tropical storm likely to form as NHC forecasters predict new disturbance in Gulf this weekend", "body": "The disturbance in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico will likely form into a tropical storm as National Hurricane Center forecasters predict another disturbance developing this weekend.\n\nNeither disturbance is currently expected to come near Louisiana.\n\nNHC forecasters have been monitoring Potential Tropical Cyclone One in the southwestern Gulf since last Wednesday. The chance of the disturbance forming into a tropical storm within the next two days is high, or 80%. NHC forecasters predict that the storm, which will be named Alberto, will slowly strengthen as it moves northwest and eventually west-northwest, posing a threat to Mexico and south Texas.\n\nAnother disturbance is forecast to develop over the southwestern Gulf of Mexico this weekend, the NHC said Tuesday morning. The system could gradually develop early next week as it slowly drifts northward or northwestward. The chance of formation within the next two days is near zero, while the formation chance within the next week is at 20%.\n\nWhile the potential cyclone does not pose a direct threat on Louisiana, NHC forecasters have issued coastal flooding advisories for the southeast portions of the state. Advisories have not been issued for New Orleans or Baton Rouge. Louisianans can also expect showers and gusty winds into midweek due to the system.\n\nNHC forecasters have been tracking a different disturbance, now located in the southwestern Atlantic Ocean, since last Tuesday. The system will likely develop early next week as it slowly moves northward or northwestward. It is expected to come toward the coast of southeastern U.S. Friday.\n\nIt is not rare for there to be tropical activity this early in the hurricane season, which takes place between June 1 and November 30.\n\nDon't miss a storm update this hurricane season. {"uri": "8185914333", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "20:28:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T20:28:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T20:26:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/very-large-storm-alberto-brings-floods-to-gulf-of-mexico-coasts/article_924fb9b7-9158-5ead-958b-ebb5791f03b4.html", "title": "'Very large' Storm Alberto brings floods to Gulf of Mexico coasts", "body": "By Sarah Morland and Stephanie Hamel\n\nMEXICO CITY (Reuters) -Tropical Storm Alberto, the first named storm of 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, has formed over the western Gulf of Mexico, the U.S. National Hurricane Center (NHC) said on Wednesday, bringing coastal flooding across the southern U.S. coast.\n\nThe \"very large\" storm was located about 180 miles (290 km) east of Tampico, Mexico, packing maximum sustained winds of 40 mph (65 kph), the Miami-based forecaster said.\n\nAlberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico as early as Thursday night, after bringing torrential rainfall, coastal flooding and strong winds from the center along north-eastern Mexico and the south Texas coast.\n\nThe NHC warned of likely \"life-threatening flooding and mudslides\" across north-eastern Mexico, including Monterrey, Mexico's third-biggest city in Nuevo Leon state.\n\n\"We don't rule out that Tropical Storm Alberto could intensify to a Category 1 hurricane\", Alejandra Mendez, who heads Mexico's SMN national meteorological service, told a news conference, citing water temperatures above 31\u00b0C (88\u00b0F).\n\nHurricanes have sustained wind speeds of at least 119 kph.\n\nMendez added the storm was interacting with formations in the Pacific, which will together bring rains over large parts of Central America, a region that is still facing strong rainfall that left some 11 people dead in El Salvador over the weekend, due to landslides and road accidents.\n\nThe storm has gathered up humidity from both the Gulf and the Pacific Ocean, Mendez said, and should bring much-needed rain over swathes of Mexico, which has suffered from an extended drought that has drained the country's dams.\n\nSome dams, especially in the north-eastern Tamaulipas state, are as little as 8% full.\n\nNuevo Leon state Governor Samuel Garcia said people should avoid leaving the house when it is raining and workers were ready to address possible impacts on the electricity grid, water and sewage systems.\n\nIn the United States as far as Louisiana, videos showed flooded coastal towns and water smashing into sea walls, while in Tamaulipas, videos shared on social media showed ominous gray skies as forecasters warned Alberto could bring waves as high as 20 feet (6 meters).\n\nAcross the Gulf on Mexico's Yucatan peninsula, local news outlets filmed strong winds and heavy rainfall, after authorities recorded as much as 192 millimeters in the last day.\n\nThe NHC predicted \"moderate coastal flooding\" along much of the Texan coast through Thursday, while Mexican forecasters expect further weekend rains in the south from another formation over the Caribbean.\n\nForecasters have warned that this year's Atlantic hurricane season will likely be highly active due to impacts from the La Nina weather pattern and warmer ocean waters.\n\n(Reporting by Brijesh Patel in Bengaluru, Stephanie Hamel in Gdansk and Sarah Morland in Mexico City; Editing by Lisa Shumaker and Sandra Maler)\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE GAZETTE", "source": {"uri": "gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": It is expected to develop over the southwestern Gulf over the weekend and move slowly west-northwest or northwest.\n\nMeanwhile, forecasters are watching an area of storminess several hundred miles east of the northwestern Bahamas that could approach the southern U.S. East Coast, potentially including Florida, late this week.\n\nAs of 8 a.m. Thursday, it has a 40% chance of development over the next two days, with some slow development possible thereafter while the system moves west-northwestward. Remember: Turn Around, Don't Drown.\"\n\nScripps News meteorologist Scott Withers said heavy rains will really start to pick up Wednesday, with places like Corpus Christi facing upwards of seven inches of rain by this weekend. Government forecasters expect 17 to 25 systems will become at least tropical storms in 2024, with eight to 13 hurricanes and four to seven major hurricanes.\n\nThe record for tropical storms and hurricanes in a year was 30 in 2020. However we do have a wind advisory in effect for today through this morning along the immediate coastline.\"\n\nTexas Governor Greg Abbott Wednesday issued a disaster declaration for 51 counties including Harris and Galveston in response to the tropical storm. A disaster declaration authorizes aid from all available state government and political subdivision resources, according to a press release from the governor's office.\n\nTexans are urged to heed the guidance of state and local officials during the tropical storm's impacts, Abbott said in a statement.\n\n\"We will probably still have some lingering wind gusts around 20 to 30 miles per hour, and even though the tropical storm warnings have been cancelled this morning, we do still have the coast flood warnings in effect through this evening,\" Fowler said on Thursday. \"In fact the elevated tides will be similar to yesterday, so we are anticipating moderate to significant coastal flooding.\"\n\nIn Galveston, lifeguard towers were relocated to higher ground and red flags were blown by strong tropical winds on Wednesday. Galveston ferry operations remained temporarily suspended amid high tides. Debris and sand washed ashore the Bolivar Peninsula Wednesday.\n\nRELATED: Houston area avoiding most impacts from Tropical Storm Alberto\n\nOne to three inches of rain was recorded across coastal Texas cities on Wednesday with some isolated higher amounts. (WNCN) -- Tropical Storm Alberto has made landfall in northeastern Mexico near Tampico. It will quickly weaken as it moves over land and mountainous terrain. It would be named Beryl. According to the National Hurricane Center, a broad area of low pressure is likely to develop and move into a favorable environment for tropical development.\n\nMeanwhile, a small area of low pressure about 250 miles east of the northernmost Bahamas is producing disorganized shower and thunderstorms. The chance of tropical development has increased to 30% over the next 2 days and 7 days. Highs Tuesday will top out in the mid-to-upper 80s along the coast and lower 90s inland.\n\nWinds will pick up out of the east through Tuesday, gusting to near 30 mph at times.\n\nRain chances hover at 30-40% for much of the week.\n\nStorm chances will have a slightly better chance to move more inland Wednesday.\n\nTropics update:\n\nThe disturbance in the southwest Gulf of Mexico has been designated as Potential Tropical Cyclone 1 by the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThis designation is given by the hurricane center when the storm is not yet tropical meteorologically but is expected to become a tropical storm and impact land soon.\n\nA disturbance east of Florida is also being highlighted for possible tropical development. Track system, see possible impacts", "body": "Storm chaser Mike Scantlin reported live from Rockport, Texas, on June 19, as Tropical Storm Alberto pounded the coast with flooding.\n\nAs Tropical Storm Alberto made landfall in Mexico Thursday morning, the National Hurricane Center is tracking two disturbances that could become tropical depressions in the coming days.\n\nOne of them, now called Invest 92L, is located off the eastern coast of Florida and is expected to approach Northeast Florida or the Georgia coast Friday, June 21, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe second disturbance is in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico and has an even higher chance for development. The National Hurricane Center said it could become a tropical depression over the weekend.\n\nThe next named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season will be Beryl.\n\nInvest 92L: National Hurricane Center forecast for system east of Florida\n\nA small area of low pressure -- Invest 92L -- located about 150 miles east of the northernmost Bahamas continues to produce disorganized showers and thunderstorms, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\u27a4 Tropics watch, June 20: National Hurricane Center tracking 2 tropical disturbances and TS Alberto\n\nWhile environmental conditions are only marginally conducive due to nearby dry air, further development of this system could lead to the development of a tropical depression while the low moves west-northwest at 10 to 15 mph and approaches the northeastern coast of Florida or the Georgia coast early on Friday.\n\nAn Air Force Reserve reconnaissance aircraft was scheduled to investigate this system Thursday afternoon, if necessary.\n\nSpaghetti models for Invest 92L as it moves toward Florida, Georgia\n\nSpecial note about spaghetti models: Illustrations include an array of forecast tools and models, and not all are created equal. The hurricane center uses only the top four or five highest performing models to help make its forecasts.\n\nWeathertiger on Invest 92L: 'Impacts on Florida little different than typical day in June'\n\n\"Thunderstorm activity with this small area of low pressure remains limited due to a nearby dry airmass, and it probably won't organize further prior to reaching Florida,\" said Dr. Ryan Truchelut is chief meteorologist at WeatherTiger.\n\n\"However, a slim chance of last-minute development while crossing the Gulf Stream can't be ruled out, as unlike large storms, the intensity of small systems takes the elevator up (or down).\n\n\"Even if a depression or minimal tropical storm briefly forms, impacts on Florida will be little different than a typical day in June. Expect enhanced rain chances along Florida's Atlantic coast and into North Florida on Thursday and Friday, and continued breezy conditions into the weekend, but that's about it\" Truchelut said.\n\nTruchelut works with the USA TODAY Network-Florida to provide the latest storm information Florida residents need.\n\nStorm sequel on horizon? Alberto targets Texas, 'featherweight' system nears Florida\n\nIsolated storms, gusty winds, dangerous surf possible as Invest 92L nears Florida\n\n\"Regardless of development, this feature can bring high seas, gusty winds and areas of heavy rain and thunderstorms to the Southeast coast,\" said AccuWeather Meteorologist Andrew Kienzle.\n\nAccuWeather predicted that from late Thursday to Saturday, 1 to 2 inches of rain could fall along the Southeast coastal regions, particularly across southeastern Georgia.\n\n\"Wind gusts directly along the coastline can reach speeds upward of 25-35 mph as this feature advances northwestward over the upcoming days,\" AccuWeather said.\n\nWatches, warnings issued across Florida, Georgia, South Carolina\n\nNational Weather Service Jacksonville, Florida, warns heavy rainfall, gusty winds possible\n\nInvest 92L is expected to move across North Central Florida late Thursday night, Friday morning, according to the National Weather Service Jacksonville.\n\nThe disturbance has the potential to bring numerous showers and embedded thunderstorms with a potential of heavy rainfall and gusty winds.\n\nIt \"still appears as this feature is moving too fast to become organized into significant tropical system, but some convective gusts to gale force and localized flooding possible in urban areas and along the beachfront locations during times of high tide late tonight,\" NWS forecasters said.\n\nRadar: See satellite view of Invest 92L\n\nIsolated storms, hazardous beach conditions ahead for East Central Florida coastline\n\nWhile strikes, local enhancement of gusty winds, and brief heavy downpours,\" the National Weather Service Melbourne said.\n\nBands of \"breezy to gusty showers and isolated storms are expected, especially Here's everything you need to know.", "body": "Tropical Storm Alberto became the first named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season Wednesday morning, threatening northeast Mexico and south Texas as it moves through the Gulf of Mexico.\n\nWhile the system does not currently pose a threat to Louisiana, portions of the state are already facing indirect impacts, such as heavy rain, gusty winds and coastal flooding. People took to social media Wednesday to post photos and videos of cars battling through the flooded streets of Grand Isle.\n\nThe National Weather Service in New Orleans has issued flash flood warnings to portions of southeast Louisiana coastline, including Orleans, St. Bernard and St. Tammany parishes.\n\nShortly after Alberto reached tropical storm strength, Louisiana State Police announced that troopers are monitoring high waters on La. Highway 1 between Golden Meadow and Grand Isle in Lafourche Parish. Some other minor coastal flooding was spotted south of Highway 22 in Tangipahoa Parish.\n\nNWS forecasters also issued a wind advisory to parts of southeast Louisiana and coastal areas along Interstate 12 Wednesday from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Winds are expected to reach 20-25 mph, with gusts up to 40 mph.\n\nResidents in southeast Louisiana can expect persistent winds and flooding Wednesday and Thursday, as well as possibly Friday, according to NWS forecaster Mike Efferson.\n\nNational Hurricane Center forecasters have been monitoring another tropical disturbance in the southwestern Gulf since Tuesday. The system is expected to gradually develop through early next week as it drifts west-northwestward or northwestward.\n\nThe second disturbance in the Gulf does not pose a threat to Louisiana. While southeast region of the state has faced impacts loosely related to the formation of Tropical Storm Alberto, it is unknown if any other system in the Gulf will have the same effects.", "source": {"uri": "2024-06-395036935", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "18:05:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T18:05:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T13:45:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-06-19/tropical-storm-alberto-forms-over-gulf-of-mexico-bringing-floods", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto Forms Over Gulf of Mexico, Bringing Floods", "body": "MEXICO CITY (Reuters) - Tropical Storm Alberto, the first named storm of 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, has formed over the western Gulf of Mexico, the U.S. National Hurricane Center (NHC) said on Wednesday, bringing coastal flooding across the southern U.S. coast.\n\nThe storm was located about 185 miles (300 km) east of Tampico, Mexico, packing maximum sustained winds of 40 mph (65 kph), the Miami-based forecaster said. Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico as early as Thursday night.\n\nThe NHC said the storm was very large and that rainfall, coastal flooding and strong winds could occur far from the center along north-eastern Mexico and the south Texas coast.\n\nHeavy rains will also impact large regions of Central America, the NHC warned, a region that is still facing strong rains that left some 11 people dead in El Salvador over the weekend, due to landslides and road accidents.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding and mudslides are likely in and near higher terrain across the Mexican states of Coahuila, Nuevo Leon and Tamaulipas,\" the NHC said, including the eastern city of Ciudad Victoria and Monterrey, Mexico's third-biggest city in Nuevo Leon state.\n\nNuevo Leon State Governor Samuel Garcia said on X that people should avoid leaving the house or crossing waterways if it is raining and to keep emergency kits at hand. Workers were ready to address possible impacts on the electricity grid, water and sewage supplies caused by strong winds and rains, he said.\n\nIn Tamaulipas state, which runs along the Gulf coast, videos shared on social media showed ominous gray skies, while in the United States as far as Louisiana videos showed flooded coastal towns and water smashing into sea walls.\n\nAcross the Gulf on Mexico's Yucatan peninsula, local news reported strong winds and torrential rains. Some authorities, however, said the storm could help fill the country's dams, depleted by an extended drought.\n\nThe NHC predicted \"moderate coastal flooding\" along much of the Texan coast through Thursday as southern areas experience tropical storm conditions.\n\nForecasters have warned that this year's Atlantic hurricane season will likely be highly active due to impacts from the La Nina weather pattern and warmer ocean waters.\n\n(Reporting by Brijesh Patel in Bengaluru, Stephanie Hamel in Gdansk and Sarah Morland in Mexico City; Editing by Lisa Shumaker and Sandra Maler)", "source": "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://www.foxweather.com/weather-news/tracking-alberto-landfall-2024", "title": "Tropical Storm Alberto makes landfall in Mexico", "body": "The reign of the Atlantic basin's first tropical cyclone of the season is quickly coming to an end with its landfall in northeastern Mexico.\n\nAlberto became classified as a tropical storm Wednesday morning after Hurricane Hunters and satellite data indicated a low-level circulation had formed underneath a mass of thunderstorm activity in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center had been tracking the disturbance for several days and even classified the system as Potential Tropical Cyclone One, which enabled government meteorologists to issue watches and warnings ahead of its naming.\n\nThe system's origin can be traced back to the Central American Gyre or what is commonly referred to as the CAG.\n\nThe weather phenomenon is usually evident a few times a year and can produce torrential rainfall and deadly landslides throughout the seven countries that are sandwiched between Mexico and South America.\n\nDRONE VIDEO: TROPICAL STORM ALBERTO LEAVES TEXAS BEACH TOWNS UNDERWATER\n\nBefore the tropical storm gained any sort of designation, its torrential rainfall was problematic for countries south of Mexico and laid the foundation for flooding and landslides that claimed the lives of at least 14 people.\n\nAuthorities in El Salvador and neighboring Guatemala closed schools and opened shelters as hundreds of rescue operations took place.\n\nPTC One and two other areas of disturbed weather produced feet of rainfall over the mountainous terrain, leading to mudslides and landslides.\n\nOnce the moisture that would become Alberto emerged into the Bay of Campeche, only slow organization took place, allowing the NHC to eventually classify the system as a tropical storm.\n\nCENTRAL AMERICAN GYRE TRIGGERS DEADLY FLOODING, LANDSLIDES\n\nDue to Alberto's poor organization and a stiff pressure gradient over the Gulf of Mexico, coastal flooding appeared to have the greatest impacts during the event.\n\nFlooded roadways were reported from Louisiana to South Texas, as water levels rose 3-5 feet, according to initial estimates.\n\nTexas communities such as Treasure Island, Surfside Beach and areas near San Luis Pass appeared to take the brunt from Alberto, with residents waking up to flooded roadways and mailboxes that were nearly underwater Wednesday.\n\nThe state's governor declared a severe weather disaster for 51 counties in the event that flooding, tornadoes or wind damage was too extensive for local authorities to respond to efficiently.\n\nWhat's left of Alberto is expected to mostly rain itself out during the next few days over communities west of Tampico, Mexico.\n\nThe region is important for agriculture, which has been hard hit by drought and heat waves due to a strong El Ni\u00f1o climate pattern.\n\nAccording to the latest North America Drought Monitor, some communities are in the most extreme drought possible, with shortages of water and widespread crop failures.\n\nNOAA anticipates a widespread 4-6 inches of precipitation will likely fall from Alberto and possibly a foot or more over the high terrain.", "source": {"uri": "foxweather.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FOX Weather"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8184265349", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "20:56:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T20:56:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T20:55:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://www.wbrz.com/news/tuesday-pm-forecast-ditching-the-dreary-pattern-for-one-more-typical-of-summer/", "title": "Tuesday PM Forecast: Ditching the dreary pattern for one more typical of summer", "body": "Tropical moisture will soon push westward, allowing a pattern more typical of summer to take over. Drier, warmer, and sunnier days are ahead.\n\nTonight & Tomorrow: Remaining showers will fizzle out with the loss of daytime heating on Tuesday night. We'll keep mostly cloudy skies overnight with mild temperatures. Look for a low temperature near 76\u00b0. The stream of tropical moisture from recent days will nudge westward on Wednesday. This will result in some degree of sunshine peeking through the clouds. The added sunshine will push highs into the low-90s. Enough moisture will be present to spark isolated afternoon showers and storms. However, much of the day will be dry and not all spots will see rain.\n\nEven though soon-to-be Alberto (see The Tropics section) will remain well to the southwest, the system will help enhance winds speeds locally. The wind should be noticeable on Wednesday, with sustained winds out of the east at 10-20 mph.\n\nUp Next: The typical summertime pattern makes a comeback by the end of the week. Highs will climb into the mid-90s, winds will back off, and sunshine will take up more of the sky. We cannot rule out a garden variety pop-up storm or two each afternoon, but most stay dry from day-to-day.\n\nThe Tropics: Potential Tropical Cyclone One is still ongoing in the Bay of Campeche. The \"Potential Tropical Cyclone\" term is a designation from the National Hurricane Center for systems that have yet to become tropical in nature, but will likely do so and make landfall within 48 hours. No direct impacts are anticipated for south Louisiana, but Tropical Storm Warnings are in effect for portions of northern Mexico and southern Texas. This disturbance will likely become a tropical storm by Wednesday. Once that happens, it will take the name Alberto.\n\nAnother disturbance appears to develop over the same region occupied by Potential Tropical Cyclone One this weekend. The overall environment will be conducive for gradual development as it moves northward or northwestward into early next week. For now, that region has a low chance of tropical development this weekend and early next week.\n\nThe Storm Station is also keeping an eye on an area of showers and storms located several hundred miles east of the Bahamas. There is a small chance of gradual development of this system as it drifts westward toward the Southeast Coast. This system will primarily be a rainmaker for parts of Mexico and far South Texas.The next area we are monitoring is located in the southwest Atlantic Ocean. This favors a slight increase in rain chances later this week. Ahead of the disturbance expect breezy days with some wind gusts of 20+ mph in Coastal Georgia and the Lowcountry. Maximum totals around 20 inches (51 centimeters) are possible across the higher terrain of the Mexican states of Coahuila, Nuevo Leon, and Tamaulipas. (WAFB) - Today's Forecast: Scattered showers and t-storms are expected today, but rain coverage should be lower than what we experienced on Monday as tropical moisture slowly shifts to our southwest.\n\nHigh temperatures will range from the upper 80s to near 90 degrees in most locations.\n\nA strengthening pressure gradient between the tropical system in the southern Gulf and high pressure to our east will result in breezy conditions. Easterly winds of 10-20 mph can be expected, with higher gusts likely.\n\nRest of This Week\n\nPotential Tropical Cyclone #1 will slowly track toward Mexico, helping to draw most of the tropical moisture south of our area. At the same time, strengthening high pressure should help our forecast trend drier and hotter.\n\nBy Friday and into the weekend, highs will likely reach the mid 90s, with rain chances only running 20% to 30%.\n\nExtended Outlook\n\nOur forecast beyond the weekend will be highly dependent on the potential for another surge of tropical moisture to impact parts of the Gulf Coast. While conditions are generally favorable for development, it has struggled thus far to develop an inner core, which has kept it loosely organized. Sign up to receive it in your inbox.\n\nParts of the Texas coast and northeastern Mexico are bracing for tropical storm conditions on Wednesday, as a potential system churns its way through the Bay of Campeche, the US National Hurricane Center said.\n\nWith winds of 40 miles per hour, the storm is already at tropical storm strength, however it currently lacks the organization to be named Alberto, the first name on this year's Atlantic list, the center said. It will likely reach that threshold Wednesday and its winds will peak at 50 miles per hour (80 kilometers per hour) as it nears Mexico's coastline, where watches are in place.\n\nTropical storm warnings have been posted for the Texas coast between Port O'Connor and the mouth of the Rio Grande, the center said. The storm will likely make landfall in the Mexican state of Tamaulipas early Thursday.\n\n\"It should be noted that regardless of the exact track of the low, we expect this system to have a large area of heavy rains, moderate coastal flooding and tropical-storm-strength winds well north of the center,\" Richard Pasch, a senior hurricane specialist at the center, wrote in a forecast.\n\nIn other weather news:\n\nUS: Heat advisories stretch from Iowa to Maine as temperatures soar into the 90sF (32C) and even to 100F or more in some places. Schools are cutting class time short across Massachusetts, governments are warning residents to prepare and electricity demand is set to soar along with temperatures.\n\nMore than 120 daily high temperatures records may be tied or broken through Sunday, the US Weather Prediction Center said. Readings are forecast to reach 100F in Springfield, Massachusetts on Thursday and Philadelphia on Friday.\n\nNew York's Manhattan is forecast to reach 93F on Thursday and Friday missing out on the most extreme temperatures, but the city will still likely rack up three consecutive days of 90-plus temperatures making this the season's first heatwave.\n\nCalifornia: Wildfire season is starting to get underway. {"uri": "2024-06-394884385", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:19:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:19:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:10:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4941176474094391, "url": "https://eu.caller.com/story/weather/hurricanes/2024/06/19/tropical-storms-depressions-meaning-hurricane-season-heavy-rain-flooding-texas/74101086007/", "title": "What's the difference between a tropical storm and tropical depression?", "body": "This storm season could be heavy -- and there's a lot of terminology to understand.\n\nTropical depression vs. tropical storm: What's the difference?\n\nTropical Depression: A tropical depression is the initial stage of a tropical cyclone. It has a well-defined low-pressure center with organized cloud circulation. It typically brings heavy rain but has lower wind speeds.\n\nTropical Storm: A tropical storm has stronger wind speeds than a tropical depression. It is better organized with a more defined center and spiral bands of thunderstorms. Tropical storms can cause significant rainfall, flooding, and wind damage.\n\nWhat is heavy flooding?\n\nHeavy flooding occurs when large volumes of water accumulate in an area, usually as a result of excessive rainfall, rapid snowmelt, storm surges, or dam failures. This water overwhelms the local drainage systems and causes rivers, lakes, or other bodies of water to overflow their banks, leading to widespread inundation of the surrounding land.\n\nAccording to the National Weather Service, the following types of flooding and types can be seen from these powerful storms.\n\nCauses of Heavy Flooding\n\nTypes of Flooding\n\nHurricane storm tracker: See active {"uri": "8185671641", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:45:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:45:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:44:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4941176474094391, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/us/alberto-heads-for-texas-first-tropical-storm-named-this-hurricane-season/articleshow/111119670.cms", "title": "Alberto heads for Texas, first tropical storm named this hurricane season - Times of India", "body": "The first tropical storm of the hurricane season is heading for Texas threatening the Gulf Coast with severe flooding and high winds. The National Hurricane Center Wednesday announced the advent of Alberto, as it has been named. The storm was located about 185 miles (300 km) east of Tampico, Mexico, packing maximum sustained winds of 40 mph (65 kph), the Miami-based forecaster said.Alberto is likely to dissipate over Mexico Thursday or Thursday night.\n\nThe storm is expected to produce rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches (about 13 to 25 centimetres) across northeast Mexico into South Texas. Maximum totals around 20 inches (51 centimetres) are possible across the higher terrain of the Mexican states of Coahuila, Nuevo Leon, and Tamaulipas. Flash flooding is likely, and mudslides are possible in some areas, the centre said.\n\nThe US National Weather Service said the main hazard for southern coastal Texas is flooding from excess rain. Eight inches (20 centimetres) of rain or more could fall by Saturday morning. On Wednesday, the NWS said, there is \"a high probability\" of flash flooding in southern coastal Texas. Tornadoes or waterspouts are possible.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicts the hurricane season that began June 1 and runs through November 30 is likely to be well above average, with between 17 and 25 named storms. The forecast calls for as many as 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes.\n\nAn average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes. A no-name storm earlier in June dumped more than 20 inches (50 centimetres) of rain on parts of South Florida, stranding numerous motorists on flooded streets and pushing water into some homes in low-lying areas.\n\nAt TOI World Desk, our dedicated team of seasoned journalists and passionate writers tirelessly sifts through the vast tapestry of global events to bring you the latest news and diverse perspectives round the clock. We will have a few isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms Tuesday afternoon, but they should be wrapping up very shortly after sunset. As that system moves into Mexico, another area of low pressure may be developing over the weekend in that same general location. The depression is expected to dissipate late Thursday but continue to produce rain over parts of the Texas and Mexico.\n\nOf interest to us in the Southeast is an area of low pressure east and north of the Bahamas. The low is moving at good pace to the west-northwest at10 to 15 mph. {"uri": "8183303904", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "09:30:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T09:30:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T09:29:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://www.americanpress.com/2024/06/18/tropical-threat-may-bring-downpours/", "title": "Tropical threat may bring downpours - American Press", "body": "A tropical disturbance across the southwest Gulf of Mexico is being monitored for possible tropical cyclone development, according to a report from the Calcasieu Parish Office of Homeland Security and Emergency Preparedness.\n\n\"It's likely headed to Mexico with no hit on Louisiana,\" said Roger Erickson, U.S. National Weather Service Lake Charles meteorologist.\n\nHe does expect the system in the Bay of Campeche to become a tropical depression or storm within the next 24-48 hours based on observations and weather models.\n\nA tropical storm means there is a closed low-pressure area with sustained winds of around 39 miles per hour. If winds are less than 39 mph, that's a depression, Erickson explained.\n\n\"We're predicting one to five inches of rain, with the higher totals being closer to the coast,\" he said.\n\nThe CPPJ OHSEP key messages includes a coastal flood watch issued today through Wednesday night, a long duration of easterly winds to increase along the coast and the possibility of a Flood Watch to be issued later today for heavy rainfall expected today through Wednesday night.\n\nHe's not expecting tornadoes to be a threat in Southwest Louisiana within this system. Flooding could be.\n\n\"We just issued a Flood Watch for Jefferson, Orange and Hardin Counties,\" Erickson said on Monday afternoon, \"nothing for Southwest Louisiana so far.\"\n\nThe U.S. Air Force's Hurricane Hunters Monday flight out over the southern Gulf of Mexico to investigate the disturbance is no cause to raise the alarm, according to Ericson. \"They investigate tropical systems, go when there is a threat to land, whether that is the U.S., Mexico or any of the islands of the Caribbean.\n\nHurricanes start out as a 'tropical disturbance' when water vapor from the warm ocean in the tropics or subtropics condenses to form clouds. This is when you first see the pattern of wind circulating around a center. {"uri": "8183251457", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "08:58:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T08:58:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T08:57:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://kpel965.com/ixp/33/p/is-a-potential-tropical-cyclone-a-named-storm-in-louisiana/", "title": "Is a Potential Tropical Cyclone a 'Named Storm' in Louisiana?", "body": "For the past few weeks, most of us in Louisiana have been glancing southward at \"something\" that was supposed to be developing in the Gulf of Mexico. Forecasters with the National Hurricane Center have been watching for it too. Yesterday, the Hurricane Center designated the broad area of low pressure in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico and its associated showers and storms as \"Potential Tropical Cyclone One\".\n\nYeah, it does sound ominous but it's basically the Hurricane Center's way of saying we know there is a weather system there. We believe it will become a tropical cyclone of some kind over the next day or so. And, most importantly, we want to make sure that people don't underestimate the potential damage to property and loss of life that might occur because of this system.\n\nFor a tropical system to earn a name it must have maximum sustained winds of 39 mph or more. There are other characteristics a storm system needs as well. A lot of those have to do with circulation around a central point. Convection (thunderstorms/rain) that is associated with that central point is also a key player in determining a storm's status. That's a very broad interpretation of some of the things forecasters look for when deciding whether or not we need to get on a first-name basis with a weathermaker.\n\nYour insurance company also looks for \"names\" when it comes to tropical weather systems. If you are not familiar with the term Named Storm Deductible with your homeowner's policy, I suggest you get familiar with it today. Hopefully, you'll never experience the great letdown that comes with learning that the coverage you thought you had for your storm recovery is a lot less than what you've been paying for.\n\nBased on information provided by the website Insurica.com a storm only earns a name when it is given by the National Weather Service. And while the NWS doesn't give tropical depressions names according to insurica.com they are still included as \"named systems\" by the insurance industry.\n\nThe other times storms earn a name is when they reach tropical storm status or hurricane status. The named storm deductible also looks at the timing of when a storm earns its name and when the storm is downgraded. Why this is important is the difference in the amount your insurance company will be covering.\n\nIn most cases, a standard deductible for homeowners insurance is a fixed rate. You know up front that if your home is damaged in a storm without a name just how much out of pocket you'll be paying. But, if that storm has a name your deductible could be as much as 10% of your home's value. It's all based on what your policy states about named storms.\n\nFor example, if your home's roof is damaged by hail you might pay the standard deductible listed in your policy. But if your roof is damaged by hail from a storm caused by a named tropical system you might be out of pocket up to 10% of your home's value. That's a heck of a lot more than $500 or $1,000 deductibles that a homeowner's policy can have.\n\nWe looked at a lot of articles on the subject online and couldn't find a definitive answer. But since the law usually doesn't take \"potential\" into consideration you'd think that a potential tropical cyclone wouldn't meet the \"naming\" criteria for a named storm deductible. But, I bet your insurance agents have already created a loophole in your policy to avoid paying out your claim.\n\nOur advice is to call your agent or policyholder today and get clarification. Because the term \"potential tropical cyclone\" is a designation by the National Weather Service. That could trigger that higher deductible.\n\nBased on the expected veracity of the tropical season for 2024, my guess is we will see a few more \"potential tropical cyclones\" before the end of normal tide levels paired with very large waves -- this sets the stage for damaging flooding along the coast including Brownsville, Corpus Christi, Houston, and around Lake Charles, Louisiana.\n\nWith The cloud cover is a result of Potential Tropical Cyclone One in the Gulf.\n\nThe storm could also bring an isolated shower, but most of North Texas will remain dry. The best rain chances are south of I-20.\n\nDue to a lack of a well-defined center, the system in the Gulf is still a potential tropical cyclone. Latest observations indicate the center is getting better organized and it could become Tropical Storm Alberto later today.\n\nThe large system is bringing rain and clouds along the Gulf Coast as well as dangerous rip currents.\n\nIt will continue to head west into Mexico Thursday, leading to flooding and life threatening flash flooding as well as tropical storm-force winds.\n\nFlood watches are in (KADN) -- People who live along the Texas coast are already feeling the impact of Tropical Storm Alberto.\n\nIn Surfside Beach, Texas, storm surge is changing beachfront roads into rivers.\n\nRELATED STORY:\n\nTropical Storm Alberto forms in Gulf of Mexico\n\nGULF OF MEXICO (The Weather Channel) -- Tropical Storm Alberto formed late Wednesday morning in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico. Flooding rain, coastal flooding, gusty winds, high surf, rip currents and isolated tornadoes are threats in Texas. Flooding rain and mudslides are also likely in parts of Mexico.\n\nWe have another question from Michael Hill of Crowley, who has sent in three good questions now. Thank you so much Michael for sending them.\n\nThis time, he wants to know: What is the difference between hurricanes, typhoons, and tropical cyclones? That is a good question.\n\nWhat better time to answer this than with our very first tropical storm forming in the Gulf.\n\nLet's take a trip around the globe.\n\nWe'll start in the Atlantic Ocean. We have tropical storms and hurricanes, which are rated on a scale of Category 1 to Category 5 on the Saffir-Simpson Scale. We also use this scale for the Pacific Ocean from off the coast of Mexico all the way near Hawaii.\n\nOnce you get past Hawaii, storms are called typhoons and super typhoons, instead of hurricanes. Japan and Hawaiian meteorologists monitor these waters.\n\nLet's go further into the Indian Ocean and South Pacific Ocean. Tropical storms also impact the southern hemisphere near Australia, but spin the opposite direction, and are called tropical cyclones and severe tropical cyclones, similar to off the coast of Madagascar near Africa. In India, they are known as cyclonic storms. The strongest storms here are known as extremely severe tropical cyclones.\n\nFinally, the Southern Atlantic. Storms here are very rare, thanks to unfavorable conditions, with only one storm ever reaching Category 2 strength. But if they do form, they are called tropical cyclones.\n\nAll of these storms form the exact same way, feeding off warm tropical waters just like our hurricanes here at home.\n\nIt really all depends You can check out at any time. More info\n\nHolidaymakers visiting Mexico on holiday have been warned about a 'potential tropical cyclone' as the country braces for torrential rain. A tropical storm warning is now in place in parts of Mexico and over the US border in Texas and the British Foreign Office has issued advice.\n\nA potential cyclone is currently heading towards the coast of Tamaulipas and is forecast to become a tropical storm by Wednesday, June 19. The extreme weather is then due to hit land on Thursday morning.\n\nHeavy rain and high winds are expected in the north-east of Mexico and people in the area have also been warned of the possibility of flooding and landslides in some areas. The region has been placed on alert ahead of what could be this year's first named tropical storm.\n\nRead more: Travel warning issued to UK tourists flying from Manchester Airport\n\nThe UK Foreign Office issued a warning to travellers on Tuesday, June 18, which reads: \"Potential Tropical Cyclone One is currently heading towards the coast of Tamaulipas and is due to make landfall on the morning of Thursday, June 20. It is currently forecast to become a tropical storm by Wednesday, June 19.\n\n\"A tropical storm warning is now in place along the coast of Tamaulipas state. High winds, heavy rainfall and coastal flooding are expected in north-eastern Mexico, with the possibility of flooding and landslides in some areas.\"\n\nThe Foreign Office currently advises against all but essential travel to the state of Tamaulipas, apart from the border crossing at Nuevo Laredo accessed by federal toll road 85D from Monterrey and federal highways 80, 81 and 85 between Tampico, Ciudad de Victoria and Magueyes, and the entire area of Tamaulipas south of these highways.\n\nMexico's hurricane season normally runs from June to November and can affect the Pacific and Atlantic coasts. Tropical storms and hurricanes cause floods, landslides and disruption to local services, including transport networks.\n\nTourists are advised to monitor local and international weather updates from the US National Hurricane Center and follow the advice of local authorities and your tour operator. In extreme cases, you may be ordered to evacuate.\n\nIn 2023, Hurricane Otis hit the south coast near Acapulco. The category five hurricane seriously damaged infrastructure along the coast in Acapulco and between Zihuatenejo and Punta Maldonado.\n\nTravel to many parts of Mexico is considered generally safe, however the Foreign Office does advice against all but essential travel to certain areas including the city of Tijuana and the states of Chihuahua, Sinaloa, Tamaulipas, Zacatecas, the areas of Guanajuato south-west of road 45D, Michoac\u00e1n and the areas of Jalisco south and south-west of Lake Chapala to the border with the state of Colima. The formation chance within the next week is 30 percent, a 10 percent increase since Tuesday.\n\nThe second system comes while NHC forecasters have been tracking Potential Tropical Cyclone One in the Gulf since last Wednesday. The potential cyclone was located in the southwestern Gulf Tuesday, but it has moved to the western area of the waters. The chance of the disturbance forming into a tropical storm within the next two days or within the next week is high, meaning 80 percent.\n\nThere is another disturbance in the southwestern Atlantic Ocean that NHC forecasters have been tracking since last Tuesday. The system, currently located several hundred miles east of the Bahamas, is expected to gradually develop during the next few days as it moves westward or west-northwestward. NHC forecasters predict that it will approach the coast of the southeastern U.S. later this week.\n\nIt is not uncommon to see developments in the Atlantic or the Gulf this early in the hurricane season, especially if the 2024 Atlantic season could be above-normal, as predicted by researchers and experts.\n\n\"If we have an above-normal seasons, it's not odd to have a few more systems develop this early in the season,\" NHC forecaster Mike Efferson told The Times-Picayune Tuesday.\n\nDon't miss a storm update this hurricane season. The system is moving toward the north near 6 mph (9 km/h). A gradual turn toward the west-northwest and west is expected is expected tonight and Wednesday, and the system is likely to approach the western Gulf coast late Wednesday. Maximum sustained winds remain near 40 mph (65 km/h) with higher gusts.\n\nSome increase in strength is likely during the next 36 hours, and the disturbance is forecast to become a tropical storm by Wednesday. It has a high (80 percent) chance of formation during the next 48 hours and the next 7 days.\n\nThe disturbance is quite large with tropical-storm-force winds extending outward up to 290 miles (465 km) to the northeast of the center.\n\nRAINFALL: Potential Tropical Cyclone One is expected to produce rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches across northeast Mexico into South Texas, with maximum totals of 15 inches possible. This rainfall will likely produce flash and urban flooding along with new and renewed river flooding. Mudslides are also possible in areas of higher terrain across northeast Mexico.\n\nSTORM SURGE: The combination of a dangerous storm surge and the tide will cause normally dry areas near the coast to be flooded by rising waters moving inland from the shoreline. It has 40mph winds but no organized circulation.\n\nThere is still a chance this becomes Alberto before it makes landfall in Mexico. There are Tropical Storm Warnings out for the southern Texas coastline.\n\nThe large circulation of this storm means it'll bring significant rain to south Texas. While flooding is certainly going to be a problem, the area is thirsty. Most of the land is in moderate to severe drought.\n\nAs the track has turned further to the south, the rain chances in North Texas have dropped.\n\nThere will plenty of clouds through the day Wednesday that will end this current seven-day run of the 90s. But rain chances are rather modest, only 20%-30% chance.\n\nA dome of high pressure is forecast to build overhead by this weekend. That means hot and dry weather returns to North Texas rather quickly and sticks around. We are going to get close to the 100\u00b0 mark by next week. Heat Advisories are possible.\n\nSummer starts on Thursday. While it is projected to remain on that path, it impacts are being felt hundreds of miles from its center, leading to warnings of coastal flooding in South Mississippi.\n\nLocal authorities reported flooded roads in low-lying areas of Hancock County on Tuesday, and forecasters warned coastal flooding caused by the system could be worst during high tide on Wednesday.\n\nForecasters are also tracking a system in the Gulf and another in the Atlantic. None of the three systems is forecast to directly impact the Mississippi Coast.\n\nFlooding appeared mostly minimal Wednesday morning.\n\nBiloxi reported at 7:30 a.m. the north and southbound lanes of Cedar Lake Bridge were closed for flooding and asked drivers to avoid the area.\n\nAuthorities in Hancock County reported Tuesday that 138 roads had water and some were impassable for cars, but the agency said the impacts cleared by Tuesday night.\n\nForecasters said the flood risk is highest in Hancock County, where they upgraded a coastal flood watch to a coastal flood warning by Wednesday.\n\nThe National Weather Service said Wednesday that southern Hancock County could see \"significant\" coastal flooding during high tide. The warning extends until 4 p.m. Thursday.\n\nDrivers should expect road closures and low-lying homes and businesses could become flooded, the NWS said.\n\nWater could cover roads in the Shoreline Park area near Bay St. Louis at high tide, according to the NWS.\n\nSouthern Harrison and Jackson counties are under coastal flood advisory until 4 p.m. Thursday. Coastal areas in those counties could see minor flooding and few road closures are expected, forecasters said.\n\nThe southern parts of Hancock, Harrison & Jackson counties are all under wind advisories from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Wednesday.\n\nThe National Weather Service said it expects winds of 20 to 25 miles per hour and gusts over 40 miles per hour.\n\nThe wind could cause damage to unsecured objects, downed tree limbs and a few power outages, the NWS said.\n\nThe Mississippi Sound is also under a gale warning until 1 a.m. Thursday, and forecasters warned strong winds could create dangerous waters with low visibility for boaters.\n\nThe system is expected to hit the northeast coast of Mexico around 1 a.m. Thursday, but forecasters warned the landfall was still uncertain and said the impacts will extend hundreds of miles beyond the area of direct hit.\n\nA tropical storm advisory extends into south Texas, and forecasters expect the system to strengthen and become Tropical Storm Alberto on Wednesday.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center is also tracking two separate systems -- one in the Atlantic and one in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico.\n\nThe southwestern Gulf disturbance is located in the same area as the system forecast to become a tropical storm. Forecasters said the system would further develop this weekend as it moved northwest toward Mexico, and it has a 30 percent chance of formation within seven days.\n\nAn Atlantic system expected to It will remain in effect through 4 p.m. Thursday.\n\nA coastal flood watch means \"sea water spillage over dune lines and sea walls is occurring, is imminent or is expected within the next 12 hours,\" according to the NWS's website. People should be prepared to evacuate inland if floodwaters rise and take steps to secure their property, including boarding up windows and securing loose objects.\n\nLocal impacts may include minor flooding; shoreline erosion, and isolated road closures, especially those that lie outside the hurricane risk reduction system. Highway 1 between Port Fouchon and Grand Isle could flood during high tide Thursday morning.\n\nAlberto, which is bringing strong winds, heavy rainfall and some flooding along the coasts of Texas and Mexico, is expected to make landfall in northern Mexico on Thursday.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said Wednesday afternoon that Alberto was located about 170 miles east of Tampico, Mexico, and about 305 miles south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas, with maximum sustained winds of 40 mph (65 kph). {"uri": "8185068174", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "09:59:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T09:59:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T09:58:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4666666686534882, "url": "https://www.wbrz.com/news/wednesday-am-forecast-windy-today-as-we-transition-to-a-drier-weather-pattern/", "title": "Wednesday AM Forecast: Windy today as we transition to a drier weather pattern", "body": "Wednesday serves as a transition day this week as we will watch tropical moisture move to the west and slightly drier air take over from the east. Through the weekend we will see more sunshine and less rain.\n\nToday & Tonight: Elevated winds from the east early Wednesday will add a refreshing feel to the air. Conditions are not quite as muggy to start off the day as the highest atmospheric moisture amounts are now to the west of our area. Temperatures early Wednesday start off in the low to mid 70's and as we will see more sunshine today, it will help the region warm back into the low-90's this afternoon. Though we are trending drier, isolated shower activity should still be expected this afternoon, about 30% coverage anticipated for afternoon storms. Winds will remain quite breezy all day, anywhere between 15-25 mph.\n\nSt. James and Assumption parishes have been highlighted in a Wind Advisory until 7pm Wednesday evening.\n\nOvernight, winds will begin to die down a bit and with partly cloudy conditions, temperatures will fall back into the middle 70's by daybreak Thursday.\n\nUp Next: We will see a sunnier and drier pattern begin Thursday and stick around through the weekend. With less clouds and rain, temperatures will creep up to slightly above average temperatures each afternoon, into the middle and possible upper-90's for some. There will still be enough moisture present in the air to make things feel a bit warmer and allow for typical summertime pop-up storms to develop each day.\n\nThe Tropics: Potential Tropical Cyclone One is still ongoing in the Bay of Campeche. The \"Potential Tropical Cyclone\" term is a designation from the National Hurricane Center for systems that have yet to become tropical in nature, but will likely do so and make landfall within 24 hours. No direct impacts are anticipated for south Louisiana, but Tropical Storm Warnings are in effect for portions of northern Mexico and southern Texas. This disturbance will likely become a tropical storm by Wednesday. Once that happens, it will take the name Alberto.\n\nAnother disturbance appears to develop over the same region occupied by Potential Tropical Cyclone One this weekend. The overall environment will be conducive for gradual development as it moves northward or northwestward into early next week. For now, that region has a low chance of tropical development this weekend and early next week.\n\nThe Storm Station is also keeping an eye on an area of showers and storms located several hundred miles east of the Bahamas. There is a small chance of gradual development of this system as it drifts westward toward the Southeast Coast. {"uri": "8187149495", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "13:51:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T13:51:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T13:50:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4627451002597809, "url": "https://www.foxweather.com/weather-news/bryan-norcross-albertos-effects-fade-today-texas-we-watch-two-other-systems", "title": "Bryan Norcross: Alberto's effects fade today in Texas as we watch two other systems", "body": "The National Hurricane Center has raised the odds of development for a tropical disturbance off the Southeast coast, noting that a tropical depression could form before it reaches the coast of Florida or Georgia by early Friday.\n\nSprawling Tropical Storm Alberto is moving into Mexico, so the gusty winds that extend hundreds of miles north into Texas will diminish today. However, this morning's high tide could still be a problem in vulnerable areas of coastal Texas.\n\nThe persistent onshore wind from a combination of Alberto and the heat-dome high-pressure system to the north will still cause the tide to be higher than normal around the western half of the Gulf. The air is being squeezed between the large, tropical low-pressure system and the extra-strong heat dome. Like squeezing a toothpaste tube, the air speeds up between two weather systems.\n\nAlberto's strongest spiral band with the heaviest rain has moved well inland. Dangerous flash flooding is still possible in the Mexican mountains, where up to 20 inches of rain might fall. In Texas, periodic tropical downpours are still possible today, but nothing sustained. The weather should be much better by tomorrow.\n\nAlberto developed from a combination of a broad low-pressure system that often develops over Central America in June called the Central American Gyre (in this context, a gyre is a large-diameter circular system) and a weak disturbance from the Caribbean. That scenario is forecast to repeat itself, more or less, over the weekend when another Caribbean disturbance will be flung toward the Gulf with an opportunity to organize.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center now has the chance of at least a tropical depression forming out of Disturbance #2 in the medium range. We'll watch over the weekend to see what develops, but at least a depression is increasingly likely. Whatever form the system takes, high pressure is forecast to hold sway across the Southeast, blocking it from moving very far north.\n\nThe current forecasts call for the system to be less intense than Alberto with less impact on South Texas. It's never smart, however, to count on forecasts for a system that hasn't yet developed. On the current schedule, the disturbance will move into the southern Gulf on Saturday where it will have an opportunity to organize. If blocking high pressure moves into place across the southeastern U.S. as forecast, it would track relatively quickly into Mexico by about Monday. We'll see.\n\nA small low-pressure system has developed offshore of the Bahamas from the remnants of the front that was part of the big deluge in South Florida the week before last. It's officially being dubbed Invest 92L because the Hurricane Center is \"investigating\" it. There is high confidence that the system will track toward the Southeast coast, arriving about Friday.\n\nA defined swirl is obvious from satellites, but the moisture and thunderstorms are not organized around it, so it doesn't qualify to be a tropical depression. The National Hurricane Center is giving the system a decent chance of attaining some organization today before it reaches the coast tonight or tomorrow. Whether it officially becomes a depression or not, gusty winds and a moisture surge are likely. People near the North Florida, Georgia, and Carolina coasts should stay informed. And mariners beware.\n\nAfter these systems move inland, nothing seems to be in the offing.", "source": {"uri": "foxweather.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FOX Weather"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8185687133", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:58:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:58:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:57:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4549019634723663, "url": "https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/extreme-heat-wallops-midwest-northeastern-us-as-first-tropical-storm-approaches-texas/3253650", "title": "Extreme heat wallops Midwest, northeastern US as first tropical storm approaches Texas", "body": "Record-breaking temperatures prompt heat emergencies across wide swathe of continental US as Tropical Storm Alberto forms in Gulf of Mexico\n\nA record-breaking heatwave is tearing through the central and northeastern US on Wednesday as the southern state of Texas prepares for the first named storm of the season.\n\nExcessive heat warnings have been issued across a broad swathe of the country stretching from New York City in the northeast to northern Indiana in the Midwest as officials prepare for heat indexes to again surpass 100 degrees Fahrenheit (38 Celsius).\n\nSuch prolonged extreme heat this early in the summer is exceptionally abnormal as scientists continue to sound the alarm about the mounting effects of climate change.\n\nIn Maine, the US' most northeastern state that is usually home to cool Atlantic breezes, heat indices have already soared past 100 degrees Fahrenheit amid stiflingly high humidity.\n\n\"A dome of very warm high pressure over the area will bring an exceptionally hot day today with inland highs in the mid 90s. Very humid air with dew points in the low to mid 70s will result in heat indices over 100 across most inland locations,\" the National Weather Service warned.\n\nThe heat wave is expected to persist through the week's end, but forecasters are warning that above-normal temperatures could continue to wrack the region well into July.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto, meanwhile, is already lashing southern Texas with flash flooding and a storm surge as it forms in the Gulf of Mexico ahead of making landfall in northeastern Mexico, likely early Thursday.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has warned of a busy upcoming hurricane season with between 17 to 25 tropical storms expected in what would mark the worst hurricane season in two decades.
