{"uri": "8186145488", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "01:15:11", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T01:15:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T01:14:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4470588266849518, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/ap/national/ap-news-in-brief-at-9-04-p-m-edt/article_50d04bf2-4978-547f-9606-f51514da7cff.html", "title": "AP News in Brief at 9:04 p.m. EDT", "body": "New law requires all Louisiana public school classrooms to display the Ten Commandments\n\nBATON ROUGE, La. (AP) -- Louisiana has become the first state to require that the Ten Commandments be displayed in every public school classroom, the latest move from a GOP-dominated Legislature pushing a conservative agenda under a new governor.\n\nThe legislation that Republican Gov. Jeff Landry signed into law on Wednesday requires a poster-sized display of the Ten Commandments in \"large, easily readable font\" in all public classrooms, from kindergarten to state-funded universities.\n\nOpponents questioned the law's constitutionality and vowed to challenge it in court. Proponents said the the measure is not solely religious, but that it has historical significance. In the language of the law, the Ten Commandments are \"foundational documents of our state and national government.\"\n\nThe posters, which will be paired with a four-paragraph \"context statement\" describing how the Ten Commandments \"were a prominent part of American public education for almost three centuries,\" must be in place in classrooms by the start of 2025.\n\nUnder the law, state funds will not be used to implement the mandate. The posters would be paid for through donations.\n\nNew Mexico wildfire claims second life, while rain offers hope of relief\n\nROSWELL, N.M. (AP) -- Heavy rain and hail fell Wednesday around an evacuated village in New Mexico threatened by wildfires that have killed at least two people and damaged more than 1,400 structures, offering the hope of some assistance for firefighters but adding the threat of high winds and flash floods.\n\nAir tankers dropped water and red retardant earlier on the pair of fires growing in a mountainous part of the state where earlier in the week residents of the village of Ruidoso were forced to flee the larger of the two blazes with little notice.\n\nNew Mexico State Police spokesman Wilson Silver said Wednesday that officers discovered the skeletal remains of an unidentified second person in the driver seat of a burned vehicle. It's the second confirmed death in the blazes. The first fire victim was a badly burned 60-year-old man found by the side of the road near the popular Swiss Chalet Inn in Ruidoso.\n\nWeather patterns were shifting Wednesday with moisture arriving from the Gulf of Mexico, said Bladen Breitreiter of the National Weather Service office in Albuquerque.\n\n\"It will be a challenging situation going into the late afternoon and evening,\" said Breitreiter, who has been an incident meteorologist at past wildfires. \"The potential for scattered to isolated thunderstorms could help, but it depends on where they hit. If the rain misses the fires, downward winds could cause problems for firefighters on the ground.\"\n\nTropical Storm Alberto forms in southwest Gulf, 1st named storm of the hurricane season\n\nTAMPICO, Mexico (AP) -- Tropical Storm Alberto formed on Wednesday in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico, the first named storm of what is forecast to be a busy hurricane season.\n\nAlberto, which is bringing strong winds, heavy rainfall and some flooding along the coasts of Texas and Mexico, is expected to make landfall in northern Mexico on Thursday.\n\n\"The heavy rainfall and the water, as usual, is the biggest story in tropical storms,\" said Michael Brennan, director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe National Hurricane Center said Wednesday afternoon that Alberto was located about 150 miles (240 kilometers) east of Tampico, Mexico, and about 320 miles (515 kilometers) south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas, with maximum sustained winds of 40 mph (65 kph). The storm is moving west-southwest at 9 miles per hour.\n\nThe center of the storm was expected to reach the northeastern coast of Mexico south of the mouth of the Rio Grande by Thursday morning.\n\nRifts seem to appear between Israel's political and military leadership over conduct of the Gaza war\n\nJERUSALEM (AP) -- The Israeli army's chief spokesman on Wednesday appeared to question the stated goal of destroying the Hamas militant group in Gaza in a rare public rift between the country's political and military leadership.\n\nPrime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has insisted Israel will pursue the fight against Hamas, the group running the besieged Gaza Strip, until its military and governing capabilities in the Palestinian territory are eliminated. But with the war now in its ninth month, frustration has been mounting with no clear end or postwar plan in sight.\n\n\"This business of destroying Hamas, making Hamas disappear -- it's simply throwing sand in the eyes of the public,\" Rear Adm. Daniel Hagari, the military spokesperson, told Israel's Channel 13 TV. \"Hamas is an idea, Hamas is a party. It's rooted in the hearts of the people -- whoever thinks we can eliminate Hamas is wrong.\"\n\nNetanyahu's office responded by saying that the country's security Cabinet, chaired by the prime minister, \"has defined the destruction of Hamas' military and governing capabilities as one of the goals of the war. The Israeli military, of course, is committed to this.\"\n\nThe military quickly issued a clarification, saying it was \"committed to achieving the goals of the war as defined by the Cabinet\" and that it has been working on this \"throughout the war, day and night, and will continue to do so.\"\n\nScorching temperatures, humidity making life miserable for millions from Midwest to Maine\n\nBOSTON (AP) -- A blistering heat wave Wednesday extended from the Midwest to New England, leaving millions of people sweltering through the Juneteenth holiday, including in places like northern Maine where they rarely experience such conditions this early in the year.\n\nThe city of Caribou, Maine, just 10 miles from the Canadian border, saw a record 103 degrees (39.4 C) on the heat index, which combines heat and humidity. The region was under a heat advisory until Wednesday evening and temperatures in Caribou were hotter than Miami: 94 degrees (34.4 C) compared with 89 (31.6 C), according to the National Weather Service.\n\nSeveral residents said they were used to temperatures in the 70s and 80s in June and rarely this humid.\n\n\"I've seen this maybe one time before where it's been this hot in June,\" said Hannah Embelton, 22, a server at an ice cream store in Caribou, adding that customers were staying away from the soft serve options because they melt took quickly.\n\n\"We usually never get the brunt of all this heat and humidity because we are so north. Just how hot it is, that is all everyone is talking about,\" she added.\n\nWhat's known, and not known, about the partnership agreement signed by Russia and North Korea\n\nBoth Russian President Vladimir Putin and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un say the strategic partnership they signed Wednesday is a breakthrough. But neither side has released the text of the agreement that resulted from their summit in Pyongyang, and its consequences for the near and long terms are uncertain.\n\nRelations between sprawling Russia and small, isolated North Korea -- both of them nuclear powers -- have warmed significantly in recent years amid Russia's growing acrimony with the West over the invasion of Ukraine and suppression of all domestic opposition.\n\nThe new agreement could bring them even closer, while also posing new challenges to the international community.\n\nWhat's in the new partnership, according to Kim and Putin:\n\nPutin told a briefing after the signing that \"the comprehensive partnership agreement provides, among other things, for the provision of mutual assistance in the event of aggression against one of the parties to this document.\"\n\nColombian family's genes offer new clue to delaying onset of Alzheimer's\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Scientists studying a family plagued by early-in-life Alzheimer's found some carry a genetic oddity that delays their initial symptoms by five years.\n\nThe finding points to novel ways of fighting the mind-robbing disease - if researchers can unravel how a single copy of that very rare gene variant offers at least a little protection.\n\n\"It opens new avenues,\" said neuropsychologist Yakeel Quiroz of Massachusetts General Hospital, who helped lead the study published Wednesday. \"There are definitely opportunities to copy or mimic the effects.\"\n\nThe first hint of this genetic protection came a few years ago. Researchers were studying a huge family in Colombia that shares a devastating inherited form of Alzheimer's when they discovered one woman who escaped her genetic fate. Aliria Piedrahita de Villegas should have developed Alzheimer's symptoms in her 40s but instead made it to her 70s before suffering even mild cognitive trouble.\n\nThe big clue: She also harbored something incredibly rare, two copies of an unrelated gene named APOE3 that had a mutation dubbed Christchurch. That odd gene pair appeared to shield her, staving off her genetic predisposition for Alzheimer's.\n\nImmigrant families rejoice over Biden's expansive move toward citizenship, while some are left out\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- Hundreds of thousands of immigrants had reason to rejoice when President Joe Biden unveiled a highly expansive plan to extend legal status to spouses of U.S. citizens but, inevitably, some were left out.\n\nClaudia Z\u00faniga, 35, married in 2017, or 10 years after her husband came to the United States. He moved to Ciudad Juarez, Mexico, after they wed, knowing that, by law, he had to live outside the country for years to gain legal status. \"Our lives took a 180-degree turn,\" she said.\n\nBiden announced Tuesday that his administration will, in coming months, allow U.S. citizens' spouses without legal status to apply for permanent residency and eventually citizenship without having to first depart the country for up to 10 years. About 500,000 immigrants may benefit, according to senior administration officials.\n\nTo qualify, an immigrant must have lived in the United States for 10 years and be married to a U.S. citizen, both as of Monday. Z\u00faniga's husband is ineligible because he wasn't in the United States.\n\n\"Imagine, it would be a dream come true,\" said Z\u00faniga, who works part time in her father's transportation business in Houston. \"My husband could be with us. We could focus on the well-being of our children.\"\n\nA US aircraft carrier and its crew have fought Houthi attacks for months. How long can it last?\n\nABOARD THE USS DWIGHT D. EISENHOWER IN THE RED SEA (AP) -- The combat markings emblazoned on the F/A-18 fighter jet tell the story: 15 missiles and six drones, painted in black just below the cockpit windshield.\n\nAs the jet sits on the deck of the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, its markings illuminate the enemy targets that it's destroyed in recent months and underscore the intensity of the fight to protect commercial shipping from persistent missile and drone attacks by the Iranian-backed Houthi rebels in Yemen.\n\nBut they also hint at the fatigue setting in, as the carrier, its strike group and about 7,000 sailors close in on their ninth month waging the most intense running sea battle since World War II. That raises difficult questions about what comes next as U.S. military and defense leaders wrangle over how they will replicate the carrier's combat power if the ship returns home to Norfolk, Virginia.\n\nAlready, the carrier's deployment has been extended twice, and sailors post dark memes around the ship about only getting one short break during their steadily growing tour. Some worry they could be ordered to stay out even longer as the campaign drags on to protect global trade in the vital Red Sea corridor.\n\nAt the Pentagon, leaders are wrestling with what has become a thorny but familiar debate. Do they bow to Navy pressure to bring the Eisenhower and the other three warships in its strike group home or heed U.S. Central Command's plea to keep them there longer? And if they bring them home -- what can replace them?\n\nOn Juneteenth, monument dedicated in Alabama to those who endured slavery\n\nMONTGOMERY, Ala. (AP) -- Thousands of surnames grace the towering monument, representing the more than 4 million enslaved people who were freed after the Civil War.\n\nThe Equal Justice Initiative, a criminal justice reform nonprofit, invoked the Juneteenth holiday -- the day that commemorates the end of slavery in the U.S. -- on Wednesday as it dedicated its National Monument to Freedom.\n\nThe monument, which honors the people who endured and survived slavery, is the centerpiece of the new Freedom Monument Sculpture Park in Montgomery, Alabama, where art and historical artifacts tell the story of enslaved people in the United States.\n\nDuring the dedication ceremony, Equal Justice Initiative founder Bryan Stevenson recounted how enslaved people endured unspeakable horrors, but also left a legacy of perseverance and strength.\n\n\"Enslaved people in this country did something remarkable that we need to acknowledge, that we need to recognize and that we need to celebrate. Enslaved people resisted. Enslaved people were resilient. Enslaved people found ways to make a way,\" Stevenson said.", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8184203201", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "19:54:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T19:54:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T19:53:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4470588266849518, "url": "https://www.houstonpublicmedia.org/articles/news/weather/2024/06/18/490977/flood-watch-looms-over-houston-as-potential-tropical-cyclone-approaches-coast/", "title": "Flood watch looms over Houston as potential tropical cyclone approaches coast | Houston Public Media", "body": "A flood watch goes into effect across Houston on Tuesday as a tropical storm system, so far deemed Potential Tropical Cyclone One, moves further into the Gulf Coast, threatening coastal flooding.\n\nThe storm is on track to drop anywhere from one to three inches of rain on Houston by Thursday, and rainfall predictions increase further south of the city, with areas in Galveston and Brazoria counties bracing for three to six inches of rain.\n\n\"We are expecting a good bit of rain over the next couple days, especially to the south of Houston, there are flood watches in effect for the area,\" said Matt Lanza, Space City Weather meteorologist during a press conference Monday. \"We all know how rain works here, it can come down pretty hard and it can cause some localized flooding.\"\n\n\"Hopefully by Wednesday evening or Thursday things will quiet down,\" Lanza said.\n\nTropical storm conditions are expected to begin Tuesday night or on Wednesday along portions of the Texas coast south of Port O'Connor and along the northeastern Mexico coast, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nRELATED: City of Houston, Mayor Whitmire announce response plan for hurricane season\n\nThe growing but disorganized system could develop into tropical storm Alberto as soon as Wednesday evening. But whether or not a cyclone is formed will likely have little effect on the storm's impact on Southeast Texas as the center of the system is forecasted to make landfall in Mexico, according to a National Weather Service webinar on Tuesday.\n\nThe bulk of the heavier rain should be past southeast Texas by Thursday morning, according to NWS, which is predicting a level three risk for flash flooding.\n\n\"One of the things to keep in mind is that the city of Houston streets is one of our primary drainage components, Randy Macchi, Houston Public Works chief operating officer said. \"They're designed primarily to help water flow and drain out of the way.\"\n\nMacchi said residents should keep an eye on storm drainage inlets on streets and report any that are not clear. He said that the department has already begun the process of converting Houston Public Works vehicles to help assist police and fire for potential high water rescues.\n\n\"If you find that you live in areas where there are open ditches, and there is debris in those ditches, please call 311 to elevate those requests as quickly as possible so that we can in partnership with solid waste make sure that we're able to get folks out there,\" he said.\n\nIn Galveston County, lifeguard towers were relocated to higher ground in anticipation of coastal flooding this week. Red flags are flying across the city's beaches, warning of strong currents and heavier winds.\n\nGalveston County Health District is urging people to avoid swimming in Galveston Bay until the threat of high rip currents reduces. There is an active risk of dangerous swimming conditions near jetties and piers and hazardous marine conditions throughout the week.\n\nA wind advisory is in effect through Thursday morning, according to the health district.\n\n\"We anticipate street flooding,\" Houston Fire Chief Samuel Pe\u00f1a said at the press conference on Monday. \"That is always a concern. {"uri": "8184308475", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "21:42:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T21:42:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T21:41:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4431372582912445, "url": "https://www.cbs17.com/weather/what-is-a-potential-tropical-cyclone/", "title": "What is a potential tropical cyclone?", "body": "RALEIGH, N.C. (WNCN) -- Our first system of the 2024 hurricane season developed Monday, but it was called a \"potential tropical cyclone.\" So what is that?\n\nLet's first talk about that word: cyclone. Cyclone is just the technical term for a low pressure.\n\nSo, a potential tropical cyclone is a low pressure (or developing low pressure) that could bring tropical storm, or even hurricane conditions to land within 48 hours, even if it's not a fully formed tropical storm just yet.\n\nIt's a little complicated, but the reason the National Hurricane Center does this is so they can put out a forecast track with enough time for people in the path to know what is headed their way, and it also allows them to issue vital watches and warnings for people who may feel impacts.\n\nThe number one thing to know is that the National Hurricane Center does everything in the interest of public safety, so whether it's a potential tropical cyclone, tropical storm or hurricane, they'll issue the forecast, watch and warnings, and we'll pass that along to you on CBS 17.", "source": {"uri": "cbs17.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS17.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "rachel_duensing@cbs17.com", "name": {"uri": "2024-06-394827592", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "14:28:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T14:28:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T14:23:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4392156898975372, "url": "https://www.sunherald.com/news/weather/article289388320.html", "title": "Flood advisories issued across MS Coast as large tropical system moves toward Mexico", "body": "A large system that forecasters say could become a tropical storm on Wednesday inched closer to the Mexican coastline but also sent impacts hundreds of miles from its center and led to warnings of coastal flooding in South Mississippi.\n\nLocal authorities reported flooded roads in low-lying areas of Hancock County on Tuesday, and forecasters warned coastal flooding caused by the system could be worst during high tide on Wednesday.\n\nForecasters are also tracking a system in the Gulf and another in the Atlantic. None of the three systems is forecast to directly impact the Mississippi Coast.\n\nMS Coast reports flooded roads\n\nFlooding appeared mostly minimal Wednesday morning.\n\nBiloxi reported at 7:30 a.m. the north and southbound lanes of Cedar Lake Bridge were closed for flooding and asked drivers to avoid the area.\n\nAuthorities in Hancock County reported Tuesday that 138 roads had water and some were impassable for cars, but the agency said the impacts cleared by Tuesday night.\n\nForecasters said the flood risk is highest in Hancock County, where they upgraded a coastal flood watch to a coastal flood warning by Wednesday.\n\nThe National Weather Service said Wednesday that southern Hancock County could see \"significant\" coastal flooding during high tide. The warning extends until 4 p.m. Thursday.\n\nDrivers should expect road closures and low-lying homes and businesses could become flooded, the NWS said.\n\nWater could cover roads in the Shoreline Park area near Bay St. Louis at high tide, according to the NWS.\n\nSouthern Harrison and Jackson counties are under coastal flood advisory until 4 p.m. Thursday. Coastal areas in those counties could see minor flooding and few road closures are expected, forecasters said.\n\nSouth MS under wind and gale advisories\n\nThe southern parts of Hancock, Harrison & Jackson counties are all under wind advisories from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Wednesday.\n\nThe National Weather Service said it expects winds of 20 to 25 miles per hour and gusts over 40 miles per hour.\n\nThe wind could cause damage to unsecured objects, downed tree limbs and a few power outages, the NWS said.\n\nThe Mississippi Sound is also under a gale warning until 1 a.m. Thursday, and forecasters warned strong winds could create dangerous waters with low visibility for boaters.\n\nWhen will system make landfall?\n\nThe system is expected to hit the northeast coast of Mexico around 1 a.m. Thursday, but forecasters warned the landfall was still uncertain and said the impacts will extend hundreds of miles beyond the area of direct hit.\n\nA tropical storm advisory extends into south Texas, and forecasters expect the system to strengthen and become Tropical Storm Alberto on Wednesday.\n\nLatest on two other systems\n\nThe National Hurricane Center is also tracking two separate systems -- one in the Atlantic and one in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico.\n\nThe southwestern Gulf disturbance is located in the same area as the system forecast to become a tropical storm. Forecasters said the system would further develop this weekend as it moved northwest toward Mexico, and it has a 30 percent chance of formation within seven days.\n\nAn Atlantic system expected to impact the southeastern coast of the United States had only a 20 percent chance of development within seven days.", "source": {"uri": "sunherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sun Herald"}, {"uri": "8185496276", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "14:37:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T14:37:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T14:37:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4392156898975372, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/jun/19/weather-heat-wildfires-tropical-storm-alberto", "title": "Heatwaves and wildfires strike across US as tropical storm forms in gulf", "body": "Potential Tropical Cyclone One - a slow churning system of low atmospheric pressure in the Gulf of Mexico - was badgering the Texas coast but had not fully developed, meteorologists said on Wednesday.\n\nThe storm, which will be named Tropical Storm Alberto when it forms fully, is set to unleash powerful winds, heavy rain and flood threats across the entire southern US, Mexico and Central America. Storm-force winds, which stretch more than 400 miles (640km) from the storm's center, are already affecting southern Texas.\n\nAs much of the US experiences anomalous weather - intense heat in the north-east and northern midwest, epic rains in Miami, fires in New Mexico and California, a winter storm warning in Montana - the tropical system in the gulf is forecast to bring intense downpours to southern Louisiana and the central and southern areas of Texas.\n\nThe National Weather Service warned in an update on Wednesday morning that the gulf system is becoming better defined, the storm activity \"remains rather meager\" and the atmospheric disturbance \"still does not meet the requirements of a tropical cyclone\".\n\nBill Nye, the respected \"science guy\", told CNN that the events meant that \"we need to contain our use of fossil fuels, putting carbon dioxide and methane in the atmosphere, and we need to do it as soon as we can\".\n\nNye said there had not been a Pearl Harbor-level climate change event \"because it's happening in slow motion ... New research indicates there is not a tipping point or point of no return - it's just things getting worse and worse.\"\n\nThe continental heatwave is expected to intensify in the north-east on Wednesday, bringing 95F (35C) heat to Detroit and 92F (33C) temperatures to Buffalo, where the average for this time of year is 75F (24C). Philadelphia is expected to stay above 90F for the next week. Pittsburgh hit 94F on Tuesday.\n\nThe National Weather Service issued its first-ever excessive heat warning for Caribou, Maine, alerting to \"dangerously hot conditions with heat index values up to 106[F] expected\" on Wednesday.\n\nIn New Mexico, where wildfires ignited on Mescalero Apache land, the village of Ruiduso, with 8,000 residents, was evacuated. Approximately 1,400 structures have been lost, local officials said in an update.\n\nThe wildfire, known as the South Fork fire, has burned across 15,276 acres (6,200 hectares) and was 0% contained as of early Tuesday.\n\n\"We knew that the fire was there and we knew it was bad. We could see it in the distance but it kept on growing closer and closer,\" Kay Bymark, 79, told CNN. \"The smoke was there and you could see it in the air\".\n\nForecasters said that spotty thunderstorm activity could ease conditions in the region. Will you share a name with a hurricane? Here's the complete list", "body": "No one wants to share their name with a meteorological monster. But it happens.\n\nThe first named stormed of the young hurricane season is about to hit Texas. Weather watchers have been tracking Tropical Storm Alberto the past few days while it was a mere disturbance in the Gulf of Mexico.\n\nBut why do storms get names?\n\nEvery six years or so, The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration releases a list of names that they will use to name hurricanes. This helps clarify any confusion when multiple storms form at the same time. And monikers for the deadliest events, such as Katrina and Sandy, are retired. Otherwise, the list is recycled.\n\nNOAA predicts an 85% chance of an above normal hurricane season for the Atlantic Ocean this year.\n\n\"NOAA is forecasting a range of 17 to 25 total named storms (winds of 39 mph or higher). Of those, eight to 13 are forecast to become hurricanes (winds of 74 mph or higher),\" according to its website.\n\nThey also predict four to seven hurricanes that will be category 3 or worse.\n\nThe last hurricane that hit Texas was Nicholas in 2021. Its storm surge was only a category 1, meaning minimal damage happened. The most recent hurricane to hit the United States was Lee in September 2023 -- another category 1 .\n\nA hurricane is when a storm's wind speeds reach up to 74 mph or higher, according to the National Weather Service. Categories are based on the maximum wind strength and the higher the category, the worse the damage. Hurricane season typically occurs from June 1 to Nov. 30.\n\nIt is likely that 2024 will bring another hurricane to the U.S., possibly even Texas. If that is the case, check to see if you will share your name with a storm.", "source": {"uri": "star-telegram.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Fort Worth Star-Telegram"}, "authors": [{"uri": It has associated a broad circulation of clouds and storms that cover the entire area of the gulf, the Mexican territory, and the western Caribbean Sea, including western Cuba. It is moving west-northwest at a speed of 13 kilometers per hour. The environmental conditions where this system is located are slightly favorable for its development, so it may become a tropical depression before entering Mexican territory.\n\nAnother area of low pressure is located in the sea's northeast of the Bahamas, over the Atlantic Ocean, which has associated some areas of disorganized storms. The atmospheric conditions remain unfavorable for this system to have any tropical development in the coming days as it moves west or west-northwest.\n\nTropical Storm Alberto continues with very little variation over the western Gulf of Mexico, near the eastern coast of Mexican territory. This system maintains maximum sustained winds of 65 kilometers per hour and a minimum central pressure of 995 millibars.\n\nThe central region of Alberto at six this afternoon was estimated at 21.8 degrees north latitude and 95.6 degrees west longitude, a position that places it about 240 kilometers east of Tampico, Mexico. It is moving with a course close to west-southwest at a rate of 15 kilometers per hour.\n\nIn the next 12 to 24 hours, Tropical Storm Alberto is expected to maintain a similar speed, turning its trajectory again to the west, gaining somewhat more in organization before entering Mexican territory in the early morning. Once over land, it will experience rapid weakening.\n\nHavana is on the periphery of the cyclonic circulation in the Gulf of Mexico, which imposes a humid flow from the south to the lower levels of the troposphere. During the next few days, it will dawn partially cloudy. From the end of the morning, it will become cloudy with some showers, rains, and thunderstorms, which will increase in the afternoon hours.\n\nThe winds will be mainly from the southeast to east with speeds between 15 and 30 kilometers per hour. The relative humidity will range from 80% to 100%. The highs will be between 31 and 32\u00baC (88 and 90 F) and the lows between 23 and 25\u00baC (73 and 77 F). {"uri": "8184658669", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "04:54:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T04:54:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T04:51:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4196078479290009, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/world/2750901/", "title": "Central American gyre causes deadly floods, landslides - ExBulletin", "body": "San Salvador, El Salvador - Days of torrential rain in Central America have caused landslides and flooding that have resulted in at least a dozen deaths, with the persistent Central American Gyre showing little sign of abating.\n\nAuthorities in El Salvador reported at least 11 people killed, while in neighboring Guatemala, at least three people drowned.\n\nA series of tropical disturbances in the Pacific and Atlantic basins have produced torrential rainfall, and by the time the model descends, rainfall totals are expected to reach several metres.\n\nIn addition to the victims, hundreds of rescue operations have been carried out and the government of El Salvador has declared a national emergency while heavy rainfall continues to cause mudslides and landslides.\n\n\"We have deployed more than 30,000 soldiers dedicated to responding to emergencies, 19 task forces and machinery. In addition, camps and shelters have been supplied to handle emergencies caused by the rains,\" Guatemalan President Bernardo Ar\u00e9valo said before the downpour. big.\n\nPhotos and videos from the affected region showed dozens of landslides that destroyed homes and blocked roads.\n\nWHAT IS A CENTRAL AMERICAN GYRE?\n\nAlmost every hurricane season, the FOX Forecast Center monitors a broad area of low pressure in the western Caribbean Sea and eastern Pacific Ocean, known as a gyre.\n\nDuring the early and late parts of the hurricane season, the area is known to aid in the development of tropical disturbances in the eastern Pacific, Bay of Campeche, or western Caribbean Sea.\n\nDuring the vortex's current evolution, the National Hurricane Center has warned of the possibility of at least three different cyclones, with what is known as Potential Tropical Cyclone One having the highest potential for development.\n\nA PTC is a designation used by the National Hurricane Center to indicate a disturbance that is not yet a tropical cyclone but has the potential to develop into one within the next 48 hours and threaten land.\n\nPOTENTIAL TROPICAL CYCLONE 1 ISSUES TROPICAL STORM WARNING ALONG TEXAS GULF COAST\n\nPTC One is expected to produce heavy rain and strong winds from Texas to Mexico over the next few days.\n\nIf the disturbance gains low-level circulation, the FOX Forecast Center says sustained winds would reach the threshold for the NHC to declare the system a tropical storm.\n\nThe forecast for the Texas coastline and Mexico will not change, as both a PTC and a tropical storm deliver similar impacts.\n\nIf the disturbance were to get a name, it would be known as Alberto and would be the first cyclone of the year in the Atlantic basin.", "source": {"uri": Season", "body": "Havana, Jun 19 (ACN) Cuba's Meteorology Center announced the formation of the first tropical storm of the current hurricane season, named Alberto, which extends until November.\n\nA development led to the formation of storm Alberto, which maintains 65-kilometer-per-hour sustained winds.\n\nAlberto was located on Wednesday at about 300 kilometers east of Tampico, Mexico, while {"uri": "8184125208", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "18:43:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T18:43:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T18:42:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4117647111415863, "url": "https://www.claimsjournal.com/news/national/2024/06/18/324536.htm", "title": "Experts: Atlantic Hurricane Season Potential on Par with 2005, 1995", "body": "Atlantic hurricane risk in the U.S. continues to increase \"substantially as oceanic and atmospheric conditions reach a point where tropical cyclone formation\" is becoming increasingly more favorable, putting the season's outlook on par with some past massive and destructive seasons, storm experts said on Tuesday.\n\nOn Monday, the National Hurricane Center designated a disturbance in the Gulf of Mexico as a potential tropical cyclone that has yet to be named, putting tropical storm warnings are in effect along the northeastern coast of Mexico and in southern Texas with winds in excess of 39 MPH expected over a large coastal stretch.\n\n\"While it's not expected to be significant wind event from a large perspective, flooding is a potential threat to both life and property if you are located in northeastern Mexico or southern Texas,\" said Jon Schneyer, director of catastrophe response at CoreLogic.\n\nSchneyer led a panel of experts on a CoreLogic webinar on Tuesday to discuss the beginning of the hurricane season, and lay out the hurricane risk landscape across the country as an ominous season is now starting to unfold - June 1 marked the beginning of the hurricane season, which extends through the end of November. The other experts were David Smith, senior director of natural hazard science, and product managers Tal Paschal, Brian Sullivan and Jesse Delmas.\n\nRelated: Potent Hurricane Weather Pattern Continues to Take Shape, Forecaster Says\n\nThe climate has moved out of the El Ni\u00f1o phase and into an ENSO neutral phase (the El Ni\u00f1o-Southern Oscillation transition state between warm and cool phases). By late summer, we're expected to go into a La Ni\u00f1a phase.\n\nBy all accounts, the hurricane season continues to shape up to be a big one.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration last month forecast an 85% chance of an above-average Atlantic hurricane season, with up to 25 named storms. Colorado State University's tropical meteorology project in April forecast 23 named storms, 11 hurricanes and five major hurricanes.\n\nAccuWeather meteorologists in March forecast an above-average Atlantic hurricane season with as many as 20 to 25 named storms.\n\nRelated: Catastrophe Bond Sales Soar as Markets Brace for Unusually Active Hurricane Season\n\nGlobal insurer Allianz Commercial recently released its annual risk article on the season's outlook, which calls out the good fortune in 2023. That was an above-average season, though only eight storms made landfall. Most of the storms, referred to as \"fish storms,\" stayed at sea.\n\nThe Allianz report summarizes the predicted number of tropical storm events for 2024 by six organizations. All of the forecasts indicate a season ahead to watch.\n\nThe CoreLogic webinar on Tuesday referenced a report on hurricane risk that points to more than 32.7 million residential properties at risk of moderate or severe damage sustained from hurricane-force winds from Texas to Maine. The number of at-risk homes in CoreLogic's 2024 Hurricane Risk Report equates to a combined reconstruction cost of $10.8 trillion.\n\nSmith detailed the 2024 hurricane season outlook and offered an assessment of the midpoint of each of the ranges of the forecasts that have so far come out.\n\n\"One theme here is that all the outlooks are really showing a highly active season,\" he said. \"Certainly at some level this is the most active forecast that NOAA has ever made, really showing the most elevated levels of activity in this forecast, and certainly well above normal with the ranges.\"\n\nOf the 17 to 25 named storms in NOAA's outlook, eight to 13 are likely to become hurricanes, and four to seven of those are likely to become major hurricanes, Smith noted.\n\nSmith said the data so far reflects weather developments ahead of other seasons that turned out to be big ones, putting this season's potential on par with seasons like those including 1995 and 2005, \"which you may remember, were very, very active, and also in terms of loss (were) very, very dramatic years.\" Forecasts for 2024, he added, are for \"way above normal, and if they're at the top end of the ranges, it's going to be really up there along with some of the most significant seasons.\"\n\nAccording to Weather Underground, 2005's 28 named storms and 1995's 19 named storms are on the list of the seasons with the most named storms. The 2005 season's 15 hurricanes topped the list of the most hurricanes on record from 1851 to present. The 2005 season was second on the list of seasons with the most major hurricanes with seven, just behind the eight major hurricanes in 1950.", "source": {"uri": "claimsjournal.com", "dataType": In addition, the camps and shelters are supplied to deal with emergencies caused by the rains,\" Guatemalan President Bernardo Ar\u00e9valo said before the heavy rainfall.\n\nPhotos and videos from the affected region showed dozens of landslides that have destroyed homes and blocked roadways.\n\nWHAT IS A CENTAL AMERICAN GYRE?\n\nNearly every hurricane season, the FOX Forecast Center monitors a broad area of low pressure in the western Caribbean Sea and eastern Pacific Ocean, known as a gyre.\n\nDuring the early and latter parts of the hurricane season, the area is notorious for aiding in the development of tropical disturbances in the eastern Pacific, Bay of Campeche or western Caribbean Sea.\n\nDuring the current gyre's evolution, the National Hurricane Center has warned about the possibility of at least three different cyclones, with what is known as Potential Tropical Cyclone One, having the highest potential for development.\n\nA PTC is a designation used by the National Hurricane Center to indicate a disturbance that is not yet a tropical cyclone but has the potential to develop into one over the next 48 hours and threaten land.\n\nPOTENTIAL TROPICAL CYCLONE 1 PROMPTS TROPICAL STORM WARNING ALONG TEXAS GULF COAST\n\nPTC One is expected to produce heavy rainfall and gusty winds from Texas into Mexico during the next few days.\n\nIf the disturbance gains a low-level circulation, the FOX Forecast Center says sustained winds would meet the threshold for the NHC to declare the system a tropical storm.\n\nThe forecast for the Texas coastline and Mexico would not change, as both a PTC and a tropical storm deliver similar impacts.\n\nIf the disturbance were to gain a name, it would be known as Alberto and be the Atlantic basin's first cyclone of the According to the forecast, the cyclone will cause Torrential rains that could be accompanied by electric shocks and possibly the fall of hail, as reported by our colleagues from Xataka Mexicoeither. It is important to take precautions against storms and blizzards.\n\nIt is important to take precautions, as in some areas there could also be a risk of flooding.\n\nIf you wish find out as soon as possible that it is going to rainor a storm has started, you can set an alarm on your Android smartphone by following one of the two methods below:\n\nThe Rain Alarm application is available directly on the Google Play Store from this linkand it does just what its name says: it will warn you when a storm is approaching your location.\n\nRain alarm allows you to set a notification on your smartphone when a storm is approaching. In addition, it also allows you to know the weather forecast. The app offers more functions and eliminates advertising if we pay a subscription, but we can set an alarm with the free version.\n\nOnce you install the application and indicate your location, try to go to the settings menu and configure the data to be expressed in Celsius and kilometers per hour, among other preferences.\n\nIFTTT (If This Then That, or \"If this, then that\") is a tool that, among many other functions, allows us to configure alarms and notifications based on different parameters.\n\nIn this case we will create an alarm so that the app tells us if it is raining:\n\nOnce the process is complete, the alarm will have been created. Yes, this tells us if it has already started to rain, not if it is going to rain, but when choosing the location we can select an area close to our frequent location to estimate that if it has already But it happens.\n\nThe first named stormed of the young hurricane season is about to hit Texas. Weather watchers have been tracking Tropical Storm Alberto the past few days while it was a mere disturbance in the Gulf of Mexico.\n\nBut why do storms get names?\n\nEvery six years or so, The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration releases a list of names that they will use to name hurricanes. This helps clarify any confusion when multiple storms form at the same time. And monikers for the deadliest events, such as Katrina and Sandy, are retired. Otherwise, the list is recycled.\n\n\u26a1 More trending stories from our newsroom:\n\n\u2192Cowboys legend Michael Irvin says wife Sandy, 58, suffers from early onset Alzheimer's\n\n\u2192 Fred's Texas Cafe opens a new restaurant outside of Fort Worth\n\n\u2192 Pastor of Southlake's Gateway Church accused of molesting 12-year-old girl in 1980s\n\nNOAA predicts an 85% chance of an above normal hurricane season for the Atlantic Ocean this year.\n\n\"NOAA is forecasting a range of 17 to 25 total named storms (winds of 39 mph or higher). Of those, eight to 13 are forecast to become hurricanes (winds of 74 mph or higher),\" according to its website.\n\nThey also predict four to seven hurricanes that will be category 3 or worse.\n\nThe last hurricane that hit Texas was Nicholas in 2021. Its storm surge was only a category 1, meaning minimal damage happened. The most recent hurricane to hit the United States was Lee in September 2023 -- another category 1 .\n\nA hurricane is when a storm's wind speeds reach up to 74 mph or higher, according to the National Weather Service. Categories are based on the maximum wind strength and the higher the category, the worse the damage. Hurricane season typically occurs from June 1 to Nov. 30.\n\nIt is likely that 2024 will bring another hurricane to the U.S., possibly even Texas. (WAFB) - Today's Forecast: The area of low pressure in the southern Gulf of Mexico designated as Potential Tropical Cyclone #1 will begin to pull moisture farther south and west, away from our local area today. Enough fringe moisture will still be in place to produce a few showers and t-storms, but rains should be noticeably less numerous than the last couple of days. Lower rain chances and a little more sunshine should allow highs to climb to around 90 degrees.\n\nRest of This Week\n\nHigh pressure will gradually build in from the east, helping to shove the low pressure system in the Gulf westward toward Mexico. As the high builds in, we'll also trend drier and hotter through the end of the week and into the weekend.\n\nIt won't be completely dry though, with rain chances running 20%-30% daily from Thursday into the weekend. Text \"Alerts\" to (201) 335-0739 or sign up here.\n\nThis year's hurricane season is expected to be an active one. An outlook issued in May by The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicted between 17 and 25 named storms -- which includes tropical storms and hurricanes -- will form this year. Of the range of storms predicted, the federal agency forecasts four to seven storms that will be category 3 or above. The prediction exceeds the 14 storms observed per year on average in the U.S. and could top the 20 named storms that materialized last year. Government forecasters have attributed their prediction to higher than average sea surface temperatures and La Ni\u00f1a -- a weather event that cools ocean surface temperatures in the Pacific.\n\nGovernment Forecasters Issue Most Dire Hurricane Season Prediction In Their History -- Here's Why (Forbes)\n\nTexas Tropical Storm Watch: What To Know As This Year's First Storm Threat {"uri": "8183969966", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "16:37:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T16:37:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T16:36:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3764705955982208, "url": "https://www.valleycentral.com/news/tracking-the-tropics-disturbance-forms-off-florida-gulf-coast-could-it-develop/", "title": "Tracking the Tropics: Disturbance forms off Florida Gulf coast. Could it develop?", "body": "TAMPA, Fla. (WFLA) -- A tropical disturbance with a chance of development formed off the Florida Gulf coast on Tuesday morning.\n\nAn area of disorganized showers and thunderstorms is expected to move across Florida over the next day or so, dumping several inches of rain on the region.\n\nIts chance of development, however, is low. The National Hurricane Center said the system has a zero percent chance of development in the next two days.\n\nIt has a 20% chance of \"slow\" development over the next seven days when it is offshore of the southeastern U.S. in the Atlantic.\n\nThe 2024 hurricane season is expected to be an active season.\n\nBoth the Colorado (CSU) long term forecast and the NOAA season forecast predict the highest number of named storms and hurricanes than they ever have on record.\n\nSeveral factors contribute to these above-average predictions and the sense that we will be very busy this fall tracking storms.\n\nWarmer seas surface temperatures provide a source of fuel for storms, often contributing to intensification. Warmer ocean temperatures mean the potential for more powerful hurricanes.\n\nSo far this year, our Atlantic sea surface temperatures are much warmer than average, closer to what we would expect to see in August. This leads us to believe that we will have more powerful hurricanes this year as well.\n\nFor every 3 degrees warmer the water is, stronger storms will be roughly around 20% stronger, especially in the strongest hurricanes. That means a storm with 150 mph winds would potentially have 180 mph winds with the warmer waters by 3 degrees. This does not consider any outside factors like wind shear, forward motion, or other potentially influential aspects.\n\nConsider what we've seen with rapid intensification in regards to hurricanes Katrina and Rita - when each of these storms passed over a warm water eddy, an area of warmer water that broke free from the loop current and moved into the Gulf.\n\nBoth storms significantly intensified as a result of the warmer sea surface temperatures.\n\nLa Ni\u00f1a typically leads to increased hurricane activity in the Atlantic.\n\nThe cooler waters in the Pacific reduce the amount of vertical wind shear (the change in wind speed and direction with height) over the tropical Atlantic. Lower wind shear allows tropical storms to develop and intensify more easily.\n\nSome of the most active hurricane seasons in the Atlantic have occurred during La Ni\u00f1a conditions.\n\nFor example, the record-breaking 2005 hurricane season, which included Hurricane Katrina, was influenced by La Ni\u00f1a conditions.\n\nThe Caribbean region often experiences more rainfall and storm activity during La Ni\u00f1a years. This can lead to more tropical storms forming in this region, which can then move into the Gulf of Mexico or along the eastern seaboard of the United States.", "source": {"uri": "valleycentral.com", {"uri": "8185549617", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:15:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:15:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:14:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3725490272045135, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2024/weather/alberto-texas-mexico.html", "title": "Tracking Tropical Storm Alberto", "body": "By William B. Davis, Madison Dong, Judson Jones, John Keefe, and Bea Malsky\n\nAlberto was a tropical storm in the Gulf of Mexico Wednesday morning Eastern time, the National Hurricane Center said in its latest advisory.\n\nThe tropical storm had sustained wind speeds of 40 miles per hour.\n\nAlberto is the first named storm to form in the Atlantic in 2024.\n\nIn late May, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicted that there would be 17 to 25 named storms this year, an above-normal amount.\n\nSatellite imagery can help determine the strength, size and cohesion of a storm. The stronger a storm becomes, the more likely an eye will form in the center. When the eye looks symmetrical, that often means the storm is not encountering anything to weaken it.\n\nThis season follows an overly active year, with 20 named storms -- including an early storm later given the official name of \"Unnamed.\" It was the eighth year in a row to surpass the average of 14 named storms. Only one hurricane, Idalia, made landfall in the United States.\n\nTypically, the El Ni\u00f1o pattern that was in force last season would have suppressed hurricanes and reduced the number of storms in a season. But in 2023, the warm ocean temperatures in the Atlantic blunted El Ni\u00f1o's usual effect of thwarting storms.\n\nThe warm ocean temperatures that fueled last year's season returned even warmer at the start of this season, raising forecasters' confidence that there would be more storms this year. The heightened sea surface temperatures could also strengthen storms more rapidly than usual.\n\nTo make matters worse, the El Ni\u00f1o pattern present last year is also diminishing, most likely creating a more suitable atmosphere for storms to form and intensify.\n\nHurricanes need a calm environment to form, and, in the Atlantic, a strong El Ni\u00f1o increases the amount of wind shear -- a change in wind speed and/or direction with height -- which disrupts a storm's ability to coalesce. Without El Ni\u00f1o this year, clouds are more likely to tower to the tall heights needed to sustain a powerful cyclone.", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York {"uri": "8185243981", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "11:50:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T11:50:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T11:49:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.2156862765550613, "url": "https://www.iflscience.com/la-nina-forecast-to-return-this-summer-what-does-that-mean-for-hurricane-season-74720", "title": "La Ni\u00f1a Forecast To Return This Summer - What Does That Mean For Hurricane Season?", "body": "El Ni\u00f1o is officially over - and while we are currently in ENSO-neutral conditions, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's (NOAA) Climate Prediction Center, La Ni\u00f1a is expected to return this summer, possibly as early as July. This new phase is forecast to persist through the Northern Hemisphere winter and ties in with Atlantic hurricane season - so, what does it mean for such extreme storms?\n\n\"After a year of dominance, El Ni\u00f1o released its hold on the tropical Pacific in May 2024,\" reads NOAA's latest update for June 2024. \"The tropical Pacific's climate pendulum appears to be swinging back toward its other extreme: La Ni\u00f1a.\"\n\nLa Ni\u00f1a, and its counterpart El Ni\u00f1o, are the extreme phases of the El Ni\u00f1o-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) cycle - a recurring climate pattern that describes how changes in the water temperature in the Pacific Ocean have a global impact on the world. Everything from wind, temperature, and rainfall patterns to the intensity of - you guessed it - hurricane seasons are affected. Even the distribution of fish in the seas can be influenced by the cycle.\n\nAround every three to seven years, the surface waters across a large swath of the tropical Pacific warm or cool by 1 to 3\u00b0C (1.8 to 5.4\u00b0F) compared to normal. La Ni\u00f1a is often called the \"cold phase\" of the ENSO, when the ocean surface temperature drops in the central and eastern tropical Pacific Ocean. During El Ni\u00f1o, on the other hand, surface temperature rises.\n\nWe've known La Ni\u00f1a was on her way for a while - forecasters originally predicted her return between June and August, but revised this as the rate of cooling slowed. According to the latest forecast from NOAA's Climate Prediction Center, ENSO-neutral conditions returned during the past month. However, they're not set to last and there's a 65 percent chance La Ni\u00f1a will develop in July-September 2024 and an 85 percent chance it will persist during November-January.\n\nThis timing means it will likely coincide with - and possibly intensify - the peak of the Atlantic hurricane season (expected between mid-August and mid-October).\n\nNOAA has already predicted an \"extraordinary\" season, thanks in part to La Ni\u00f1a. Per their estimates, there's an 85 percent chance of an above-normal season, a 10 percent chance of a near-normal season, and just a 5 percent chance of a below-normal season.\n\nBetween eight and 13 storms are forecast to become hurricanes, with wind speeds of 119 kilometers (74 miles) per hour or higher, and four to seven major hurricanes with winds of 178 kilometers (111 miles) per hour or higher are also anticipated. The forecasters have a 70 percent confidence in these ranges.\n\nYou might be wondering how a dip in ocean surface temp could impact the swirling winds of a hurricane. It is primarily down to vertical wind shear - the change in wind speed and direction from near the surface to high up in the atmosphere. Over the Atlantic, La Ni\u00f1a reduces vertical wind shear, which enhances hurricane activity. It also decreases the amount of sinking motion and atmospheric stability, which contribute.\n\nIn the central and eastern Pacific, meanwhile, La Ni\u00f1a suppresses hurricane activity.\n\nWith this year's Atlantic hurricane season already underway, and La Ni\u00f1a looming, 2024 could be set to see some intense storms.", "source": {"uri": "iflscience.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8184409031", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "23:45:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T23:45:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T23:44:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.2000000029802322, "url": "https://azdailysun.com/counterpoint-climate-change-fearmongering-isn-t-working-anymore/article_1bdb4a1e-2cf1-11ef-a9ae-cb965f98a423.html", "title": "COUNTERPOINT: Climate change fearmongering isn't working anymore", "body": "The adage that \"nothing is certain except death and taxes\" ought to be updated for our modern times to: Nothing is certain except death, taxes, and government-generated climate alarmism.\n\nIn late May, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicted that the \"coming Atlantic hurricane season is expected to have above-normal activity due to a confluence of factors, including near-record warm ocean temperatures in the Atlantic Ocean.\"\n\nSpecifically, \"NOAA is forecasting a range of 17 to 25 total named storms ... including 4 to 7 major hurricanes.\"\n\nOf course, NOAA points to \"human-caused climate change\" as the primary culprit for its apocalyptic hurricane season warning. According to NOAA, \"human-caused climate change\" is solely responsible for \"warming our ocean globally,\" \"melting ice on land\" and \"sea level rise.\"\n\nIn 2022, NOAA issued a very similar hurricane season prediction, which was way overblown. \"Overall, the 2022 Atlantic hurricane season featured near normal activity in terms of the number of named storms and hurricanes, but was slightly below average in terms of the number of major hurricanes,\" notes the National Hurricane Center.\n\nJust because NOAA was wrong in 2022 does not mean that its 2024 prediction will be wrong, too. However, more important, the entire narrative about hurricanes becoming more frequent and more intense due to anthropogenic (human-caused) climate change is not true.\n\nConsider.\n\nIn 2012, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change stated, \"Many weather and climate extremes are the result of natural climate variability (including phenomena such as El Ni\u00f1o), and natural decadal or multi-decadal variations in the climate provide the backdrop for anthropogenic climate changes. Even if there were no anthropogenic change in climate, a wide variety of natural weather and climate extremes would still occur.\"\n\nIn 2014, the National Climate Assessment stated, \"There has been no significant trend in the global number of tropical cyclones nor has any trend been identified in the number of U.S. land-falling hurricanes.\"\n\nMoreover, in 2018, the IPCC reported that there is \"only low confidence for the attribution of any detectable changes in tropical cyclone activity to anthropogenic influences.\"\n\nIn 2019, a peer-reviewed report in the American Meteorological Society stated, \"The majority of authors had only low confidence that any other observed tropical cyclone changes were beyond what could be attributed to natural variability.\"\n\nIn 2020, the World Meteorological Organization acknowledged that \"any single event, such as a severe tropical cyclone, cannot be attributed to human-induced climate change, given the current status of scientific understanding.\"\n\nPerhaps Steven E. Koonin, the undersecretary for science in the Department of Energy in the Obama administration, put it best when he said, \"Pointing to hurricanes as an example of the ravages of human-caused climate change is at best unconvincing, and at worst plainly dishonest.\"\n\nOver the past century, the number of hurricanes on a per-decade basis making landfall in the United States has declined. For instance, in the 1850s, well before humans harnessed fossil fuels as a viable energy source, 20 hurricanes made landfall, including six \"major\" storms. In the 1940s, 24 hurricanes made landfall, including 10 significant storms.\n\nObviously, the experts at NOAA can read graphs that illustrate that the frequency and severity of hurricanes striking the United States have not increased over the past several decades.\n\nSo, why does NOAA, along with so many other government-affiliated organizations, continue to engage in public fearmongering regarding hurricanes, wildfires, tornadoes and so forth? They need to create panic and instill fear to justify their very existence. It is self-preservation.\n\nLike it or not, climate change is big business. Over the next decade, the United States will spend at least $500 billion to \"combat\" climate change. To keep the money flowing, the government needs an endless list of scary predictions to keep the alarmist narrative going.\n\nThe good news is Americans are beginning to realize that they are being lied to about climate change. More and more, polls show that Americans no longer automatically believe that climate change is an existential threat. Because they are starting to lose their hold, the alarmists are resorting to even more desperate measures.\n\nCopy article link", "source": {"uri": "azdailysun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": Forecasters predict that heat will hit over 135 million Americans in the Northeast and Midwest from Chicago to Philadelphia, as a so-called heat dome shifts over the Eastern U.S., trapping hot and dry air over an area for days.\n\nForecasters also believe excessive heat will also drive up the number of named tropical storms and hurricanes in the Atlantic this year. Last week, meteorologists at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicted the upcoming 2024 season will bring a record 17 to 25 named storms, including up to 13 hurricanes, with four to seven of those intensifying into category 3 hurricanes (maximum sustained wind speeds of 111 mph or greater). If that prediction holds up, it would far outpace the yearly average of just over 14 named storms observed over the past 30 years, and potentially outnumber the busy 2023 season, which brought 19 named storms and seven hurricanes.
